05-31-03
Midnight till Sunrise

East Bay Free Outdoor Renegade

Djs
Dj M (Freebeats Tenderloft)
Drag n' Fly (epiphany teknique)
Chad Mindrive (Nice Musique Clean Plate)
orestes ( asr nbc)

family. Please wear warm clothes, bring water, and do no bring
glowsticks/flashlights. This party is a renegade, so be careful not to
draw attention to yourself when walking to the party. Call the voicemail
around 11PM on Saturday night for directions and more details on the
party.

take care,

- jeremy

Subject: RE: [sfraves] BSP :: ASR Gemini :: TONIGHT! :: FREE Outdoor party

Well all I have to say is that I had a blast playing outside again and
doing something completely illegal dammit!

Damn poo-poo's had to come out and break up a good thing - and I have
the feeling that had the party been allowed to continue, it would have
gained legendary status in many of those who attended.  

DJ M tore it up and sadly the fun was over by the time I was about to
play one of my last records...  Gar!  

But if anyone was at the after party - there was some good stuff being
thrown down during my short stay.  I think I even moved my butt & feet a
little bit.

Well props to Jeremy & Mook & the rest of the gang for trying to do
something that just felt GOOD!  

And as for Jonas and his OLDNESS! - You're still younger than me bud, so
there's no reason to quit partying - at least until I do!!!   LOL

Until next time...

; )
`dina

Subject: Re: [sfraves] e bust, blah, blah, blah...

> Where are these parties? The most I have ever been offered e is once!

Well, I think it depends, not only on which parties you go to (And you DO go to
different parties than me usually, after all.), but also it varies greatly from
person to person.  Though, for the life of me, I don't know why YOU don't
attract your fair share as well.

But it seems like whenever I leave the house, I'm a magnet for drug dealers. 
I'll have friends bitch to me about not being able to find a pill the whole
night, when the first three people who talked to ME when I got in the door were
offering me pills, and the next person to talk to me AFTER my friend, will be
trying to sell to me too.

This even happens to me, every so often, when I'm just walking down the street!
 Wandering down Haight street, all those random hippys with weed, or shrooms
they picked in Golden Gate Park, who USUALLY wander around muttering "buds...
shrooms" to EVERYONE... they ignore me.  But the ONE person on the whole bloody
street who has E, will home in on me, and try to sell me pills.`

Not infrequently as well, random people seem to assume that *I* am a dealer. 
And I've never sold (illegal) drugs in my life!  (I did used to tend bar tho,
which is morally equivelent to any E dealer.  Alcohol *IS* a drug, no matter
what the republicans and their uniformed minions tell you.)  And even AFTER
people get the clue that *I*'m not a dealer, they STILL expect me to be able to
"hook them up".

I don't know what it is about me...  But SOMETHING just seems to broadcast:
"This person wants/has drugs!!!".


cya,
john

until I informed them I hadn't even had a drop of alcohol and wasn't
leaving the front of the crowd to cool down and by state law they have
to bring me water.  So they did :)

parties am I on anything and depending on the club I'm usually sober
too.  I like to do everything elsewhere.)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJs: Remaster Your Demo Tape to CD


>>Subject: [sfraves] DJs: Remaster Your Demo Tape to CD

> Do you have a demo tape that you would like to have digitally
> remastered to CD?

Considering that casettes are an analog medium and CDs are a digital medium,
any transfer from one medium to the other is a de facto "digital
remastering."  There's no such thing as an analog CD.  Can you please
describe exactly what your "remastering" process is and what equipment you
use in the process?  Is there processing applied to the "remaster?"  What
distinguishes your (fairly expensive) service from a simple "transfer" where
the contents of the program material on the casette are simply recorded onto
a CD?

Subject: ASR Gemini: WTF happened? (aftermath)

All,
I had fun at Gemini too, dancing beside friends and enjoying the vibe/music, but
I really need to know what happened (the aftermath).

I have a terrible memory of Jeremy sitting on the steps above the RR tracks,
with a cop nearby, monitoring his actions. I did not know if he was being
arrested or just receiving a citation. Regardless it was disconcerting because
earlier in the night I had given him a big hug and I did not know how to react
to this frightening situation.

Also, I gave a donation to the "sound fund," especially when someone mentioned
Marshall's name, because I always appreciate his efforts at renegades,
undergrounds, and other parties. Please reassure me that the donations were used
appropriately (even if it was for someone'e bail or whatever). I understand that
given the situation, the proceeds might need to be redistributed.

About the renegade sound system, the cops did not seem to be concerned about
confiscating equipment, but I wonder happened. Did everything turn out all right
in the end? I vaguely remember Jeremy saying something to the cop about "wanting
to make sure that the mess is cleaned up" and the cop said something about "they
just want you out of here."

It was a very confusing night. I don't know why people are writing glowing
reviews. Yeah, I enjoyed the music too but I feel really "put down" by the
authorities with the big flashlights.

Finally, I offered to take Osby home (since he was stranded), and while we were
walking to my car, DragnFly mentioned an after-party at Ryan's place, and I was
wondering how that turned out.

That's all, just wondering what's up and if Jeremy (and other ASR crew members)
are OK.

Greg VP

Subject: Demo Tape s to CDs!! If your still wondering



We're actually improving the sound quality from the cassette by running it 
through a digital soundboard (Yamaha MD4S) and adjusting the eq levels for 
optimal clarity. It's not the the same as if you used a burnner on your 
computer.
You'd be surprised how many sorry souls out there still have mix tapes.
peace

Tom

PS: this whole process takes well over an hour for each tape. I don't 
suggest buying 100 copies. You can get them elsewhere for less (obviously).

References: <BAY8-F98DaCdhxJKocJ000248fa@hotmail.com> <04ad01c32940$51817430$0a00000a@dawgbuddha> <01cb01c32940$d46991c0$280110ac@hiddendragon>
Date: Mon, 2 Jun 2003 13:31:13 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.50.4807.1700
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4910.0300
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJs: Remaster Your Demo Tape to CD

How is questioning the value of someone's service based on its technical
merits "hating?"  I was merely saying that there were certain aspects of the
original post/advertisement/spam that seemed to be misleading, and asking
what it was about the service that made it so expensive.  You're absolutely
correct, though, that 15 dollars MIGHT not be expensive for a Tape --> CD
transfer, depending on what sort of equipment is used in the transfer and
what sort of mastering is applied afterwards.  If he's got a Nakamichi tape
deck connected to an Avalon A/D converter and is then processing through
Massenburg and Drawmer plugins in ProTools, then no, it's not expensive at
all.  If, however, he's running a Teac tape deck into the back of his
Soundblaster card and hitting "Normalize" in Sound Forge, then, you know, I
think 15 dollars is a bit much.

Personally, I think it's a bit silly to be transferring things from casette
tape, a lo-fi medium, to CD, a much higher fidelity medium, because you're
never going to get MORE out of the CD than you got out of the tape.  This is
why I quibbled with the phrase "digital remastering" in this context, as it
is generally applied to situations where original, archival masters that
have been carefully preserved are remastered for the CD medium.

word-of-mouth promotional campaign to spread the word and attract new faces?

post. I'm sure we could have gotten just as many people there and decreased

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP :: ASR Gemini :: TONIGHT! :: FREE Outdoor party

My guess? I saw a lot of people wandering up by the train tracks thoughout
the night. It seemed like there was a rather large turnout and a lot of cars
nearby. I wouldn't be surprised if a cop merely drove by the street with the
cars and saw people crossing the train tracks into the park. I really doubt
that the party was busted due to posts to SFR. Had that been the case the
party wouldn't have gone on as long as it did. When I got searched by police
there was no mention of getting the infoline. It seemed like a very chance
occurance. Of course I was a bit too trashed at this point so things were
rather a blur until getting back to my house.

I do want to say that the party was great up until the bust. Even then it
was handled in a friendly manner. The woman that searched me was really cool
and didn't screw with me at all. Even when I couldn't find my id and she had
to search me to get it she was still cool. Made me pour out my NewCastle. =(

Things continued at my house all night and into the morning. That was a
rather wild time and I can't believe I didn't hear about it from my
neighbors. I had a great time and it's great to hear everyone respond in a
positive manner.

:: r y a n ::

Subject: well, it is time to eat again nrr

--0-2142008731-1054589115=:28832
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

i am trying like everyone else to make wise food choices, but also, i can't stop eating everything that i want. this is a common thing that people do in america. they eat whatever they want to whenever they want to, or rather, when time permits, because also, people are in control of when you eat sometimes, what you eat, and also, how you will eat it. i like to be in control of the kitchen sometimes, but lots of times, i am too tired or just bored of it, or just don't remember what it was that i wanted to make to share, so that is good for people  who don't want to eat my cooking, but who WILL eat my cooking, because if i took the time out to cook, it WILL be eaten. just kidding. i am not that much of a brat or anything like that. i like cooking for people, because i always wait in life until the one that wants to eat will just be doing it. anyway, this brings me back to the fact that i feel like eating, and while nutrition is important, i really like hostess cupcakes, and the last time i ate them, they just looked so velvety smooth on top (i picked the perrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrfect pack), and also, if i were in the middle east, for example, maybe one of the reasons i would be uninterested in anything else is that maybe i wouldn't know about those cupcakes, but i do. i know lots of things. :)

From apollo@speakeasy.org  Mon Jun  2 22:15:55 2003
Return-Path: <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 44900 invoked from network); 2 Jun 2003 22:15:55 -0000
Received: from mail12.speakeasy.net (HELO mail.speakeasy.net) (216.254.0.212)
  by taz3.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 2 Jun 2003 22:15:55 -0000
Received: (qmail 32345 invoked from network); 2 Jun 2003 22:15:52 -0000
Received: from unknown (HELO speakeasy.speakeasy.org) (apollo@[64.81.52.16])
          (envelope-sender <apollo@speakeasy.org>)
          by mail12.speakeasy.net (qmail-ldap-1.03) with SMTP
          for <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>; 2 Jun 2003 22:15:52 -0000
Message-Id: <5.1.0.14.2.20030602142135.02847b80@mail.speakeasy.net>
X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.net
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 5.1
Date: Mon, 02 Jun 2003 15:21:00 -0700
To: "SFRaves@hyperreal. org" <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_17633474==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: The Fool and SWAT UG Loft Party

--=====================_17633474==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

The underground certainly seems to be heating up these days, and I expect 
in the next few months the creative pot is going to boil over.  Just as in 
the early nineties, folks are tired of the lack of diversity and family 
vibe in the clubs and have begun seeking the freedom (that lovely TAZ), 
musical and social experimentation, and community bonding that only the 
underground can offer.

For a long time it was hard to find a house music ug, but that is 
changing.  On Saturday night The Fool and S.W.A.T. threw an event at the 
same loft location as Sticky a few weeks back.  At The Fool I picked up 
several fliers for future house ugs including "Houseplant" that goes down 
June 14th.

The email for The Fools party  warned : "ARRIVE EARLY, VERY LIMITED 
CAPACITY. WHEN THE SPOT'S FULL, THE DOORS WILL BE CLOSED."   When I checked 
the voicemail and discovered the venue was the Sticky location (one room 
dance floor with a rooftop that holds not more than 200 comfortably) we 
decided to go early and arrived at the sobering hour of ten -- for us, at 
least.  I haven't arrived at a party where I wasn't on crew before midnight 
in years.

I'm happy we decided to roll in before the witching hour.  We had a chance 
to relax, look at the art show that was part of the event, and say goodbye 
to Milo, a good friend who worked at Housewares for years, who is leaving 
the City.

Everything was rockin' at the event until around 2:30 am or so, when the 
crew began, IMHO, to lose control.  I really enjoyed Andrew Kelsey's set, 
the dance floor and the crowd vibe until -- the crew failed to keep their 
promise to close the doors when capacity was reached.  The peeps poured in 
and as far as I could see there was no effort to limit the attendance 
numbers.  Must have been over 400 folks packed into that small place.

My own personal drama quest began during Rasoul's set.  I had been dancing 
in sweaty oblivion for quite some time when I realized I had better hit the 
bathroom.  Well, this place has two bathrooms, barely adequate for 
200.  The facility on the main floor had a line backed up into the narrow 
hallway causing gridlock -- same with the toilet on the small second 
floor.  We had hand stamps so we figured after fighting the through the 
masses for about twenty minutes that we would go outside and hit the 
alley.  Apparently this was on many minds, because another 
impenetrable  crowd was building at the exit and we were told ins-and-outs 
were canceled.  Ah.  The pressure on both the bladder and mind 
increases.  What to do.  The roof.

So we head for the steps (yes, they replaced the ladder) and there is chaos 
again here.  Folks trying to come down, go up, long lines and the 
beginnings of aggression on all sides.  The crew managed some control here 
and we finally got to the top and searched for a corner or 
somethin'.  There was a roped off section and we head into this empty space 
at a gallop only to be told by crew that we should feel free to smoke our 
weed in the crowd.  Misinterpreted intentions.  Out we go, and then there 
is a rush into the same forbidden are by guys in similar bladder 
crises.  At this point, shame is overridden by panic and I blast my way to 
a corner on the roof and let loose.

Relieved and ready to dance again, even in this over-packed venue, we plow 
downstairs and back on the dance floor for Jeno's set.   I understand there 
was some conflict with the venue owner who was freaked at the over-sold 
conditions.  He turns up all the house lights.  The music goes on, but from 
three to four the house lights kept going up and down.  Industrial lights 
were left on in the middle of the dance floor.  Rasoul seemed to be having 
some problems with the turntables.  Jeno didn't come on at the scheduled 
time.  And then, finally, the music went down, the lights went up, and we 
were all told to stand in silence for a what seemed like an eternity so 
that the party could continue.

When the music came back up we decided we had enough of this and left a bit 
after four.  I hear Jeno's set was smokin'.  Sorry we missed it, but my 
vibe was broken by the crowd issues and the blinding house lights going up 
and down.

Now, I like the people who threw this party but....  When you throw a ug in 
an "intimate' space you do PRESALES and a map point.  It is really absurd 
to post a BSP with a voicemail that motivates peeps to show up at the venue 
doorstep when one has very limited capacity.  Hard to turn them away.  One 
has crowds building outside.  Greed can motivate some to imprudently take 
in the bucks.  This venue was not designed for 400;  the crew was not 
prepared to manage this number.

The other side of the coin here is that I genuinely believe the crew did 
not anticipate the interest generated by this ug.  Dancers were still 
showing up when we left.  There is a growing appetite for the underground 
again in the Bay Area.  All the more reason to throw more events -- but 
events that are governed by some of the old rules:  selective presales, map 
point controls, and a break-even-at-best motivation.

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

(it was an honest to god opening, with wine and jazz) He thought it was a ug rave flyer and he jumped up in the air, clicked his heels, and exclaimed " I'm Gonna go get my friends and get me some extacy pills!" he ran off before I could explain to him that he wasn't going to find anything stronger than cheap wine and cloves!  And people on bart or the street or at work love to ask me for E, I use it as a chance to educate them that not everybody who looks like me does drugs, or knows where to find them. To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Catharsis <catharsis@egregious.net>
Mime-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] DJs: Remaster Your Demo Tape to CD (BSP)

Well,

I will throw my info out there. I have a nice page detailing the DJ 
compilation remastering service I offer here:
http://audio.egregious.net/dj-remastering.html

It isn't all fud though; it explains my process clearly and there also is a 
nice section on recording tips that should come in handy for anyone 
recording a mix comp.

This service is mainly for sets recorded digitally (computer, etc.), but 
can also be applied to a transfer of a tape or a heavily degraded 
source;  you would be surprised what you can bring back to life!

If you are an aspiring techno DJ or simply are getting into music that is 
not following the herd hit me up and chances are I'll give you a discount 
if I like what I hear!


I am just getting my first vinyl pressed soon and once I QC the results and 
they pass my ear I'll post a sweet deal for those producing tracks, but 
haven't quite managed to get anything on vinyl yet.

Best,
--Mike

Egregious
"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."
http://www.egregious.net/

respectively). This also means a clean cut death to
the space formerly known as new hack city (come to
dorkbot and DAMN while you still can)

worksheets and a ton of cables  $2500 (this thing is

__________________________________________________ Y8b __
                         |
           San Francisco | Something Old, SOMETHING NEW
          This Wednesday |
                June 4th | GRETSKI
                         | EPSILON
                         | KI
_________________________________________________________

A unique experience at elastiq this Wednesday, as we'll
have zero residents playing --- it's a 100% pure guest dj
night! Traipse on by to taste-test three distinct stylistic
genres through three diverse individuals. It's going be
*yummy*.

_ FEATURED MP3 SET DOWNLOAD ________________________

Our MP3 set of the week goes to the incredibly smooth
techhouse/house set by The Oracle, who played for us
last week.  Incredible taste in music and clean mixing are
guaranteed to take you on a journey.

82MB | 1hr:25min @ 128 Kbps hi:fi
http://technostate.com/~zeel/audio/others/2003_05_28__oracle@elastiq-sf.mp3

_ KI _____________________________________________________

Influenced by Industrial music of the 80's & 90's, Ki
ventured to the realm of djing in early 1997 after
moving to SF. Shortly thereafter, he purchased his first
techno album which began his deep love for all things
techno.  In 2000 he began his first residency at a techno
monthly which brought in top producers such as John
Selway and Theorem.

Though he is currently focusing on music production,
he can still get the dance floor going with his mature
and impeccable taste. His sets range from tech-house to
tribal to hard techno with the intent of never ending
where he began.

_ EPSILON _______________________________________________

Epsilon was first exposed to DJing at the climactic UNITY
campout in August 2002. Since then he has shared his love
of progressive and epic trance at several events, playing as
a resident for Preserve and Deciblast.org.  Since last playing
at Elastiq, he has flirted with the dark side, exploring the
deep, exotic realm of progressive psytrance, but keeping
the light of trance melodies ready in case of an emergency.

_ GRETSKI _______________________________________________

DJ Gretski: "Music has always been a big part of my life.
I started mixing about a year ago, but I didn't start playing
progressive until last November.  When I bought my first
progressive house record, I knew that i had found my
groove.  Paul, a.k.a Paul the Fanman, has played an
influential role in my dj'ing."

_________________________________________________________

                 Every Wednesday @ Il Pirata
             2007 16th Street @ Potrero Ave
               10pm - 2am, age 21+, only $2 cover
         Full bar, Great people, Comfy atmosphere

                massage oil for your ears
            caffeine for your cerebral cortex
      [ house | tribal | tech-house | progressive ]

             With residents Joseph Lee, Kem,
            Zeel, Telene, plus weekly guests.

_________________________________________________________

 For info or bookings please email bookings@elastiq-sf.com
     We have a web site: http://www.elastiq-sf.com/
    Please visit the site for any upcoming schedules.

So much for truthful politicians, right?

> ------- Forwarded message -------
> From: "Joseph W. Durwin" <jdurwin@bcn.net>
> To: orbits-project@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [orbits-project] Worst fears about the RAVE Act realized
> Date: Wed, 04 Jun 2003 04:05:15 -0000
>
> > Dear Supporters and Friends,
> >
> > On May 30, the DEA showed up early to a highly publicized concert in
> > Billings, Montana set to benefit Montana's Medical Marijuana Law
> > campaign in 2004, and shut it down-merely on the threat that if they
> > were to apprehend someone in the crowd in possession of marijuana the
> > venue itself would have been subject to a quarter million dollar fine
> > (the maximum penalty under the recently passed Senate bill 151.  As
> > many of us feared, this legislation will be used specifically for
> > targeting organizations and events trying to raise money to reform our
> > nations's drug policies.  THEY LIED TO US-it becomes increasingly
> > clear that this law has nothing to do with curtailing the use of
> > Ecstasy and other dangerous drugs, but instead will be a tool for
> > suppressing activism in issues like Medical Marijuana where 80% of
> > Americans already support change.  These Drug War Fanatics cannot win
> > this battle on the basis of sound reason and common sense, so they
> > have resorted to using our tax dollars to lobby against it in
> > violation of the Hatch Act, as the ONDCP has done for the past two
> > years, and where they can't outshout the movement using ill-gotten
> > funds, they will use dangerous new laws like the Rave act, or result
> > to brute force  as they have in other places like St. Louis.
> >
> > FIRST AMENDMENT: VOID WHERE PROHIBITED.
> >
> > If you are able, please consider making a donation of $10 or more to
> > the Drug Policy Alliance's fund earmarked for fighting this law, which
> > is by its very existence and affront to democracy everywhere.
> > http://secure.ga3.org/05/raveact
> > Headed by former Princeton Professor Ethan Nadelmann, this
> > organization has an increasingly formidable lobbying presence in
> > Washington, DC and can really make a difference.
> >
> > Please forward this to all those who care about protecting the ideals
> > of free speech and dissent we were all brought up believing this
> > nation was supposed to stand for.
> >
> > Best,
> >
> > Joseph Durwin

> > The Orbits Project
> > Consciousness Research, Information, and Activism

June 13th, 2003
Oneiromancy Productions Presents
"Quantum Singularity"

Join us as we try to warp spacetime to a taste of what SF was like when names 
like "Frequency 8" or "Skills" were still young, and trance parties were still 
mystical journies that could change lives.
(and welcome Apot to the lineup...)

Featuring:

Axis Mundi (Nashville, TN)
One of the East Coast's up & coming Psytrance DJs, Axis Mundi has been turning 
on dancefloors all over the US, Canada, and Southern America to the magic of 
Psy. Combining years of mixing experience with an array of Live PA synths, 
drum machines, and samplers, Axis Mundi blends on-the-fly production into each 
of his sets, creating an unforgettable perfomance.

limited capacity, SF venue
9pm - 5am

**OK, So, I'm back hitting the scene again and promoting better since I graduated with a my B.A in Adverting. . . SO, here is a li'l tidbit of info that I thought I'd let you know of a really Awesome party going down.  People will actually be dressed up as the characters of "Peanut Butta Jelly TIme."  check out the Peanut Butta Jelly Time site and shake your booty before you party here. . . 
 
 
Your Underground Movement and Flawless USA invites you to: 
Peanut Butta Jelly Time! 
Friday, June 20th, 2003 ____________________________________________________________________ UFO SYSTEMS  (EARTH ISLAND RECORDINGS, GSPENTERTAINMENT.COM, FL) UFO SYSTEMS (aka David White) has been enlightening crowds with his Euro/Progressive sound for six years now. You can find him blowing up dance floors across the world, capturing the masses with his hypnotic rifts and melodic rhythms. His DJ sets are intended to be a vivid journey through his musical world, which separates him from the rest. David's sets have left crowds speechless and on their feet! Make sure not to miss his sensational performance and come see why people compare him to Paul Van Dyke and Christopher Lawrence! 
DJ KUE (TECHNO MISSIONARIES, MISDIRECTION - TX) DJ Kue, hailing from Texas, is the next rising star in the house scene. Inspired by Richard Humpty Vission and Bad Boy Bill, he displays an arsenal of various scratches, juggles, and other turntablist tricks. Do not miss his first San Francisco showcase and see why he is one of fastest rising DJs in the house scene today. 
THE FUNKIST AKA DJ FLAVE (USCEVENTS.COM, AND ZION'S GATE RECORDS - SEATTLE, WA) After searching the globe we are excited to bring you one of the most talented, cutting edge DJs we have ever seen. The next level of DJs is here! Dj Flave not only scratches with his foot but also has an arsenal of new dj tricks to blow your mind. All the way from Seattle, come see why his last bay area party sold out! The best way to describe his style is having the interactive energy of Donald Glaude, the technical skills of DJ Dan and a personality all his own. 
_____________________________________________________________________ AREA 1 - Funky Chunky Peanut Butta House Room Hosted by Nerd Nate 
JOEY MAZZOLA (Solmatic, joeymazzola.com) RON REESER (djronreeser.com/solmatic/sf) -cd release- JAMES DUB (Space Monkey, SF) VAL SPARKS  (www.valeriesparks.com) THE DOCTOR (DECIBLAST, BR) DJORIONZ ( www.nlpro.net/orionz ) ZELDA (Absolutely Flawless, YUM) ____________________________________________________________________ AREA 2 - GOT MILK ROOM Sponsored By BASSLINE FM Hosted by Geno Giovanni 
RECKLESS RYAN  (www.recklessryan.com, basslineFM - 90.5 KSJS, Zero Magazine) BAZOOKA JOE (www.djbazookajoe.com, Straight Hits) FREQUENCY - (WWW.DJFREQUENCY.COM) MATT FROST cd release- (WWW.GLOBALFUNKRECORDINGS.COM) JACK LACORTE VS ABSOLUTE ALEX (http://jack.yakshead.com, YUM vs. Fresh Ent, YUM, STAND OUT) PETER BLADES  (YUM) BILLY SOUL  (HIT FACTORY) _________________________________________________________________ AREA 3 - Jam N Jelly Room SPONSORED BY HIT FACTORY HOSTED BY D BOX (WILD 94.9) 
DENISE - (DJDENISE.COM) FELIPE AVELAR (DJFELIPEAVELAR.COM, ELEVATE, HIT FACTORY) DJ HOPE - (HOUSE NATION, AFTERHOURS ON 102.5) JAXX THE RIPPER - (ULTRA SOUNZ, CTB, DJAJAX.COM) JASEN CHAVEZ - (CLOCKWORK, ELEVATE) DANNY BOY - (HIT FACTORY, FUNKYFRESHMUSIK.COM) CARLOS ALFONSO - (BAYRAVES, DECIBLAST.ORG) AKIL TAYLOR (HIT FACTORY, DA FUNK) 
______________________________________________________________________ ARENA 4 - NO TIME FOR COTTONMOUTH ARENA SPONSORED BY REMIX AND DYSFUNKTION 
DJ LIQUID (REMIX/ JOURNEES.COM/ DUBCOAST - SAN FRANCISCO) MADAME MERCURY - (MAD WAX, STREET BEAT, REMIX) MATT THOMAS (REMIX) LUCKY MACROPOLIS (REMIX) DJ FOXX (REMIX) TEK THREAT (REMIX) BRYAN DELEON (REMIX) STEVE K (REMIX) 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 
Arena 5 - Best Thing Since Sliced Bread Sponsored By Synesthesia, Earth Island Records and Global Sound Philosophy. 
SOMA KINETIC (SYNESTHESIA, BURN BROTHERS) THEZPROJECT (SYNESTHESIA, CURE, GSP, GANJA JEDIS) SPECTIVE (ZERO MAGAZINE/SPECTIVEDANCEDOTCOM) RYAN THOMAS (A10, SYNESTHESIA) DJ CROIX (SYNESTHESIA) TREBURNE (SYNESTHESIA, PURE DIGITAL SPACE) 
____________________________________________________________________ 24 hour Info line: 1-877-410-1425 All Responsible Ages Welcome. Fully Stocked Bar for the 21+. 5 Room air-conditioned venue with plenty of dancing space, well lit parking and friendly security. Awesome sound and visuals. Tons of free give a ways all night long! Arrive early, Doors open @ 8pm sharp! Presale Tickets will be at: 
Straight Hits Vinyl Shop (510) 745-7843 Hit Factory (408) 929-4487 F-8 (415) 221-4142 Skills (510) 704-9876 Ultra Soundz (650) 871-4170 Solid Grooves (408) 248-6399 Remix (650) 344-8060 In Tha Mix (916) 442-0499 Pipeline (831) 425-7473 Generation Rock (925) 682-9042 5:15 Records (209) 464-5677 
Tickets go on sale for just $5! Then $13, then $20, and then $25. Tickets will also be available @ groovetickets.com or by phone 877-71GROOVE and @ spinfoil.com Buy pre sales early to ensure entry! Limited amount of door tickets available. 
BUY YOUR PRESALES NOW!!! 
Become a VIP and receive VIP treatment... Free Drinks and special giveaways in our VIP lounge. Not too mention; a chance to chill with your favorite djs, shorter lines and Free Food, including Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwiches (bananas optional). VIP tickets are $35 
Proceeds from Peanut Butta Jelly Time will be going to The American Cancer Society in memory of those we love, as well as The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation in honor of Lindsay Mulic. 
Interested in vending or helping promote for the show? E-mail flawlessusa@yahoo.com 
For more information and special lodging information go to www.flawlessUSA.com

BUY YOUR PRESALES NOW!!!
Become a VIP and receive VIP treatment... Free Drinks and special giveaways
in our VIP lounge. Not too mention; a chance to chill with your favorite
djs, shorter lines and Free Food, including Peanut Butter and Jelly
Sandwiches (bananas optional). VIP tickets are $35

Society in memory of those we love, as well as The Cystic Fibrosis
Foundation in honor of Lindsay Mulic.

Subject: =[ HIGH OCTANE ]= mini-MASSIVE...June 13th w/Lock N' Load, Chris C., and more

--0-1616325018-1054769196=:88958
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


IMPORTANT!!! all High Octane Presale holders will get into our next event "Aquatech" FREE!!!



From the Creators of Power Puff Girls 1 and 2, Enter the Dragon 1-3 and countless other record breaking events.

 

Shaolin Presents.Our BIGGEST party ever!

June 13, 2003

HIGH OCTANE <~~mini-MASSIVE

============================

 

LOCK N LOAD

The Lock N' Load project consists of two Dutch producers / DJs: Frank van Rooijen and Niels Pijpers. One fine day the Club Caviar boys came to visit the Lock N' Load studio, heard the old version of a song and offered to do a remix of it. In collaboration with Lock N' Load they delivered this stunning result and Niels decided to release "Blow Ya Mind". After all on Blue White Records, within a period of three weeks, it became the No. 1 club record in the Netherlands, and Europe followed soon after that, the United Kingdom was ready to be conquered. Through no. 1 positions in both the UK Club and UK Dance chart it had an amazing entry at 6. Help us welcome Lock N' Load to Sacramento.

Chris C.

Now firmly established as one of the Biggest and most popular DJ / Producers on the UK Hard House/NRG scene, Chris has masterminded the emergence and rapid success of his 3 Labels, Mohawk, Aztec and Nile. Positioning the former today as one of the genres top 5 marques. With over 30 single releases and 2 Albums to his name on various labels including Tidy Trax, Tinrib, Eve, Honeypot, Phoenix Rising, GBT, Bulletproof, etc...Chris' reputation as one of Britain's finest exponent of Hard House, both behind the decks and in the studio, continues to grow.

Whistler

Victor Cape a.k.a. Whistler shines as a highly respected DJ on the Pacific Northwest dance scene. Known for his tight mixing skills and uplifting personality behind the decks, Whistler blends energy and emotion from Hard Melodic Trance, Epic Anthems and Hard House to take his listeners on a dance floor rollercoaster ride. If being a DJ wasn't enough, he also manages Lovetribe which has quickly become one of the most well respected event productions in Seattle. It's been over a year and a half since Whistler's last performance in Northern California. So we're excited to bring him out for his first Sacramento performance!

 

 

Dyloot

Arguably Nor-Cals BIGGEST Trance DJ/Producer watch him work his MAGIC over the crowd.

 

Tom Slik Vs. Tracer

Two of Nor-Cals Biggest Trance DJs wage war for the first time in Sacramento.

Denise Vs. Paul the Fanman

First ever Teacher vs. Student battle between the establish Denise and the BIG up n comer Paul. Lets see if he learned some tricks on his own.

Dragnfly Vs. Scepter

Shaolins two BIGGEST DJs go head to head to see who really is the SHAOLIN MASTER.

Bazooka Joe Vs. Reckless Ryan

Showmanship is the only way to describe the performance these two put on. Turntablist House at its best. Watch as these two leave you in a wicky-wick-AWWW!

Valerie Sparks vs. The Doctor

Nor Cals Best Hardcore Female DJ goes against this up n coming Junglist.

Sascha 23 Vs. Gauge

The founder of Xtort bumps heads with one of Shaolins Most talented Producer in a must see set with original Shaolin tracks.

 

 

IMPORTANT!!!

All High Octane Presale Holders will get into our next event (Aquatech) FREE!

Free: Glowsticks, Glow Bracelets, Glow mouth pieces, Stickers, Tasty Candy, CDs and Gift Bags.

ALL RESPONSIBLE AGES!!!

7pm - 5am

Tons of Lasers, Lighting and Visuals. Plus dancing AIR PEOPLE and vendor village.

www.shaolinproductions.net <http://www.shaolinproductions.net>

Subject: NRR:  Sex in the Matrix

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Sex in the Matrix

By Annalee Newitz, AlterNet
June 4, 2003

A lot of people seem troubled by the amount of sex in "The Matrix=20
Reloaded." This summer's sequel to 2000's science fiction smash hit "The=20
Matrix" is the ultimate cyberaction flick, complete with hackers, exploding=
=20
trucks, and fight sequences as visceral as the ones in a first-person=20
shooter. But much to the confusion of audiences used to S.F. films full of=
=20
burly but virginal astronauts, "The Matrix Reloaded" is also punctuated by=
=20
two graphic, extended sex sequences.

No "kiss and cut away" Star Wars-style moments here =96 we get full-blown=20
R-rated smut. One scene is a six-minute rave-orgy, the other a regrettable=
=20
depiction of a computer code-induced clitoral orgasm. There are other=20
seemingly gratuitous erotic moments, too: hero Neo makes out hungrily with=
=20
hacker grrrl Trinity in an elevator; evil Persephone helps Neo find the=20
valuable Keymaker in exchange for an intense,=20
tight-close-up-on-the-spit-covered-lips kiss.

So what's the deal with all this sexiness in a movie whose premise is that=
=20
we can transcend our bodies using computers? After all, most of us went to=
=20
see it for another taste of the eponymous virtual world where Neo can fly,=
=20
Trinity can leap across tall buildings in a single bound, and ship captain=
=20
Morpheus has to battle albino vampire bodyguards who can dematerialize at=20
will.

Adding insult to injury, sex in the matrix is pretty lame. The rave scene,=
=20
with its sweaty, half-naked bodies and trying-to-be-hip jungle beats, feels=
=20
hopelessly dated already. And the orgasm sequence =96 well, let's just say=
=20
that combining the "scary grid" special effects from Disney's Black Hole=20
with female genital anatomy wasn't such a great idea. You can tell the=20
Wachowski brothers grew up jacking off to ASCII p0rn. That's nice, but=20
nobody really wants to think of her clitoris as a glowing dot on a graph,=20
OK, boys?

Yet the more I thought about Reloaded, the more I realized that the sex, as=
=20
cartoony as it might be, is one of the most innovative parts of the movie.=
=20
Think about it: When was the last time you saw a special-effects=20
blockbuster with hot, sweaty sex in it? Especially multiracial,=20
multipartner, out-of-wedlock sex that didn't spell doom for its=20
practitioners? The heroes in Reloaded are frankly sexual, with no apologies.

None of this would matter outside of the hotel bars at science fiction=20
conventions if it weren't for the extraordinary popularity of the "Matrix"=
=20
trilogy (the third movie comes out in November). Joel Silver, who produced=
=20
"Reloaded," told Entertainment Weekly that audience tracking by the=20
National Research Group revealed the movie was the top choice for 43=20
percent of people polled =96 an extremely high number in the industry.=
 Ticket=20
sales have been astronomical too. It grossed $365 million worldwide in its=
=20
first two weekends.

What those numbers mean is that "Reloaded" has saturated our culture as=20
much as, if not more than, political propaganda coming from the Bush=20
administration. People are watching Neo and Trinity grope each other with=20
more relish than they are Attorney General John Ashcroft's latest salvo on=
=20
the evils of Internet pornography. It's very possible that the war for=20
human liberation in Reloaded has garnered higher audience awareness than=20
the war for Iraqi freedom.

As if in a kind of corollary to its sexual openness, the "Matrix" movies=20
are self-consciously multicultural. Their human heroes are fighting against=
=20
machines who have enslaved most of the human race, and it's hard to avoid=20
comparing our heroes' rebellion to that of colonized peoples all over the=20
world. As if to drive this point home, one of the outspoken members of the=
=20
liberated human city Zion is played by progressive, antiracist intellectual=
=20
Cornel West. Tellingly, most of our heroes are people of color and racially=
=20
mixed. The "bad guys" are all white men in suits. More startling still,=20
Zion is a city both pious and sexually liberated: The rave-orgy scene is a=
=20
public celebration that follows a group prayer.

What does it mean that "Reloaded" has become so mind-bendingly popular=20
during one of the most politically conservative periods in the history of=20
the United States? We've fallen in love with an epic of multicultural=20
rebellion during an era of "homeland security" with more than a few racist=
=20
overtones. And in a time of hysteria over everything from erotic cartoons=20
on the Web to the ensoulment of stem cells, people are drinking in images=20
of women having remote-controlled clitoral orgasms.

Is "Reloaded" all the liberation we'll get this decade? Or are our=20
preferences for progressive fantasies a hint of political preferences to=
 come?

Annalee Newitz (rabbithole@techsploitation.com) is a surly media nerd who=20
was glad to see that nmap works much faster inside the matrix. Her column=20
also appears in Metro, Silicon Valley's weekly newspaper.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to=20
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great=20
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in=
=20
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of=20
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the=20
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

----- Original Message -----
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: "SFRaves@hyperreal. org" <SFRaves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, June 04, 2003 6:57 PM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Sex in the Matrix


Sex in the Matrix

By Annalee Newitz, AlterNet
June 4, 2003

A lot of people seem troubled by the amount of sex in "The Matrix
Reloaded." This summer's sequel to 2000's science fiction smash hit "The
Matrix" is the ultimate cyberaction flick, complete with hackers, exploding
trucks, and fight sequences as visceral as the ones in a first-person
shooter. But much to the confusion of audiences used to S.F. films full of
burly but virginal astronauts, "The Matrix Reloaded" is also punctuated by
two graphic, extended sex sequences.

No "kiss and cut away" Star Wars-style moments here - we get full-blown
R-rated smut. One scene is a six-minute rave-orgy, the other a regrettable
depiction of a computer code-induced clitoral orgasm. There are other
seemingly gratuitous erotic moments, too: hero Neo makes out hungrily with
hacker grrrl Trinity in an elevator; evil Persephone helps Neo find the
valuable Keymaker in exchange for an intense,
tight-close-up-on-the-spit-covered-lips kiss.

So what's the deal with all this sexiness in a movie whose premise is that
we can transcend our bodies using computers? After all, most of us went to
see it for another taste of the eponymous virtual world where Neo can fly,
Trinity can leap across tall buildings in a single bound, and ship captain
Morpheus has to battle albino vampire bodyguards who can dematerialize at
will.

Adding insult to injury, sex in the matrix is pretty lame. The rave scene,
with its sweaty, half-naked bodies and trying-to-be-hip jungle beats, feels
hopelessly dated already. And the orgasm sequence - well, let's just say
that combining the "scary grid" special effects from Disney's Black Hole
with female genital anatomy wasn't such a great idea. You can tell the
Wachowski brothers grew up jacking off to ASCII p0rn. That's nice, but
nobody really wants to think of her clitoris as a glowing dot on a graph,
OK, boys?

Yet the more I thought about Reloaded, the more I realized that the sex, as
cartoony as it might be, is one of the most innovative parts of the movie.
Think about it: When was the last time you saw a special-effects
blockbuster with hot, sweaty sex in it? Especially multiracial,
multipartner, out-of-wedlock sex that didn't spell doom for its
practitioners? The heroes in Reloaded are frankly sexual, with no apologies.

None of this would matter outside of the hotel bars at science fiction
conventions if it weren't for the extraordinary popularity of the "Matrix"
trilogy (the third movie comes out in November). Joel Silver, who produced
"Reloaded," told Entertainment Weekly that audience tracking by the
National Research Group revealed the movie was the top choice for 43
percent of people polled - an extremely high number in the industry. Ticket
sales have been astronomical too. It grossed $365 million worldwide in its
first two weekends.

What those numbers mean is that "Reloaded" has saturated our culture as
much as, if not more than, political propaganda coming from the Bush
administration. People are watching Neo and Trinity grope each other with
more relish than they are Attorney General John Ashcroft's latest salvo on
the evils of Internet pornography. It's very possible that the war for
human liberation in Reloaded has garnered higher audience awareness than
the war for Iraqi freedom.

As if in a kind of corollary to its sexual openness, the "Matrix" movies
are self-consciously multicultural. Their human heroes are fighting against
machines who have enslaved most of the human race, and it's hard to avoid
comparing our heroes' rebellion to that of colonized peoples all over the
world. As if to drive this point home, one of the outspoken members of the
liberated human city Zion is played by progressive, antiracist intellectual
Cornel West. Tellingly, most of our heroes are people of color and racially
mixed. The "bad guys" are all white men in suits. More startling still,
Zion is a city both pious and sexually liberated: The rave-orgy scene is a
public celebration that follows a group prayer.

What does it mean that "Reloaded" has become so mind-bendingly popular
during one of the most politically conservative periods in the history of
the United States? We've fallen in love with an epic of multicultural
rebellion during an era of "homeland security" with more than a few racist
overtones. And in a time of hysteria over everything from erotic cartoons
on the Web to the ensoulment of stem cells, people are drinking in images
of women having remote-controlled clitoral orgasms.

Is "Reloaded" all the liberation we'll get this decade? Or are our
preferences for progressive fantasies a hint of political preferences to
come?

Annalee Newitz (rabbithole@techsploitation.com) is a surly media nerd who
was glad to see that nmap works much faster inside the matrix. Her column
also appears in Metro, Silicon Valley's weekly newspaper.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Sex in the Matrix

This piece is pretty funny. But it's kinda weird how
she's all snooty about the "hopelessly dated" beats in
the rave scene, and then she says they're jungle. I
recall those beats as house, not jungle, and I could
swear there was a difference.

(Altho to be fair those beats, whatever they turn out
to have been, sure were cheesy.)

I thought the sex scene with Neo & Trinity was a bit
creepy, and the gratuitous tits in the "rave" thing
kinda cheese, and yeah the Persephone bit made no
sense at all -- but the bit with the orgasm cake
program was funny! plus, I liked it because the guys
who made that movie were always horny bastids. check
out the first Wachowski brothers movie, "Bound." a
lesbian mobster flick named after its bondage scene.

("Bound" is visually stunning and lots of fun but it
probably has very little connection to real-life
lesbians -- at least I don't think I've ever met any
real-life lesbians who killed mobsters and took their
money, but maybe that just means I have a boring life.
or, perhaps, that I don't ask the right questions of
the lesbians I do meet.)

years ago, I thought it would be cool to set up a
business to create pornos with Matrix effects. I got
bored of the idea but it's still kinda neat to see the
Matrix with porno effects. makes me think I saw the
future coming or something.

(the amazing Giles Bowkett! capable of turning any
thread into a discussion of himself! watch his ego fly
to the spotlight of discussion, gigantic and
simultaneously mothlike -- like it was Mothra!)

blah, blah, blah.


Giles

Subject: BSP: Calling all Pro Techno Alliance members.  AndyW on EOS today.

That's right.  PURE brainfood is in store this morning, and what better
way is there to start the day.  Your chef this morning is AndyW, serving
up hot buttered beats of the crunchy variety.  Straight up 110% of your
RDA.  It all goes down starting at 9a this morning on 90.1 FM in the bay
area, or online at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu and wraps up at noon.
Do listen in.  We've got plenty of ticket giveaways also, including
passes to The Braintree tonight, and the Velvet Shop grand reopening
tonight at the new Zoe nightclub in San Jose with Jeno & Julias Papp.

Be talking with ya.
Peace.

experience what an awesome year it has been musically for our DJ's of =
this up-and-coming progressive collective.

catch a night of pulsating progressive anthems that will prepare you for =
the week ahead.

Date: Wed, 04 Jun 2003 11:00:32 -0700
From: studioz-announce@mail2.studioz.tv
To: Jon Scott Stevens <jon@studioz.tv>
Subject: [StudioZ-announce] 11th & Folsom Street Businesses Need Your Help!

Once again, nightlife and businesses in San Francisco are being attacked.
Please pass this message on to all your friends.

This THURSDAY, June 5th @ approx 6:30pm, there is going to be a
DISCRETIONARY REVIEW HEARING at City Hall, ROOM 400. Please join us and sho=
w
your support in this matter.

The owner of 1525 Folsom St. has evicted the business from that location an=
d
is attempting to convert the space into a residential dwelling unit. The
location of this space is above the Holy Cow Bar and V Caf=E9. 1525 Folsom =
is
also situated between the StudioZ.tv "B Space" and the Wish Bar.

Here is a crude overhead drawing of the layout of the business in the
immediate area.

                ------------------.  |   |
                |  S      |   |   |  |   |
            11  |-----| S |   |   | N|   |
                |  P  |   | V | H |  | W |
                L_________________.  .___.
                           F

11 =3D 11th Street
N =3D Norfolk Alley
F =3D Folsom St.
S =3D StudioZ.tv
P =3D Paradise Lounge
V =3D V Caf=E9
H =3D Holy Cow
W =3D Wish

Again, the proposed plan is to put a dwelling unit above the V Caf=E9 and t=
he
Holy Cow bar.

You might be aware that nightlife in San Francisco typically needs to work
with residential neighbors in order to peacefully co-exist. For example, th=
e
San Francisco Late Night Coalition was originally formed to help give
existing neighbors and nightlife business a means to communicate peacefully
and productively. This process has worked quite well for cases of existing
neighbors and business conflicts.

Now, we are in a situation where someone wants to construct a dwelling unit
right on top of known late night entertainment businesses and this is our
chance to stop it before it is too late.

The reality is that no amount of expensive sound proofing is going to
prevent residents in this location from being in conflict with the existing
businesses. The building is quite old and we have been told by architects
that the entire building would need to be torn down and rebuilt with modern
materials in order to have even close to adequate sound attenuation. There
is no known plan by the owner to do this.

If we or other establishments go out of business because of this, it will
affect the business-ecosystem which exists on 11th Street. In other words,
we all depend on each other, the more businesses on 11th Street the better
for everyone. This is hard economic times, let's not make it worse with
problems that can be easily mitigated.

This THURSDAY, June 5th @ approx 6:30pm, there is going to be a
DISCRETIONARY REVIEW HEARING at City Hall, ROOM 400. Please join us and sho=
w
your support in this matter.

Here is the information about the hearing from the SF Planning website:

---------------------------------------------------------------------------=
-
http://sfgov.org/site/planning_page.asp?id=3D17743

14. 2003.0293D (D. SIDER: (415) 558-6697)

1525 FOLSOM STREET - east side between Norfolk and 11th Streets, Lot 053 in
Assessor's Block 3521 - Mandatory Discretionary Review of Building Permit
Application Number 2003.02.05.6758, a proposal to convert the second story
of an existing two story building from that of storage into a dwelling unit=
=2E
The construction of a new rear deck, stairs, and garage are also proposed.
The property is located in an SLR (Service / Light Industrial / Residential=
)
Zoning District, the IPZ (Industrial Protection Zone) as set forth in
Planning Commission Resolution Number 16202, and a 50-X Height and Bulk
District.

Preliminary Recommendation: Take Discretionary Review to approve the projec=
t
with conditions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------=
-

We need your help to change the preliminary recommendation to not allow thi=
s
to happen at all. No amount of conditions will prevent noise problems with
these neighbors. Please come to the hearing and show your support!

Thank you for your support in this pressing matter! Please pass this messag=
e
on to all your friends.

Subject: Fw: Victory in Congress!!


----- Original Message -----
From: Drug Policy Alliance <alerts@actioncenter.drugpolicy.org>
To: <osbyjamz@hotmail.com>
Sent: Thursday, June 05, 2003 4:50 PM
Subject: Victory in Congress!!


> **White House Prohibited From Using Taxpayer Money to Tell You
>      How to Vote!
> **Attacks on Medical Marijuana Defeated!!
> **Higher Education Ban Reformed!!!
>
>
> A couple of weeks ago we alerted you to an intense lobbying campaign
> the Drug Policy Alliance was waging in Congress to defeat a number of
> dangerous provisions in HR 2086, the "Office of National Drug Control
> Policy Reauthorization Act of 2003." Our campaign, which was in
> partnership with the Marijuana Policy Project, was gaining steam and
> we urged you to call the Government Reform Committee. Your calls
> launched a tidal wave of reform that ultimately cleaned up this bad
> bill.
>
> In a letter to the Government Reform Committee dated May 29th, the
> Drug Policy Alliance urged the Committee to make seven amendments to
> the bill. The Committee voted today: we got five out of seven!!!
>
> We also won another important reform we were asking for in a separate
> lobbying campaign.
>
> What did the drug policy reform movement win?
>
> The House Government Reform Committee:
>
> * Repealed provisions allowing Drug Czar John Walters and the Bush
> White House to spend up to $195 million a year in taxpayer money
> to defeat medical marijuana ballot measures and pro-reform candidates;
>
> * Added new provisions prohibiting the National Youth Anti-Drug
> Media Campaign from ever being used to defeat pro-reform candidates,
> legislation, regulations, and ballot measures;
>
> * Eliminated provisions allowing the Drug Czar's office to run
> anti-drug ads without telling voters the ads were paid for by the
> government;
>
> * Restored requirements that to the extent possible anti-drug ads
> include contact information for local drug treatment providers;
>
> * Repealed provisions allowing the Drug Czar to divert millions of
> dollars away from local and state law-enforcement agencies to federal
> agencies to arrest medical marijuana patients and their caregivers;
> and
>
> * Passed provisions requiring the Drug Czar to decertify the federal
> budget if the Department of Education blocks school loans and grants
> to former drug offenders; as well as compelling the Department to
> develop a plan for providing financial assistance to people who have
> been unfairly denied.  (This major reform was the result of years of
> aggressive lobbying by the Coalition for HEA Reform
> http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=23913&l=1959.
>
> The campaign to reform this bill made national headlines, including
> articles in the Washington Times, Las Vegas Review-Journal, and Roll Call:
> http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=23913&l=1955
>
> Newspapers across the country editorialized against the bad
> provisions in it, including the Orange Country Register, Los Angeles
> Times, St. Petersburg Times and the Baltimore Sun.
> http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=23913&l=1956
>
> A letter to the Government Reform Committee urging the Committee "to
> add provisions...explicitly prohibiting the media campaign from being
> used to influence elections and legislation" was signed by the Ballot
> Initiative Strategy Center, Common Cause, Drug Policy Alliance,
> Justice Policy Institute, Initiative & Referendum Institute,
> Marijuana Policy Project, National Black Police Association, National
> Taxpayers Union, and Taxpayers for Common Sense.
> http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=23913&l=1957
>
> We are grateful for everything these and other groups did. But we are
> especially grateful for what you did to persuade the Government
> Reform Committee to vote for drug policy reform. We owe this victory
> all to you. Thank you, thank you, and thank you!
>
> Of course, these reforms still face a long road ahead. The full House
> has yet to vote on the bill and the Senate has yet to take it up at
> all. Over the next couple of weeks we may face challenges from drug war
> extremists who will stop at nothing to try to undo our reforms. As
> usual, we will speak truth to lies and fight them every step of the
> way.
>
> Thanks again for your help.
>
>
> P.S.
>
> If you want to help in our campaign, please consider becoming a
> member of the Drug Policy Alliance, if you are not already. This
> helps the Alliance in two ways. First, it helps pay for the cost of
> our public education efforts, including our action alerts and fax
> campaigns. Without contributions from people like you who believe in
> freedom and justice, the John Walters and John Ashcrofts of the world
> will get their entire drug war agenda through Congress. Secondly,
> becoming a member of the Alliance improves our ability to educate
> Congress on the need for reform. There's an iron law in Washington --
> the more members you have, the more politicians listen. If we are
> going to protect electronic music, stop the war on marijuana users,
> eliminate the racial injustices of the drug war, and protect the Bill
> of Rights, we need people like you to join the Alliance.
>
> You can become a member for an investment of as little as $35. Find out
more at:
> http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=23913&l=1958
>
>
> ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
> You received this message because osbyjamz@hotmail.com is a member of the
mailing list originating from alerts@actioncenter.drugpolicy.org.
>
> Please visit http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/unsubscribe to unsubscribe
from all lists.  Visit
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/managesubscription.asp to learn about
other lists you can subscribe to.
>
> For problems, please contact Jeanette Irwin at jirwin@drugpolicy.org.
>
> Please consider joining the Drug Policy Alliance:
http://www.drugpolicy.org/join

Subject: DEA Uses RAVE Act Threats to Block Montana NORML/SSDP Benefit 

--=====================_2172030==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

DEA Uses RAVE Act Threats to Block Montana NORML/SSDP Benefit

An agent of the federal Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) used threats 
of RAVE Act prosecutions to intimidate the owners of a Billings, Montana, 
venue into a canceling a combined benefit for the Montana chapter of the 
National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws 
(http://www.norml.org) and Students for Sensible Drug Policy 
(http://www.ssdp.org) last week.

The RAVE Act, now known officially as the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation 
Act, championed by Sen. Joe Biden (D-DE), was ostensibly aimed at so-called 
raves, the large electronic music concerts often associated with open drug 
use, but was so broadly written that opponents argued it could be applied 
against any event or venue where owners or organizers did not take 
sufficiently repressive steps to prevent drug use. Opposition to the bill 
stalled it in the Senate last year, but this year Biden stealthily inserted 
it into the enormously popular Amber Alert Bill, which passed last month 
and was signed into law by President Bush.

While the Billings event was advertised as a benefit concert for two local 
groups interested in drug law reform -- not as a drug-taking orgy -- it 
still attracted the attention of the DEA. On May 30, the day the event was 
set to take place, a Billings-based DEA agent showed up at the Eagle Lodge, 
which had booked the concert. Waving a copy of the RAVE Act in one hand, 
the agent warned that the lodge could face a fine of $250,000 if someone 
smoked a joint during the benefit, according to Eagle Lodge manager Kelly, 
who asked that her last name not be used.

"He freaked me out," Kelly told DRCNet. "He didn't tell us we couldn't have 
the event, but he showed me the law and told us what could happen if we 
did. I talked to our trustees, they talked to our lawyers, and our lawyers 
said not to risk it, so we canceled," she said. "I felt bad. I knew the 
guys in the bands."

Primary event organizer Adam Jones was unavailable for comment, having been 
arrested and jailed by his probation officer for switching work-study jobs 
at Montana State University-Billings without first informing him. He is on 
probation for possession of psychedelic mushrooms. It has been speculated, 
but not yet confirmed, that the probation officer, described in unprintable 
terms by several local sources, was responsible for siccing the DEA on the 
benefit.

"The DEA guy kept talking about Adam Jones," Kelly said. Jones apparently 
got the hint. In a message relayed from jail, Jones announced that we was 
resigning from SSDP and NORML and foregoing further drug reform efforts 
until he is free from the clutches of the state. That probably spells the 
temporary demise of Teachers Against Prohibition 
(http://www.teachersagainstprohibition.org), a group that education major 
Jones founded after having run smack up against drug war reality with his 
arrest (http://www.drcnet.org/wol/278.html#teachersagainstprohibition).

DEA Denver regional office spokesman Bill Wyman confirmed to DRCNet that an 
agent had visited the Eagle Lodge to warn of possible RAVE Act violations 
and their consequences, but deferred a more detailed response to Special 
Agent in Charge Jeff Sweet, whom Wyman promised would call back shortly. 
We're stilling waiting for that call.

"This confirms all our fears about the RAVE Act," said Bill Piper of the 
Drug Policy Alliance (http://www.drugpolicy.org), which spearheaded 
opposition to the bill, succeeding in blocking it last year. "This isn't 
about drug parties or raves, it's about having a club to hold over people's 
heads, whether its hemp festivals, circuit parties, dances, whatever. The 
RAVE Act is being used to suppress political speech. This is exactly what 
Sen. Biden said would not happen, and now it's happening," he told DRCNet.

Biden's office did not respond to repeated DRCNet inquiries about whether 
the Montana intimidation effort was what he intended the act to accomplish. 
But Biden wasn't alone in his silence. None of the three members of the 
Montana congressional delegation, Sens. Max Baucus (D) and Conrad Burns 
(R), and Rep. Dennis Rehberg (R), responded to DRCNet inquiries either.

Other national drug reform organizations also expressed shock and outrage. 
"This looks like the first application of the RAVE Act, and this is a very 
scary precedent, said NORML Foundation head Allen St. Pierre. "Preemptively 
shutting down a First Amendment-protected event is something that just 
doesn't happen in America," he told DRCNet. "This is absolutely what we 
feared and predicted would happen if the RAVE Act passed. Isn't Montana 
known for being resistant to federal encroachment? This should make them 
mighty uneasy."

"This is just more evidence that the current administration is engaged in a 
culture war targeting medical marijuana patients, glass blowers, festival 
goers and young people," said SSDP national director Shawn Heller.

"Wow," said Marijuana Policy Project communications director Bruce Mirken. 
"This appears to be a clear violation of the purpose and intent of the law. 
The RAVE Act's sponsors said repeatedly it was to crack down on people 
knowingly allowing open drug use," he told DRCNet. "To use it to crack down 
on reform organizations is an outrageous First Amendment violation. If 
laws, no matter how wrongheaded, aimed at drug use and distribution are 
used to intimidate efforts to discuss reform or raise money for reform, we 
are getting really Orwellian. I really hope the folks up there sue and sue 
hard."

Montana activists are also worried but undaunted. Missoula Hempfest 
organizer and Montana NORML spokesman John Masterson told DRCNet the threat 
of RAVE Act prosecutions was being carefully considered. "The Hempfest 
committee just spent most of our last meeting talking about this," he said. 
"We have more than 5,000 people each year in a Missoula city park. Is the 
DEA going to come after the city? We are meeting with local attorneys to 
discuss this, but we're not talking about canceling Hempfest. Screw that."

And the drug reformers are mobilizing. A conference call among NORML, SSDP, 
MPP, Montana NORML and the Montana ACLU was set for Thursday night or this 
morning. "We may have a coalition up to fight this by the end of the day," 
St. Pierre said Thursday. "The Drug Policy Alliance warned us the RAVE Act 
would be used to suppress free speech, and they haven't been proven wrong. 
Looks like we have our first case."



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: ATP: BSP: Twenty-six things a perfect guy would do, and other propaganda disseminated by misguided women.

------=_NextPart_000_0021_01C32C19.CB94FF90
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

**not my views, or quotes....just sharing... jt*

Someone recently sent me an email titled 26 things a perfect guy would =
do. I thought "hmm, nobody could possibly send me anything so stupid, it =
can't possibly be as dumb as it sounds." I stand corrected. The email =
was just as advertised: a wish list of how women supposedly want men to =
act, as if men in this country weren't already an episode of Friends =
away from turning into giant walking vaginas.=20

I never thought I'd ever read anything that would induce my gag reflex =
so quickly, and this is after having read the details of an anal =
prolapse that a friend sent me tonight. Here is the abridged list =
(because the full list might literally cause you to barf on your =
keyboard, and frankly, it's not worth reading), followed by my response =
to each "thing" that a "perfect guy would do:"=20

1. Know how to make you smile when you are down!=20
When will women realize that they don't live on the set of a romantic =
comedy? Unless making you smile involves me playing video games while =
you cook me a steak, you're in for a disappointment. You don't think =
guys ever feel "down?" The door swings both ways, bitch.=20

2. Try to secretly smell your hair, but you always notice.=20
What? Why the hell would I want to smell a woman's hair? It smells bad =
enough with all the sprays and perfume they use. Enough with the =
conditioners, sprays, and cream already; that shit makes my eyes water. =
What the hell is conditioner anyway?=20

3. Stick up for you, but still respects your independence.=20
Translation: bail you out when you fail at life, but never bring it up =
during conversations.=20

4. Give you the remote control during the game.=20
This one is inherently stupid because it implies that all guys like to =
watch "the game." Since I'd rather be shot in the chest with projectile =
diarrhea than watch "the game," I'll assume the author meant something =
worthy of watching, such as Ren & Stimpy, in which case you need to put =
the bitch down if she touches your remote.=20

5. Come up behind you and put his arms around you.=20
LAME. Who has time for this? Sounds like something out of a herpes =
commercial where some lady is rock climbing or doing something else =
which symbolizes her independence, then out of nowhere she blurts out "I =
HAVE HERPES." The music gets all serious and you hear a voice over =
"...there is no cure," cue inspirational music "but treatment is =
available." Then it cuts to a shot of the bitch on a beach and a guy =
runs up behind her and puts his arms around her. Good job dumbass, =
you're dating a skank with herpes.=20

6. Play with your hair.=20
Again with the hair? Women never play with the hair on my back, why the =
double standard?=20

7. His hands always find yours.=20
This is one of those things women read and say "AWW HOW ROMANTIC." I =
have news for you: holding hands is stupid. Women don't know the first =
thing about being romantic. Only lesbians hold hands anyway; allow me to =
explain. The only time it's acceptable to hold hands with anyone is if =
you're at a peace vigil. Guys don't go to peace vigils, period. If you =
do, you have to surrender your balls and get a sex transplant because =
you're a bitch; in either case, you're a woman, and when two women hold =
hands it can only lead to one thing as far as I'm concerned.=20

8. Be cute when he really wants something.=20
Bullshit. When I want something, I yell. If she can't hear me in the =
kitchen, sometimes I'll threaten beatings if I'm sober.=20

9. Offer you plenty of massages.=20
For your boobs maybe. I happen to have the uncanny ability to massage =
breasts. With my mouth.=20

10. Dance with you, even if he feels like a dork.=20
Let's face it: there are few things in this world more stupid than =
dancing. Except break dancing, which pirates and lumber jacks would =
agree is awesome. Other than that, dancing makes me envy cripples.=20

11. React so cutely when you hit him and it actually hurts.=20
See, this is what pisses me off about women: they expect special =
treatment at their discretion. They want equal rights, equal pay, and =
equal treatment for everything EXCEPT when it comes to shit like this, =
then they want you to "react cutely" instead of, say, putting them in a =
head lock and making them eat ants and/or spiders while you give them =
carpet burn. Why don't women react "cutely" when men hit them for a =
change? Oops, I forgot, that's domestic abuse.=20

12. Drive 5 hours just to see you for 1.=20
Any guy who would drive five hours just to see a chick for one is an =
asshole. If every guy drove around for five hours just to spend one with =
their girlfriend, we'd fill up the air with so much pollution that we'd =
all choke on the exhaust, get cancer, and then bake under the sun while =
our lungs rupture and we slowly die from internal bleeding.=20

13. Stare at you.=20
You stupid attention seeking whore, just buy the bitch a mirror, because =
apparently she thinks that you don't have anything better to do than to =
sit around and stare at her. If women ran the world, we'd still be =
searching for the wheel.=20

14. Call for no reason.=20
Oops, this one belongs on the list of "Twenty-six things women do that =
piss men off because they need to fill their otherwise vapid lives with =
something to make them feel like they have a purpose for existing as =
they eventually realize that they're pissing their youth away on stupid =
bullshit like fashion trends."=20

I can't go on, I'm going to go do something less painful like stick my =
dick in the oven.=20

--
DJ Jack Triumph

Sunday, June 8TH
COMPRESSION 80's NIGHT : JOHN B & DISCO D
We love em so much, thats why on this night we bring 2 of Compression's 
favorite DJ's together for a night of crazy ass fun...

JOHN B (Beta, Tangent, Nu Electro, Chihuahua, London, UK)
John B is a name synonymous with originality. He has constructed some of the 
most daring Drum & Bass audio experiments of the last five years, and this 
is a consequence of his reluctance to pigeonhole himself under any one 
style. His refusal to conform to traditional methods means that his 
productive streak is ever changing; and so in delving into the timeline of 
John's musical career, some staggeringly contrasting and imaginative vinyl 
pressings can be discovered.

*Recent Music Production:
Bad Dreams (Sleepwalk) - Click here to listen


DISCO D (Tommy Boy, Bootybar.biz, NYC) "a night at the booty bar" cd world 
tour
To the press, he has been dubbed "phenom", "holder of the Ghettotech torch", 
"devastatingly wicked" and "surreally filthy." To his fans, he's no less 
than legendary behind the decks, captivating audiences worldwide with his 
distinguished blend of hard-hitting music and turntablist tricks. To others, 
he's a seasoned entrepreneur, as the founder and head of his second 
successful company. To his mom, he's just Dave Shayman, your friendly 
neighborhood white Jewish kid. No matter who you ask, it's apparent that 
21-year old DJ, producer, and international Ghettotech sex symbol Disco D 
has made quite the impact.

*Recent Music Production:
Booty Bar Anthem - Click here to listen

Suporting tallent:
back again N.A.W, (Not Average Whiteboys) & Sarah Delush

*Free Happy Hour 8pm-10pm:
You go around telling everyone you listen to all different kinds of music. 
BULLSHIT. But don't worry, cuz TEAM HOE is here to edumacate your ass like 
whoa. Playing happy hour exclusively for Compression on June 8th, djs ho-lia 
and pab-ho are down to drop everything from the big hair sound of the 80's 
to the shaggy-mullet sounds of today. So come early to get your swerve 
on...but stay later for the hoes.

111 Minna St. Gallery
Show 9:00 PM - 2:00 AM
Tickets $15 door/ advanced tix Available here.

Message-ID: <002e01c32c68$dd6d61e0$6401a8c0@cronos>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="----=_NextPart_000_002F_01C32C2E.310E89E0"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Looking for talented Electronic DJ's in the Bay Area

------=_NextPart_000_002F_01C32C2E.310E89E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

There is going to be a new web site that has never been done before.  It
will cater to the underground electronic DJ scene in the Bay Area, with
styles of music ranging from House, Trance, NRG, Hard Trance, Hard
House, Jungle, DnB, Ambient, Acid Jazz, Turntablism, etc. (I think you
get the point).  Interested?  Keep reading...
 
Does this fit your description?  An electronic DJ or composer that is
too talented for their own good, but doesn't know how to get themselves
known...
 
...This is where we come in.  
 
If you think you got some killer dj mixes or some tracks you put
together yourself, then we are looking (more specifically, listening)
for you.  We're looking for 25-50 talented DJ's and composers to get the
site launched with fresh, off-the-hook slammin' music.  We're looking
for 160kbps - 192kbps mp3's of your mixes or tracks.  If we like what we
hear, then we'll give you a free 6-month membership to our site.  More
details will be explained once we make contact with you.
 
We are just like you - we are doing this for the music, and for the
electronic community.  This site will cater to the electronic DJ's in
every aspect imaginable.
 
If you are interested, please email djunderground@wctech.net with a link
to where we can listen to your music.  Remember, it can be either a
complete mix, or just a track you created.  If you don't have a link to
your music, still send an email.  If you have to send it to us on a CD
in the mail, so be it.  Whatever it takes for us to hear your music.  If
you're dedicated enough, you'll get it to us.
 
Did I mention this site will be viewed on a daily basis by record labels
and music producers?
 
More information will follow once we do get in contact with you.  Due to
the site being 2-3 weeks away from completion, we can't say much without
some sort of confidentiality.  So shoot us an email to
djunderground@wctech.net so we can start talking.
 
If you're serious about DJ'ing, send us an email.  If you're not, don't
bother.

------=_NextPart_000_002F_01C32C2E.310E89E0--
