[image noborder]http://www.shaolinproductions.net/images/high_octane_banner.jpg[/image]
From the Creators of Power Puff Girls 1 and 2, Enter the Dragon 1-3 and countless other record breaking events.

Shaolin Presents.Our BIGGEST party ever!
June 13, 2003
HIGH OCTANE <~~mini-MASSIVE
============================

LOCK N LOAD
The Lock N' Load project consists of two Dutch producers / DJs: Frank van Rooijen and Niels Pijpers.  One fine day the Club Caviar boys came to visit the Lock N' Load studio, heard the old version of a song and offered to do a remix of it.  In collaboration with Lock N' Load they delivered this stunning result and Niels decided to release "Blow Ya Mind".  After all on Blue White Records, within a period of three weeks, it became the No. 1 club record in the Netherlands, and Europe followed soon after that, the United Kingdom was ready to be conquered.  Through no. 1 positions in both the UK Club and UK Dance chart it had an amazing entry at 6.  Help us welcome Lock N' Load to Sacramento.
 
Chris C.
Now firmly established as one of the Biggest and most popular DJ / Producers on the UK Hard House/NRG scene,  Chris has masterminded the emergence and rapid success of his 3 Labels, Mohawk, Aztec and Nile.  Positioning the former today as one of the genres top 5 marques.  With over 30 single releases and 2 Albums to his name on various labels including Tidy Trax, Tinrib, Eve, Honeypot, Phoenix Rising, GBT, Bulletproof, etc...Chris' reputation as one of Britain's finest exponent of Hard House, both behind the decks and in the studio, continues to grow.
 
Whistler
Victor Cape a.k.a. Whistler shines as a highly respected DJ on the Pacific Northwest dance scene.  Known for his tight mixing skills and uplifting personality behind the decks, Whistler blends energy and emotion from Hard Melodic Trance, Epic Anthems and Hard House to take his listeners on a dance floor rollercoaster ride.  If being a DJ wasn't enough, he also manages Lovetribe which has quickly become one of the most well respected event productions in Seattle.  It's been over a year and a half since Whistler's last performance in Northern California.  So we're excited to bring him out for his first Sacramento performance!
 
Dyloot
Arguably  Nor-Cals BIGGEST Trance DJ/Producer watch him work his MAGIC over the crowd.

Tom Slik Vs. Tracer
Two of Nor-Cals Biggest Trance DJs wage war for the first time in Sacramento.
 
Denise Vs.  Paul the Fanman
First ever Teacher vs. Student battle between the establish Denise and the BIG up n comer Paul.  Lets see if he learned some tricks on his own.
 
Dragnfly Vs. Scepter
Shaolins two BIGGEST DJs go head to head to see who really is the SHAOLIN MASTER.
 
Bazooka Joe Vs. Reckless Ryan
Showmanship is the only way to describe the performance these two put on.  Turntablist House at its best.  Watch as these two leave you in a wicky-wick-AWWW!
 
Valerie Sparks vs. The Doctor
Nor Cals Best Hardcore Female DJ goes against this up n coming Junglist.
 
Sascha 23 Vs. Gauge
The founder of Xtort bumps heads with one of Shaolins Most talented Producer in a must see set with original Shaolin tracks.
 
IMPORTANT!!!

Subject: dreamers of dreams (nrr)

"I quote others only the better to express myself."
--Michel de Montaigne

"Die knowing something.  You are not here long."
--Walker Evans

"Knowledge has three degrees - opinion, science,
illumination.  The means or instrument of the first is
sense; of the second, dialectic; of the third,
intuition."
--Plotinus

"Look within.  Within is the fountain of good, and it
will ever bubble up, if thou wilt ever dig."
--Marcus Aurelius

"You can't depend on your judgment when your
imagination is out of focus."
--Mark Twain

"It is only when we realize that life is taking us
nowhere that it begins to have meaning."
--PD Ouspensky

"Only those who will risk going too far can possibly
find out how far one can go."
--TS Eliot

"Life is either a daring adventure or it is nothing."
--Helen Keller

"Is not life a thousand times too short for us to bore
ourselves?"
--Friedrich Nietzsche

"always the beautiful answer who asks a more beautiful
question."
--ee cummings

"Everywhere I go I find a poet has been there before
me."
--Sigmund Freud

"If you ask me what I came to do in this world, I, an
artist, I will answer you: 'I am here to live out
loud.'"
--Emile Zola

"Beware of artists - they mix with all classes of
society and are therefore most dangerous"
--Queen Victoria

"We are the music makers
and we are the dreamers of dreams"
--Arthur O'Shaughnessy

----
have a good weekend, y'all.

peace & love,
sooz

Your Underground Movement and Flawless USAinvites you to: 

Peanut Butta Jelly Time! 

Friday, June 20th, 2003 

UFO SYSTEMS  (EARTH ISLAND RECORDINGS, GSPENTERTAINMENT.COM, FL) UFO SYSTEMS (aka David White) has been enlightening crowds with his Euro/Progressive sound for six years now. You can find him blowing up dance floors across the world, capturing the masses with his hypnotic rifts and melodic rhythms. His DJ sets are intended to be a vivid journey through his musical world, which separates him from the rest. David's sets have left crowds speechless and on their feet! Make sure not to miss his sensational performance and come see why people compare him to Paul Van Dyke and Christopher Lawrence! 

DJ KUE (TECHNO MISSIONARIES, MISDIRECTION - TX) DJ Kue, hailing from Texas, is the next rising star in the house scene. Inspired by Richard Humpty Vission and Bad Boy Bill, he displays an arsenal of various scratches, juggles, and other turntablist tricks. Do not miss his first San Francisco showcase and see why he is one of fastest rising DJs in the house scene today. 

THE FUNKIST AKA DJ FLAVE (USCEVENTS.COM, AND ZION'S GATE RECORDS - SEATTLE, WA) After searching the globe we are excited to bring you one of the most talented, cutting edge DJs we have ever seen. The next level of DJs is here! Dj Flave not only scratches with his foot but also has an arsenal of new dj tricks to blow your mind. All the way from Seattle, come see why his last bay area party sold out! The best way to describe his style is having the interactive energy of Donald Glaude, the technical skills of DJ Dan and a personality all his own. 

AREA 1 - Funky Chunky Peanut Butta House Room Hosted by Nerd Nate . 

JOEY MAZZOLA (Solmatic, joeymazzola.com) RON REESER (djronreeser.com/solmatic/sf) -cd release- JAMES DUB (Space Monkey, SF) VAL SPARKS  (www.valeriesparks.com) THE DOCTOR (DECIBLAST, BR) DJORIONZ ( www.nlpro.net/orionz ) ZELDA (Absolutely Flawless, YUM) 

AREA 2 - GOT MILK ROOM Sponsored By BASSLINE FM Hosted by Geno Giovanni and Taminator.

RECKLESS RYAN  (www.recklessryan.com, basslineFM - 90.5 KSJS, Zero Magazine) BAZOOKA JOE (www.djbazookajoe.com, Straight Hits) FREQUENCY - (WWW.DJFREQUENCY.COM) MATT FROST cd release- (WWW.GLOBALFUNKRECORDINGS.COM) JACK LACORTE VS ABSOLUTE ALEX (http://jack.yakshead.com, YUM vs. Fresh Ent, YUM, STAND OUT) PETER BLADES  (YUM) BILLY SOUL  (HIT FACTORY) 

AREA 3 - Jam N Jelly Room SPONSORED BY HIT FACTORY HOSTED BY D BOX (WILD 94.9) 

DENISE - (DJDENISE.COM) FELIPE AVELAR (DJFELIPEAVELAR.COM, ELEVATE, HIT FACTORY) DJ HOPE - (HOUSE NATION, AFTERHOURS ON 102.5) JAXX THE RIPPER - (ULTRA SOUNZ, CTB, DJAJAX.COM) JASEN CHAVEZ - (CLOCKWORK, ELEVATE) DANNY BOY - (HIT FACTORY, FUNKYFRESHMUSIK.COM) CARLOS ALFONSO - (BAYRAVES, DECIBLAST.ORG) AKIL TAYLOR (HIT FACTORY, DA FUNK) 

ARENA 4 - NO TIME FOR COTTON MOUTH ARENA SPONSORED BY REMIX AND DYSFUNKTION 

DJ LIQUID (REMIX/ JOURNEES.COM/ DUBCOAST - SAN FRANCISCO) MADAME MERCURY - (MAD WAX, STREET BEAT, REMIX) MATT THOMAS (REMIX) LUCKY MACROPOLIS (REMIX) DJ FOXX (REMIX) TEK THREAT (REMIX) BRYAN DELEON (REMIX) STEVE K (REMIX) 

Arena 5 - Best Thing Since Sliced Bread Sponsored By Synesthesia, Earth Island Records and Global Sound Philosophy. 

SOMA KINETIC (SYNESTHESIA, BURN BROTHERS) THEZPROJECT (SYNESTHESIA, CURE, GSP, GANJA JEDIS) SPECTIVE (ZERO MAGAZINE/SPECTIVEDANCEDOTCOM) RYAN THOMAS (A10, SYNESTHESIA) DJ CROIX (SYNESTHESIA) TREBURNE (SYNESTHESIA, PURE DIGITAL SPACE) 

24 hour Info line: 1-877-410-1425 All Responsible Ages Welcome. Fully Stocked Bar for the 21+. 5 Room air-conditioned venue with plenty of dancing space, well lit parking and friendly security. Awesome sound and visuals. Tons of free give a ways all night long! Arrive early, Doors open @ 8pm sharp! Presale Tickets will be at:

BUY YOUR PRESALES NOW!!! 

·          Become a VIP and receive VIP treatment... Free Drinks and special giveaways in our VIP lounge. Not too mention; a chance to chill with your favorite djs, shorter lines and Free Food, including Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwiches (bananas optional). VIP tickets are $35

Electric Daisy Carnival 2003 
By: Insomniac Events
Saturday, June 28th, 2003
Presale: $25.00


Talent: 5 STAGES BLOOMING WITH ONLY THE FRESHEST OF BEATS!

 - stage one - THE MERRY GO ROUND (Progressive/Trance/Techno/House & Breaks):

 DJ Dan, Christopher Lawrence, Sandra Collins, Micro, Donald Glaude, Simply Jeff, Mars, Thee-o

---------------------------------------------------------

 - stage two - THE FUN HOUSE (House):

 Miguel Migs, Gene Farris, Garth, Greens Keepers, Jason Bentley, DJ Lillyanne, Trent Cantrelle, DJ Lush

---------------------------------------------------------

 - stage three - THE BASSRUSH ARENA (Drum & Bass):

 The Virus Tour featuring... Ed Rush, Optical, MC Rymtyme, Planet Of The Drumz Tour featuring... Dieselboy, Dara, AK1200, MC J Messinian. Along side DJ's... Mampi Swift, DJ Rap, MC Armanni, DJ Tao, Origin

---------------------------------------------------------

- stage four - THE CONFUSIN' & AMUSIN' MIRROR MAZE (Hip Hop/Turntabilzm):

 Z-Trip, Supernatural, Aceyalone, Planet Asia, Abstract Rude, Klever, Relm, Streak, Art of Wax

---------------------------------------------------------

- stage five - CLOWN ALLEY (a variety of music styles):

 Omar Santana + many more!

 

-->Info: 10 HOURS OF NON-STOP FREAKS, FUN & FESTIVITEEZ! This year the Insomniac family brings you an Electric Daisy Carnival that is sure to please. The festival grounds provide plenty of room to spread out and enjoy five musical areas, a vendor village, carnival attractions, and the many talented performers that will be strolling about. Expect fat beats, cotton candy, and full-size carnival rides, combined with Insomniac's attention to detail and love for creating a positive atmosphere. Join us in celebration of summer as we once again flip the script and come with an event that bumps both day and night. This year's Daisy kicks off at 4 p.m. and rocks it well into the moonlight. Show up early to enjoy the sun and stay late to groove under the stars. Electric Daisy Carnival 2003 will be an aural and visual delight. So don't sleep, come down and share in the vibe! - 

CARNIVAL ATTRACTIONS - FORCE TEN, THE ORBITER, CLIFF HANGER, THE YO-YO, THE TORNADO & THE GIANT SUPER SLIDE! All rides are freakin' free, day & night for your family's daisy dee-light! DREAM CIRCUS is coming to tantalize your spirits at this years event with musical acts and performances. ALL AGES - FULL BARS FOR 21+. 

- THE LOCATION - The National Orange Show is a safe, secure location centrally located in Southern California. Insomniac will transform the spacious indoor/outdoor festival grounds into a delightfully unique carnival atmosphere where you'll be free to roam about five musical areas. Take some time to relax on the grass and, later, take a stroll by the lagoon under the starlit sky. 

ELECTRIC DAISY CARNIVAL IS A DRUG FREE LOVE FILLED ENVIRONMENT. For more info check out the EDC web site at: www.electricdaisycarnival.com

we've re-scheduled him for next month on July 7. Special thanks to the 
fabulous furry Leath Brothers for last weeks techno ho showdown.. We had a 
blast! Tonight we welcome DJ SCIENCE with a special old skool house and 
breaks set.. come on down and enjoy!

Eternal E

 


 


Yo Ren, you're ready to go get this move? 
Believe that, boy 
You're strapped ? 
Yeah, you know it 
Let's go do this, man, I got it all planned out 
Yeah, shoot any motherfucker that moves 

Verse 1: 
This is a stick-up, everybody get face down 
Ren, gag their mouths so they can't make a sound 
Tie'em up for the fact that I'm kickin' ass 
I got my hand on my gat, and I'm tempted to blast 
My name is Eazy, but I go the hard way out 
This ain't personal, but now I'm about 
to commit a crime and go thru with it 
You know what, no need for shakin' because I'm used to it 
Take out the security guard with a slap of my hand 
Yeah, he's wearin' a badge, but he's a ole ass man 
Pump his ass in the head, and take his gun 
so me and the punk can go one on one 
Cover the lens on the TV screen 
you know, so me and my gang just can't be seen 
Lock the doors, and throw away the key 
Close the blinds, so no motherfuckers can see 
and smile, you know, cause I'm controllin' the shit 
and no sucker ass nigga's gonna stop the hit 
Wardrobes and loads, and a ruthless shirt 
That means I'm ready to work, and bum rush a fool to the dirt 
So... 

Chorus: 
Nobody moves, nobody gets hurt (4x) 

Allright, anybody move and I'll blow your fuckin' head off 

Verse 2: 
Allright... 
Empty your pockets, but do it slow 
Take everything you got and lay it on the fuckin' floor 
Don't make me have to set an example today 
and blow one of you crazy motherfuckers away 
I'm in a bank, and it's a little bit funny 
takin' all you stupid motherfuckers' money 
Peepin' at a bitch cause my dick's on hard 
Laughin' at the dumb ass security guard 
who's tied up for the moment, not sayin' a word 
I should have known it before, the motherfucker's a nerd 
But back to the bitches I'm peepin' 
and then untie the ho, so I can start (?briefin') 
Took her to the backroom, about to jack 
Cold trailed the bitch, with a gun in the back 
I said: "Lay down, and unbutton your bra!" 
There was the biggest titties that a nigga ever saw 
I said, "Damn", then the air got thinner 
Only thought in my mind, was goin' up in her 
The suspense was makin' me sick 
She took her panties down and the bitch had a dick! 
I said, "Damn", dropped the gat from my hand 
What I thought was a bitch, was nothing but a man 
Put the gat to his legs, all the way up his skirt 
because this is one faggot that I had to hurt 
So... 

Chorus: 

I said get down. I want you all face-down on the floor 
Anybody moves and I shoot 

Verse 3: 
Stackin' up the money and there's more to collect 
cause I don't give a fuck, I take traveler's checks 
Yo, Ren, peep out the window, and tell me what you see 
[MC Ren: Three motherfuckin' police starin' at me 
What to do now ?] 
Hurry up and get on 
Allright, tell me, who is the motherfuckin' alarm ? 
I'm a give ya a chance, and count to three 
or else five o' ya bitches are comin' with me 
[Police: Allright, Allright, come out niggaz, or we're coming in 
This is the only chance to turn yourself in] 
Fuck you! We got hostages, and plenty of loot 
and don't give a damn and not afraid to shoot 
We're sendin' out the hostages, all except five 
and if you don't meet our demands, they won't stay alive 
We want a 'copter, so we can get away clean 
and take some pussy along, if you know what I mean 
One hostage got brave, and got off the floor 
but I smoked his ass before he got to the door 
[Police: They shot a hostage, they shot a hostage!] 
[MC Ren: You stupid motherfucker tryin' to run 
now you're dead as fuck tryin' to race a gun] 
[Police: Allright, this is the last chance to get off your ass 
or else the tear gas is about to blast] 
I ran to the back and Ren followed behind 
to a hell of a spot that was hard to find 
The bank was fucked up, the shit was smokin' 
with screamin' hostages, runnin' and chokin' 
Gettin' away, but I was suddenly stopped 
at point blank range, by a motherfuckin' cop 
And I hope they don't think that a lesson was taught 
cause a nigga like the E was finally caught 
My gat wouldn't fire, the shit wouldn't work 
So...Y'all know what time it is... 

Chorus: 

Police: Well I'm giving you five seconds to let us thru the gate or 
I'm gonna shoot two of your guards

 

 

Jason Philips

Compos-Mentis

Problematic Beats

Subject: SRR: forwarded from a friend of burning man (fwd)

FYI

**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

<Begin Forward>

Burning Man needs a bit of help, and it needs it
fast, so please read on. As you may or may not have heard, the Washoe County
Board of Commissioners have refused Burning Man a permit to use property
they own near Gerlach, from which the event is staged. This staging area is
the ranch from which all operations are run, and where all the gear is
stored. Apparently, if they can't use this land, it will make it nearly
impossible to organize the event.
BM has requested that as many people as possible show up at the county
meeting on June 10th in Reno to voice their opinions, and that those who
can't make it write letters to the Reno Gazette voicing their displeasure. I
figure that a petition wouldn't hurt either, so here's the plan:
We need to get at least 5000 signatures in the next 4 days, so we really
need to move on this. Please go to the petition site at the link below
immediately, sign it, and forward this email to as many sympathetic people
as possible. It would probably work best to simply copy and paste this msg
into a new email rather then forward so as to avoid getting the text all
screwed up, as often happens in forwards.
I'll be informing the BM organizers of the petition in hope that they also
spread the word, and so that they can bring a printout to the meeting.
Again... sorry for the spam, but I figured that this is worth it. The petition
is can be signed here:
http://www.petitiononline.com/burn42/petition.html

been a trippy time up 2 now (I'm still here 'til like 8 something 2night).

years ago) & man... it was a totally mondo happy occasion, but man, it was 
soooo sad!!  Alota friends from the Bay Area were there @ the wedding also & 
they're all like moving away from the Bay =(  Oh yeah... it's like also a 
sad thing, well, not sad, but well.... I have 2 learn 2 watch my language 
when I'm in front of a Church & I see an old friend!!  What happen was I saw 
my Friend James who've I've known 4  like the passed 6-7 years & he's dating 
my friend Katie who was Mel's maid of honor.... So like a soo as I saw

Atomic & Brian pick me up from the Reception & tell me that we're goin 2 an 
outdoor underground that they got the info 4!!!  I mean like... I kinda knew 
about this party like a month ago 'cause Justin Hela told me about it 'cause 
he was like on the line up & then well... la la la la la....We made the 
loooooooooooong journey to get 2 the spot....... oooooooooooooh My goodness.

The outdoor space is this camping ground that was filled w/ like well... 
there were tents that  there.... mondo cars, & all these Awesome people were 
there =)  It was nice!!  I was like walkin around meeting people there then 
Justin Hale & I like totally bump in2 each other!!!  Weeeeeee.... then he 
brings me 2 like the rest of the Bay Area posse that was there..... Zack, 
Scott, Beth, Nicole, & Libby were like all there!!!  Oh My Gosh man.... it 
was soooooo Dope!!  So I totally had 2 find my Socal crew & intro them!!!  
"'Cause like it was Me, Atomic, Maggy, Crash, & Brian!!  Brian's a Baby 
Raver... so we're like bringing him out more =)   It was neat 'cause it was 
like havin' my 2 worlds come 2gether =)  YAY!!

The DJ who was spinning when we got there was well,.,... HOuse.... this was 
an all HOuse event=)  OK... I dunno... but man... when Justin went on... 
Ooooooh My Goodness,,,,,, Hello 2Day.... his set was sooooooooooo fuckin' 
Dope!!!  I mean.... He totally went everywhere w/ his set from like Chucago 
stylee kinda house to Disco to tek to a few progrssive tracks if I recall 
correctly, & yeah... it was Fuckin' Awesome man =)  Was was really CooL was 
when he played the Green Velvet "La La Land" track 'caise it  was like he 
was sayin' thank U 2 the LA kids & the Jam On It crew 4 letting him spin 
down here!!! LoL

The next 2 DJs after him spun like well... the DJ after him like totally 
cleared the floor when he was spinning like I dunno... this minimal like 
house stuff I guess... I dunno.... but he started playing like Disco HOuse & 
totally got the floor packed again =)

The last Dj totally spun this Tak HOuse set!!!

But man.... it was soooo neat =)  This was the 1st undground 4 a few of the 
people I went w/ & they Love it!!!   I mean... the vibe was Groovy & people 
were so nice!!!  I was kinda bummed @ 1st 'cause of the $5 enterance fee 
thingie we paid 2 get in & Hello 2Day... it was 4 an outdoor & I dunno.... 
but later I found out that proceeds from the party were going 2 a:"Save the 
forest" foundation & well.... I met the crew 4 the party & they didn't seem 
like shadey people & really pure in their intentions!!!

It was jus' a Totally Groovy night!!!  I Loved it!!!  Wow man... I'm still 
after glowin' from this party =)

OK... will C U when I get back 2 the bay!!!  Hope every1 had a Groovy 
weekend!!!! =)

Oh... when my homeboy crash puts up the pictures he took from the party on 
his site.... I'lll post the lonk on here! =)

From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: Good records for learning to DJ???

So, a friend of mine just graduated med school, and is moving (hit the road
today) to the east coast to begin his residency.  In the process of cleaning
out his stuff and deciding what NOT to take east with him, he gave me an old
pair of his turntables, and an old mixer.

They're just belt-drive Numarks and a VERY basic mixer.  But I'm not one to
look a gift horse in the mouth.  And this finally gives me the chance to see if
I can develop any kind of skills without dropping >$1,500 (which I don't have)
on 1200s and a high-end mixer.

So I was wondering if anyone could recommend a few (3 or 4) records that would
be good for a total beginner (I've read a few DJ howto's, and understand the
principles of what you're SUPPOSED to do, I have just never had the opportunity
to try before) to start learning basic techniques on.

Cheapness, availability, and good learning techniques are my priority here.  I
don't want to be asking Skills or F8 to special-order anything expensive or
hard to get here, and since I'll be LEARNING on these, I don't want to to be a
big deal if said records get beat to shit in the process (IOW, no
collectibles).  Since I'm more concerned about being able to LEARN with these,
than them being my favorite music, genre doesn't matter that much.  I would,
though, like it to be an enjoyable experience, so I AM looking for something
faster than plain old house, and not as obnoxious as jungle...  perhaps
something in the hard house or NRG or hard trance or acid techno areas.

Any recommendations?

Oh, and I'll also need a pair of cheap, but useable, headphones.  Again, I'm
definately not looking for anything top-flight.  Just useable, and hopefully
useful for just LISTENING to music if I do turn out to be 100% useless behind
the decks.

Any help there too?

Thanks a bunch!


cya,
john

  by taz3.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 9 Jun 2003 22:48:46 -0000
Message-ID: <20030609224843.52030.qmail@web12307.mail.yahoo.com>
Received: from [207.33.100.198] by web12307.mail.yahoo.com via HTTP; Mon, 09 Jun 2003 15:48:43 PDT
Date: Mon, 9 Jun 2003 15:48:43 -0700 (PDT)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Missed opportunities...

So yesterday I was cleaning out a bunch of my crap, and happened across a big
stack of flyers from a couple of years ago.  Me being the obnoxiously organized
QA engineer at the time, they were sorted by date, and how bad I wanted to go
to each.  I had even included (and sorted) printouts of emails and BSPs about
parties I didn't HAVE flyers for.

Two stuck in my head:  Dave's first Herbonium, and Sarah and David Diez (well,
Sarah was still Backes, at the time) party: Phonosynthesis.  Both were on 4/20
of that year.  I remember these because I WANTED to go to both, and was having
a hellacious time deciding which to attend.  I wound up putting said decision
off (and buying a tixket for either) so long, that I was eventually COMMANDED
to attend a 4/20 party being but on by one of my dotcommer friends.

Now, I don't regret going to the dotcom party.  It was a night of excess and
debauchery and a good time was had by all.  But it's weird to think of all the
people I'm good friends with NOW, but I didn't know at the time.  If I had gone
to either Herbonium or Phonosynthesis, I would have met some of these a good
three or six months, or even a whole YEAR before I eventually did!

It's strange how things work out like that...  Sometimes when comparing old
parties with your friends you even find out that you were at a LOT of the same
parties, without EVER meeting each other, until much later.  It's a shame. 
There are a lot of people I know now that I REALLY wish I had met a lot earlier
than I did.


cya,
john

Do you Yahoo!?

http://calendar.yahoo.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Good records for learning to DJ???

that is a tuff question, if i were you i would just head down to AMOEBA and
dig thru the bargain bins...look for 2 copies of something, just dont spend
too much, take them home and have at it! you can also look for Twitch or
Ultamix records, they have the bpms right on them plus what key they are in,
but they will cost you more money, usually $20 but they come in a double
pack which means you can start mixing right away. you should have no problem
finding records to play, and there are plenty of ppl in the bay who will
help you out with the basics.

AUDiOTACTiX

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Simon Gatrall <gatrall@pacbell.net>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Good records for learning to DJ???

Picking up some used records at Amoeba is not a bad idea.  And 
getting some Twitch or Ultimix or whatever "DJ-only" comps is also a 
good idea.  One thing I would recommend against is buying any 
breakbeat, jungle, 2-step, etc.  To start with you want to find stuff 
that is really simple percussion-wise with a very steady 4/4 beat. 
House with a lot of shuffle and funky syncopated hi-hat patterns can 
also throw you off.  I learned with New Order's "Blue Monday" and 
"Perfect Kiss" which are both about the same BPM and they're both 
fairly dj-friendly.  Don't try to mix stuff that is really far apart 
BPM-wise or style-wise, at least not while you're learning.  Also 
keep in mind that the belt-drive tables will work for basic 
beat-matching, but don't drive yourself crazy trying to learn 
turntablist tricks with them.
-- 
Simon Gatrall
gatrall@pacbell.net

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [nrr] bad english?

Samples of "Conjunctions"

From: http://www.getitwriteonline.com/archive/032601.htm

"...The word "but" [and "so"] is one of the seven coordinating
conjunctions:

and
but
or
nor
for
so
yet

Coordinating conjunctions are used to join words, phrases, and clauses
that are balanced as logical equals:

Mary AND I went to the meeting. [joins two subjects]

We were tired YET exhilarated by the end of our first day hiking up Mt.
Everest. [joins two adjectives]

We swam all morning BUT fished in the afternoon. [joins two verbs]

Often these conjunctions are used to coordinate two independent clauses
(groups of words that can stand alone as sentences). Here are two
examples, with the independent clauses in brackets:

[We started to go home], but [we had run out of gas].

[She was a good leader], for [she could delegate well].

--------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Most likely, many people believe they should not start a sentence with a
coordinating conjunction because their grammar teachers in grade school
discouraged them from doing so. Yet such a rule is completely
unjustifiable. When grammar teachers teach youngsters the essentials of
sentence structure, they most likely explain that coordinating
conjunctions are used to hold together elements within a sentence.
Therefore, they may discourage students from starting sentences with
coordinating conjunctions because they are trying not only to explain
conjunctions but also to help their students learn to avoid sentence
fragments like this one:
--------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------

She was a nice girl. And smart, too.

In this example, using "and" after the period is wrong because the second
"sentence" is not really a sentence at all: it has neither a subject nor a
verb.

Thus, youngsters carry forward into adulthood the notion that a sentence
should never begin with a coordinating conjunction, especially not with
"and" or "but." In fact, however, professional writers have started
sentences with coordinating conjunctions throughout history.

Starting virtually every sentence with a conjunction would, of course,
make your writing thoroughly monotonous. And one would probably not want
to use such a construction in very formal contexts. For every coordinating
conjunction, there is a conjunctive adverb (however, nevertheless,
moreover, furthermore, etc.) that holds the same meaning but represents a
somewhat higher level of diction..."
--------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------

In the case of formal diction, cutting down on the number of "So"s in your
sentence helps. In the case of email, which is usually less than formal,
it is not always necessary to be bound to traditional diction and grammar
rules (see above).

Regards,
K

**************************************************************
******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
**************************************************************

Date: Tue, 10 Jun 2003 03:51:00 -0700
From: Radley Marx <rmarx@sbcglobal.net>
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <BB0B0624.17DB2%rmarx@sbcglobal.net>
In-Reply-To: <20030609223529.29812.qmail@web12303.mail.yahoo.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Good records for learning to DJ???

on 6/9/03 3:35 PM, John B. at svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com wrote:
>=20
> So I was wondering if anyone could recommend a few (3 or 4) records that =
would
> be good for a total beginner (I've read a few DJ howto's, and understand =
the
> principles of what you're SUPPOSED to do, I have just never had the
> opportunity
> to try before) to start learning basic techniques on.

> Any recommendations?

At this point I'll make a couple of beginner suggestions.

First - to learn to beatmix, talk to a friend who's a DJ and ask them to
help you out. It's easy.

2nd - as a total beginner,the best way to learn how to "drop a beat" and
"match beats" is to buy two copies of the exact same record. It can be
anything you want, but make sure that the record starts with a kickdrum. No
syth buildups, just a "thump" right at the beginning. The simpler the
better. Make sure there's no weird changes too early. Have two copies of
this and work back and forth with them.

As for building a library, you're best off buying "compilations" to get
yourself a collection without breaking your bank. These may seem to be more
expensive ($20-30 each) but they have lots of songs and give you a lot to
play with.

Finally, I'd suggest you learn the BPM (beats per minute) of your favorite
songs. You can get a beat-count tapper for your PC (record plays, you tap o=
n
the beat for 30 seconds, it tells your BPM.) Then, write down the BPM of
your record on a piece of masking tape and stick it to the inside edge of
your record sleeve. Why? You'll find it's easier to mix songs that are
closer in BPM.



That's it. You experience will be fun initially, but Numarks are very
frustrating. Simply not the same experience, but a good rough intro.



-radley




o--- Radley Marx - Head of Operations
o--- Electronica-Optica / VJTV
o--- 1311 Curtis St
o--- Berkeley California 94702
o--- USA

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ooooo ooo oo yeah (nrr?)

As soon as the dvd was on the net a few weeks back I made sure to track it
down and watch it over and over again. The 4 segments that were on the
Animatrix website were NOT enough! I think it's number 6 that I like the
most because of it's whimsical nature. It's the one with the girl that has a
star on her face and is looking for her cat. Very dreamy. Second Renaissance
I+II, come in second because they show you the history of the Matrix and
it's formation. Flight of Osirus is somewhat critical to the background of
the current Reloaded movie and if you didn't see that prior to watching
Reloaded you're missing a chunk of story. Detective Story with animation
done by the Cowboy Bebop people is a style/segment I would love to see more
of. *GREAT* soundtrack. I will be buying both the movie and the
soundtrack(which wasn't in tower this weekend - wtf??). Meat Beat Manifesto,
Layo and Bushwacka, Juno Reactor, and more.

I can't tell you just how much better the Animatrix is compared to the
theatrical release of Reloaded. Reloaded is a crying mess that used too much
soy filler in the form of action segments while the Animatrix is pure meat.
It's the best <$20 you can spend on a movie right now.

:: r y a n ::

X-Authenticated-Sender: Z3JlZ3ZwQGF0dGJpLmNvbQ==
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: SS last night: review

Secret Society, the weekly party held in Santa Clara, really got me moving last
night. The fun depends on your concept of a good time, because people kept
saying its really dead tonight.

Nevertheless, I believe that whenever two or three people gather together with
good music, there can be a spirit of happiness. I know that I was dancing hard
and smiling big from the vibes thrown down by Science and Justin Hale.

I forgot how much fun house music could be when handled by experienced DJs. You
guys really missed some great sets. Later, Science told me that he personally
selected old school tracks from 1993-1994 as his criteria for the night, and it
was great music.

In addition, Justin was just getting me going with too many tracks to name here.
Overall, it was a good night. I think many people chose drum & bass for their
evening, elsewhere in San Jose (KillaSubz), but if you want a good time with
room to dance in a nice setting, be sure to visit the Secret Society weekly
party (generally held every Monday night). The visuals are also great,
especially since Terry E. from SFRaves does them (Viberation). If there is no
one to dance with, you can just watch the video monitors while moving your body,
and forget about the outside world.

Disclaimer: I am not affiliated with the crew. I just like to dance.

Greg VP

Subject: ATP: NRR: A little Tale of Integrity

------=_NextPart_000_0046_01C32F50.2E629E50
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

As some of you may, or may not be aware, I solicited the opinion of =
fellow SF Rave'ers to gather data on the Shure Whitelabel series of =
needles...I received an overwhelming positive response that, yes, these =
were damn fine needles. So, I bought a set.

After about 3 hours of play on one of the needles, and a very good =
initial experience in not only the new design but the overall boost in =
sound quality, all of a sudden it wouldn't grab the groove of the vinyl =
and was literally sliding across the whole record...not a very good =
impression, especially since I had already sold my Nightclubs'...

So I emailed a fellow from shure on the www.needlz.com website. He told =
me to ship the entire unit to him, he would take a look at it and get =
back to me. So I sent him the whole unit, and let him know that without =
needles I can't play, so please be quick about it. As soon as he =
received the tracking number, not the actual shipment, he "FedEx =
Priority Overnight" shipped me a whole new unit and extra stylus, for my =
troubles he said. I received a replacement in less than 10 hours.=20

I am writing to share this because I am completely flattered in the =
attention I received from the shure corporation and the integrity they =
showed in standing behind their product...It turned out nothing was =
wrong with the needle...I had it adjusted the wrong way at 49 mm, not =
the recommended 52 mm, and the wires were hitting the record. Regardless =
of my "stupidity" in not noticing this, I often find that there are =
those in this industry that are scammers, liars, purveyors of false =
promises, and overall real shitheads when it comes to getting product =
support. I believe shure stands apart from these characters and they now =
have a customer for life. [applause]
--
DJ Jack Triumph

"I saw an Angel in the Marble,=20
and carved until I set him free"

Subject: SRR:  DEA Uses RAVE Act to Stop a Benefit to Raise Money for
  Marijuana Reform

--=====================_12703430==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

** DEA Uses RAVE Act to Stop a Benefit to Raise Money for Marijuana Reform


**Fax the DEA and Tell Acting Administrator William Simpkins to Stop Using 
the RAVE Act Against Political Events 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2008


Only two months after the RAVE Act was passed by Congress it has been used 
by the federal Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) to intimidate the 
owners of a Billings, Montana, venue into canceling a combined benefit for 
the Montana chapter of the National Organization for the Reform of 
Marijuana Laws (NORML) and Students for Sensible Drug Policy (SSDP). One of 
the biggest reasons the Drug Policy Alliance waged a national campaign to 
stop the RAVE Act was that we feared it would be used to shut down 
political events like this.


On the day the fundraiser was set to take place a Billings-based DEA agent 
presented the venue owners with a copy of the RAVE Act warning them that 
they could face a fine of $250,000 if illicit drugs were found in the 
premises. The bands - most of which regularly played at the venue - were 
also approached and warned that their participation in the event could 
result in a fine.


Rather than risk the possibility of enormous fines, the venue decided to 
cancel the event. This blatant intimidation by the DEA was obviously 
designed to shut down the marijuana reform fundraiser. Unless the American 
people speak out against this attack on free speech, the DEA will be 
emboldened to use the law against other events they do not like, such as 
all-night dance parties, hip hop concerts, hemp festivals, and circuit parties.


Join the Drug Policy Alliance, National Organization for the Reform of 
Marijuana Laws, Students for Sensible Drug Policy, and numerous other 
organizations in our campaign to pressure the DEA to stop using the RAVE 
Act to shut down political events.


ACTIONS TO TAKE


1) Fax the DEA. Urge Acting Administrator William Simpkins to stop using 
the RAVE Act to harass innocent business owners and stifle free speech.
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2008


2) Forward this alert to friends and family. Send it to e-mail lists and 
post it in chat rooms.

BACKGROUND


Sponsored by Senator Biden (D-DE), the RAVE Act (also known as the Illicit 
Drug Anti-Proliferation Act) was first introduced last year. It proved so 
controversial then that two of its original co-sponsors withdrew their 
support because they feared it would send innocent business owners to jail. 
Business owners collected over 20,000 signatures in opposition to the 
bill.   Protests against it were held around the country and tens of 
thousands of voters urged their elected official to oppose it. Controversy 
over the bill stalled it last year, but Senator Biden attached it to the 
popular "Amber Alert" bill without public debate or a vote of Congress 
earlier this year and snuck it into law.


The RAVE Act expands federal law to make it easier to jail and imprison 
event organizers and property owners that fail to stop drug offenses from 
occurring on their property - even in cases when they take serious steps to 
reduce drug offenses. It applies to "any place", including bars and 
nightclubs, hotels, apartment buildings, and homes. Legal experts warned 
that the law was so broad that it could be used to shut down not only raves 
and electronic music events, but also Hip Hop, rock, and country music 
concerts, sporting events, gay and lesbian fundraisers, political protests, 
and any other event federal agents do not like.

On May 30th an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) told 
managers of the Eagle Lodge in Billings, Montana that the Lodge could be 
fined $250,000 if anyone smoked marijuana during a planned benefit to raise 
money for a campaign to change Montana's medical marijuana law. After 
consulting their attorneys, the Eagle Lodge canceled the event.
For more information on the RAVE Act see: 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=1989


For more information on the DEA and the Eagle Lodge see: 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=1990




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: NRR:  Hip Hop Activism Buds Beautifully

--=====================_2568915==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hip Hop Activism Buds Beautifully

By Opio Lumumba Sokoni, J.D., AlterNet
June 10, 2003

Harry Belafonte stated to me in an interview that entertainers have the=20
responsibility to speak out on issues concerning the community. He also=20
said that entertainers are so often used to take people's minds off real=20
issues and that entertainers who do not act are part of the problem. In a=20
recent Wall Street Journal article entitled, "Mean Street Theater," written=
=20
by John McWhorter, he called social and political contributions to the=20
community made by rapper's "sideline donations." About the recently slain=20
rap artist Camoflauge, McWhorter writes, "Despite his searingly profane,=20
violent lyrics, [he] was regularly invited to speak at Savannah high=20
schools." This article could have been more appropriately titled, "Mean=20
Muggin' Hip Hop."

There's more. The article went on to run off other artists, i.e. Tupac,=20
Biggie, and Jam Master Jay as products of the genre. Never mind the=20
failings of law enforcement who have yet to find the killers of any of=20
these men. But, they could find any small-time hustlers in the hood and=20
lock them up for years and years for a nonviolent offense, i.e. drug=20
possession.

This brings me to the most appealing part of the piece. While the author=20
gave credit to Russell Simmons' Hip Hop Action Network for setting a goal=20
to register millions of hip hop voters for the 2004 elections, he asked a=20
poignant question. "What does the organization want the hip-hop generation=
=20
to vote for?" If for nothing else, his article should have been printed for=
=20
this query.

It is true that Hip Hop has to have a political issue or issues to mobilize=
=20
around. And we got issues; no doubt about that. Well, Russell Simmons, P=20
Diddy, Jay Z and many other hip hoppers are right on point in their effort=
=20
to address what should be the number one issue to focus hip hop activism =96=
=20
fighting against the failed war on drugs. These celebrities are doing=20
exactly what Mr. Belafonte says is expected of them.

This is a perfect issue for hip hop activism because the lives affected the=
=20
greatest are in the same communities that Hip Hop most represents. In=20
addition, the unchecked drug war is now devastating lives in white=20
communities as well. But what makes this an even greater issue for the hip=
=20
hop generation is the fact that it is The Issue of our time.

No other cause has as many moving parts as the issues associated with the=20
failed drug war. First, the war on drugs has created a prison population=20
that should be an embarrassment to any rational person. I do not know any=20
African-American that does not have a personal connection to someone in=20
jail for a drug crime. Most of the over two million people in jail are=20
non-violent, low-level drug offenders who would be better in treatment,=20
therapy, job training and/or on a job than in jail. But instead, the war on=
=20
drugs has delivered young bodies to jails that are used to support the=20
heartbreaking reality of the prison industrial complex.

Second, our babies are in foster care in high numbers because their parents=
=20
have been given long sentences, usually for minor use or possession=20
charges. In Washington, DC, an estimated 70% of the children who are in=20
foster care are there directly or indirectly due to drug addiction. There=20
are no studies that show prison as being better than treatment for a parent.

Finally, aside from the other civil and human rights problems related to=20
the war on drugs, i.e. a person losing the right to vote or a person being=
=20
denied financial aid for college, there is the matter of racism. The=20
fallout from the drug war has been more devastating than the KKK lynchings=
=20
of the 1920s. Young people are racially targeted, set up, captured,=20
convicted, sentenced and jailed at a staggering rate.

A 2000 Human Rights Watch report confirms that in Wisconsin a black man is=
=20
53 times more likely to go to prison on a drug charge than a white man.=20
This rate is reported to be the second highest in the country and more than=
=20
4 times the national average. Only Illinois ranked higher - there, a black=
=20
man is 57 times more likely to go to prison on a drug charge.

In New York, 94% of the people sentenced under the Rockefeller drug laws=20
are from Black and Latino communities. That's right, 94 percent. Debra=20
Small, who works for Drug Policy Alliance, says that the Rockefeller drug=20
laws are the granddaddy of the federal mandatory sentencing laws. A=20
low-level drug offender can be sentenced to 15 years to life if convicted.

I recently met a victim of the Rockefeller drug laws named Anthony Papa who=
=20
is the painter of "15 Years to Life: Self Portrait". Anthony, spent twelve=
=20
years in a maximum-security prison for passing an envelope containing 4=20
ounces of cocaine. When asked about this law, he says, "The millions of=20
dollars being spent to house non-violent persons can be used to feed the=20
hungry, put shoes on children's feet and spent on education."

Russell Simmons' Hip Hop Action Network has decided to work with Mothers of=
=20
the New York Disappeared and other activists, celebrities and organizations=
=20
to change these laws. A victory in New York could have a domino affect=20
among other states that have adopted similar drug policies. Further, this=20
may be the catalyst to make drug policy reform front and center in the 2004=
=20
elections.

Hip Hop is coming into political maturity and can work to change some of=20
the realities that are reported so vividly in rap lyrics. It is so=20
fascinating how music has always been a part of social action in the black=
=20
community. During slavery, coded songs were used to take persons to=20
freedom. In the civil rights movement, marchers sang songs like, "Ain't=20
Gonna Let Nobody Turn Me Round." Now, there is an entire genre that is=20
budding into full political awareness. How beautiful. And, it does not look=
=20
like a mere "sideline donation" to me.

http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=3D16107




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to=20
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great=20
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in=
=20
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of=20
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the=20
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager




--=====================_2568915==_.ALT--

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] BSP Jason Philips Hot August Tour - Jack Triumph joins in.

It is true Jason has contributed to this list over the past couple of months 
  that I have seen.

And it does not hurt to BSP your goods to the list..

However my experience as a DJ/promoter in this area for the past 6 years has 
been. If you are an out of town DJ Most likely you will not get booked in SF 
Unless there are 2 factors.

1.) You have records out on a fairly decent label and are somewhat known
2.) You know the promoter personally.


There are those rare cases where a promoter takes a chance on what some 
might consider a fairly popular DJ in another state/area.. But that is 
pretty few and far between (IMO)

I mean why book some "Knowbody" from another state when you can call up 
Jeno,Garth,Mark Farina,Mars,Mystre etc... and Just book them.. We have some 
of the best and well know Producer/DJ's in the world right here in our own 
hometown. And if your party is small enough alot of those jocks will play 
for a decent rate.

Thats just my 50cent   ;)


M

Subject: mid week humour - how to be annoying - nrr

------=_NextPart_000_00C3_01C33012.FD9FF8D0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

How to be Annoying=20





Adjust the tint on your TV so that all the people are green, and insist =
to others that you

"like it that way".=20

Drum on every available surface.=20

Remove every line of someone's .newsrc file except the entry for

alt.sex.fetish.hamster.duct-tape.=20

Sing the Batman theme incessantly.=20

Staple papers in the middle of the page.=20

Ask 800 operators for dates.=20

Produce a rental video consisting entirely of dire FBI copy warnings.=20

Sew anti-theft detector strips into people's backpacks.=20

Hide dairy products in inaccessible places.=20

Write the surprise ending to a novel on its first page.=20

Specify that your drive-through order is "to go".=20

Set alarms for random times.=20

Learn Morse code, and have conversations with friends in public =
consisting entirely of

"Beeeep Bip Bip Beeeep Bip..."=20

Buy large quantities of mint dental floss just to lick the

flavor off.=20

Order a side of pork rinds with your filet mignon.=20

Instead of Gallo, serve Night Train next Thanksgiving.=20

Leave your Nine Inch Nails tape in Great Uncle Ed's stereo, with the =
volume properly

adjusted.=20

Publicly investigate just how slowly you can make a "croaking" noise.=20

Honk and wave to strangers.=20

Dress only in clothes colored Hunter's Orange.=20

Change channels five minutes before the end of every show.=20

Tape pieces of "Sweating to the Oldies" over climactic parts of rental =
movies.=20

Wear your pants backwards.=20

Decline to be seated at a restaurant, and simply eat their complementary =
mints by the cash

register.=20

Begin all your sentences with "ooh la la!" Rouse your roommates from =
slumber each

morning with Lou Reed's "Metal Machine Music".=20

Leave someone's printer in compressed-italic-cyrillic-landscape mode.=20

ONLY TYPE IN UPPERCASE.=20

only type in lowercase.=20

dont use any punctuation either=20

Buy a large quantity of orange traffic cones and reroute whole streets.=20

Pay for your dinner with pennies.=20

Tie jingle bells to all your clothes.=20

Repeat everything someone says as a question.=20

Repeat everything someone says as a question?=20

Write "X - BURIED TREASURE" in random spots on all of someone's =
roadmaps.=20

Inform everyone you meet of your personal Kennedy assassination/UFO/OJ =
Simpson

conspiracy theories.=20

Repeat the following conversation a dozen times: "Do you hear that?" =
"What?" "Never

mind, it's gone now."=20

Light road flares on a birthday cake.=20

Wander around the restaurant, asking other diners for their parsley.=20

Leave tips in Bolivian currency.=20

Demand that everyone address you as "Conquistador".=20

Push all the flat Lego pieces together tightly.=20

At the Laundromat, use one dryer for each of your socks.=20

When Christmas caroling, sing "Jingle Bells, Batman smells" until =
physically restrained.=20

Wear a cape that says "Magnificent One".=20

As much as possible, skip rather than walk.=20

Stand over someone's shoulder, mumbling, as they read.=20

Finish the 99 bottles of beer on the wall song.=20

Sing the "This is the song that never ends..." song. (Ya know, Lamb =
Chops?) Pretend your

mouse is a CB radio, and talk to it.=20

Try playing the William Tell Overture by tapping on the bottom of your =
chin. When nearly

done, announce "no, wait, I messed it up", and repeat.=20

Drive half a block.=20

Name your dog "Dog".=20

Inform others that they exist only in your imagination.=20

Ask people what gender they are.=20

Reply to everything someone says with "that's what YOU think." Lick the =
filling out of all

the Oreos, and place the cookie parts back in the tray.=20

Cultivate a Norwegian accent. If Norwegian, affect a Southern Drawl.=20

Forget the punchline to a long joke, but assure the listener it was a =
"real hoot".=20

Routinely handcuff yourself to furniture, informing the curious that you =
don't want to fall

off "in case the big one comes".=20

Follow a few paces behind someone, spraying everything they touch with a =
can of Lysol.=20

Deliberately hum songs that will remain lodged in co-workers' brains, =
such as "Feliz

Navidad", the Archies' "Sugar" or the Mr. Rogers theme song. (DAVE, =
JENN, PAUL &

JOHN, equally annoying - the theme to Jesus Christ Super Star!) While =
making

presentations, occasionally bob your head like a parakeet.=20

Lie obviously about trivial things such as the time of day.=20

Make beeping noises when a large person backs up.=20

Leave your Christmas lights up and lit until September.=20

Change your name to John Aaaaasmith for the great glory of being first =
in the phone book.

Claim it's a Hawaiian name, and demand that people pronounce each A.=20

Sit in your front yard pointing a hair dryer at passing cars to see if =
they slow down.=20

Chew on pens that you've borrowed.=20

Invent nonsense computer jargon in conversations, and see if people play =
along to avoid

the appearance of ignorance.=20

Wear a LOT of cologne.=20

Ask to "interface" with someone.=20

Listen to 33rpm records at 45rpm speed, and claim the faster speed is =
necessary because

of your "superior mental processing".=20

Sing along at the opera.=20

Mow your lawn with scissors.=20

At a golf tournament, chant "swing-batatatatatata-suhWING-batter!" =
Finish all your

sentences with the words "in accordance with prophesy".=20

Ask the waitress for an extra seat for your "imaginary friend".=20

Go to a poetry recital and ask why each poem doesn't rhyme.=20

Ask your co-workers mysterious questions, and scribble their answers in =
a notebook.

Mutter something about "psychological profiles".=20

Incessantly recite annoying phrases, such as "sticky wicket isn't =
cricket." Stare at static

on the tv and claim you can see a "magic picture".

------=_NextPart_000_00C3_01C33012.FD9FF8D0--

In a message dated 6/10/2003 7:41:16 PM Pacific Daylight Time, BRAKYOFAC 
writes:

> wanted to share this with all of you. This morning my brother and I 
> attended church together for the first time in 6 months. He was welcomed home Friday 
> from serving in Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom in 
> Saudi Arabia. During the church service he was introduced to the congregation 
> and was given a standing ovation and a huge thank you for his service. My 
> brother being the big guy he is got all teary eyed and said on the way out of the 
> service to me sis, I don't no what all of the fuss is about I only did my 
> job. I looked up at him(just because he's younger he's alot taller at 6'5) and 
> said well bro, you troops have so many people that want to thank you for what 
> you've done. There are alot of us that support all of you that have been 
> there and those that remain. We both cried and he said well I'm glad I was able 
> to do it, but I was just doing my job. The troops see what they are doing as 
> their job, but they will always hold a special place in alot of our hearts. 
> My brother is a hero, and my boyfriend who is still in Iraq is a hero, as well 
> as the loved ones each of you have had over there or are still over there 
> are all heroes. Most importantly those that didn't make it back will be heroes 
> and shall never be forgotten. I want to say thank you to the troops for their 
> service for our country! God Bless them all, and bring them home safe and 
> soon! 
> 


--part1_1a0.1632773f.2c18f5a1_alt_boundary

<html>
I wanted to share this with all of you. This morning my brother and I attended church together for the first time in 6 months. He was welcomed home Friday from serving in Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom in Saudi Arabia.  During the church service he was introduced to the congregation and was given a standing ovation and a huge thank you for his service.  My brother being the big guy he is got all teary eyed and said on the way out of the service to me sis, I don't no what all of the fuss is about I only did my job.  I looked up at him(just because he's younger he's alot taller at 6'5) and said well bro, you troops have so many people that want to thank you for what you've done.  There are alot of us that support all of you that have been there and those that remain.  We both cried and he said well I'm glad I was able to do it, but I was just doing my job.  The troops see what they are doing as their job, but they will always hold a special place in alot of our hearts.  My brother is a hero, and my boyfriend who is still in Iraq is a hero, as well as the loved ones each of you have had over there or are still over there are all heroes.  Most importantly those that didn't make it back will be heroes and shall never be forgotten.  I want to say thank you to the troops for their service for our country!  God Bless them all, and bring them home safe and soon! 

<br>
</br>

I wanted to share this with all of you. This morning my brother and I attended church together for the first time in 6 months. He was welcomed home Friday from serving in Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom in Saudi Arabia.  During the church service he was introduced to the congregation and was given a standing ovation and a huge thank you for his service.  My brother being the big guy he is got all teary eyed and said on the way out of the service to me sis, I don't no what all of the fuss is about I only did my job.  I looked up at him(just because he's younger he's alot taller at 6'5) and said well bro, you troops have so many people that want to thank you for what you've done.  There are alot of us that support all of you that have been there and those that remain.  We both cried and he said well I'm glad I was able to do it, but I was just doing my job.  The troops see what they are doing as their job, but they will always hold a special place in alot of our hearts.  My brother is a hero, and my boyfriend who is still in Iraq is a hero, as well as the loved ones each of you have had over there or are still over there are all heroes.  Most importantly those that didn't make it back will be heroes and shall never be forgotten.  I want to say thank you to the troops for their service for our country!  God Bless them all, and bring them home safe and soon!

Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] [nrr] banner printing

Or if you are cheap and a crazy DIY type:

Go to Home Depot, pick up some vinyl -- all construction workers use it.
You may get more than you need so get some scissors and cut the size you
want, grab a couple sprockets so you can punch holes in the vinyl where
you want to hang it. Also get a couple cans of spray paint, make sure to
get white as the base, a couple rolls of shelf lining and an exacto
blade and do it yourself.

Total price will be about 10 bux and maybe 3 hours labor depending on
the intricacies of your banner.

-tim

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fwd: tears from a airman

quoth CPT Scarlet:
> it's better than most of the other crap that comes across this
> service.  i'm tired of hearing about people's road trips and personal
> problems on this list.  and for your information, while it may seem
> jingoistic to you.. it's not to me.. 

Well, I certainly didn't expect the kind of backlash I've received thus
far, but allow me to elaborate a bit further as to why I feel this type
of content doesn't belong on sfraves:

This looks to me like one of those emails that somebody either wrote
honestly (or worse, made up), then sent out to everyone they possibly
could. Shiny happy Americans around the country got it, thought it was
nice, and forwarded it to all their friends. The message is attributed
to:

Imhere4u478 <imhere4u478@aol.com>

...who appares to have originally sent it (CC'ing him/herself, so we'll
have to also assume that he/she BCC'd a bunch of other people at the
same time) to "militaryfamilyus@groups.aol.com", which is, presumably,
an online support group for families with members in the military.
We don't know if it's genuine. If the person that posted it to this
list appeared to have had some personal connection to the subject(s),
then I would've given him/her some slack, but c'mon... Basically, it's
just patriotic spam from somebody with a family member in the military.

No regard for the thousands dead and still dying in Iraq; no regret for
having supported a military force that tore a country to shreds under
false pretenses; just thankfulness that their baby got home in one piece
so they could "attend church" together. That's American jingoism at its
best.

Look, I'm sorry if my response offended anyone, but I feel very strongly
that this crap does not belong here. I'll be happy to belate the point
further offlist, if anyone's interested :)

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: BSP: Jack Triumph on An Epiphany Of Sound tomorrow

Join us Thursday morning as we have a secured a 3 hour progressive baptism
for all. Jack Triumph will be in rare form for a 3 hour appearance in
support of his new monthly event, "Sacred Institution" and the August 2003
release of his Progressive/Breaks Double Disc, entitled, "Empire". Tune in @
9am as DJ Triumph will spin an assortment of progressive / tribal house
cuts. We will be giving away 10 spots on the guest list for the June 15th
event, "Sacred Institution", and listeners who call in will have also have a
chance to win a copy of either of his released mixset albums, "Paganism", or
"Regressive Progressive: Evolution of the Dirty Beat".

Over the past 2 1/2 years DJ Triumph has become obsessed with spreading his
ideology of music and obtaining performances. He has been very fortunate to
play countless house parties, bar gatherings and other <100 person events.
Spinning a wicked assortment of dark, tribal influenced, tech/progressive
beats, he shuns all popular opinion in exchange for musical freedom. He has
played the Annual Boardstock event 3 years running, is a repeat guest on
KZSU Radio and held down a year long "downtempo" residency at the Paragon
lounge, located in the Claremont Hotel. In March 2003, he was selected to
play the Qoöl "Wednesday Night Happy Hour", at the 111 Minna Street Gallery,
where he shared the decks with Spesh, Scott Carrelli and Gee Moore. His has
been selected to make a repeat appearance at Qoöl on July 30th, 2003.

Jack feel's very positive about the impact that he can make in exposing the
masses to the dark tribal beat. "Right now I am focusing on obtaining more
shows, and becoming aligned with similar minded people who share my passion.
Whether that opportunity comes from a record label, or a small crew of DJ's,
it doesn't matter to me." He added, "Moving forward, I am not concerned with
people perceiving me as not being 'underground' enough," he said. "What
concerns me is to deliver and maintain the integrity of this art form, in a
balance act that will allow me to stay loyal to myself and still deliver
driving bass to the masses every time. In essence," he added, "to unleash my
reality of paganism."

--

that we are to stand by the President right or wrong is not only
unpatriotic and servile but it is morally treasonable to the
American public."

-Theodore Roosevelt, 1918

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

> Join us Thursday morning as we have a secured a 3 hour progressive baptism
> for all. Jack Triumph will be in rare form for a 3 hour appearance in
> support of his new monthly event, "Sacred Institution" and the August 2003
> release of his Progressive/Breaks Double Disc, entitled, "Empire". Tune in
@
> 9am as DJ Triumph will spin an assortment of progressive / tribal house
> cuts. We will be giving away 10 spots on the guest list for the June 15th
> event, "Sacred Institution", and listeners who call in will have also have
a
> chance to win a copy of either of his released mixset albums, "Paganism",
or
> "Regressive Progressive: Evolution of the Dirty Beat".
>
> Over the past 2 1/2 years DJ Triumph has become obsessed with spreading
his
> ideology of music and obtaining performances. He has been very fortunate
to
> play countless house parties, bar gatherings and other <100 person events.
> Spinning a wicked assortment of dark, tribal influenced, tech/progressive
> beats, he shuns all popular opinion in exchange for musical freedom. He
has
> played the Annual Boardstock event 3 years running, is a repeat guest on
> KZSU Radio and held down a year long "downtempo" residency at the Paragon
> lounge, located in the Claremont Hotel. In March 2003, he was selected to
> play the Qoöl "Wednesday Night Happy Hour", at the 111 Minna Street
Gallery,
> where he shared the decks with Spesh, Scott Carrelli and Gee Moore. His
has
> been selected to make a repeat appearance at Qoöl on July 30th, 2003.
>
> Jack feel's very positive about the impact that he can make in exposing
the
> masses to the dark tribal beat. "Right now I am focusing on obtaining more
> shows, and becoming aligned with similar minded people who share my
passion.
> Whether that opportunity comes from a record label, or a small crew of
DJ's,
> it doesn't matter to me." He added, "Moving forward, I am not concerned
with
> people perceiving me as not being 'underground' enough," he said. "What
> concerns me is to deliver and maintain the integrity of this art form, in
a
> balance act that will allow me to stay loyal to myself and still deliver
> driving bass to the masses every time. In essence," he added, "to unleash
my
> reality of paganism."
