Subject: Electronic Dance Music and Social Liberation

--=====================_14741351==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Fifth Estate, the oldest anarchist publication in the USA, has just 
published an article by me titled  "Electronic Dance Music & Social 
Liberation:  Sacred, Sweet, Wicked Ecstasy"  (Summer 2003, Vol. 38 #2, 
361).  The piece appears in FS's Music and Dance Issue.  Much of "Sweet 
Ecstasy" comes from "House Music 101."

Fifth Estate has no paid staff or copyright, so I am reproducing the 
article below since it is timely and a reaction to the RAVE Act.  FS is 
funded solely by subscription and purchases so I hope some of you pick up a 
copy.  I know Bound Together Book Store on the Haight carries it.

Much love,

Apollo

_______________________________________________________

Editors' note: Thanks to some typically sleazy last-minute conniving by 
Democratic Party Senator Joseph Biden, the "Reducing Americans' 
Vulnerability to Ecstasy" (R.A.V.E.) Act was signed into Federal law by 
Bush on April 30, 2003. The bill's introduction says in no uncertain terms 
that raves are "drug dens" where promoters sell illegal drugs and charge 
exorbitant prices for Ecstasy paraphernalia, such as bottled water, massage 
oil, and glow sticks. Under the law's measures, property 
owners/renters/leasers and event promoters are criminally liable for drug 
use on their premises and may be fined up to $250,000 and nine years in 
prison. The effect, of course, is to discourage the execution of any 
electronic music events since the actions of just one dancer could result 
in jail time for event organizers.

The rationale for the R.A.V.E. Act (and similar state and municipal 
anti-rave laws) is allegedly to open up another front in the ludicrous War 
on [some] Drugs. But it appears that Ecstasy is mentioned by name in the 
law only in the interest of a cutesy acronym logo, as cops and prosecutors 
have said explicitly that they are looking to go after crank and pot users 
as well. However, in the following article, Apollo offers a deeper look 
into anti-rave legislation. This is an excerpt of a much longer work by 
Apollo on the social history of underground dance and the evolution of 
electronic dance music in the US.  The work is being rewritten for 
publication at a later date.  Apollo is a rave producer, founder of the 
Moksha Tribe collective, a house music DJ, and has been involved with dance 
culture for over thirty years.  He lives in San Francisco.


Sacred, Sweet, Wicked Ecstasy
by Apollo


Those who believe that the current oppression of raves (and dance culture 
in general) is based entirely on a desire to stop the spread of the drug 
Ecstasy are missing the broader context. Crucial to understanding this 
atmosphere of police and governmental oppression is our culture's long 
historical fear of the union of body and soul represented by dance. If we 
are to fight this new wave of repression effectively, we must first 
understand something about the hate, fears, and prejudice of what really 
drives it beyond anti-drug rhetoric.

The house and modern electronic dance music scenes grew out of an oppressed 
peoples' need to build alternative communities in which they find refuge 
from the bigotry and racism of mainstream culture. The new dance culture 
arose, as did prior musical and dance movements in this country, from 
underground subcultures, evolving spiritually and aesthetically in the US 
out of the need for African-Americans, gays, lesbians and Latinos to build 
a community through dance.

Before the Stonewall bar uprising in Greenwich Village in 1969, the gay 
subculture was really an underground, secret society: all states outlawed 
gay sex by prohibiting sodomy and related non-standard sexual practices 
(some still have sodomy laws on the books).

Further, same-sex dancing was prohibited. And these laws were enforced: 
police regularly raided gay clubs and other meeting places, packed the 
participants off to jail, charged them with a variety of morals related 
offenses and, the worst part for most, published their names in local 
newspapers, all of which gave most pre-'69 gay dance clubs the clandestine 
feel of underground raves or of  speakeasies during Prohibition.

In the years after Stonewall and before AIDS, tens of hundreds of 
oppressed, abused, rejected gay kids who had experienced the worst kind of 
mind-fucking while growing up in rural and suburban American poured into 
NYC to express themselves freely as sexual beings for the first time. Some 
had never actually seen a room full of people like themselves. They 
certainly had no support groups or community to grow into.

For them, this was the fulfillment of a secret and distant dream: life for 
the first time. They wanted to build a world that accepted them, where they 
could have sexual relationships without punishing guilt, self-hatred or 
suicidal thoughts. Among other things, these sexual rebels started to build 
a new paradigm for social interactions on the dance floor, intuitively 
based on ancient rituals. Instinctively they seemed to know that dance 
would help make them whole-- dance would exalt both their bodies and souls. 
They would be FREE for the first time, and they would be freed from 
oppression, in part, through the power of communal dance.


Dancing is the Devil's Work

It is the body, of course, which is the vehicle of dance, meaning that 
people's attitudes towards dance are shaped by cultural and religious 
beliefs about the body and its uses. From its start, Christianity developed 
a complex love-hate relationship with the body for a variety reasons. For 
one, early Christians wished to disassociate themselves from pagan beliefs.

Linked to this was the influence of Neo-Platonist philosophy-- there's no 
need to get into a detailed discussion of philosophy here except to say 
that early Christian thought was fueled by the Neo-Platonic teaching that 
flesh was inferior to the intellect and the spirit. (This has always been a 
paradox to me, for the core belief of Christianity, the incarnation, seems 
to be a powerful metaphor for the need to redeem the soul through the 
flesh.) From this we arrive at the dreadful bifurcation of the body and the 
soul and the origin of much unhappiness in our culture.

  It may have been Increase Mather who defined the American Puritan 
attitude towards dance in 1685 with his tract against "Mixed or Promiscuous 
Dancing" : "sober and grave Dancing of Men with Men, or of Women with 
Women" was okay "in due season and with moderation," but "wanton" (that it 
is to say, "pleasurable") dancing, especially "Gynecandrical Dancing," was 
literally considered evil. When one recalls that US Attorney-General John 
Ashcroft adheres to a Christian sect that forbids dancing, we can see how 
little has really changed in three hundred years.

Puritanism remains as powerful a force in politics and culture as ever. 
Work, the Puritan focal point, is the centerpiece of our daily lives, and 
pleasure is still suspect. Anything that is perceived to interfere with 
productivity of the individual is damned. In Mather's day, the controllers 
used hell-fire sermons as the vehicle of social control; now it's anti-drug 
pseudo-science.

Dance culture has always been under very heavy fire in this country. My 
grandmother was arrested repeatedly during Prohibition when she went 
dancing at jazz clubs in the twenties, not because she was drinking the 
devil's brew, but because she was dancing the devil's dance.

Dancing to rock 'n' roll was bitterly opposed because it was believed that 
this passionate "Negro" music (facilitated by "reefer madness") would lead 
to teenage promiscuity and social chaos.

For a few brief years in the seventies, everyone, even the elite white man, 
was disco dancing, but this came to an end in the Reagan years when we were 
all reminded of the Puritan dictum that playing too hard can lead to 
unhappiness, and making money was a far more acceptable and righteous way 
to spend one's time.

No, things haven't changed that much. Good, righteous mainstream Americans 
don't dance all night long to tribal beats of the devil's music because it 
may reduce productivity and undermine the Gross National Product.

Pagan beats --those of house music, in particular, given its evocative 
fleshy-spiritual dimensions--  unleash all those disorderly pagan 
connections between the body and soul, and we can't have that in this 
rigidly controlled, work- and money-oriented Puritan society that we all 
seem to accept without question. Puritans, after all, are suspicious of 
pleasure, especially pleasures of the flesh.


The Ancient Rites of House Music

It's got something to do with the speed of the beats. It's hypnotic, 
tribal, and primal. That particular speed has worked for thousands of 
years, which is why you can spin in Arab music, Bhangra music, Aboriginal 
music... You can take all these different cultures and find the same beat, 
between 125-130 bpm. It's there in ecstatic, trance music, where people 
shake and spin until they reach a state of hyperventilation and psychedelic 
alpha-wave experience. In a sense (house) is regressive music. You're going 
back to the roots of why music was invented: to reach ecstatic and 
visionary states, in a communal tribal celebration.

                                                         Simon Reynolds, 
"Where 'now' lasts longer,"
                                                                 in Blissed 
Out (London: Serpent's Tail, 1990)

The belief that individuals can achieve spiritual liberation through 
communal dance and sexuality is nothing new. The concept of salvation 
through music, dance and eroticism is ancient and can be found in both 
Eastern and Western cultures. Many specifically religious rituals were, and 
still are, constructed around communal dance -- often with a sexual component.

It is primarily in the West, however, that one encounters the total divorce 
of body and soul. This distinction between the sacred and secular, the 
spirit and the flesh, is part of the Judeo-Christian tradition but has 
little currency in non-Western cultures. In pre-Christian Polynesia, for 
example, communal dance and sexuality were integrated into daily life. The 
arioi (a troupe of dancers-actors) would go from island to island to 
celebrate the cult of Oro, god of rain and fertility.

The core of their performance was sacred dance where the men would wear 
mock phalluses made from animal bladders and simulate sexual intercourse. 
On Tahiti, men and women danced day and night to praise their gods, 
celebrate the completion of various communal projects, honor the chiefs, 
and for the sheer fun of it.

  Dance was also an extremely important feature of many American Indian 
religious rituals. The Hopi calendar revolved around a sacred dance cycle, 
and they used dance to connect with the very forces that they believed 
governed the universe, such as the Snake Dance held in late summer to 
summon life-giving rain. The gods dance in India, and Shiva, the god of 
creation and destruction, is represented as Nataraja, Lord of Dance. Shiva 
is depicted as a four-armed deity, shown in a dancing mode, his raised left 
leg signifying that one of the blessings of dance is to free the dancer 
from worldly cares. The Yoruba of southwestern Nigeria believe dance opens 
direct channels to the gods, and speak of actually being "mounted" by a god 
during a sacred dance in which the dancer actually makes the god within his 
or her body while in a deep trancelike state.

  One could cite many other examples of non-Western traditions where dance 
plays a crucial role in ritual and worship. In the West, however, there is 
much ambivalence about dancing in any context, and especially the religious.

  Judeo-Christian culture embraced the notion of the bifurcation of body 
and soul, adopted a fearful attitude towards dance that aroused bodily 
passion, especially in a spiritual context and, for the most part, confined 
dancing to a strictly secular activity. Although the Hasidic movement of 
the eighteenth century and some visionary Protestant sects like the Shakers 
incorporated ecstatic dance into worship, mainstream Western 
Judeo-Christian societies from the Renaissance onward severed dancing from 
any spiritual content.

While I have always felt that the best communal dance experiences were 
transformative events where body and soul, sexuality and spirituality, 
worked together to produce a very valuable altered state of consciousness, 
it was not until I studied non-Western cultures that I came to understand 
that what I once thought was addictive behavior was actually an ancient and 
very natural part of life.

This ecstatic dance was the glue that bonded many of the world's tribal and 
other communities, and it was the source of energy and validation of the 
self and soul in the intentional communities in which I lived most fully. 
 From African priests to Korean shamans, there was and still is the belief 
that dance and music can open communication with intangible powers and 
produce tangible benefits for the communities involved: self-knowledge, 
fuller understanding of the natural world, good health, and a sense of 
belonging to a supportive group in an often dark and hostile but ultimately 
understandable universe.

The exquisite integration of the erotic and the spiritual in early house 
music partly derives, I believe, from primarily non-Western traditions of 
salvation and release through communal music and dance.

It's not at all surprising that African-American culture gave birth to the 
modern yet ecstatic, erotic yet spiritual dance experiences and music in 
underground gay venues like the Paradise Garage and the Warehouse. The vibe 
of these parties was intensely pagan, non-Western, and exuberantly 
non-Puritan.

The dancers were people who were all about loss of control and of giving 
oneself over to a collective eroticism, a movement into an altered state of 
consciousness resembling that spoken by the ancients when they describe 
possession by spirits. I believe that all of us who were passionate about 
this new dance experience knew intuitively at the time that what we were 
doing was something far more ambitious than throwing parties. This was 
about liberation of the loins and the soul through music and dance.

That said, though, I want to be clear that I am in no way suggesting that 
the form and content of house music was intentionally designed to resurrect 
some pagan tribal rituals. This desire was, I believe, bubbling below the 
surface as part of some natural need that is consciously suppressed in the 
West. The context in which house was born --oppression, mortality connected 
to sexuality, the need for redemption and release through communal dance-- 
brought these needs and ancient rites to the surface, and the body and soul 
were once again united in music and dance. Much of the early rave community 
was well aware of these pagan erotic, spiritual ecstatic trance dance 
experiences, and this may explain why the spiritual symbols used at early 
raves were intentionally non-Western and most often evoked Eastern and 
Hindu erotic-spiritual dance traditions. To this day, these intentions are 
still clearly evident at many electronic dance music events, especially 
those given by the psytrance community, where the connections are more 
explicit.

  With these issues underlying and informing the electronic dance 
experience, it is no wonder that dance culture is again a source of moral 
panic for a full spectrum of cultural authorities. The language of these 
crackdowns always comes wrapped in the codes of law enforcement and public 
safety-- after its investigation of electronic dance music subcultures, 
Congress declared that "raves have become little more than a way to exploit 
American youth."

And though anti-rave bills are most commonly associated with Ecstasy, it is 
not the drug and drug dealers that are really the issue, but rather the 
ecstasies of the dance. The Puritanical terror of the ecstatic movement of 
bodies has been drafted into the Drug War, and unless we work to subvert 
the Puritan paradigm and fundamentally change this culture's anxieties over 
unruly flesh and mind, more of this kind oppression should be expected.


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

it's kinda like an object lesson in the ups and downs
of Hollywood. if you make a hit movie, you get the
option of releasing an anime DVD in America and
selling it to a mass audience -- pretty unusual, and
pretty cool. not something everybody gets to do!

but the downside is, you *have* to make a sequel, and
you *have* to work with six times the budget of your
first movie, and you *have* to deal with twenty times
as many people breathing down your neck about it and
endlessly "improving" your script.

but that's sequels. I can only think of three sequels
that were better than the original movies, and two out
of those three were by Jim Cameron. legendary
filmmaker, legendary asshole too. I read somewhere
that people in LA have t-shirts that say "You can't
scare me, I've worked with Jim Cameron."


Giles

IMPORTANT!!! all High Octane Presale holders will get into our next event "Aquatech" FREE!!!



From the Creators of Power Puff Girls 1 and 2, Enter the Dragon 1-3 and countless other record breaking events.

 

Shaolin Presents.Our BIGGEST party ever!

June 13, 2003

HIGH OCTANE <~~mini-MASSIVE

============================

 

LOCK N LOAD

The Lock N' Load project consists of two Dutch producers / DJs: Frank van Rooijen and Niels Pijpers. One fine day the Club Caviar boys came to visit the Lock N' Load studio, heard the old version of a song and offered to do a remix of it. In collaboration with Lock N' Load they delivered this stunning result and Niels decided to release "Blow Ya Mind". After all on Blue White Records, within a period of three weeks, it became the No. 1 club record in the Netherlands, and Europe followed soon after that, the United Kingdom was ready to be conquered. Through no. 1 positions in both the UK Club and UK Dance chart it had an amazing entry at 6. Help us welcome Lock N' Load to Sacramento.

Chris C.

Now firmly established as one of the Biggest and most popular DJ / Producers on the UK Hard House/NRG scene, Chris has masterminded the emergence and rapid success of his 3 Labels, Mohawk, Aztec and Nile. Positioning the former today as one of the genres top 5 marques. With over 30 single releases and 2 Albums to his name on various labels including Tidy Trax, Tinrib, Eve, Honeypot, Phoenix Rising, GBT, Bulletproof, etc...Chris' reputation as one of Britain's finest exponent of Hard House, both behind the decks and in the studio, continues to grow.

Whistler

Victor Cape a.k.a. Whistler shines as a highly respected DJ on the Pacific Northwest dance scene. Known for his tight mixing skills and uplifting personality behind the decks, Whistler blends energy and emotion from Hard Melodic Trance, Epic Anthems and Hard House to take his listeners on a dance floor rollercoaster ride. If being a DJ wasn't enough, he also manages Lovetribe which has quickly become one of the most well respected event productions in Seattle. It's been over a year and a half since Whistler's last performance in Northern California. So we're excited to bring him out for his first Sacramento performance!

 

 

Dyloot

Arguably Nor-Cals BIGGEST Trance DJ/Producer watch him work his MAGIC over the crowd.

 

Tom Slik Vs. Tracer

Two of Nor-Cals Biggest Trance DJs wage war for the first time in Sacramento.

Denise Vs. Paul the Fanman

First ever Teacher vs. Student battle between the establish Denise and the BIG up n comer Paul. Lets see if he learned some tricks on his own.

Dragnfly Vs. Scepter

Shaolins two BIGGEST DJs go head to head to see who really is the SHAOLIN MASTER.

Bazooka Joe Vs. Reckless Ryan

Showmanship is the only way to describe the performance these two put on. Turntablist House at its best. Watch as these two leave you in a wicky-wick-AWWW!

Valerie Sparks vs. The Doctor

Nor Cals Best Hardcore Female DJ goes against this up n coming Junglist.

Sascha 23 Vs. Gauge

The founder of Xtort bumps heads with one of Shaolins Most talented Producer in a must see set with original Shaolin tracks.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Another View on the RAVE Act:  The Right to Party

--=====================_18318051==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

The Right to Party

By Neal Pollack, The Brooklyn Rail
June 12, 2003

A few years ago, when I was a reporter in Chicago, I did a story on a=20
phenomenon I called "The New Prohibition." The city, for various reasons,=20
was shutting down neighborhood bars. In poor black neighborhoods, taverns=20
were the targets of moralistic church crusaders. In gentrifying=20
neighborhoods, they were the b=EAte noire of noise-averse yuppies. What was=
=20
wrong with Mayor Daley? I asked. Didn't he want Chicago to be fun anymore?

The article garnered a bit of local attention. I appeared on an episode of=
=20
a nightly public-affairs show. For once, a piece of mine actually got a few=
=20
letters to the editor. And I decided to take it further. I did a local NPR=
=20
radio commentary in which I called, tongue-in-cheekly, for a new political=
=20
party, "The Party Party," that would campaign to make Chicago the=20
freewheeling town I imagined it had once been.

Oh, how na=EFve I was then, and how foolish I feel now! Those little tavern=
=20
raids and precinct vote-dry initiatives were nothing, a little internecine=
=20
tap-dance, compared to the assault on fun currently being waged by the=20
federal government. Our right to party is being attacked by forces far more=
=20
powerful, more sinister, and more organized than Mayor Daley's liquor-law=20
enforcement bureaucracy. Everything fun about America is under serious=
 threat.

Let's review the evidence of the last few months.

In late February, DEA and Department of Justice officials arrested 55=20
people and seized thousands of dollars of drug paraphernalia during=20
"Operation Pipe Dreams." The arrests mainly targeted online bong dealers,=20
who attorney general John Ashcroft claimed had "invaded the homes of=20
families across the country without their knowledge." But also included in=
=20
the arrests were employees of several head shops in Pittsburgh, where the=20
investigation was centered. The feds even raided the California home of=20
Tommy Chong, who in mid-May pleaded guilty to conspiring to sell drug=20
paraphernalia. The most stunning quote from the whole affair came from=20
acting DEA chief John Brown, who said, "People selling drug paraphernalia=20
are in essence no different than drug dealers. They are as much a part of=20
drug trafficking as silencers are a part of criminal homicide.''

The government is equating Tommy Chong with murderous criminals. Perhaps=20
next they'll haul in Rodney Dangerfield and the inflatable pilot from=20
Airplane! Something is wrong. Very wrong.

In March, Senator Joe Biden of Delaware managed to sneak the RAVE act=20
through as an attachment to a bill establishing a national warning system=20
about child abductions. RAVE stands for, amazingly, Reducing Americans'=20
Vulnerability to Ecstasy. But its main targets are concert promoters and=20
club owners, whom the act holds to an absurd standard.

According to the law, it is illegal to "manage or control any place,=20
whether permanently or temporarily, either as an owner, lessee, agent,=20
employee, occupant, or mortgagee, and knowingly and intentionally rent,=20
lease, profit from, or make available for use, with or without=20
compensation, the place for the purpose of unlawfully manufacturing,=20
storing, distributing, or using a controlled substance."

This definition was derived from a 20-year-old federal law that permitted=20
raids on "crackhouses." The law is so broad that you could have 10 people=20
over for dinner, put on some loud music, and you've got yourself a rave. If=
=20
someone lights a joint at your "rave," and the neighbors complain about the=
=20
music, and the police are in a bad mood that night, you face decades in=20
prison. Suddenly everyone is a potential drug criminal and it's doubly=20
dangerous if there's dancing involved.

And this just in: In late May, a DEA agent in Montana threatened a venue=20
owner with a $250,000 fine, under the RAVE Act, if she hosted a joint=20
benefit for the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws=20
(NORML) and Students For Sensible Drug Policy. The event was canceled. The=
=20
RAVE Act has officially arrived.

Keep in mind that these are Democrats pushing these laws. This War On Fun=20
is not single-party. That said, the Republicans seem to have a serious=20
problem with sex. The federal government's financial commitment to=20
"abstinence education" reached a new high this year. When I say a new high,=
=20
I mean $120 million. This is not the sex education we received in high=20
school. According to federal guidelines for applying for abstinence=20
education grants, a federally funded program must, among other things,=20
teach "abstinence from sexual activity outside marriage as the expected=20
standard for all school age children," and that "a mutually faithful=20
monogamous relationship in the context of marriage is the expected standard=
=20
of human sexual activity."

 From personal experience, I will agree with certain tenets, such as the=20
fact that "drug use increases vulnerability to sexual advances," and I=20
cannot argue with the fact that "sexual activity outside of the context of=
=20
marriage is likely to have harmful psychological and physical effects," but=
=20
is this really something that needs to be legislated? Can you imagine being=
=20
a teenager today in this context? Teen pregnancy and STDs are a problem,=20
for certain. But is the answer really organizations like Pennsylvania's=20
Silver Ring Thing, which, in exchange for $12 and a pledge of abstinence=20
until marriage, offers high-school students a silver ring and a Bible?=20
Sounds like a bad trade to me. Couldn't they at least throw a couple of=20
condoms into the gift pack, just to make sure?

Lest we think that these phenomena, which seem to be loosely linked, are=20
just the usual mix of anti-drug nonsense and hypocritical fundamentalism,=20
we should think again. Journalist Eric Schlosser, in his excellent new book=
=20
"Reefer Madness," drops the stunning statistic that more than 20,000=20
Americans are in prison for marijuana-related "crimes." But the current=20
trend in policy goes far beyond that. Under the RAVE act, you're guilty by=
=20
association with marijuana smokers.

Abstinence education had a foothold during Bill Clinton's America, too, but=
=20
now there's an extra moral force, and lots more money, behind the=20
preaching. When Pennsylvania Rick Santorum made his controversial remarks=20
in April about not approving of homosexual "acts," he also said, "the idea=
=20
is that the state doesn't have rights to limit individuals' wants and=20
passions. I disagree with that. I think we absolutely have rights because=20
there are consequences to letting people live out whatever wants or=20
passions they desire. And we're seeing it in our society."

What is he talking about? What consequences? As far as I'm concerned, that=
=20
phrase, from a leading Republican Senator, is an official government=20
declaration of a War On Fun. What exactly would be Rick Santorum's idea of=
=20
a good party? One where nobody got drunk or high, where nobody hooked up,=20
and where nobody danced with abandon? Why, that doesn't sound like a party.=
=20
It sounds like church.

I've had enough.

This time, for real, I'm calling for the establishment of a Party Party,=20
or, at the very least, for a Party Party attitude. I'm issuing a call to=20
arms for those of us always in need of, as the great Jeff Spicoli once=20
said, tasty waves and a cool buzz. Of course there are many issues in the=20
world that are more pressing, and we should continue to press them. But=20
Saturday night eventually comes even for the most politically committed.=20
These are tense times. People want to loosen the steam valve a little bit.=
=20
They want to participate in culture outside of the jurisdiction of federal=
=20
"morality" educators. We don't want the government telling us how to spend=
=20
our free time, sussing out and prosecuting casual drug users and harassing=
=20
nightclub owners. And for heaven's sake, give the kids some condoms.

Sex and drugs and live music make life great. These are the kinds of things=
=20
that were outlawed in Taliban-run Afghanistan. If they can't be legal and=20
easy in America, then I don't want to live here anymore. I want to live in=
=20
a place where drugs and sex are tolerated, where the government provides a=
=20
sane level of social services, where religion isn't always threatening to=20
take over the state. Amsterdam. It always comes back to Amsterdam.

Americans, we have to party. It is our right. And we have to fight for that=
=20
right. Yes, you heard me. We have to show the moralizers that they cannot=
 win.

We have to fight for our right to party.

Neal Pollack is the author of "The Neal Pollack Anthology Of American=20
Literature" and "Beneath The Axis Of Evil." HarperCollins will publish his=
=20
first novel, "Never Mind the Pollacks," in September. He lives in Austin,=20
Texas.

http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=3D16145




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to=20
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great=20
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in=
=20
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of=20
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the=20
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

June 13th, 2003
Oneiromancy Productions Presents
"Quantum Singularity"

Join us as we try to warp spacetime to a taste of what SF was like when names 
like "Frequency 8" or "Skills" were still young, and trance parties were still

Featuring:

Axis Mundi (Nashville, TN)
One of the East Coast's up & coming Psytrance DJs, Axis Mundi has been turning 
on dancefloors all over the US, Canada, and Southern America to the magic of 
Psy. Combining years of mixing experience with an array of Live PA synths, 
drum machines, and samplers, Axis Mundi blends on-the-fly production into each 
of his sets, creating an unforgettable perfomance.

Majere (SF) - [Hard Trance]

Dekota (SF) - [Hard Trance]

9pm - 5am

          by attbi.com (rwcrmhc11) with SMTP
          id <2003061304492301300amla1e>; Fri, 13 Jun 2003 04:49:23 +0000
Message-ID: <005a01c33166$531339e0$16dbe90c@attbi.com>
From: "Greg Van Pelt" <gregvp@attbi.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Thu, 12 Jun 2003 21:43:13 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="----=_NextPart_000_0057_01C3312B.A03839E0"
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2615.200
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: NRR: Hollywood golden era & Gregory Peck's passing

------=_NextPart_000_0057_01C3312B.A03839E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I am so saddened by the passing of Gregory Peck, one of the great actors =
of the past. I will never forget his performance in The Omen, from 1976. =


I mourn today the loss because he was one of America's greatest actors. =
In cinematic history there have been only a handful of men who meet =
legend status, and he was one of those, and he was the last.

With his passing, we close the book on an earlier time in history when =
our only link to the outside were the movies that we got to see on the =
weekend, at 5 cents a pop.=20

Gregory Peck was one of the great ones, along with Cary Grant, John =
Wayne, William Holden, Humphrey Bogart, Peter Lorre, Tyrone Power, Clark =
Gable, Jimmy Stewart, and Henry Fonda. Now there are no more left. These =
great talents were lucky enough to be around to usher us in to the new =
age of filmmaking, and what films could offer. And now they are all =
gone. Their memories and their dreams of what they could be will live on =
forever in their films and in our memories,

I feel very strongly about this, griefstruck, although I know that Mr. =
Peck lived a wonderful life. He was a decent man, and an honest man, and =
I never got the chance to meet him but I will miss him nevertheless.
Gregory Van Pelt



------=_NextPart_000_0057_01C3312B.A03839E0--

Subject: [downloadable] Mongrel Seed and Noise Kombat


Just uploaded a bunch of new noise.

My live techno set from mongrel seed last weekend:  Something was clipping
at the mixer, but luckily I was recording straight from my CPU.  So, the
recording sounds better (in spots) than it did at the event.

I also put up 9 one minute noise kombat tracks.  These were composed for
the madame chao noise battle, where noise artists go head to head and the
audience votes for the winner.  I made it up three tiers to the final five
(out of 20+) with these beautiful (horrible) waveforms.

All this and my entire music archive can be found here:

http://typhoon.enabled.com/~esc/

You will need an audio player that supports the excellent ogg format.
Winamp3, or macamp are good choices.

Would love to get some feedback.

-ed-

Subject: [NRR] Friday Poetry.. Lets make this a theme and see our poets out there.

Inside my head, no one sees my tears.
Inside my head, no one sees my fears
Inside my head, no one sees these dreams.
Inside my head, no one hears my screams.
Inside my head, everything makes sense.
Inside my head, life is not past tense.

Outside my head, my smile shines brightly on
Outside my head, nothing seems at all wrong
Outside my head, the world must never know
Outside my head, I will not show sorrow.
Outside my head, nothing makes sense.
Outside my head, I treat the world like a prince.

Mantra of the Altruist
Rayn McCormick 6/10/03

> > I understand that tomorrow, Friday, from 10:00 am to noon the "Crackdown on
> > Raves" will be discussed on KQED's radio talk show FORUM,  with host
> > Michael Krasny.
>
>Apparently it was 9-11am. By the time I found the online stream it was
>almost over. For future reference (re-broadcast tonight?) you can listen
>online (real & media player) here:

Actually, the program was on from 10:00 AM to 11.  The discussion was a bit 
lop sided (against the legislation) because one of the guests from 
"Drug-free America" or something didn't appear.  You can listen to it now 
at http://tinyurl.com/a95a

The host was Angie Coiro.  Guests were: Jacob Sullum , senior editor of 
Reason magazine and author of "Saying Yes: In Defense of Drug Use" ;   Mark 
Rennie , an attorney who represents San Francisco nightclubs and promoters 
including the End-Up, Paradise Lounge, and AsiaSF  ;  and  Trinka Porrata , 
retired LAPD Narcotic Detective and private consultant on drug issues, 
specializing in designer/club drugs and raves; her clients include the 
California Attorney General's Office and the US Department of Justice.

Ms. Porrata was predictable.  She has made a career out of "uncovering" 
underground rave behaviours and making them identifiable to 
law-enforcement:  things like pacifiers and chill rooms as identifiers of 
illegal drug activity.  For a person who consults on drug issues she seems 
to know very little about actual research and data in the area.

Sullum was more interested in overall WOD issues, I think.  Rennie 
presented a good feel for the chilling effect the RAVE legislation is 
having on local club promoters.

I didn't get to hear all of it.  Interrupted by business.

Love,

Apollo






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [NRR] Friday Poetry.. Lets make this a theme and see our poets out there.

My turn:


Unrequited

Where do I go from here?
Which fork in the road do I take?
Each path can lead to some terrble fate.
Each road so inviting.
One lead by fear,
One by hope.
I am taught to stay and hang in there
But I am conditioned to run away.
I am surrounded by the results of my past mistakes.
Surrounded by painful reminders and scars.
Living life for its end,
But sometimes seeing more.

Which road will lead to my ultimate dream.
And which to my downfall.
Is what I feel real?
Or is it just what I want to feel?
The world has become so cynical
So pesimistic.
We all know it's not the Brady Bunch,
Or full house.
People die without getting to say goodbye.
People steal and do drugs,
Without getting caught and learning new ways.
Alcoholics 
Stay alcoholics.
And love can forever remain unrequited.


--- Rayn <acydrayn@hotmail.com> wrote:
> Inside my head, no one sees my tears.
> Inside my head, no one sees my fears
> Inside my head, no one sees these dreams.
> Inside my head, no one hears my screams.
> Inside my head, everything makes sense.
> Inside my head, life is not past tense.
> 
> Outside my head, my smile shines brightly on
> Outside my head, nothing seems at all wrong
> Outside my head, the world must never know
> Outside my head, I will not show sorrow.
> Outside my head, nothing makes sense.
> Outside my head, I treat the world like a prince.
> 
> Mantra of the Altruist
> Rayn McCormick 6/10/03
>

Subject: BSP:  Ggreg Taylor's Forgotten Opera.

--=====================_20232778==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Many of you may remember Ggreg Taylor from Burning Man or his wonderful 
Product parties at 1015 Folsom in the early nineties.  Well, Ggreg is back 
with his own brand of magik this Saturday.


FORGOTTEN OPERA/SF - 6.14.03

San Francisco Opera is sponsoring this one-time-only party, allowing Ggreg 
Taylor (aka Nambla the Clown) to utilize their huge elaborate sets for his 
massive SOMA warehouse dance party to promote opera.  Opera is powerful 
spectacle and art on its own; combined with a wild warehouse party, this 
event will be outrageous.  And you'll only able to see it once.

Saturday, June 14, 2003
@ 44 Tehama Street (2nd St)
10pm-4am

DJ's include Lewis from Sugar opening for Jeno from Wicked's four hour set 
on the main dance floor.  Ouchy the Clown and Pinky Ring spin on the indie 
floor. It's a masked costume ball with opera ticket prizes given out for 
best costumes in four categories.

Advance tickets are available at Cafe Flore (Market @ Noe, SF) and Body 
Body Wear, 535 Castro.

Advance tickets are $20 for costumed, $25 non-costumed, and $30 at the door.

All Forgotten Opera attendees will also get vouchers for two-for-one 
tickets to this summer's opera performances (up to $135 savings).

Loads of details on The  Forgotten Opera site:  http://ggreg.com/opera


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

-----Original Message-----
From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org] 
Sent: Friday, June 13, 2003 3:31 PM
To: SFRaves@hyperreal. org
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Ggreg Taylor's Forgotten Opera.

Many of you may remember Ggreg Taylor from Burning Man or his wonderful 
Product parties at 1015 Folsom in the early nineties.  Well, Ggreg is
back 
with his own brand of magik this Saturday.


FORGOTTEN OPERA/SF - 6.14.03

San Francisco Opera is sponsoring this one-time-only party, allowing
Ggreg 
Taylor (aka Nambla the Clown) to utilize their huge elaborate sets for
his 
massive SOMA warehouse dance party to promote opera.  Opera is powerful 
spectacle and art on its own; combined with a wild warehouse party, this

event will be outrageous.  And you'll only able to see it once.

Saturday, June 14, 2003
@ 44 Tehama Street (2nd St)
10pm-4am

DJ's include Lewis from Sugar opening for Jeno from Wicked's four hour
set 
on the main dance floor.  Ouchy the Clown and Pinky Ring spin on the
indie 
floor. It's a masked costume ball with opera ticket prizes given out for

best costumes in four categories.

Advance tickets are available at Cafe Flore (Market @ Noe, SF) and Body 
Body Wear, 535 Castro.

Advance tickets are $20 for costumed, $25 non-costumed, and $30 at the
door.

All Forgotten Opera attendees will also get vouchers for two-for-one 
tickets to this summer's opera performances (up to $135 savings).

Loads of details on The  Forgotten Opera site:  http://ggreg.com/opera


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It
is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a
purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished
in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the

past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: NRR: The Tao

Some days I read a passage from the Tao and it fits so well with modern
day life here is the one I read today-


Lesson 30

Whenever you advise a ruler in the way of the Tao,
Counsel him not to use force to conquer the universe.
For this would only cause resistance.
Thorn brushes spring up wherever the army has passed.
Lean years follow in the wake of great war.
Just do what needs to be done.
Never take advantage of power.


Achieve results,
But never glory in them.
Achieve results,
But never boast.
Achieve results,
But never be proud.
Achieve results,
Because this is the natural way.
Achieve results 
But not through violence.


Force is followed by a loss of strength.
This is not the way of the Tao.
That which goes against the Tao comes to an early end.




Jason Philips
Compos-Mentis
Problematic Beats

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP:  Ggreg Taylor's Forgotten Opera.

the very first rave i ever attended was one of gGreg taylor's
in '89 i think.  it was at this huge warehouse on minna, and
they had trapeze artists performing above the crowd of dancers.

it was the most amazing party i'd ever been to.

every day one would call the info line for the party and it
would say something different.  sometimes they would change it
multiple times a day.  it wouldn't just give info like, "DJs
are tom suck, doh-loot, martian & mystery-e", it would say
stupid witty little things that got you hyped for the party,
pretend conversations between ditzy girls and transvestites,
and other nutty things...

bottom line:  this guy is the SHIT.  if i weren't heading off
to the desert, i'd be at this party no matter what.  :/

m

-----Original Message-----
From: michael, the red stickman [mailto:red_stickman@yahoo.com] 
Sent: Friday, June 13, 2003 5:50 PM
To: Apollo; SFRaves@hyperreal. org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP: Ggreg Taylor's Forgotten Opera.


the very first rave i ever attended was one of gGreg taylor's in '89 i
think.  it was at this huge warehouse on minna, and they had trapeze
artists performing above the crowd of dancers.

it was the most amazing party i'd ever been to.

every day one would call the info line for the party and it would say
something different.  sometimes they would change it multiple times a
day.  it wouldn't just give info like, "DJs are tom suck, doh-loot,
martian & mystery-e", it would say stupid witty little things that got
you hyped for the party, pretend conversations between ditzy girls and
transvestites, and other nutty things...

bottom line:  this guy is the SHIT.  if i weren't heading off to the
desert, i'd be at this party no matter what.  :/

m


--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org> wrote:
> Many of you may remember Ggreg Taylor from Burning Man or his 
> wonderful Product parties at 1015 Folsom in the early nineties.  Well,
> Ggreg is back 
> with his own brand of magik this Saturday.
> 
> 
> FORGOTTEN OPERA/SF - 6.14.03
> 
> San Francisco Opera is sponsoring this one-time-only party, allowing 
> Ggreg Taylor (aka Nambla the Clown) to utilize their huge elaborate
> sets for his 
> massive SOMA warehouse dance party to promote opera.  Opera
> is powerful 
> spectacle and art on its own; combined with a wild warehouse
> party, this 
> event will be outrageous.  And you'll only able to see it
> once.
> 
> Saturday, June 14, 2003
> @ 44 Tehama Street (2nd St)
> 10pm-4am
> 
> DJ's include Lewis from Sugar opening for Jeno from Wicked's four hour

> set on the main dance floor.  Ouchy the Clown and Pinky Ring spin
> on the indie 
> floor. It's a masked costume ball with opera ticket prizes
> given out for 
> best costumes in four categories.
> 
> Advance tickets are available at Cafe Flore (Market @ Noe,
> SF) and Body
> Body Wear, 535 Castro.
> 
> Advance tickets are $20 for costumed, $25 non-costumed, and $30 at the

> door.
> 
> All Forgotten Opera attendees will also get vouchers for two-for-one
> tickets to this summer's opera performances (up to $135
> savings).
> 
> Loads of details on The  Forgotten Opera site:
> http://ggreg.com/opera
> 
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
> 
> House Music 101:
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

> to a purpose."

At 05:50 PM 6/13/2003 -0700, michael, the red stickman wrote:
>the very first rave i ever attended was one of gGreg taylor's
>in '89 i think.  it was at this huge warehouse on minna, and
>they had trapeze artists performing above the crowd of dancers.
>
>it was the most amazing party i'd ever been to.

Yep, Ggreg is one of the best event producers I've ever met.  He was one of 
the early organizers of Burning Man, many awesome early rave parties, the 
Gay Pride Day event...all mind-bending, creative stuff.  He went to London 
and NYC for awhile.  The guy is also a programmer.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Quoting Jason <djjasonphilips@hotmail.com>:

> Some days I read a passage from the Tao and it fits so well with modern
> day life here is the one I read today-
> 
> 
> Lesson 30
> 
> Whenever you advise a ruler in the way of the Tao,
> Counsel him not to use force to conquer the universe.
> For this would only cause resistance.
> Thorn brushes spring up wherever the army has passed.
> Lean years follow in the wake of great war.
> Just do what needs to be done.
> Never take advantage of power.
> 
> 
> Achieve results,
> But never glory in them.
> Achieve results,
> But never boast.
> Achieve results,
> But never be proud.
> Achieve results,
> Because this is the natural way.
> Achieve results 
> But not through violence.
> 
> 
> Force is followed by a loss of strength.
> This is not the way of the Tao.
> That which goes against the Tao comes to an early end.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> Jason Philips
> Compos-Mentis
> Problematic Beats
>

at the barn, you know that his style and programming is totally unique - =
a result of his access to music that no one else can get for months or =
even years.  he was playing stuff for us 2 years ago that is just being =
released today!  to say that we're stoked to have him back is an =
understatement!

Access"! + barefoot from orangeage/aranji, psynthetic from =
g.o.a.play/aranji, ATUM of thump radio, and upstairs chilled and =
beautiful beats from todd and DJ field (interchill records) w/the sultry =
vocal stylings of irina, DJ masonic, neal and t.o.b.

http://www.thumpradio.com/thumpparty.cfm

we have a couple guest list and 2for1 spots open if you'd like to join =
us for this evening of trance-en-dance!

email me back if you know what country jirah is from...and you'll win =

peace and see you tonight!

Subject: 1st live performance / SCREAM

Greets,

Last week I did my 1st live electronic music performance in Santa Cruz at 
ELectron_SAlon7 (www.elsaproductions.com). It went quite well; the set is 
available at a new section of my site for live sets:
http://catharsis.egregious.net/live/

This performance isn't EDM and more on the "experimental" tip. I used 
custom software I created for the performance along with an amplified and 
heavily processed (analog) violin. I feel it is marginally rave related 
though as the sample sources are 10 people from around the world saying 
"Welcome to the fucking rave." in their native language.

I am working on adding the video of the concert to a DVD that covers my 
early work.

The software environment I am creating is called SCREAM. Introductory 
information can be found here: http://audio.egregious.net/scream/
I will be updating this site soon with much more information as the project 
develops. Soon, modules will be available publicly and eventually a 
developers API to build modules will be released for programmers.

I also collected all the media (audio/visual) links on the Egregious site 
and they can be found here:
http://www.egregious.net/media/

I put up mp3s of Timeless Beginnings and Live @ Minimal Monday for those of 
you that can't handle ogg... at the moment the mp3s for both of these sets 
are on a 640kbps connection, so it may get bogged down...

I suppose I'll be catching up with some of you next week! ;)

Best,
--Mike

Egregious
"Spiritual renewal through music for those outside the heard."
http://www.egregious.net/

	boundary="----=_NextPart_000_0035_01C332DB.5D4A8FA0"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Still looking for talented undiscovered DJ's and Producers

------=_NextPart_000_0035_01C332DB.5D4A8FA0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

To all the very talented DJ's and Producers out there in the Bay Area:
 
For those who have read this post and have emailed me, thank you.  We
are within the final steps of releasing the site and making it "live".
EVERYONE who has responded will get an email back, if you haven't heard
from me already.
 
There is going to be a new web site that has never been done before.  It
will cater to the underground electronic DJ scene in the Bay Area, with
styles of music ranging from House, Trance, NRG, Hard Trance, Hard
House, Jungle, DnB, Ambient, Acid Jazz, Turntablism, etc. (I think you
get the point).  Interested?  Keep reading...
 
Does this fit your description?  An electronic DJ or composer that is
too talented for their own good, but doesn't know how to get themselves
known...
 
...This is where we come in.  
 
If you think you got some killer dj mixes or some tracks you put
together yourself, then we are looking (more specifically, listening)
for you.  We're looking for 25-50 talented DJ's and composers to get the
site launched with fresh, off-the-hook slammin' music.  We're looking
for 160kbps - 192kbps mp3's of your mixes or tracks.  If we like what we
hear, then we'll give you a free 6-month membership to our site.  More
details will be explained once we make contact with you.
 
We are just like you - we are doing this for the music, and for the
electronic community.  This site will cater to the electronic DJ's in
every aspect imaginable.
 
If you are interested, please email djunderground@wctech.net with a link
to where we can listen to your music.  Remember, it can be either a
complete mix, or just a track you created.  If you don't have a link to
your music, still send an email.  If you have to send it to us on a CD
in the mail, so be it.  Whatever it takes for us to hear your music.  If
you're dedicated enough, you'll get it to us.
 
*** Due to the mass amounts of email I get in regarding this, I am now
only listening to 192kbps mp3's that I am able to download, or CD's that
are sent in the mail.  I've had a lot of people who have sent me a URL
for streaming mp3's and Real Media, but since I lead a very hectic life,
CD's seem to be my only way of taking your mixes with me.  MP3's are
fine, just as long as they are 192kbps.  If you send me a CD, it makes
things easier when I do pick you if you send me two CD's - one with a
single mp3 track, and an audio CD.  I hate to make things complicated,
but it will save us both time if I can get the mixes and tracks in those
mediums.
 
We are also looking for people to help throughout the site as well.
Currently we are looking for people to write articles within the
underground electronic scene, help keep the site up to date with news,
and help us keep up to date with the events that are going on in the bay
area.  If you would like to help, please email to
djunderground@wctech.net.
 
Did I mention this site will be viewed on a daily basis by record labels
and music producers?
 
More information will follow once we do get in contact with you.  The
site is in its final stages and are currently in testing.  We can't say
much without some sort of confidentiality.  So shoot us an email to
djunderground@wctech.net so we can start talking.
 
If you're serious about DJ'ing or producing, send us an email.  If
you're not, don't bother.
 
Patrick Masciocchi
Founder
DJUnderground.com
 

------=_NextPart_000_0035_01C332DB.5D4A8FA0--

kinda downtempo, but clocks in @ 120bpm.  Its got live

Neve room at Expression, and arranged, mixed and
mastered on my little protools computer at home.  The
link is

it, i've got copies on 12" for sale.

found here: http://mateojones.djcentral.com

studio for about a year.  I've done studio design,
installation, wiring (custom).  I set up & am teaching
a recording class for the Bayview Safehaven kids
program.  Oh, i do club/live sound too (design, setup,
engineering).  If anyone has any questions, please
feel free to e-mail me.  Hope you enjoy it!

Subject: Repealing the RAVE Act

--=====================_2426690==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

We understand that many people have concerns about writing to the DEA.  It 
also seems that your faxes have either overloaded the DEA's fax machines or 
the machines have been turned off because your letters are no longer 
getting through. So, we've decided to shake things up at the source. 
Senator Biden (D-DE) - the man behind the RAVE Act - is a national 
political figure considering running for the Democratic nomination for 
President.  He told critics of the law that he expected it to only be 
applied to "rogue" promoters that sold drugs. He needs to know that 
everything voters like you warned would happen has happened. It took less 
than two months for the law to be used against a political fundraiser and 
we're holding him accountable. As a possible Presidential candidate Biden 
needs to know that voters across the country care about this issue and 
won't stop until he repeals or reforms the RAVE Act. You can fax him a 
letter for free from our website
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2269. Copies of the fax 
will also go to the Members of Congress who represent your district.


It only takes one minute to fax Senator Biden:
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2269


Also, our new action alert is below. Please forward the alert to your 
friends, family, e-mail lists, etc.


You're making the difference!


==============================
*** Tell Senator Biden, "Repeal the RAVE Act"
*** Send a Free Fax:
      http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2269


Only two months after the RAVE Act was passed by Congress it has been used 
by the federal Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) to intimidate the 
owners of a Billings, Montana, venue into canceling a combined benefit for 
the Montana chapter of the National Organization for the Reform of 
Marijuana Laws (NORML) and Students for Sensible Drug Policy (SSDP).


On the day the fundraiser was set to take place a Billings-based DEA agent 
presented the venue owners with a copy of the RAVE Act warning them that 
they could face a fine of $250,000 if illicit drugs were found in the 
premises. The bands - most of which regularly played at the venue - were 
reportedly also approached and warned that their participation in the event 
could result in a fine.


Rather than risk the possibility of enormous fines, the venue decided to 
cancel the event. This blatant intimidation by the DEA was obviously 
designed to shut down the marijuana reform fundraiser. Unless the American 
people speak out against this attack on free speech, the DEA will be 
emboldened to use the law against other events they do not like, such as 
all-night dance parties, hip hop concerts, hemp festivals, and circuit parties.


Join the Drug Policy Alliance, National Organization for the Reform of 
Marijuana Laws, Students for Sensible Drug Policy, and numerous other 
organizations in our campaign to pressure the sponsor of the law to repeal 
or reform it.


ACTIONS TO TAKE


1) Fax Senator Biden: http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2269
Urge him to repeal the RAVE Act or amend it to better protect innocent 
business owners, public health, and free speech. Copies of the fax will 
also go to the Members of Congress that represent your district.


2) Forward this alert to friends and family. Send it to e-mail lists and 
post it in chat rooms.

BACKGROUND


Sponsored by Senator Biden (D-DE), the RAVE Act (also known as the Illicit 
Drug Anti-Proliferation Act) was first introduced last year. It proved so 
controversial then that two of its original co-sponsors withdrew their 
support because they feared it would send innocent business owners to jail. 
Business owners collected over 20,000 signatures in opposition to the 
bill.   Protests against it were held around the country and tens of 
thousands of voters urged their elected official to oppose it. Controversy 
over the bill stalled it last year, but Senator Biden attached it to the 
popular "Amber Alert" bill without public debate or a vote of Congress 
earlier this year and snuck it into law.


The RAVE Act expands federal law to make it easier to jail and imprison 
event organizers and property owners that fail to stop drug offenses from 
occurring on their property - even in cases when they take serious steps to 
reduce drug offenses. It applies to "any place", including bars and 
nightclubs, hotels, apartment buildings, and homes. Legal experts warned 
that the law was so broad that it could be used to shut down not only raves 
and electronic music events, but also Hip Hop, rock, and country music 
concerts, sporting events, gay and lesbian fundraisers, political protests, 
and any other event federal agents do not like.

On May 30th an agent of the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) told 
managers of the Eagle Lodge in Billings, Montana that the Lodge could be 
fined $250,000 if anyone smoked marijuana during a planned benefit to raise 
money for a campaign to change Montana's medical marijuana law. After 
consulting their attorneys, the Eagle Lodge canceled the event.


For more information on the RAVE Act see:
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2267


For more information on the DEA and the Eagle Lodge see: 
http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2268




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed

Flyer link:

http://www.norcalraves.org/IMG/FLYERS/6_27_03_sdream/ 
full_6_27_03_sdream.jpg

Alright Party Kidz! Tha time is near and tha party is almost here!  
We've been workin hard to bring you guys a great party with heart N  
some thick a$$ vibes- that ya could cut with a spoon
SO.. With that in mind .. we've made a few changes and added some  
surprises to give this party even more ol' skool flava with a lil taste  
of some fresh new blood!
First though-There's been a few rumors commin through the grape vine  
that this event will be at the "crackhouse" venue in Oakland... THIS IS  
NOT TRUE!! A Summer Dream will be at a 100% Secure- Air Conditioned-  
VIRGIN Location .. that will also feature an outdoor smokin area   
However... the rumor that IS Mos Definatly true.. we'e added a second  
room to tha party to give you kidz even more for your buck! Line up  
TBA!!  Now this is gunna be totally chill status-with two liscensed  
message therapists, to take care of all your aches N pains from tearin  
up tha dance floor!
Your also gunna wana arrive early as we're gunna have free glowsticks  
for the first 100 (0r so ) kidz .. if ya don't though .. I hear ya  
might be able to still find some free CD's and goodies inside too! Now  
if those aren't reason enough... then take a look at what else we have  
in store~
California Dreamz is proud to announce that we will be accepting  
donations for our "raver scholorship" program at our upcomming event.  
In short-this is how it works- we're gunna be asking you all to donate  
whatever you can--if you can-- to put towards a scholorship that will  
be given away at our next event! This will be given to someone based  
on: GPA, application, interview,financial need- and will require that  
the individual is a high school senior, or college freshman, that we  
feel, is bound to someday make a positive difference & contribute to  
society. FYI: The check will be made out to tha school of their  
choosing-sorry guyz-no free lunch!  And u gotta attend our event to  
apply... so - For more information please contact us!
*This is only tha beginning and a hint of whats up our sleeves! So come  
take a glimpse into tha future.. June 27th @ A Summer Dream!

--Apple-Mail-10-190489361--

Subject: Another day, another song ID

Hey Bay Area :)

So I haven't written much of anything lately - been far too unmotivated 
to do much more than punch in at work...

Last week I got motivated and went up to Liquid, and the DJ played a 
really supa-supa-funky house track (I mean FUN-KAY) with a lot of mean 
bass.. I asked him what it was and he said "All I know is it says 
'Nebraska' on it - I picked it up at BPM."  So I'm assuming this is 
some sort of white label, but my searches have yielded nothing.

Anyone have any clue what this might be? I'm dyin' here...

Fanx...

  - omid

Subject: Bodhi is now teknobuddha

 After signing up with Juno, I found out I had two accounts, so I decided
to stick with teknobuddha. So far kinda so good, getting signed up and
downloading their softwere was a pain in the ass, and i'm still waiting
for the disc to get internet connection, but for $10 a month vs $28 for
AOL, I think it's worth all the trouble. If this turns out to be a good
alternative ISP to the high priced ones like AOL and people are looking
for a good cheep one, I'll let you know if this one rocks or suxs.

I didn't realize how may "solstice" events were going this weekend.  It
looks like a bit of something for evereyone this weekend!=20


Friday June 20th - Sunday June 22nd, 2003
SOLSTICE - outdoor festival
Don't miss this outdoor tribal gathering weekend of dancing and camping
under the stars, just 3 hours away from SF! Tickets are limited, first
come first served. Community healing offerings include: Yoga, Tai Chi,
Massage, Didjeridu & Drum Circle, Fire Performers, String Art, Henna
body art, and more... Live performances by: LOGIC BOMB, PENTA, MAXX,
SECTOR 7G, COSMIC SELECTOR Dj performances by: Dutch, KJ, T.O.B., Atum,
Sentient, Eve, Neal, Hanan, Akasha, Psynthetic, Kevin Nelson,
Redstickman, Djen Masti, Christine, Yohimbe, Shane, Tandava, Maxx,
Surreal, Michael Liu, Adam Ohana, Doctor Spook, Sfdatman, Jeremiah,
Kenni, Yohei, Omar,Kevin, Laura, Hallucid, Alon, and many more... All
ages $25 presale / $30 gate. Tickets are limited. Once presale tickets
sell out, no tickets will be made available at the gate. updated info
and directions at www.solsticehealing.org=20

Friday June 20th - Saturday June 21st, 2003
Solstice 3 by Summit Sessions and Random Party
FEATURING... Dragn'Fly Billy Lane Vega Scepter Cantos Rif Climaxxx & Dr
Smile Slim & Tofu w/ mc Skurge D-Calvin vs Digital E E.M.P. vs Subtext
w/ MC Micatron Atom O.N.E. Nomad w/ MC Blaze C-Dub Flat_Line Rogerthat
Jetson vs Crisis vs The Beast (2 hour set) Tupperwareblue Officer bunch
Matteous Preston Land Drumhustler Headcayce Kellys Heroes 59 Crime The
Caws Rightous Movement more djs TBA+ 2 rooms of ACTIVE MAKIE SOUND by
SUMMIT SESSIONS Lighting by VIVID FUSION visuals by RANDOM and P.M.S.
Blacklights by MIDDLEGROUND This will be a 2 night Outdoor Event ONLY
15$ per VEHICLE!!!!!!! 24 hour infoline 1 (916) 321-7059 info @
random_party@hotmail.com

Saturday June 21st, 2003
Summer Solstice by Ill Behavior and Pangea
Come and join us in the celebration of the first night of summer. Shed
the spring and enjoy the summer to the sounds of the Bay Area's best
underground sounds White Room Sol Americano Berkeley,Ca Reckless Ryan
Reckless Ryan.com/bassline W/MC Nerd Nate Frogger Live P.A. Dawn of
Sound ESDJCO,Funkytechnotribe Les Elemental accompanied by Rebekah live
improv operatic vocals eden collective/pangea NY/SF James Dub
spacemonkey/Bayraves.com visual d=E9cor by M.O.F. Black Room Gridlock
(live final scratch set)Violence/Project51 SF Havoc vs DJ Sharp
Compression Tag team Arson vs Coda triple 5 soul/urban drums/510
junglists/halflife<Oracle orphan Pavel Urban Drums/bc transit Tony 2
Step Ill Behavior/ftb Visual d=E9cor by Pangea Purple Room Spective Zero
mag/ In the Scene mag Kris Kent ill behavior Thomas Kent ill behavior
Mahesh resurrection project Scott resurrection project Timo Space Monkey
Garrett Ryan Ill Behavior/92.7 Fire performance by Daelon De 18+ $15 For
more info call Pangea @ 510 273 2484 Ill Behavior @ 925 210 9821 Or
e-mail pangea@edencollective.com Illbehaviorkk@hotmail.com=20

O§bY <osbyjamz@hotmail.com> wrote:
So I been like mondo chillin' like since I got back from LA & not dancin' as much or at all really.... & lookin' 4 work, la la la la... but this weekend was pretty simple & Dope! I didn't do nothing major on Friday but I did talk 2 my Brother 4 like an hour & Aryck sayd HI & he misses U all 4 those who remember him! LoL... pretty much became an internet geek & well... I was on Friendster 4 like oh gosh... 5 hours... Yes... I'm proud of being a friendster whore!

Sat I went 2 Brooks Happy Hardcore BDay BBQ!! It was Groovy ';cause I hung out w/ my friend Al from Sweden that day & we chilled! It was fun hangin' out w/ him! It was also fun @ Brooks!! Hello 2Day... Fuckin' Moshen & Leslie show up!! I haven't seen those 2 in like months!! So that was Dope catchin' up w/ them!

It was Groovy... also met a few people & hmmmm.... it was fun & well... totally unexpected! LoL.. Hello 2Day!

OK.. Sunday... went 2 a family gathering in the early afternoon.... oh o oh oho oh.. I saw Miki yestereday... we hiung out 4 a while & kicked it... it was Doooooope!! I Love Miki!

But anywaze... after the small family gathering... I went 2 Pleasenton 4 Sacred Institution @ Popi's Lounge!!! LoL... it was a really fun time there!!! I mean... I weas kinda unclear kinda about what exactly prog house really is, but after lastnight... I realized I been hearing it alot! alota Alot Alot! LoL... But yeah.... man... Jack Triumph played some clean sets of prog house & Wow, he played alota Vocal prog tribal tekky house that totally made me cream!!! I Love It! the other guy who spun was DJ Mike someting... but he was hella CooL!! He played alota prog house also, LoL, but man... when he busted out Disco house.. LoL... I was on the floor DMAO oh oh oh.. & he spun this remixs of a New Order song that had this mondo Wicked fuckin' Downtempo breakdown which made me dance so hard I almost put my back out! LoL

The whole night there was Great!! The venue was a nice lil' hole in the wall in a strip mall!! I mean... the place was FILLED w/ pretty Groovy people! I mean... there were a bunch of like preppy suburban Sat Night SoundFactory people who don't really understand what Electronic music's all about, but it was Groovy though!! LoL... yeah.... we decided lastnight that Jack Triumph is a trendy preppy, but it'sd OK!! O Love Homeboy still! =)

LoL... the last song like totallly played was "On More Time" & it was Groovy!!! By that point... I was on the Dance floor w/ like all this Latin People & it was Awesome!! LoL... I mean... I was totally havin' like Mondo Flashbacks of 1 of the last parties @ Butterfly house when Aryck, Me, Mimi, Jason, Becca, Ryan, & Tina were in the garage dancing 2 this song man.... so sweeT!! =)

Oh Yeah... Greg VP came 2 Sacred lastnight also!! LoL... He was trippin out that he saw there & it was fun!!! I mean... I seriously think alota y'all missed out 'cause it was soooooooo fun lastnight & the music was PRIMO!!! LOVED IT!!! Can 't wait 'til the next 1!!! Thanks Jack & Crew!!! =)

Peace=-=-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ~*PULSE*~ FRIDAY.AUGUST.8th.2003 (*TWO ROOMS* w/13

over the years I have commented on this very same point.. And each time the 
Xtort guys nicely explain how and why they do what they do. It obviously 
works and works well for them.. On a small time party scale. At least for me 
personally it burns the shit out of me and gets me frustrated that people 
can be so dumb and fall for the easy cheese lineup/parties and you got 
promoters/DJ's/Producers that go out of there way to bring something 
different and unique to the scene and just have it looked over. That is why 
personally.. Im not doing parties anymore.. Well maybe a few more small club 
things for some friends etc.. ;)  But in terms of full on flyers and putting 
up my 5-10k cash fuck that shit.. It ain't worth it to me.. For a bunch of 
pubscent teens that want to hear the cheese.. And of course people like 
myself and others can take the easy way out and throw cheese parties.. Hell 
I think if I wanted to.. I could be on the level of some of the Mid size 
promoters (With a few parties) and book the mega events I have enough of my 
OWN capital and contacts/connections to do it. But I choose not to.. I would 
rather focus on other things.

I think that is what may burn people up.. Cause you can be a dipshit and 
still come up in the scene like a skills or F-8 you just have to "Market 
your events" accordingly.. doesn't take a genius to do it just a big helping 
of cheese.. mmmmm gouda

thanks for listening to my rant  :)

M

From: MidNite232@aol.com

Date: Tue, 17 Jun 2003 05:35:18 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Mailer: 8.0 for Windows sub 6014
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [NRR] ::FUNNIE::  Change the Atmosphere Of Your Bedroom

--part1_3d.31202e08.2c203ad6_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

It's especially good for couples that have been together for a long time to 
create a new atmosphere in an all too familiar bedroom, but you don't have to 
be in a long term relationship to try some of these suggestions. Variety is the 
spice of life. Altered surroundings can turn a routine sex session into a 
night of passion you will remember for the rest of your life. 


Add Some Strange Music

Playing music that you normally wouldn't can profoundly change the feel of a 
room and the sex you have in it. Reggae and jazz are favorites in the bedroom 
for the sense of rhythm they help provide, as well as a lot of dance music 
played in singles bars. 


The Nose Knows

Our sense of smell is one of the most powerful memory queues we have. Scented 
candles and incense are very good for changing the atmosphere of a room. If 
your bedroom smells different your brain will unconsciously think it's a 
different place. Don't just buy one flavor or scent, buy dozens. A wide range of 
scents is much better. 

There is another huge bonus to using a variety of scents over a long period 
of time- even without consciously trying, your mind can associate a particular 
sex session with a unique smell (as long as the smell is unique enough). In 
the distant future it will be easier to reenact a particularly passionate night 
if you burn the same incense fragrance. 

Sometimes a memory association will happen by accident. It's a very cool 
experience to be out shopping and smell a candle and have it remind you of an 
intense orgasm or a particularly kinky sex act. 


New Sheets

New sheets always beg to be broken in. They don't have to be satin or silk, 
but it helps. 


A Black Light

Florescent body paint is really cool with one of these. 


A Disco Ball

Small ones can be purchased at a novelty store. Nothing changes a room quite 
like spots of different colored light all over the ceiling and walls. A 
cheaper substitute is a novelty lampshade. If you can't find a store for those 
they're very easy to make yourself. Any craft shop will help you out. 


Mirrors

It isn't hard or expensive to fix a few panels to the ceiling and it makes a 
very tantalizing addition to the bedroom. They don't have to stay there 
forever and it doesn't have to be a perfect job. Just make sure you have them out 
before you host a Christmas party or find a way to keep your bedroom private. 


Go With A Theme

Ever fantasize about fucking in a jungle? You can have the next best thing 
and not have to worry about twigs and creepy crawly things. Buy a cd with sounds 
of the jungle and move all the plants in your house to the bedroom. 

Want to fuck on a beach without getting sand in your ass? Try playing an 
ocean sounds cd and massage one another with sun tan oil. 


Flood Lights

Many people already own colored floodlights for decorating the outside of 
their house at Christmas. You don't have to wait for December to put them to good 
use. Indoors they make everything in a room their particular color, even your 
partner. Science fiction fans really appreciate fucking under a green light. 
Just make sure you have some good blinds for your windows, you'll be sending a 
colorful beacon out to the entire neighborhood that might be embarrassing to 
explain. 
    
    
    


--part1_3d.31202e08.2c203ad6_boundary--

Anniversary

FRIDAY ? SATURDAY ? SUNDAY
July 25-27, 2003
BOBCAYGEON, ONTARIO, CANADA
