touches down in Ontario, Canada. We promise a weekend of musical=20
delights from around the world that will imbibe your senses and gratify=20=

your soul. =46rom the very beginning of the electronic music scene in=20
Canada to the present day, we have been there to entertain you and=20
provide you with something others can't. We now invite you to join us=20
for a very special milestone - our TENTH ANNIVERSARY! Yes - that right,=20=

after years of festivals, massive one-off concerts, club nights and=20
weekly events, Destiny is a perfect 10!  Expect nothing but the best as=20=

we cap off another glorious year with a lineup second to none and an=20
event that will blow your socks off... We invite you to be part of=20
history in the making!

Event Attractions
*  Over 200 different performers from around the world
*  Two massive outdoor all ages dance stages both featuring full=20
service liquor bars for the 19+ crowd
*  Four all ages circus big-top tents for rain or shine enjoyment all=20
weekend long
*  Daytime entertainment and music
*  Visual art displays and performances throughout the weekend
*  Newly added parking fields allowing on-site parking for thousands
*  Organized camping zones located adjacent to the parking fields
*  Breakfast, lunch and dinner menus served by a wide range of food=20
vendors including vegetarian choices and available 24hrs. a day
*  24hr security patrols for your safety
*  On-site medical staff and first aid centers
*  Clean beaches, parks and shops just moments from the event site
*  In-out privileges for people and cars through our wristband policy
*  Improved shuttle bus service from Toronto that can be pre-booked by=20=

date and time
*  Vendors from across North America
*  RV access and electrical hook-ups
*  Free giveaways and prizing all weekend long
*  Two licensed areas for those with ID

Tribe/WEMF 2003 New Talent Tent

We are happy to welcome back the TRIBE NEW IMPROVED New Talent Tent to=20=

WEMF2003. That?s right ? better sound, light & d=E9cor for ?03! If you=20=

are interested in getting an hour to showcase your talent at the=20
largest event of its kind in North America then put together a phat=20
demo tape, CD or DVD and send it along with WEMF2003 advance ticket=20
proof of purchase (ie. photocopy clearly showing ticket number or=20
Ticketmaster/Tripdecks.com confirmation code in your name) to:=20
TRIBE/WEMF2003 New Talent Tent, Box 65053, 358 Danforth Avenue,=20
Toronto, Ont. M4K 3Z2. All those selected to perform in the New Talent=20=

Tent will have their advance ticket purchase REFUNDED at the gate upon=20=

entry.

We are looking for all types of electronic dance music, so whether you=20=

play tranced-out harmonic breakbeat or hardcore ambient jungle, we=20
wanna hear it!

Selected artists will have their names posted on the official WEMF=20
website (www.wemf.com), the official TRIBE website (www.tribe.ca) and=20
listed in the official event programme handed out to everyone who comes=20=

through the gates WEMF weekend.

For more details please visit www.wemf.com


Please visit the official WEMF 03 website @ www.wemf.com for=20
information on:

The Ninth Annual World Electronic Music Festival :: Destiny 10 Year
Anniversary

FRIDAY ? SATURDAY ? SUNDAY
July 25-27, 2003
BOBCAYGEON, ONTARIO, CANADA
www.wemf.com - 416-631-8821


Once again, the biggest, best and longest running festival of its kind
touches down in Ontario, Canada. We promise a weekend of musical
delights from around the world that will imbibe your senses and gratify
your soul. From the very beginning of the electronic music scene in
Canada to the present day, we have been there to entertain you and
provide you with something others can't. We now invite you to join us
for a very special milestone - our TENTH ANNIVERSARY! Yes - that right,
after years of festivals, massive one-off concerts, club nights and
weekly events, Destiny is a perfect 10!  Expect nothing but the best as
we cap off another glorious year with a lineup second to none and an
event that will blow your socks off... We invite you to be part of
history in the making!

Event Attractions
*  Over 200 different performers from around the world
*  Two massive outdoor all ages dance stages both featuring full
service liquor bars for the 19+ crowd
*  Four all ages circus big-top tents for rain or shine enjoyment all
weekend long
*  Daytime entertainment and music
*  Visual art displays and performances throughout the weekend
*  Newly added parking fields allowing on-site parking for thousands
*  Organized camping zones located adjacent to the parking fields
*  Breakfast, lunch and dinner menus served by a wide range of food
vendors including vegetarian choices and available 24hrs. a day
*  24hr security patrols for your safety
*  On-site medical staff and first aid centers
*  Clean beaches, parks and shops just moments from the event site
*  In-out privileges for people and cars through our wristband policy
*  Improved shuttle bus service from Toronto that can be pre-booked by
date and time
*  Vendors from across North America
*  RV access and electrical hook-ups
*  Free giveaways and prizing all weekend long
*  Two licensed areas for those with ID

Attention all DJs:
Tribe/WEMF 2003 New Talent Tent

We are happy to welcome back the TRIBE NEW IMPROVED New Talent Tent to
WEMF2003. That?s right ? better sound, light & décor for ?03! If you
are interested in getting an hour to showcase your talent at the
largest event of its kind in North America then put together a phat
demo tape, CD or DVD and send it along with WEMF2003 advance ticket
proof of purchase (ie. photocopy clearly showing ticket number or
Ticketmaster/Tripdecks.com confirmation code in your name) to:
TRIBE/WEMF2003 New Talent Tent, Box 65053, 358 Danforth Avenue,
Toronto, Ont. M4K 3Z2. All those selected to perform in the New Talent
Tent will have their advance ticket purchase REFUNDED at the gate upon
entry.

We are looking for all types of electronic dance music, so whether you
play tranced-out harmonic breakbeat or hardcore ambient jungle, we
wanna hear it!

Selected artists will have their names posted on the official WEMF
website (www.wemf.com), the official TRIBE website (www.tribe.ca) and
listed in the official event programme handed out to everyone who comes
through the gates WEMF weekend.

For more details please visit www.wemf.com


Please visit the official WEMF 03 website @ www.wemf.com for
information on:
*  The WEMF2003 Leviathan Mini-Ramp Demo
*  The Tribe Magazine New Talent Tent
*  Parking and RV Info
*  Vendors
*  Travel Directions and Maps
*  Flight Packages
*  Mix Tapes/CD ?s
*  Media & Guestlist Info
*  Special offers from our sponsors
*  Important WEMF updates and much more!!!

July 25/03

July 26/03

Advance:        $60.00 ? Before July 26/03 (While Supplies Last)
At The Gate:      $70.00

Sunday arrival tickets available at the gate only - check www.wemf.com
for pricing.

>We are happy to welcome back the TRIBE NEW IMPROVED New Talent Tent to
>WEMF2003. That?s right ? better sound, light & décor for ?03! If you
>are interested in getting an hour to showcase your talent at the
>largest event of its kind in North America then put together a phat
>demo tape, CD or DVD and send it along with WEMF2003 advance ticket
>proof of purchase (ie. photocopy clearly showing ticket number or
>Ticketmaster/Tripdecks.com confirmation code in your name) to:
>TRIBE/WEMF2003 New Talent Tent, Box 65053, 358 Danforth Avenue,
>Toronto, Ont. M4K 3Z2. All those selected to perform in the New Talent
>Tent will have their advance ticket purchase REFUNDED at the gate upon
>entry.
>
>We are looking for all types of electronic dance music, so whether you
>play tranced-out harmonic breakbeat or hardcore ambient jungle, we
>wanna hear it!
>
>Selected artists will have their names posted on the official WEMF
>website (www.wemf.com), the official TRIBE website (www.tribe.ca) and
>listed in the official event programme handed out to everyone who 
>comes
>through the gates WEMF weekend.

Subject: New Law Covers Political Intimidation

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

 From the Nation --
http://www.thenation.com/doc.mhtml?i=20030630&s=forbes


New Law Covers Political Intimidation
by Daniel Forbes

Drug reformers and concert promoters united a year ago to block passage of
Democratic Senator Joe Biden's Rave Act, which would have subjected
promoters and club owners to prohibitive fines for any but the most
incidental drug use at their events. This year, though, Biden--who said the
law was needed to deter drug use and "protect kids"--attached it to the
anti-child abduction AMBER Alert bill, which passed in April.

It took about a month for reformers' fears to be realized. Emphasizing the
possible $250,000 fine, a DEA agent brandished a copy of the law at a
fraternal lodge in Billings, Montana, that was about to host a benefit
concert to raise money to help qualify a medical-marijuana measure for the
state ballot next year, and the event was immediately canceled.

Denver-based Special Agent in Charge Jeff Sweetin, who runs the DEA's Rocky
Mountain Division, said the lodge trustees may not have known what they
were in for because typically such events feature "open air" drug use. It's
the DEA's duty to inform them, he said, so they can beef up security. "The
emphasis was, there were a lot of people coming, and they need to be
prepared," said Sweetin.

Kelly (who declined to give her last name) was the manager on duty at the
Fraternal Order of Eagles Lodge when agent Dan Dunlap showed up on May 30,
several hours before the $5 event, proceeds from which were to go to local
chapters of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws and
Students for a Sensible Drug Policy as well as the medical-marijuana ballot
fight. Kelly said Dunlap made no overt threats but showed her a copy of the
new Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act and informed her that should any
drugs be found on the premises, the lodge might be subject to the $250,000
penalty. He didn't tell the lodge to cancel the event, but just indicated,
Kelly said, "what could happen." Dunlap also told her that undercover DEA
agents or some in "squad cars" might attend. She called her boss.

Lodge chairman Roger Diehl confirmed his meeting with Dunlap, but declined
comment beyond saying it was his decision to cancel the event.

Sweetin acknowledged that Dunlap mentioned the quarter-million-dollar fine
as "one possible ramification of the law." He said, "If they chose to have
the concert, we told them what could happen." Asked about the fine, Sweetin
said, "There is a liability attached if you don't control your patrons."
Sweetin maintained that the DEA is duty-bound to inform the public about
the new law while noting, "It's pretty broad. It's a very aggressive
approach to drug users and people who profit from drug use at events." He
added that the DEA is still seeking guidance from the Department of
Justice. "We don't know how it's going to shake out."

Had the lodge lacked proper security, said Sweetin, "It can turn into
Ecstasy use and marijuana use, and people could have gotten hurt." His
worst fear, he said, is having "to talk to the mother of some girl who was
doped or raped or killed." He added that the DEA actions are likely to be
presented as "the bad narcs trying to stop a fundraiser, but no, that's not
the case."

Scott Proctor, the interim coordinator for the Montana State Green Party,
says that while there might have been some potheads skulking around the
parking lot if the concert had taken place, there would not have been any
open pot smoking. "You'd get nailed for that in Billings. It's a very
conservative town," he said.

Rather than curtailing political speech, Biden staffer Chip Unruh said, the
law "targets people who knowingly and intentionally promote an event for
the purpose of drug use, sales or manufacturing. The law is very clear and
there's a high burden of proof." Paradoxically, Unruh said, "I can't think
of too many instances where someone knowingly promoted an event for the
purpose of drug use. That would be stupid--just another form of dealing drugs."

Bill Piper, associate director of national affairs at the Drug Policy
Alliance, said the incident--not to mention Unruh's statement--proves
opponents' contention that the law would be used as a form of intimidation.
Existing laws, he contended, adequately cover drug dealing by concert
promoters.

Had the concert come off, organizer Adam Jones, a 21-year-old Montana State
student and founder of the local NORML and SSDP chapters, would have
skipped it despite his months of preparation. He was locked up for three
days for failing to inform his probation officer that he'd switched from
his winter to his summer YMCA job, and for a urinalysis described by Pam
Bunke, regional administrator for Montana's Department of Corrections, as
"borderline hot" for marijuana. Having not checked with Jones's job since
January, probation officer Barry Ivanoff did so the day before the concert.
Asked whether this was coincidental, Bunke said, "Coincidence--sure." Bunke
said that Jones came to the authorities' attention for his April 2001
felony possession of 3.7 grams of psychoactive mushrooms. Then a May 2002
search of his home turned up a baggie with some mushroom residue and, said
Bunke, a "bottle of liquid spores"

Bunke said the state crime lab would do a more extensive analysis of
Jones's urine, and should it determine Jones had used marijuana, Jones's
probation could conceivably be revoked, and he could do up to two years in
prison, though a lesser penalty is likely.

The Green Party's Proctor declared Jones a great organizer who has "done
more at age 21 than a lot of people do their whole lives." But more
politics will have to wait. With his probation officer riding herd--and
facing that urinalysis result--Jones said he's resigned his posts because
"There's a real conflict of interest for me to be involved with reform
organizations right now." This despite what he views as "a scary and
complete infringement of my First Amendment rights."


Daniel Forbes (ddanforbes@aol.com) writes on social policy and has
testified before both the US Senate and the House about his work.


Copyright  2003 The Nation



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

In-Reply-To: <BAY1-F90osA91E9GQvn00085c47@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0306170939100.27953-100000@gere.odin.pdx.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ~*PULSE*~ FRIDAY.AUGUST.8th.2003 (*TWO ROOMS* w/13
 DJs)(XTORT)*BSP*


Now, I'm not going to go out of my way to defend anyone. Especially the
kinds of krewes that throw 20, 30 dollar parties.

But why is everyone so afraid of a little cheese?

I'll be the first to admit -- my loves at intelligent d&b and nice, hard,
banging techno. I've never been immensely into the foofoo trance, nor do I
enjoy most house for a party atmosphere. To give you some idea, the
majority of 'lounge house', to me, belongs in a chill room or somethin --
everybody on the dance floor should be jumping up and down and howling
like wild monkeys if they aren't dancing. If they can't dance, they should
just do what I do gnaw on a wild dog for a few hours before a party, and
flail about in a rabid haze.

But you know what? I went to a foofoo cheese trance party the other day.
I distinctly remember a number of washing audial breakdowns. Cheesy
synths. THe occasional boppy, poppy beat. And you know what?

It was actually kinda nice.

No wangsters doing the ah so fresh to deep house. Very few people just
chilling in a back room all night. Those kids danced, and they danced
until about 4 in the morning. If the music hadn't gotten weak, they
probably would have kept dancing.

Sure, the music got cheesy. Yes, I distinctly remember a couple of big
name local trance DJs grinning like fools and totally playing the crowd's
loveyfluffiness and silly optimism.

But don't you guys remember partying 5 years ago, and being the
optimistic, lovey fluffy (albeit occasionally -- benefit of the doubt,
here; occasionally -- etarded) kiddies? Who weren't ashamed of enjoying a
little cheese?

This isn't directed at you, specifically, Macadio -- it's an overall
attitude i've noticed. A certain level of cynicism that underlies a large
portion of the local community, be it at a more subtle level in some than
others. Yeah, sure, it isn't '95 any more. But isn't it being '03 good
enough?

</rant>

The Rational Hatter

Subject: (BSP) Estuary - Monday June 30th

------=_NextPart_000_0033_01C334CE.DC8EA8B0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Estuary: (Noun) 1. Where the river blends with the sea.  2. A place =
where all styles mix.

    Ever since Ascension died, I have missed having a weekly spot to =
meet cool people, hear great music and dance my ass off. We want to give =
back the things we love about the scene.=20

    Every Monday from 9pm-1am we will have 1/2 hour open deck slots. =
Sign ups start at 8:30p, first come first served. If you have no skills =
at all, but have some cool tracks that you'd like to share, you are just =
as welcome as anyone else! Please bring needles and headphones. If you =
don't have your own, find a friend to share with!

There will be a weekly special guest featured from 1am-2am.

Opening night is Monday June 30th, 2003
Special guest DJ will be Amber (:CODE/Sister SF)

If you would like to be a featured guest, please email me directly.

Wooden dance floor, outdoor smoking lounge, pool tables, free water, =
drink specials.

21+ With ID, Free

Estuary is brought to you by Happy Devil and the Full Circle Collective

Masse's Nightclub
6180 Stoneridge Mall Drive
Pleasanton - (650) 463-8181
Located near the junction of 580 and 680

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ~*PULSE*~ FRIDAY.AUGUST.8th.2003 (*TWO ROOMS* w/13 DJs)(XTORT)*BSP*



Being able to throw a successful string of events on a monthly (or now,
bimonthly) basis for 4 years solid is not an accomplishment that many
small-level, electronic-based event organizers can claim - Xtort can.
The guy must be doing something right and I think he deserves a bit of
respect for what he's done.  Same DJs at every event?  C'mon now, that
doesn't quite work.  Yes, I'll agree that has resorted to a rather
predictable method of putting certain DJs on rotation and trying to
bring in at least one or two new names on the lineup every other event
or so, but hey it works for him and for the people who choose to go to
his shows on a regular basis.  In a day where events are typically $20,
he keeps his tickets close to the $10 mark, desite the annual increase
in overhead - the guy is definitely not in this thing to make the bank.
Throughout the past 4 years, not a single one of his events has ever
been shutdown by the authorities.  As for his musical tastes - the guy
likes trance of all sorts and he tosses in some techno and dnb when it
fits - but to sum up his events as simply cheesefests for "kids" - well
that's a bit of a flawed generalization.  As for who he books - he books
the people that can pull in a crowd.  Remember, this is Sacramento not
San Francisco and experimentation doesn't go so well up here (a sad, but
true phenomenon I've witnessed throughout the years).  His shows are
small and his tickets prices are low = so maybe he doesn't feel in a
position to experiment with DJs that no-one has heard of.  

On a personal note: if the guy was a chode, then there's no way he would
be getting as much support from me for as long as he has.  I've been
invited to play at every single Xtort event since 1999 and have chosen
to play at all with the exception of one.  This support comes from a
well-respected, non-cheese-slinging, 30-something year old DJ who has
played for a most diverse and respected list of event organizers from
all over: from the deep-level underground, to clubs to massives to
events attented to by predominately younger individuals to parties who's
age median is within my own age group.  What is it that some of you see
that I'm missing?  How am I able to maintain a generally non-jaded,
open-minded attitude whilst the world around me melts into a sea of
jaded bitterness?  Perhaps I see each event for what it is and my being
involved in such a diverse pool of organizations has helped me keep a
positive outlook on things.  All I know is that I actually have fun at
Xtort events and this party on Aug. 8th is no exception.  They won't be
around forever, none of this will, so I say enjoy what you can while
it's still there to enjoy and if you can't, then damn, I'm sorry.

Well that's enough ranting from me... Holy smokes!

The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that he favors =
the development of technology that would remotely destroy the computers =
of people who illegally download music from the web. Republican Senator =
Orrin Hatch, (quite the established musician himself) noted during a =
hearing on copyright abuses that destroying the PC's of illegal file =
traders "may be the only way you can teach somebody about copyrights".=20

Hatch apparently supports a technology that would warn offenders twice, =
then on a third offense send their PC's to digital oblivion. "If we can =
find some way to do this without destroying their machines, we'd be =
interested in hearing about that," the Senator suggests. "If that's the =
only way, then I'm all for destroying their machines. If you have a few =
hundred thousand of those, I think people would realize" the error of =
their ways.

http://arstechnica.infopop.net/OpenTopic/page?a=tpc
<http://arstechnica.infopop.net/OpenTopic/page?a=tpc&s=50009562&f=174096
756&m=5720909075&r=5720909075>
&s=50009562&f=174096756&m=5720909075&r=5720909075
 
The following is a transcript from orin hatch about his desire to let
record companies nuke and destroy people's computers for copyright
infringement.  If this guy isn't bought and paid for by the RIAA, I
don't know who is.
 
"I'm interested," Hatch interrupted. He said damaging someone's computer
"may be the only way you can teach somebody about copyrights." 
The senator acknowledged Congress would have to enact an exemption for
copyright owners from liability for damaging computers. He endorsed
technology that would twice warn a computer user about illegal online
behavior, "then destroy their computer." 
"If we can find some way to do this without destroying their machines,
we'd be interested in hearing about that," Hatch said. "If that's the
only way, then I'm all for destroying their machines. If you have a few
hundred thousand of those, I think people would realize" the seriousness
of their actions, he said. 
"There's no excuse for anyone violating copyright laws," Hatch said.

At 06:36 PM 6/17/2003 -0700, Dan Haskovec wrote:
>You seem to be saying that the kinds of products we buy and services we
>use is the predominant factor in defining who we are. Do you think that's
>true?
>
>
>On Tue, 17 Jun 2003, max phillips wrote:
>
> >  Well... he's kind of right in a way, I mean, right now the US thinks it
> > rules the world or is trying to rule the world. Walmart, Mc Donalds,
> > Starbucks, Coors beer and Chevys are all over Canada, so Canada might as
> > well be part of the US.
> >  Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^


Some people do.  Take a look at Alissa Quart's "Branded: The Buying and=20
Selling of Teenagers" (Perseus, 2003).  Or...

One Mom's Struggle with Brand Mania

By Nandini Pandya, AlterNet
June 17, 2003

When she was 10 years old, my daughter wanted to buy underwear at Limited=20
Too. I just did not get it. "Why does the brand of your underwear matter?"=
=20
I asked her.

"Because," she said, as if explaining the most obvious fact to a child, "my=
=20
friends can see the name on the band and know that even my underwear is=20
from Limited Too."

I still did not get it. "Why would the top of your underwear show?"

"Mommy, when I sit down, my jeans get pulled down slightly and it shows.=20
Or, when I raise up my arms, my shirt gets pulled up and it can show then=20
too." Of course, this opened another can of worms in my mind. Why is my=20
10-year-old daughter wearing clothes that just barely cover her body? But=20
that, as they say, is another story.

It is now four years later and I think I have learned the motivations=20
behind this brand-name mania. More important, I have learned things about=20
myself and I have learned how to teach her some of the values that I hold=20
dear.

To a teenage girl of today, using brand-name merchandise is like carrying=20
important universally recognized credentials. It tells the world that she=20
can afford this stuff, that she uses only the "best" and that she is way=20
above using ordinary discount store merchandise. (Brand awareness is so=20
pervasive that even teachers are not immune =96 a science problem was worded=
=20
this way: A poor person must decide whether to buy store brand cereal or=20
brand name cereal.)

As a caring, understanding parent I try to provide her with things that are=
=20
considered standard issue. So, her backpack is from L.L. Bean ($55) instead=
=20
of one from Bradlees ($20); her bathing suit is Speedo ($30) instead of one=
=20
from Kmart ($15). Clothes are bought at one of these stores: American=20
Eagle, Abercrombie and Fitch, Gap, Old Navy. If they are bought at stores=20
like JCPenney or Sears, they are not the store brand like Arizona or Canyon=
=20
River Blues =96 they must be L.E.I or Calvin Klein or a comparable=
 well-known=20
label. Shoes must be Nike, Adidas etc. ($50) as opposed to those from=20
Payless ($15). (During the "Back To School" purchasing spree last=20
September, Payless was empty and the store selling brand-name shoes was=20
packed!)

The peer pressure is brutal and relentless. On one occasion, she noted that=
=20
two of her friends were wearing what looked like identical pants.=20
Immediately, one of them said, "but mine are Ralph Lauren." This happened=20
with a group of girls who are her "best friends" or even "BFFs =96 Best=20
Friends Forever. Clearly, when it comes to brand names all other loyalties=
=20
are forgotten. I shudder to think how much worse it gets when she is not=20
with her BFFs. Another time, she admired her friend's pea coat and=20
mentioned that she might buy one at Costco. The comeback? "I doubt it is a=
=20
real pea coat. Mine cost $300!"

Purchasing decisions are governed by how the item will "play" among her=20
friends. She knows that she will be asked, "Where did you buy it?" She has=
=20
paid what I consider exorbitant prices for otherwise ordinary T-shirts just=
=20
because they have a Reebok logo, or a "cute" quip such as "Girls Rule" or=20
"Princess." She bought a metal lunchbox with a 60s-style design for $15 and=
=20
raved to me about how many compliments she gets because of it. The problem=
=20
is that she hardly ever took lunch from home before getting the lunch box=20
and, after buying the lunch box she took lunch from home for only as long=20
as the lunch box was a novelty.

What happens to a child who does not have the requisite brand-name=20
merchandise? Well she is considered a reject, not quite "A List" material.=
=20
Not that the child is aware of all this in any explicit way. All she knows=
=20
is that she "needs" these labels to be taken seriously by her peers. A low=
=20
point was when my daughter was reluctant to go to K-Mart because someone=20
from school might be there. My point that she would not be harmed by being=
=20
seen by someone from school because that someone from school would also=20
have to be shopping at K-Mart was lost on her.

Strategies for Sanity

As a caring, understanding parent I worry about what this slavish devotion=
=20
to brand names does to my pocket book and to her morality. After almost=20
four years of this type of brand-name awareness in our home, I have=20
developed some strategies.

First, she gets a monthly allowance of $20. She must pay for all her=20
discretionary purchases out of this money. That includes paying for=20
lip-gloss, hair accessories and even candy/soda at the movies. This has=20
given birth to an interesting phenomenon. When she wants some knick-knack,=
=20
she tries to convince me to buy it for her. It's like thinking "better if I=
=20
can get it with mom's money than with mine!" After a few false starts, I=20
have learned to be steadfast in my refusal. Then she thinks really hard=20
about getting it. She still buys items that I consider frivolous or=20
extravagant. But now there is an automatic cap on these indulgences and=20
without much aggravation for me.

Second, she gets a mutually agreed-upon budget for clothes at the beginning=
=20
of the school year and she must choose her mix of brand-name/discount brand=
=20
purchases to fit this budget. (We have not been very successful at this=20
because she has "needed" additional clothes throughout the year =96 either=
=20
because they "fell apart," got stains from spills, or she outgrew them.)

Third, I have tried to teach her to ask herself three questions before=20
making a purchase: 1) Do I need it? 2) Can I afford it? 3) Is it worth the=
=20
money?

I cannot say that this last has met with a great deal of success. But, I am=
=20
hopeful that over time it will teach her valuable skills about managing her=
=20
wants and needs.

Finally, I have taught her to keep her guard up even with BFFs when it=20
comes to brand-name mania. It is OK to tell white lies - "I bought it at=20
Bobs" (Bob's is one of the "in" stores); "I don't remember how much I=20
paid"; "It was a gift from an aunt." And, if she feels particularly brave,=
=20
laugh it off and say, "What is it with you and brand names? Jeez! Can we=20
talk about something else?!"

Spending Style

Growing up in Bombay in the 60s and 70s "spending style" was not an issue.=
=20
Kids wore what the parents bought them, took out the hem when pants/skirts=
=20
became too short, sewed on buttons when they fell off, and thought nothing=
=20
of using hand-me-downs. This was because of necessity, of course. But it=20
was also because the culture was one of minimalism =96 why get more when one=
=20
can make do with less?

Also, the pervasive presence of multitudes of people managing with much=20
less and doing it with grace was enough to put an end to any ideas of false=
=20
grandeur and pretense. Another important factor was an understanding of=20
delayed gratification. I knew that I should-would-could allow myself all=20
the indulgences that I might desire when I came into my own =96 after=
 getting=20
a good education, a good job and becoming both financially and emotionally=
=20
autonomous. In fact, to this end, it was very important to do well at=20
school and the good grades that I achieved were my brand!

When I explain all this to my daughter (where I am coming from, so to=20
speak), she tries to understand. And I think she does, in her own way. It=20
took quite a bit of explaining to convince her that my family in India was=
=20
not poor or struggling or cheap. It has taken a lot more explaining to=20
convince her of the need to put in the effort needed to produce brand-name=
=20
quality =96 whether it is doing schoolwork, doing household chores or=
 keeping=20
her room clean.

Yesterday she said to me "If I were you, I would use a Gucci leather purse=
=20
and not this thing that you bought at Sears." I told her that if I had $50=
=20
to buy a purse, I would spend half of that on a purse, save a fourth and=20
give a fourth to charity. She just rolled her eyes.

Nandini Pandya is the publisher of DesiJournal.com, a website about life in=
=20
the Indian Diaspora. She lives in Connecticut with her husband and their=20
two children.





>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is=
=20
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to=20
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great=20
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in=
=20
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of=20
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the=20
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

From the creators of METROPOLIS...

Clockwork invites you to join us, as we ignite the long anticipated 5TH 
ANNUAL

ATLANTiS 2003 
An Aquatic Underworld Beyond Your Imagination 
Saturday JULY 19th, 2003


* Richmond Civic Auditorium 403 Richmond Civic Center Plza, Richmond, CA
* 8 Hours of Musical Mayhem (6PM-2AM )
* 4 Boomin' Dance Arenas
* Featuring the Illest International &Local DJ's, on the Planet&
* Exotic GoGo Dancers,
* Theatrical Stage designs by: ArtVark/Clockwork
* Amazing Earth Circus Performers, 
* Friendly and Helpful Security, 
* Tribal drum circles, Eco-conscious booths, Tribal Faire with tattoos and 
body piercing, 
* Aromatherapy and massage, arts and crafts, carnival performers, CD Music 
giveaways all night long and many more surprises



::AREA 1::
TEMPLE OF BOOM
(FunkyHouse/TechHouse):

Always, PLURified peeps, Cultureized beats, Positive Vibes and Collective 
Tribes. The events we envision can only be possible because of your support. And 
because of you, we have collectively made a stance to keep the electronic 
music scene alive today. We are only one part in a growing Phenomenon of Music and 
Dance that is forever getting stronger, more artistic and culturally diverse. 
Please remember that this is your party, your music, your scene. Be 
Responsible and Dance till the sun comes up.

BUY PRESALE!! THIS EVENT WILL SELL OUT!!! Buy your tickets early, Save Green, 
and secure you and your friends guaranteed entry inside Atlantis.

Buy only from listed outlets, beware of forgeries!

Once those Sell Out, Tickets will then be $30.

not everyone gets to be in charge. being in charge is a big job. i don't want to be in charge of anyone else, not because i am lazy, but because i am not into that kind of job. regardless of your position, you have to sort of just do what you have to do to get around people who want to be in charge who also think that being in charge means that you know how they feel at every single moment and exactly what words they need in the second, what smells, what foods and everything else they personally require. not everyone in charge is like that, but lots of times, people are after that sort of thing and they think that putting that sort of thing out there will make them feel more powerful or something like that, but really, all they get is madder than they were when you didn't guess their instantaneous needs right the first time. president bush isn't like that, thank god. :)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: help elect a President who is against the Drug War


I'm going to apologize in advance for what might
be considered political spam, but I really think
it's important that the rave communities around
the US become aware of Dennis Kucinich.  Kucinich
is the only major party political candidate for
President who has taken a firm stand against the
War on Drugs.

If the rave communities want a President who will
scale back the War on Drugs, then it is critical
that Dennis Kucinich get the Democratic Party's
nomination for the Presidency in 2004.  One thing
that will help Kucinich achieve this is the support
of an organization called Move On, which will give
a lot of money and exposure to the candidate that
Move On members like the most.

Move On members will be voting on candidates next
week.  I urge you to sign up as a Move On member
(which is free) today, so that you can vote in
Move On's election next week.  You can do this by
going to this URL: http://www.moveon.org/pac/reg/

Here is Kucinich's stand on the War on Drugs:

"A safe, free and just America is undermined, not
bolstered, by the costly and ineffective War on
Drugs.  While well-intentioned, this misguided
policy -- which emphasizes criminalization over
treatment -- has led to increased violent crime,
misdirected resources of law enforcement and
restricted Constitutional liberties.  Despite
billions spent yearly on the drug war, addiction
is up.  Our country must rethink a policy that
produces many casualties, but benefits only the
prison-industrial complex.  Non-violent drug
offenders often receive Draconian sentences,
tearing apart families."

The rest of Kucinich's platform can be summed up
with these 10 key points:

- Universal Health Care with a Single Payer Plan
- Full Social Security Benefits at Age 65
- Withdrawal from NAFTA and WTO
- Repeal of the "Patriot Act"
- Right-to-Choose, Privacy, and Civil Rights
- Balance Between Workers and Corporations
- A Renewed Commitment to Peace and Diplomacy
- Restored Rural Communities and Family Farms
- Environmental Renewal and Clean Energy

These points are talked about in more detail at
this URL:
http://www.kucinich.us/issues/issue_10key.htm

_________________________________________________________________

http://join.msn.com/?page=features/junkmail

I am not going to re post the whole branding thing cuz it was long, but my response:
WTF!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I mean, I love fashion, probably more than most people, but GOD!
My pea Coat from sal. army in brighton mi:$2
MY powerpuff girls tank top: $3.99 big lots
MY KIKwear:$5 at marshals clearance
MY ANT Industrial Design backpack:$10 at sample sale
MY "I'm friendly" shirt: $ 6 at anchor blue clearance

That girl should get a JOB!
Or better yet LEARN TO SEW.
This branding crap didn't make sence to me in high school and it makes LESS SENCE TO ME NOW. I shopped at DEB and RAVE and "Sally Ann's" and Yard sales and vintage stores and big lots. Now vintage stores have gotten overpriced... dont get me started on that one! Plus I made my own clothes. I haven't been able to do that for a couple years because of a bad shoulder injury.
Anyway, I am really sick. who gave me MONO at QS?

                          |
            San Francisco | SHOW US YOUR SKILLS
           This Wednesday |
                June 18th | KEM
                          | TOM SLIK
                          | DENISE
_________________________________________________________

This weeks Elastiq is sure to please with an all-star line up
planned to devestate the dancefloor.  Kem will be opening up with
flavorful house grooves, followed by Tom Slik playing a special
old school set to show us his roots (not to be missed!).  Last
but certainly not least will be Denise laying down the FUNK
extra thick.

_ TOM SLIK ____________________________________________

Co-founder of Skills, Tom has been very busy the last six years
creating the reknown Skills events and opening Skills DJ Workshop
in Berkeley which quickly grew to be one of the Bay's #1 record
stores.  In the studio Tom has been cranking out releases for his
own label Skills Recordings as well as for Dancing Spirit and
even an acclaimed track on the legendary Tinrib Recordings.  When
hes not busy jet setting to  Germany to write tracks with Steve
Baltes, Tom maintains a steady DJ schedule playing at the top
events around the country.

http://www.skillsdjworkshop.com

_ DENISE _____________________________________________

Since the moment she first touched the tables on that
unforgettable day in '98, Denise has never been able to envision
another fate but DJing. In this world of divas, she stands out as
an original with the talent to go far. She doesn't do it for the
fame; she does it because she loves to make people happy through
music. Thousands of fans can attest: it's working so far!

email: denise@djdenise.com
http://www.djdenise.com

_________________________________________________________

                  Every Wednesday @ Il Pirata
              2007 16th Street @ Potrero Ave
                10pm - 2am, age 21+, only $2 cover
          Full bar, Great people, Comfy atmosphere

                 massage oil for your ears
             caffeine for your cerebral cortex
       [ house | tribal | tech-house | progressive ]

              With residents Joseph Lee, Kem,
             Zeel, Telene, plus weekly guests.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] solstice again..cause I'm dumb ;)

I hear ya girl.

It's like I always used to say:  I did the bulk of my shopping at Hot Topic. 
But I did most of my BUYING on ebay, from people who shopLIFTED at Hot Topic.

I got most of my "raver clothes" online from ebay, usually complete with tags
and everything!  And I get most of my "normal clothes" from the good old
standby: Ross.  

I mean:  I understand wanting to look nice and all.  And I do keep an eye out
for good looking clothes.  But I favor the right style FAR more than the
"right" designer.  And I've never gotten the whole "in season" thing.  I mean.
god forbid that the khackis that I wear to work, or the cargo pants in which
I'm going to sit on a nasty-ass floor at a rave, are *last* season's style.

I gotta disagree on the backpack tho.  As many el-cheapo
self-destruct-o-backpacks as I went through in elementary and middle school
before I convinced my mom to let me spend my own money on my first Jansport
backpack (which proceeded to last for something like six years, that streach
ending only because it was stolen); I've become quite the believer that, in
SOME, cases, you really DO get what you pay for.  I put a good $30 into my
current backpack; but it has lasted me almost three years now; wheras in
elementary and middle school, I'd go through at least three PER year.

The trick is, of course, figureing out when that extra 50% cost gets you heavy
canvas and quadruple stiches, and when it gets you nothing more than a patch
with a tommy hillfugger logo on it.


cya,
john

From: max phillips <teknobuddha@juno.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to me!

  I agree, Sadam is, or was a first class thug, but again I have to
remind well meaning "patriotic" people one more time, like they are in
some hypnotic trance and need to wake up from it, that Sadam wouldn't
have been where he was without the USA. We put him in power to counteract
a Leftist government we didn't like, we gave him the WMDs, we gave him
the helicopter to spray the Kurds and knew about it. Back in 90 I think,
or the late 80's, Donald Rumsfeld was sucking up to Sadam. He was our
friend back then (when he was busy brutalizing and gassing his people)
because he was Iran's enemy. We turned against Sadam when he wanted to
nationalize Iraqi oil and when he invaded Kuwait, a Provence of Iraq
stolen from Iraq to set up a puppet regime to have access to oil. Kuwait
was stealing oil from Iraq and the US blocked any efforts for Iraq to get
justice. Why all the concern about him now?
  To be blunt, patriotic Americans and their honest but dumbed down
patriotism have been played on big time by Bush. Bush, along with most of
his neo conservative, religious fundamentalist (religious fascism) or
Ayan Rand's Objectionist (secular fascism)  cronies, nearly all of them
draft dodgers who are so willing to put our troops, most of them kids of
color and poor white kids in so called "wars of liberation" i.e.
"Operation Iraqi Freedom", but when it came for them to show their
patriotism in their youth, had their daddies fix their military
conscription. Bush/Blair fabricated intelligence about Sadam's WMDs and
the truth is coming out. Are you hearing what Blair's former cabinet
ministers are saying? It's interesting to hear what kind of lies they are
telling us to cover their previous lies. 
  Bush and his posy are the real traitors and need to be impeached and
tried as war criminals, right along with Milosivich. If you think the war
is outrageous, thanks to this tax cut (how do you justify millionaires
getting $91,000 and up refunds), the capitalist are doing to America what
they did to Russia when the Soviet Union collapsed. They came in and
cleaned out the country of it's wealth and left the country poor,
starving and controlled by the Mafia. this tax cut is legalized
embezzlement of our, not their wealth.
  Many Americans can't come to grips with the fact that America is not a
divine country, no more blessed than any other country, our prayers and
provocations for god to bless the USA is no more answered that any other
prayer or provocation to a divinity another country may invoke. Our god
is no better than someone else's god. We are so blinded by the red white
and blue that we become bewildered when the rest of the world doesn't
agree with our "divine destiny" illusion and when we act it out in the
world, like a vain girl who can't understand why not everyone thinks
she's not all that.  We become extremely enraged when someone dares to
point out the reality that we are not as pure and holy as we try to
constantly make believe we are with our obsessive and cult like
patriotism. We can't and will not believe we can do no wrong and we
refuse to believe that we can be as brutal and fascist as anyone else.
When we do things that the world condemns us on, it can't be wrong
because the America did it? And since we are so "blessed by god", how can
anything we do be wrong? Listen to dumbed down Americans when they loose
the debate on Bush and faced with the truth about the Iraqi war and it
quickly descends into charges of being unpatriotic and un American, ugly
name calling, threats and character assignation, and the worse of all
when you can't defend Bush and his war anymore; "but we got rid of
Sadam!"  There are two untouchables in America you dare not speak up
against; god (the official version and manipulation of god) and American
Values.  There is a Hitler, Stalin, Sadam, Mugabe, Kim IL potential in
all of us. What is bringing us down to their level is our
pompous/supremist attitude about ourselves and our denial that we can go
and have many times gone that low.
  We may think we "liberated" Iraq, but the only people who believe that
is us. The Iraqis don't think so. We trashed their country to get to a
toothless dictator who was no threat to it's neighbors or especially to
the US, all to get to the oil supply. His WMD's (again, supplied by the
US) was destroyed and verified. We scowled the country and haven't found
a thing. Bush and doggy style Blair said they had evidence and knew where
the WMDs were. Remember the lie about Sadam trying to purchase plutonium
from Africa? Even Sadam's scientist with all the bribes we give them
can't come up with them, neither can the captured government leaders tell
them where something that doesn't exist is. Where are they? What was the
reason to go to war premised on lies?
  Our troops are being ambushed and killed everyday by people who are
telling us that we are not liberators and that they want us out. On the
other hand, reports are coming out about racist attitudes toward Iraqis
and condescending views toward Islam by US troops, house searches where
families are thrown down to the ground with M-16's pointed at their heads
and women being disrespected, that US troops are firing on mostly
peaceful demonstrations, mostly about pay and needed services, and
killing a whole bunch of people for exercising a right we will loose
under Patriot Act II, and much of this is fueling the drive by's on US
troops. Many are saying US troops are beginning to act like Israeli
soldiers in regards to the Palestinians. 
  I don't blame the troops, they are canon fotter and expendable labor
for the rich and powerful. Because most of the NCOs came from shitty
schools in the first place and join the military to get an education,
they are not as educated and this situation being taken advantaged of by
those who give them orders and believe what they are being told by the
draft dodgers back in Washington and the elitist educated military
officers.
  Afghanistan is a disaster. Our puppet leader Karzi only rules Kabul,
nothing much outside of the city limits. The warlords are in control
again, women are getting beaten up again, heroin production is blossoming
again and where is American concern? Where's Afghanistan's liberation? We
say Iran, North Korea, Syria are the axis of evil, what about Myamar
(Burma) and it's brutal military dictatorship who abducts people to work
as slave labor to build roads and resorts for the tourists? What about
Zimbabwe where Mugabe is putting into prison dissidents on the charges of
treason and being responsible for the starvation of millions of his
people? What about Nigeria who guns down protestors by the request of oil
companies like Shell/Texaco who are protesting their land being taken
away and their land and water being poisoned by companies like
Shell/Texaco? Where's the concern for China where much of the products
imported here were made by slave prison labor, where prisoners have their
kidneys and other body parts forcibly taken out to be sold on the organ
donor market? shall I mention what they are doing to Tibet?
  As bad as Sadam was, he was no worse than ruthless people we support
and are not on our axis of evil list. They are not "evil" because we can
exploit and control. Under Sadam, Iraqis had one of the highest standard
of living in the middle east until we started to enforce and embargo, and
killed hundreds of thousands of it's people, mostly children, with hunger
and dysentery. Iraqis had a liberal/secular government that was actually
more free than our friends in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Jordan and Egypt,
with free education and health care to all it's citizens. Women could
vote, get educated, drive a car and choose to wear the berka or not in
Sadam's Iraq. Iraqis remember the better days and wonder how destroying
their country and leaving them in ruins like we did in Afghanistan is
liberating them?
  With schools closing, people loosing their jobs, health care being cut,
our infrastructure falling apart, the rich stealing the country's wealth,
the Anti Rave/Crack house laws, people going to jail for 20 years to life
for growing pot for the sick, our computers being snooped on, me possibly
getting into serious trouble from Ashcroft's Justice Department for this
post, and loosing my citizenship and being deported to Guantanamo Bay for
dissenting under Patriot Act II, in my personal opinion, we need to
liberate ourselves before we become "liberators" of others. Regime change
begins at home first.
  But if Americans continue to believe and stand behind Bush and refuse
to unwrap themselves from the small world of the red, white and blue and
continue to live in "god bless America" denial, then we will get the
government we deserve. I will shed no crocodile tears when fascism comes
to our concerts, clubs and raves, our homes and in our personal lives.
When enough Americans become "losers" in our emerging Darwinian, compete
or be left behind ethos, and loose their jobs and end up living in homes
made up of scrap metal and cardboard boxes like our neighbors in the
south, while the rich with their tax cuts build million dollar homes up
in the hills, maybe we will have an uprising then. But then it may be too
late. 
  This isn't a "left" or "right" issue, this is way beyond names and
labels. This has absolutely nothing to do with being "liberal" or
"conservative", this is all to do about fascism and a government that are
predators, and not only prey on defenseless countries around the world,
but ignorant Americans and patriotism. These people are no more honorable
than the Benny Hinns and Pat Robertsons of fundamentalist Christianity
who prey on the ignorance and fear of good honest people.
  To get our freedom back then may take a lot of blood letting on the
streets and sacrificing, like what women, labor, people of color and gays
did to secure a place in the Bill of Rights and the constitution. But
with our addiction to fear and materialism and with plenty of diversions
to keep us dumb and pacified, we may not be up to the challenge and
become the most pitied people that ever existed.
 To be a Bush supporter and to be a raver still sounds like s&m to me!
 Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

> is outrageous, thanks to this tax cut (how do you justify millionaires
> getting $91,000 and up refunds), the capitalist are doing to America what
> they did to Russia when the Soviet Union collapsed. They came in and
> cleaned out the country of it's wealth and left the country poor,
> starving and controlled by the Mafia. this tax cut is legalized
> embezzlement of our, not their wealth.

I got 4,000 back for a tax refund. I got 3,200 back last year. I made 
about the same amount of money too. I'm kinda happy about the tax cut, 
and I'm not going to complain this year.

>   Many Americans can't come to grips with the fact that America is not a
> divine country, no more blessed than any other country, our prayers and

Subject: [sfraves] BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to me!

  I agree, Sadam is, or was a first class thug, but again I have to
remind well meaning "patriotic" people one more time, like they are in
some hypnotic trance and need to wake up from it, that Sadam wouldn't
have been where he was without the USA. We put him in power to
counteract
a Leftist government we didn't like, we gave him the WMDs, we gave him
the helicopter to spray the Kurds and knew about it. Back in 90 I think,
or the late 80's, Donald Rumsfeld was sucking up to Sadam. He was our
friend back then (when he was busy brutalizing and gassing his people)
because he was Iran's enemy. We turned against Sadam when he wanted to
nationalize Iraqi oil and when he invaded Kuwait, a Provence of Iraq
stolen from Iraq to set up a puppet regime to have access to oil. Kuwait
was stealing oil from Iraq and the US blocked any efforts for Iraq to
get
justice. Why all the concern about him now?
  To be blunt, patriotic Americans and their honest but dumbed down
patriotism have been played on big time by Bush. Bush, along with most
of
his neo conservative, religious fundamentalist (religious fascism) or
Ayan Rand's Objectionist (secular fascism)  cronies, nearly all of them
draft dodgers who are so willing to put our troops, most of them kids of
color and poor white kids in so called "wars of liberation" i.e.
"Operation Iraqi Freedom", but when it came for them to show their
patriotism in their youth, had their daddies fix their military
conscription. Bush/Blair fabricated intelligence about Sadam's WMDs and
the truth is coming out. Are you hearing what Blair's former cabinet
ministers are saying? It's interesting to hear what kind of lies they
are
telling us to cover their previous lies. 
  Bush and his posy are the real traitors and need to be impeached and
tried as war criminals, right along with Milosivich. If you think the
war
is outrageous, thanks to this tax cut (how do you justify millionaires
getting $91,000 and up refunds), the capitalist are doing to America
what
they did to Russia when the Soviet Union collapsed. They came in and
cleaned out the country of it's wealth and left the country poor,
starving and controlled by the Mafia. this tax cut is legalized
embezzlement of our, not their wealth.
  Many Americans can't come to grips with the fact that America is not a
divine country, no more blessed than any other country, our prayers and
provocations for god to bless the USA is no more answered that any other
prayer or provocation to a divinity another country may invoke. Our god
is no better than someone else's god. We are so blinded by the red white
and blue that we become bewildered when the rest of the world doesn't
agree with our "divine destiny" illusion and when we act it out in the
world, like a vain girl who can't understand why not everyone thinks
she's not all that.  We become extremely enraged when someone dares to
point out the reality that we are not as pure and holy as we try to
constantly make believe we are with our obsessive and cult like
patriotism. We can't and will not believe we can do no wrong and we
refuse to believe that we can be as brutal and fascist as anyone else.
When we do things that the world condemns us on, it can't be wrong
because the America did it? And since we are so "blessed by god", how
can
anything we do be wrong? Listen to dumbed down Americans when they loose
the debate on Bush and faced with the truth about the Iraqi war and it
quickly descends into charges of being unpatriotic and un American, ugly
name calling, threats and character assignation, and the worse of all
when you can't defend Bush and his war anymore; "but we got rid of
Sadam!"  There are two untouchables in America you dare not speak up
against; god (the official version and manipulation of god) and American
Values.  There is a Hitler, Stalin, Sadam, Mugabe, Kim IL potential in
all of us. What is bringing us down to their level is our
pompous/supremist attitude about ourselves and our denial that we can go
and have many times gone that low.
  We may think we "liberated" Iraq, but the only people who believe that
is us. The Iraqis don't think so. We trashed their country to get to a
toothless dictator who was no threat to it's neighbors or especially to
the US, all to get to the oil supply. His WMD's (again, supplied by the
US) was destroyed and verified. We scowled the country and haven't found
a thing. Bush and doggy style Blair said they had evidence and knew
where
the WMDs were. Remember the lie about Sadam trying to purchase plutonium
from Africa? Even Sadam's scientist with all the bribes we give them
can't come up with them, neither can the captured government leaders
tell
them where something that doesn't exist is. Where are they? What was the
reason to go to war premised on lies?
  Our troops are being ambushed and killed everyday by people who are
telling us that we are not liberators and that they want us out. On the
other hand, reports are coming out about racist attitudes toward Iraqis
and condescending views toward Islam by US troops, house searches where
families are thrown down to the ground with M-16's pointed at their
heads
and women being disrespected, that US troops are firing on mostly
peaceful demonstrations, mostly about pay and needed services, and
killing a whole bunch of people for exercising a right we will loose
under Patriot Act II, and much of this is fueling the drive by's on US
troops. Many are saying US troops are beginning to act like Israeli
soldiers in regards to the Palestinians. 
  I don't blame the troops, they are canon fotter and expendable labor
for the rich and powerful. Because most of the NCOs came from shitty
schools in the first place and join the military to get an education,
they are not as educated and this situation being taken advantaged of by
those who give them orders and believe what they are being told by the
draft dodgers back in Washington and the elitist educated military
officers.
  Afghanistan is a disaster. Our puppet leader Karzi only rules Kabul,
nothing much outside of the city limits. The warlords are in control
again, women are getting beaten up again, heroin production is
blossoming
again and where is American concern? Where's Afghanistan's liberation?
We
say Iran, North Korea, Syria are the axis of evil, what about Myamar
(Burma) and it's brutal military dictatorship who abducts people to work
as slave labor to build roads and resorts for the tourists? What about
Zimbabwe where Mugabe is putting into prison dissidents on the charges
of
treason and being responsible for the starvation of millions of his
people? What about Nigeria who guns down protestors by the request of
oil
companies like Shell/Texaco who are protesting their land being taken
away and their land and water being poisoned by companies like
Shell/Texaco? Where's the concern for China where much of the products
imported here were made by slave prison labor, where prisoners have
their
kidneys and other body parts forcibly taken out to be sold on the organ
donor market? shall I mention what they are doing to Tibet?
  As bad as Sadam was, he was no worse than ruthless people we support
and are not on our axis of evil list. They are not "evil" because we can
exploit and control. Under Sadam, Iraqis had one of the highest standard
of living in the middle east until we started to enforce and embargo,
and
killed hundreds of thousands of it's people, mostly children, with
hunger
and dysentery. Iraqis had a liberal/secular government that was actually
more free than our friends in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Jordan and Egypt,
with free education and health care to all it's citizens. Women could
vote, get educated, drive a car and choose to wear the berka or not in
Sadam's Iraq. Iraqis remember the better days and wonder how destroying
their country and leaving them in ruins like we did in Afghanistan is
liberating them?
  With schools closing, people loosing their jobs, health care being
cut,
our infrastructure falling apart, the rich stealing the country's
wealth,
the Anti Rave/Crack house laws, people going to jail for 20 years to
life
for growing pot for the sick, our computers being snooped on, me
possibly
getting into serious trouble from Ashcroft's Justice Department for this
post, and loosing my citizenship and being deported to Guantanamo Bay
for
dissenting under Patriot Act II, in my personal opinion, we need to
liberate ourselves before we become "liberators" of others. Regime
change
begins at home first.
  But if Americans continue to believe and stand behind Bush and refuse
to unwrap themselves from the small world of the red, white and blue and
continue to live in "god bless America" denial, then we will get the
government we deserve. I will shed no crocodile tears when fascism comes
to our concerts, clubs and raves, our homes and in our personal lives.
When enough Americans become "losers" in our emerging Darwinian, compete
or be left behind ethos, and loose their jobs and end up living in homes
made up of scrap metal and cardboard boxes like our neighbors in the
south, while the rich with their tax cuts build million dollar homes up
in the hills, maybe we will have an uprising then. But then it may be
too
late. 
  This isn't a "left" or "right" issue, this is way beyond names and
labels. This has absolutely nothing to do with being "liberal" or
"conservative", this is all to do about fascism and a government that
are
predators, and not only prey on defenseless countries around the world,
but ignorant Americans and patriotism. These people are no more
honorable
than the Benny Hinns and Pat Robertsons of fundamentalist Christianity
who prey on the ignorance and fear of good honest people.
  To get our freedom back then may take a lot of blood letting on the
streets and sacrificing, like what women, labor, people of color and
gays
did to secure a place in the Bill of Rights and the constitution. But
with our addiction to fear and materialism and with plenty of diversions
to keep us dumb and pacified, we may not be up to the challenge and
become the most pitied people that ever existed.
 To be a Bush supporter and to be a raver still sounds like s&m to me!
 Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

>counteract
>a Leftist government we didn't like, we gave him the WMDs, we gave him
>the helicopter to spray the Kurds and knew about it. Back in 90 I think,

>nationalize Iraqi oil and when he invaded Kuwait, a Provence of Iraq

>was stealing oil from Iraq and the US blocked any efforts for Iraq to
>get
>justice. Why all the concern about him now?

>patriotism have been played on big time by Bush. Bush, along with most
>of
>his neo conservative, religious fundamentalist (religious fascism) or
>Ayan Rand's Objectionist (secular fascism)  cronies, nearly all of them
>draft dodgers who are so willing to put our troops, most of them kids of
>color and poor white kids in so called "wars of liberation" i.e.
>"Operation Iraqi Freedom", but when it came for them to show their
>patriotism in their youth, had their daddies fix their military
>conscription. Bush/Blair fabricated intelligence about Sadam's WMDs and
>the truth is coming out. Are you hearing what Blair's former cabinet
>ministers are saying? It's interesting to hear what kind of lies they
>are
>telling us to cover their previous lies.
>   Bush and his posy are the real traitors and need to be impeached and
>tried as war criminals, right along with Milosivich. If you think the
>war
>is outrageous, thanks to this tax cut (how do you justify millionaires
>getting $91,000 and up refunds), the capitalist are doing to America
>what
>they did to Russia when the Soviet Union collapsed. They came in and
>cleaned out the country of it's wealth and left the country poor,
>starving and controlled by the Mafia. this tax cut is legalized
>embezzlement of our, not their wealth.
>   Many Americans can't come to grips with the fact that America is not a
>divine country, no more blessed than any other country, our prayers and
>provocations for god to bless the USA is no more answered that any other
>prayer or provocation to a divinity another country may invoke. Our god
>is no better than someone else's god. We are so blinded by the red white
>and blue that we become bewildered when the rest of the world doesn't
>agree with our "divine destiny" illusion and when we act it out in the
>world, like a vain girl who can't understand why not everyone thinks
>she's not all that.  We become extremely enraged when someone dares to
>point out the reality that we are not as pure and holy as we try to
>constantly make believe we are with our obsessive and cult like
>patriotism. We can't and will not believe we can do no wrong and we
>refuse to believe that we can be as brutal and fascist as anyone else.
>When we do things that the world condemns us on, it can't be wrong
>because the America did it? And since we are so "blessed by god", how
>can
>anything we do be wrong? Listen to dumbed down Americans when they loose
>the debate on Bush and faced with the truth about the Iraqi war and it
>quickly descends into charges of being unpatriotic and un American, ugly
>name calling, threats and character assignation, and the worse of all
>when you can't defend Bush and his war anymore; "but we got rid of
>Sadam!"  There are two untouchables in America you dare not speak up
>against; god (the official version and manipulation of god) and American
>Values.  There is a Hitler, Stalin, Sadam, Mugabe, Kim IL potential in
>all of us. What is bringing us down to their level is our
>pompous/supremist attitude about ourselves and our denial that we can go
>and have many times gone that low.
>   We may think we "liberated" Iraq, but the only people who believe that
>is us. The Iraqis don't think so. We trashed their country to get to a
>toothless dictator who was no threat to it's neighbors or especially to
>the US, all to get to the oil supply. His WMD's (again, supplied by the
>US) was destroyed and verified. We scowled the country and haven't found
>a thing. Bush and doggy style Blair said they had evidence and knew
>where
>the WMDs were. Remember the lie about Sadam trying to purchase plutonium
>from Africa? Even Sadam's scientist with all the bribes we give them
>can't come up with them, neither can the captured government leaders
>tell
>them where something that doesn't exist is. Where are they? What was the
>reason to go to war premised on lies?
>   Our troops are being ambushed and killed everyday by people who are
>telling us that we are not liberators and that they want us out. On the
>other hand, reports are coming out about racist attitudes toward Iraqis
>and condescending views toward Islam by US troops, house searches where
>families are thrown down to the ground with M-16's pointed at their
>heads
>and women being disrespected, that US troops are firing on mostly
>peaceful demonstrations, mostly about pay and needed services, and
>killing a whole bunch of people for exercising a right we will loose
>under Patriot Act II, and much of this is fueling the drive by's on US
>troops. Many are saying US troops are beginning to act like Israeli
>soldiers in regards to the Palestinians.
>   I don't blame the troops, they are canon fotter and expendable labor
>for the rich and powerful. Because most of the NCOs came from shitty
>schools in the first place and join the military to get an education,
>they are not as educated and this situation being taken advantaged of by
>those who give them orders and believe what they are being told by the
>draft dodgers back in Washington and the elitist educated military
>officers.
>   Afghanistan is a disaster. Our puppet leader Karzi only rules Kabul,
>nothing much outside of the city limits. The warlords are in control
>again, women are getting beaten up again, heroin production is
>blossoming
>again and where is American concern? Where's Afghanistan's liberation?
>We
>say Iran, North Korea, Syria are the axis of evil, what about Myamar
>(Burma) and it's brutal military dictatorship who abducts people to work
>as slave labor to build roads and resorts for the tourists? What about
>Zimbabwe where Mugabe is putting into prison dissidents on the charges
>of
>treason and being responsible for the starvation of millions of his
>people? What about Nigeria who guns down protestors by the request of
>oil
>companies like Shell/Texaco who are protesting their land being taken
>away and their land and water being poisoned by companies like
>Shell/Texaco? Where's the concern for China where much of the products
>imported here were made by slave prison labor, where prisoners have
>their
>kidneys and other body parts forcibly taken out to be sold on the organ
>donor market? shall I mention what they are doing to Tibet?
>   As bad as Sadam was, he was no worse than ruthless people we support
>and are not on our axis of evil list. They are not "evil" because we can
>exploit and control. Under Sadam, Iraqis had one of the highest standard
>of living in the middle east until we started to enforce and embargo,
>and
>killed hundreds of thousands of it's people, mostly children, with
>hunger
>and dysentery. Iraqis had a liberal/secular government that was actually
>more free than our friends in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Jordan and Egypt,
>with free education and health care to all it's citizens. Women could
>vote, get educated, drive a car and choose to wear the berka or not in
>Sadam's Iraq. Iraqis remember the better days and wonder how destroying
>their country and leaving them in ruins like we did in Afghanistan is
>liberating them?
>   With schools closing, people loosing their jobs, health care being
>cut,
>our infrastructure falling apart, the rich stealing the country's
>wealth,
>the Anti Rave/Crack house laws, people going to jail for 20 years to
>life
>for growing pot for the sick, our computers being snooped on, me
>possibly
>getting into serious trouble from Ashcroft's Justice Department for this
>post, and loosing my citizenship and being deported to Guantanamo Bay
>for
>dissenting under Patriot Act II, in my personal opinion, we need to
>liberate ourselves before we become "liberators" of others. Regime
>change
>begins at home first.
>   But if Americans continue to believe and stand behind Bush and refuse
>to unwrap themselves from the small world of the red, white and blue and
>continue to live in "god bless America" denial, then we will get the
>government we deserve. I will shed no crocodile tears when fascism comes
>to our concerts, clubs and raves, our homes and in our personal lives.
>When enough Americans become "losers" in our emerging Darwinian, compete
>or be left behind ethos, and loose their jobs and end up living in homes
>made up of scrap metal and cardboard boxes like our neighbors in the
>south, while the rich with their tax cuts build million dollar homes up
>in the hills, maybe we will have an uprising then. But then it may be
>too
>late.
>   This isn't a "left" or "right" issue, this is way beyond names and
>labels. This has absolutely nothing to do with being "liberal" or
>"conservative", this is all to do about fascism and a government that
>are
>predators, and not only prey on defenseless countries around the world,
>but ignorant Americans and patriotism. These people are no more
>honorable
>than the Benny Hinns and Pat Robertsons of fundamentalist Christianity
>who prey on the ignorance and fear of good honest people.
>   To get our freedom back then may take a lot of blood letting on the
>streets and sacrificing, like what women, labor, people of color and
>gays
>did to secure a place in the Bill of Rights and the constitution. But
>with our addiction to fear and materialism and with plenty of diversions
>to keep us dumb and pacified, we may not be up to the challenge and
>become the most pitied people that ever existed.

That wasn't the mandate of the true international coalition that was
created.  Desert Storm was to liberate Kuwait, that's all.  The coalition
did not want to get rid of Sadam.  And back then, we actually cared about
what the international community wanted.
 
> I got 4,000 back for a tax refund. I got 3,200 back last year. I made 
> about the same amount of money too. I'm kinda happy about the tax cut, 
> and I'm not going to complain this year.

Well great, enjoy that cash now, my friend.  Becuase eventually, all of us
well have to pony up the dough to keep this country running.

Yeah, liberals are tax and spend.  But conservatives are just spend.  
If the Republicans actually cut the services needed to pay for these 
tax cuts, there would be outrage in America.  But instead, they are just
passing the burden off to us, the youth of the nation.  Oh we'll pay.
don't think we won't pay.
 
> Of course, those hundreds of thousands of people he's executed for 
> speaking out against his dictatorship, or the thousands of kurds in 
> northern iraq he used chemical weapons on don't matter. Or even those 
> 300 skeletons of kurds found in boxes in southern iraq, all of which 
> were executed. Nah, it's cool.

America would have never supported a war if Bush billed it as needed
simply to liberate Iraq.  Lets face it, Bush lied to get the country
to War, and thats an impeachable offense if there ever was any.  

If Clinton got impeached for lying about a blowjob, Bush should be to for
lying on why we went to war.

> Anyhow, This is the last time I'm going to respond to this. I hate sound 
> like a dick, but I remember subscribing to sfraves@hyperreal.org, not 
> ihatebush@hyperreal.org.

The national media is bought and payed for by the Republicans.  We have to use
whatever means left to get our viewpoint out.  sorry if we made you think.

-troy

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to me!

{yawn}  do some fact checking will you.

Hussein rose quickly through the ranks, known for his
extreme efficiency as a torturer. He was appointed to
be a member of the Baath Regional Command. In 1964,
Hussein was jailed by some "rightist" military
officers who opposed the Baathist takeover. In 1966 he
"escaped" from prison and Saddam's older cousin,
General Ahmad Hassan al-Bakr, appointed him deputy
Secretary-General of the Baathists.

Saddam set up the Baathist internal party security
system known as the Jihaz Haneen. It was to serve as
the vehicle for his rise to power in Iraq. In 1968,
another major upheaval in Iraq gave Hussein the
greatest opportunity for further advancement; his
mentor, Gen. Bakr and the Baathist seized the
government.

http://www.efreedomnews.com/News%20Archive/Iraq/SpecialReportWaronIraq/SR2RisetoPower.htm
