>they did to Russia when the Soviet Union collapsed. They came in and
>cleaned out the country of it's wealth and left the country poor,
>starving and controlled by the Mafia. this tax cut is legalized
>embezzlement of our, not their wealth.
>   Many Americans can't come to grips with the fact that America is not
a
>divine country, no more blessed than any other country, our prayers and
>provocations for god to bless the USA is no more answered that any
other
>prayer or provocation to a divinity another country may invoke. Our god
>is no better than someone else's god. We are so blinded by the red
white
>and blue that we become bewildered when the rest of the world doesn't
>agree with our "divine destiny" illusion and when we act it out in the
>world, like a vain girl who can't understand why not everyone thinks
>she's not all that.  We become extremely enraged when someone dares to
>point out the reality that we are not as pure and holy as we try to
>constantly make believe we are with our obsessive and cult like
>patriotism. We can't and will not believe we can do no wrong and we
>refuse to believe that we can be as brutal and fascist as anyone else.
>When we do things that the world condemns us on, it can't be wrong
>because the America did it? And since we are so "blessed by god", how
>can
>anything we do be wrong? Listen to dumbed down Americans when they
loose
>the debate on Bush and faced with the truth about the Iraqi war and it
>quickly descends into charges of being unpatriotic and un American,
ugly
>name calling, threats and character assignation, and the worse of all
>when you can't defend Bush and his war anymore; "but we got rid of
>Sadam!"  There are two untouchables in America you dare not speak up
>against; god (the official version and manipulation of god) and
American
>Values.  There is a Hitler, Stalin, Sadam, Mugabe, Kim IL potential in
>all of us. What is bringing us down to their level is our
>pompous/supremist attitude about ourselves and our denial that we can
go
>and have many times gone that low.
>   We may think we "liberated" Iraq, but the only people who believe
that
>is us. The Iraqis don't think so. We trashed their country to get to a
>toothless dictator who was no threat to it's neighbors or especially to
>the US, all to get to the oil supply. His WMD's (again, supplied by the
>US) was destroyed and verified. We scowled the country and haven't
found
>a thing. Bush and doggy style Blair said they had evidence and knew
>where
>the WMDs were. Remember the lie about Sadam trying to purchase
plutonium
>from Africa? Even Sadam's scientist with all the bribes we give them
>can't come up with them, neither can the captured government leaders
>tell
>them where something that doesn't exist is. Where are they? What was
the
>reason to go to war premised on lies?
>   Our troops are being ambushed and killed everyday by people who are
>telling us that we are not liberators and that they want us out. On the
>other hand, reports are coming out about racist attitudes toward Iraqis
>and condescending views toward Islam by US troops, house searches where
>families are thrown down to the ground with M-16's pointed at their
>heads
>and women being disrespected, that US troops are firing on mostly
>peaceful demonstrations, mostly about pay and needed services, and
>killing a whole bunch of people for exercising a right we will loose
>under Patriot Act II, and much of this is fueling the drive by's on US
>troops. Many are saying US troops are beginning to act like Israeli
>soldiers in regards to the Palestinians.
>   I don't blame the troops, they are canon fotter and expendable labor
>for the rich and powerful. Because most of the NCOs came from shitty
>schools in the first place and join the military to get an education,
>they are not as educated and this situation being taken advantaged of
by
>those who give them orders and believe what they are being told by the
>draft dodgers back in Washington and the elitist educated military
>officers.
>   Afghanistan is a disaster. Our puppet leader Karzi only rules Kabul,
>nothing much outside of the city limits. The warlords are in control
>again, women are getting beaten up again, heroin production is
>blossoming
>again and where is American concern? Where's Afghanistan's liberation?
>We
>say Iran, North Korea, Syria are the axis of evil, what about Myamar
>(Burma) and it's brutal military dictatorship who abducts people to
work
>as slave labor to build roads and resorts for the tourists? What about
>Zimbabwe where Mugabe is putting into prison dissidents on the charges
>of
>treason and being responsible for the starvation of millions of his
>people? What about Nigeria who guns down protestors by the request of
>oil
>companies like Shell/Texaco who are protesting their land being taken
>away and their land and water being poisoned by companies like
>Shell/Texaco? Where's the concern for China where much of the products
>imported here were made by slave prison labor, where prisoners have
>their
>kidneys and other body parts forcibly taken out to be sold on the organ
>donor market? shall I mention what they are doing to Tibet?
>   As bad as Sadam was, he was no worse than ruthless people we support
>and are not on our axis of evil list. They are not "evil" because we
can
>exploit and control. Under Sadam, Iraqis had one of the highest
standard
>of living in the middle east until we started to enforce and embargo,
>and
>killed hundreds of thousands of it's people, mostly children, with
>hunger
>and dysentery. Iraqis had a liberal/secular government that was
actually
>more free than our friends in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Jordan and Egypt,
>with free education and health care to all it's citizens. Women could
>vote, get educated, drive a car and choose to wear the berka or not in
>Sadam's Iraq. Iraqis remember the better days and wonder how destroying
>their country and leaving them in ruins like we did in Afghanistan is
>liberating them?
>   With schools closing, people loosing their jobs, health care being
>cut,
>our infrastructure falling apart, the rich stealing the country's
>wealth,
>the Anti Rave/Crack house laws, people going to jail for 20 years to
>life
>for growing pot for the sick, our computers being snooped on, me
>possibly
>getting into serious trouble from Ashcroft's Justice Department for
this
>post, and loosing my citizenship and being deported to Guantanamo Bay
>for
>dissenting under Patriot Act II, in my personal opinion, we need to
>liberate ourselves before we become "liberators" of others. Regime
>change
>begins at home first.
>   But if Americans continue to believe and stand behind Bush and
refuse
>to unwrap themselves from the small world of the red, white and blue
and
>continue to live in "god bless America" denial, then we will get the
>government we deserve. I will shed no crocodile tears when fascism
comes
>to our concerts, clubs and raves, our homes and in our personal lives.
>When enough Americans become "losers" in our emerging Darwinian,
compete
>or be left behind ethos, and loose their jobs and end up living in
homes
>made up of scrap metal and cardboard boxes like our neighbors in the
>south, while the rich with their tax cuts build million dollar homes up
>in the hills, maybe we will have an uprising then. But then it may be
>too
>late.
>   This isn't a "left" or "right" issue, this is way beyond names and
>labels. This has absolutely nothing to do with being "liberal" or
>"conservative", this is all to do about fascism and a government that
>are
>predators, and not only prey on defenseless countries around the world,
>but ignorant Americans and patriotism. These people are no more
>honorable
>than the Benny Hinns and Pat Robertsons of fundamentalist Christianity
>who prey on the ignorance and fear of good honest people.
>   To get our freedom back then may take a lot of blood letting on the
>streets and sacrificing, like what women, labor, people of color and
>gays
>did to secure a place in the Bill of Rights and the constitution. But
>with our addiction to fear and materialism and with plenty of
diversions
>to keep us dumb and pacified, we may not be up to the challenge and
>become the most pitied people that ever existed.
>  To be a Bush supporter and to be a raver still sounds like s&m to me!

From insrevolution@yahoo.com  Thu Jun 19 18:01:54 2003

max phillips <teknobuddha@juno.com> wrote:
I agree, Sadam is, or was a first class thug, but again I have to
remind well meaning "patriotic" people one more time, like they are in
some hypnotic trance and need to wake up from it, that Sadam wouldn't
have been where he was without the USA. We put him in power to counteract
a Leftist government we didn't like, we gave him the WMDs, we gave him
the helicopter to spray the Kurds and knew about it. Back in 90 I think,
or the late 80's, Donald Rumsfeld was sucking up to Sadam. He was our
friend back then (when he was busy brutalizing and gassing his people)
because he was Iran's enemy. We turned against Sadam when he wanted to
nationalize Iraqi oil and when he invaded Kuwait, a Provence of Iraq
stolen from Iraq to set up a puppet regime to have access to oil. Kuwait
was stealing oil from Iraq and the US blocked any efforts for Iraq to get
justice. Why all the concern about him now?
To be blunt, patriotic Americans and their honest but dumbed down
patriotism have been played on big time by Bush. Bush, along with most of
his neo conservative, religious fundamentalist (religious fascism) or
Ayan Rand's Objectionist (secular fascism) cronies, nearly all of them
draft dodgers who are so willing to put our troops, most of them kids of
color and poor white kids in so called "wars of liberation" i.e.
"Operation Iraqi Freedom", but when it came for them to show their
patriotism in their youth, had their daddies fix their military
conscription. Bush/Blair fabricated intelligence about Sadam's WMDs and
the truth is coming out. Are you hearing what Blair's former cabinet
ministers are saying? It's interesting to hear what kind of lies they are
telling us to cover their previous lies. 
Bush and his posy are the real traitors and need to be impeached and
tried as war criminals, right along with Milosivich. If you think the war
is outrageous, thanks to this tax cut (how do you justify millionaires
getting $91,000 and up refunds), the capitalist are doing to America what
they did to Russia when the Soviet Union collapsed. They came in and
cleaned out the country of it's wealth and left the country poor,
starving and controlled by the Mafia. this tax cut is legalized
embezzlement of our, not their wealth.
Many Americans can't come to grips with the fact that America is not a
divine country, no more blessed than any other country, our prayers and
provocations for god to bless the USA is no more answered that any other
prayer or provocation to a divinity another country may invoke. Our god
is no better than someone else's god. We are so blinded by the red white
and blue that we become bewildered when the rest of the world doesn't
agree with our "divine destiny" illusion and when we act it out in the
world, like a vain girl who can't understand why not everyone thinks
she's not all that. We become extremely enraged when someone dares to
point out the reality that we are not as pure and holy as we try to
constantly make believe we are with our obsessive and cult like
patriotism. We can't and will not believe we can do no wrong and we
refuse to believe that we can be as brutal and fascist as anyone else.
When we do things that the world condemns us on, it can't be wrong
because the America did it? And since we are so "blessed by god", how can
anything we do be wrong? Listen to dumbed down Americans when they loose
the debate on Bush and faced with the truth about the Iraqi war and it
quickly descends into charges of being unpatriotic and un American, ugly
name calling, threats and character assignation, and the worse of all
when you can't defend Bush and his war anymore; "but we got rid of
Sadam!" There are two untouchables in America you dare not speak up
against; god (the official version and manipulation of god) and American
Values. There is a Hitler, Stalin, Sadam, Mugabe, Kim IL potential in
all of us. What is bringing us down to their level is our
pompous/supremist attitude about ourselves and our denial that we can go
and have many times gone that low.
We may think we "liberated" Iraq, but the only people who believe that
is us. The Iraqis don't think so. We trashed their country to get to a
toothless dictator who was no threat to it's neighbors or especially to
the US, all to get to the oil supply. His WMD's (again, supplied by the
US) was destroyed and verified. We scowled the country and haven't found
a thing. Bush and doggy style Blair said they had evidence and knew where
the WMDs were. Remember the lie about Sadam trying to purchase plutonium
from Africa? Even Sadam's scientist with all the bribes we give them
can't come up with them, neither can the captured government leaders tell
them where something that doesn't exist is. Where are they? What was the
reason to go to war premised on lies?
Our troops are being ambushed and killed everyday by people who are
telling us that we are not liberators and that they want us out. On the
other hand, reports are coming out about racist attitudes toward Iraqis
and condescending views toward Islam by US troops, house searches where
families are thrown down to the ground with M-16's pointed at their heads
and women being disrespected, that US troops are firing on mostly
peaceful demonstrations, mostly about pay and needed services, and
killing a whole bunch of people for exercising a right we will loose
under Patriot Act II, and much of this is fueling the drive by's on US
troops. Many are saying US troops are beginning to act like Israeli
soldiers in regards to the Palestinians. 
I don't blame the troops, they are canon fotter and expendable labor
for the rich and powerful. Because most of the NCOs came from shitty
schools in the first place and join the military to get an education,
they are not as educated and this situation being taken advantaged of by
those who give them orders and believe what they are being told by the
draft dodgers back in Washington and the elitist educated military
officers.
Afghanistan is a disaster. Our puppet leader Karzi only rules Kabul,
nothing much outside of the city limits. The warlords are in control
again, women are getting beaten up again, heroin production is blossoming
again and where is American concern? Where's Afghanistan's liberation? We
say Iran, North Korea, Syria are the axis of evil, what about Myamar
(Burma) and it's brutal military dictatorship who abducts people to work
as slave labor to build roads and resorts for the tourists? What about
Zimbabwe where Mugabe is putting into prison dissidents on the charges of
treason and being responsible for the starvation of millions of his
people? What about Nigeria who guns down protestors by the request of oil
companies like Shell/Texaco who are protesting their land being taken
away and their land and water being poisoned by companies like
Shell/Texaco? Where's the concern for China where much of the products
imported here were made by slave prison labor, where prisoners have their
kidneys and other body parts forcibly taken out to be sold on the organ
donor market? shall I mention what they are doing to Tibet?
As bad as Sadam was, he was no worse than ruthless people we support
and are not on our axis of evil list. They are not "evil" because we can
exploit and control. Under Sadam, Iraqis had one of the highest standard
of living in the middle east until we started to enforce and embargo, and
killed hundreds of thousands of it's people, mostly children, with hunger
and dysentery. Iraqis had a liberal/secular government that was actually
more free than our friends in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Jordan and Egypt,
with free education and health care to all it's citizens. Women could
vote, get educated, drive a car and choose to wear the berka or not in
Sadam's Iraq. Iraqis remember the better days and wonder how destroying
their country and leaving them in ruins like we did in Afghanistan is
liberating them?
With schools closing, people loosing their jobs, health care being cut,
our infrastructure falling apart, the rich stealing the country's wealth,
the Anti Rave/Crack house laws, people going to jail for 20 years to life
for growing pot for the sick, our computers being snooped on, me possibly
getting into serious trouble from Ashcroft's Justice Department for this
post, and loosing my citizenship and being deported to Guantanamo Bay for
dissenting under Patriot Act II, in my personal opinion, we need to
liberate ourselves before we become "liberators" of others. Regime change
begins at home first.
But if Americans continue to believe and stand behind Bush and refuse
to unwrap themselves from the small world of the red, white and blue and
continue to live in "god bless America" denial, then we will get the
government we deserve. I will shed no crocodile tears when fascism comes
to our concerts, clubs and raves, our homes and in our personal lives.
When enough Americans become "losers" in our emerging Darwinian, compete
or be left behind ethos, and loose their jobs and end up living in homes
made up of scrap metal and cardboard boxes like our neighbors in the
south, while the rich with their tax cuts build million dollar homes up
in the hills, maybe we will have an uprising then. But then it may be too
late. 
This isn't a "left" or "right" issue, this is way beyond names and
labels. This has absolutely nothing to do with being "liberal" or
"conservative", this is all to do about fascism and a government that are
predators, and not only prey on defenseless countries around the world,
but ignorant Americans and patriotism. These people are no more honorable
than the Benny Hinns and Pat Robertsons of fundamentalist Christianity
who prey on the ignorance and fear of good honest people.
To get our freedom back then may take a lot of blood letting on the
streets and sacrificing, like what women, labor, people of color and gays
did to secure a place in the Bill of Rights and the constitution. But
with our addiction to fear and materialism and with plenty of diversions
to keep us dumb and pacified, we may not be up to the challenge and
become the most pitied people that ever existed.
To be a Bush supporter and to be a raver still sounds like s&m to me!
Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

We did not give WMD or a helicopter to spray Kurds....we gave things that
were
to be used for non-military purposes and Saddam used them for the purpose of
killing Kurds.

Kuwait is not a province of Iraq.  The world (not just us) turned against
Saddam when he
invaded Kuwait.  Kuwait was not setup by the U.S. as  a puppet country to
get oil.
http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+kw0017)

We did not put Saddam in power, though we helped
him in order to keep the Iran/Iraq war a stalemate.  That isn't the same as
liking the guy
and yelling "ra ra go Hussein go!" from the bleachers.

Iraq's oil was nationalized in 1972....how could we turn against Saddam for
wanting to
nationalize in the 80's or 90's during the Kuwait fiasco?  They'd been
nationalized for a long
long time.  Duh.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to me!

Via the history channel..
http://www.historychannel.com/cgi-bin/frameit2.cgi?p=%2Fperl%2Fsearch.pl
&word=saddam+rise+to+power

I challenge anyone to post PROOF that the US government in some way
financed his ascension.  

The Ascension of Saddam Hussein 

In 1979, President Bakr resigned, and Saddam Hussein Takriti assumed
control of the government. He immediately purged the Ba'ath party after
an unsuccessful coup, killing leftist members. War between Iran and
Iraq, primarily over the Shatt al Arab waterway, erupted full-scale in
1980 (see Iran-Iraq War). The eight-year war became a series of mutual
attacks and stalemates, as both countries' oil production fell
drastically, the death toll rose, and great mutual destruction was
inflicted. Poison gas was reportedly used by both sides, and by Iraq on
Kurdish villages as the Kurdish rebellion continued. Eventually, a
cease-fire under the auspices of the United Nations led to the war's end
in 1988. Iran and Iraq restored diplomatic relations in 1990.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to me!



the exact details on US's support to Sadam isn't the point.

The point is that America often supports the most brutal dictators in the
world.

So to say "The war was justified becuase we ousted an evil dictator!" is
nonsense.  There are far worst dictators we could have ousted if America
is in the liberation business.

But even that isn't really the point.  The point is that War makes some folks
feel good.  makes them feel big and rightous.  They like being on the
winnning team.  To these people, the reasons why we went to war are completely
irrevelent.  The point is, we went to war, we kicked ass, and that means
America is great.

Arguing the details on why we went to war with these people is pointless.

But just remember, the day American leaders can lie their way into war,
and the people don't care, is the day Democracy is dead.

Welcome to the facist state, you'll be feeling the oppression soon enough, just
you wait.

-troy


On Thu, Jun 19, 2003 at 11:23:22AM -0700, Captain Scarlet wrote:
> Via the history channel..
> http://www.historychannel.com/cgi-bin/frameit2.cgi?p=%2Fperl%2Fsearch.pl
> &word=saddam+rise+to+power
> 
> I challenge anyone to post PROOF that the US government in some way
> financed his ascension.  
> 
> The Ascension of Saddam Hussein 
> 
> In 1979, President Bakr resigned, and Saddam Hussein Takriti assumed
> control of the government. He immediately purged the Ba'ath party after
> an unsuccessful coup, killing leftist members. War between Iran and
> Iraq, primarily over the Shatt al Arab waterway, erupted full-scale in
> 1980 (see Iran-Iraq War). The eight-year war became a series of mutual
> attacks and stalemates, as both countries' oil production fell
> drastically, the death toll rose, and great mutual destruction was
> inflicted. Poison gas was reportedly used by both sides, and by Iraq on
> Kurdish villages as the Kurdish rebellion continued. Eventually, a
> cease-fire under the auspices of the United Nations led to the war's end
> in 1988. Iran and Iraq restored diplomatic relations in 1990.
> 
>

Subject: PINK TRIANGLE PARTY: What day is it?

 I forgot if it's on Friday night or Saturday.  Anyone who is new here
and never been to a Pink Triangle Party, you are in for a sic time!  18th
and Castro near Cala foods is blocked off, and there is teckno up until
4am. Technically not legal, but a SF tradition and the 5-0 leaves it
alone and winks at open container laws as long as it's not too blatent
and things don't get out of hand, but most likely they don't. That's why
they're down with it. The only thing you may see that's funky is some
drunk str8 guy getting head in the Walgreen's parking lot. It's not
anything like the infamous Halloween party in the Castro,  because it
doesn't attract that kind of crowd, very little violence, totally heathen
with just a bunch of queers and open minded str8 people having a good
time. Nothing wrong with that as long as people play safe.
  Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

Subject: Phuturo Recordings : Newsletter : June 2003

Phuturo Recordings
Newsletter: June 2003. 

1. Phuturo Releases now and forthcoming.
2. Other Label Releases.
3. Phuturo Presents: Breakbeat Science Exercise II Mix CD
4. Juju Collaborations. 
5. Cartel Recordings Launch.
6. Phuturo Club and live dates.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

1. Phuturo Releases now and forthcoming.

 Phuturo 013 - Telefunken 'Liars / Skeptics' - is out now in stores worldwide.
 Phuturo 014 - Juju 'Cartel Run / Mai Tai - promos are out now and with full release early July. 
 Phuturo 015 - Drumagick 'Levada Tropical / Tempo Fechado' - Promo's will be around early July.
 Phuturo 016 - Mikrob 'Come To Funky / Sweet Wind' realize date is scheduled for late Summer.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

2. Other Label Releases. 

 Juju 'Space Vato / Voodoo' out now on Invaderz's [of metalheadz fame] label Invaderz Transmission.
 In more recent events Juju has just signed 4 new tunes to Trouble On Vinyl / Renegade Recordings.  The tunes are 'Taboo / Manimalism / Jinx / Land Shark' which will be released in various of the TOV labels.  Two of the tunes will be released as a single for TOV. The remaining two tunes will be released on 'Here Comes Trouble LP' on TOV and "Renegades Of Funk II" on Renegade Recordings.  For more info on release dates go to:  www.tovmusic.com.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

3. Phuturo Presents: Breakbeat Science Exercise II Mix CD

Juju will be mixing the next Breakbeat Science Exercise II CD which will include the best of Phuturo Recordings catalog, plus tunes by international talent such as Total Science, Invaderz, Baron and many more.  The mix CD will be out early October and followed by a massive tour in support.  "Breakbeat Science Exercise 1, Mixed by DJ Dara" is on sale now and doing extremely well.  We are talking about 10,000 units already sold!  For more info:  www.breakbeatscience.com

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

4. Juju Collaborations. 

 Juju has recently returned from NYC where he'd been in the studio with DJ Dara finishing a new lick which infuses old 'ardcore ragga vibes with rugged amen soundbwoy beats.  No release date as of yet.

 Juju has also been traveling to Miami to work in the studio with DJ Craze.  The 1st Session gave way to 'Murda' a smasher that has been tearing up dance floors everywhere.  Read more below about this collaboration which is fixing to do the big takeover in 2003!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

5. Cartel Recordings / Juju and Craze New Imprint.

The vibes were so heavy in the recent studio session between Juju and Craze that the logical move for them was to start a brand new imprint.  The Cartel Collaboration will cater only to pure dancefloor smashers.  Period!  Worldwide Distribution of the product will be taken care via S. T. Holdings LTD, UK. This new imprint will be the vessel for all the Cartel collaborations as well as product by world talent.  Big things coming your way!  Expect to see tunes, tours and here THE BIG TAKEOVER BEGINS! 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

6. Phuturo Club and live DJ dates.

 Phuturo D&B Tuesdays is officially 5 years old!  Through good and bad we are still here steady rocking.  Here is whats coming up in July 2003.

Phuturo Drum and Bass
Date:  Every Tuesday
Location:  The Top, 424 Haight Street, San Francisco
TIme: 10:00 PM - 2:00 AM
Hosted by Phuturo Recordings
Residents:  Juju, Rando, 4Real and Genome

July 1st - Mathematics [31, Defunked, CIA - NYC]
July 8th - Silver [Metalheadz, Virus - UK]
July 15th - Residents
July 22nd - Residents
July 29th - Total Science [CIA, Metalheadz - UK]

phuturo fotos:  http://www.djsatplay.com/gallery/Phuturo

 Juju DJ Dates
June 29th  Toronto
July 11th   Seatlle 
July 23rd   Washington DC  
July 25th   East Bay
July 26th   Los Angeles 
Aug 1st     Pittsburgh 
Aug 7th      Denver 
Aug 16th   Los Angeles

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Thanks everyone who has been supporting over the years!

Contact Info:  

Postal Address [CD's - Vinyl - gifts]
Phuturo Recordings 
490 lisbon street
SF, CA 94112
North America
Email - Jujutek@aol.com
Web - http://www.phuturo.com

Juju Booking info:

Contagious Musiq
Mihai Crisan
email - Mihai@contagiousmusiq.com
web - http://www.contagiousmusiq.com

Subject: RE: [sfraves] (NRR) BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to me!

I see your point, however, the details in this case were important.  If
you were following the thread, you would see I was responding to the
lefty meme that the "US put saddam into power".  So the details were
important.

On that note, and since you brought it up.  I'd like to address your
Chomskyesqe "the US supports dictators" remark.  It's easy to paint the
US in a bad light when you take an event out of context.  Yes, the
support of oppressive dictators is bad.  Ever wonder why we did that?
Ever do any research into the facts involved of the assassinations we
carried out?  I bet you haven't.  you're probably satisfied with your
smug self-righteousness so there is no need to know "the details".  I
was idealistic once too and you'll probably grow out of it when you find
out how the real world works.  

I'd rather not waste this techno email server trying to convince someone
too lazy to do his own research outside of listening to Chomsky or the
democratic underground.

the exact details on US's support to Sadam isn't the point.

The point is that America often supports the most brutal dictators in
the
world.

So to say "The war was justified becuase we ousted an evil dictator!" is
nonsense.  There are far worst dictators we could have ousted if America
is in the liberation business.

But even that isn't really the point.  The point is that War makes some
folks
feel good.  makes them feel big and rightous.  They like being on the
winnning team.  To these people, the reasons why we went to war are
completely
irrevelent.  The point is, we went to war, we kicked ass, and that means
America is great.

Arguing the details on why we went to war with these people is
pointless.

But just remember, the day American leaders can lie their way into war,
and the people don't care, is the day Democracy is dead.

Welcome to the facist state, you'll be feeling the oppression soon
enough, just
you wait.

-troy

> The Ascension of Saddam Hussein 
> 
> In 1979, President Bakr resigned, and Saddam Hussein Takriti assumed
> control of the government. He immediately purged the Ba'ath party
after
> an unsuccessful coup, killing leftist members. War between Iran and
> Iraq, primarily over the Shatt al Arab waterway, erupted full-scale in
> 1980 (see Iran-Iraq War). The eight-year war became a series of mutual
> attacks and stalemates, as both countries' oil production fell
> drastically, the death toll rose, and great mutual destruction was
> inflicted. Poison gas was reportedly used by both sides, and by Iraq
on
> Kurdish villages as the Kurdish rebellion continued. Eventually, a
> cease-fire under the auspices of the United Nations led to the war's
end
> in 1988. Iran and Iraq restored diplomatic relations in 1990.
>

> > drastically, the death toll rose, and great mutual destruction was 
> > inflicted. Poison gas was reportedly used by both sides, and by Iraq
on 
> > Kurdish villages as the Kurdish rebellion continued. Eventually, a 
> > cease-fire under the auspices of the United Nations led to the war's
end 
> > in 1988. Iran and Iraq restored diplomatic relations in 1990. 
> > 
> >

At 01:28 PM 6/19/2003 -0700, Captain Scarlet wrote:
>Why don't you ask the 2 million Africans that died last year what
>oppression is?  If you aren't breaking the law, you won't get arrested.
> From what I have seen, as long as a Rave organizer makes a true effort
>to keep drugs out, the cops leave them alone.  Of course there will be
>mistakes made but so far, I haven't seen many.

How does a "rave organizer" make a true effort to keep drugs out of an 
event, Scarlet?  Strip search?:)

In fact, this law is not in the spirit of true conservatism; rather it is 
an abridgement of first amendment rights.  Civil liberties.  Flinging 
idiotic stereotypical phrases like "democratic underground" (what is that 
-- democrats meeting in old missile silos?) and misinformed "lefties" to my 
mind indicates a sixties political mentality.  The Rave Act in its present 
form was sponsored by "lefty" "underground" Democrats.

Personally, I see that there is not much difference between Islamic 
fundamentalist regimes and the clear direction in which our government is 
moving:  both wish to create theocratic states that fuse law with religious 
beliefs;  neither like dancing, or pleasure for its own sake;  both value 
preserving security and order over freedom.

I'm for freedom.  I believe in the Constitution and the Bill of 
Rights.  What does that make me?  How do you define those who would trade 
freedom for security and theocratically-based government?

Love,

Apollo


"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"Americans have, for the most part, been exempt from the genuine tragedy of 
war and, as a consequence, seem more ready to accept their myths about war. 
They have never endured the reality against which other nations readily 
measure the cost of combat. And this makes us a very dangerous people. "
-Richard A. Gabriel

I'll be honest.  I've lived outside of America for the past five years
so I haven't heard much about how the RAVE act is actually being
implemented.  I've read a few news articles and I've heard some first
hand stories but I'm hardly an expert on the subject.  What I don't like
is people and their over emotional hyperbole about what is happening to
America when you have no real idea.  You just assume.  It is a
"perception" that I take issue with.  If you were to support your
opinion with facts, I might agree.  E.g. since the implementation of the
RAVE act, X number of parties were shut down when no drugs were involved
resulting in blah blah blah.  But you don't do that.  You just say that
because the RAVE act was passed it is automatically bad and fascist.
All I heard last year was how the US was becoming a police state because
of Ashcroft's desire to arrest terrorist suspects without legal
representation or rights for them.  I haven't heard of any of these mass
arrests that the left predicted.  In fact, I saw many a peace protestor
doing tons of "subversive" acts during the war and still, no mass
arrests.  I'm a show me guy.  Show me or save your breath.  

It is quite obvious when people are doing drugs other than alcohol at
raves.  You make sure people know you run a clean show and have security
escort the pill heads out the door.  Life isn't as fun when you have to
be responsible and follow the laws of the land is it?

Btw.. this is the Dem underground.  Warning: it is a freak show of lefty
idiots.  http://www.democraticunderground.com/

I'm for freedom.  I believe in the Constitution and the Bill of 
Rights.  What does that make me?  How do you define those who would
trade 
freedom for security and theocratically-based government?

Love,

Apollo


"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.
It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well
can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when
we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"Americans have, for the most part, been exempt from the genuine tragedy
of 
war and, as a consequence, seem more ready to accept their myths about
war. 
They have never endured the reality against which other nations readily 
measure the cost of combat. And this makes us a very dangerous people. "
-Richard A. Gabriel

poorly-thought out law? C'mon now. How 'bout some harm reduction? How 
'bout some EMTs on sight? I don't want some hophead kicked out of a 
party, only to get in his car (another illegal act) injuring himself, 
his passengers, and whomever he hit, costing us thousands in uncovered 
life support costs. Granted, that's an extreme case, but that's the 
slippery slope being trod upon when simply sweeping problems under the 
rug.

"Captain Scarlet," all I've seen you do thus far is provide support for 
the status quo. Instead of questioning why this law is problematic, you 
seem to apply a "Father Knows Best" attitude of "well if ya don't break 
the law, you've got nothin' to worry about, son."   You know what? In 
Iran, if you don't write bad things about the Ayatollah in your 
newspaper column, they won't throw you in jail and whack you with a 
stick. In China, if you download pictures of naked 
big-breasted-blonde-babes at an internet cafe, it gets shut down and 
the owner locked up. Because that's the damn law. Does that make it 
right?

> Btw.. this is the Dem underground.  Warning: it is a freak show of 
> lefty
> idiots.  http://www.democraticunderground.com/

transcripts? Rejection letters from junior colleges?

Oh, wait, I forgot, the Right will always impatiently ask for immediate 
evidence (see: Blix, Hans), but can't seem to conjure it up when 
they're asked for it (see: Rumsfeld, Donald).  Do I sense a pattern 
here?

Well, to be honest I guarantee almost no raves will be shut down by the
race act directly including prison time.  Like has already happened, the
DEA is going to show up at high profile events, show the land
owner/promoter/venue owner what they might face and 9/10 of the people
who own the venue will not allow it to happen on their ground on the
basis that just for renting to someone they may face 250k in fines and
20 years in prison.  Its implementation has just been recent and its
first use was to shut down a NORML fundraiser in Montana after the venue
owners were shown what could happen to them if they let the event go off
and someone might be smokin' a joint.  It costs too much to directly
shut down a party, do the arrests, run the court time etc so most laws
are waved in people's faces as an overbearing warning to spook people
into abiding more by the law even if it is wrong.  In Utah they brew
beer at 2.8% alcohol to stay well under the 3.2% alcohol limit.

Rave act:  1 party threatened about its possible consequences shut down
by owners of venue.  So far its got a 1 for 1 success rate.

And if you happened to miss the mass arrests you should've been down by
where I work, where they were bringing them in by the busload down here
by the base of the bay bridge on embarcadero.  I've also read some scary
livejournals from one of my friends who is a teacher and all of a sudden
one of her Iraqi students had disappeared, family turned up missing, all
approx 2 weeks after their father had disappeared misteriously.  Her
responses from other teachers were even scarier as some of them started
realizing it had happened in their classromes as well but they hadn't
put 2 and 2 together.  Do you honestly think the government wants the
publicity of mass public arrests after running our own concentration
camps for the japanese during WWII?

you if anyone under the influence of drugs was found in your home,
right?

enjoy freedom, or because I feel that nobody should be able to tell me
what I can or can't do with *my* body? Should I pigeonhole you as a
"conservative" because you like telling people how they should live
their lives?

-----Original Message-----
From: shawn allen [mailto:shawn@alterior.net] 
Sent: Thursday, June 19, 2003 2:43 PM
To: 'SFRaves@hyperreal. org'
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to
me!

quoth Captain Scarlet:
> I'll be honest.  I've lived outside of America for the past five years
> so I haven't heard much about how the RAVE act is actually being
> implemented.  I've read a few news articles and I've heard some first
> hand stories but I'm hardly an expert on the subject.

OK... Maybe you should go on a little "fact-finding mission" then.

> What I don't like is people and their over emotional hyperbole about
> what is happening to America when you have no real idea.  You just
> assume.  It is a "perception" that I take issue with.  If you were to
> support your opinion with facts, I might agree.  E.g. since the
> implementation of the RAVE act, X number of parties were shut down
> when no drugs were involved resulting in blah blah blah.  But you
> don't do that.  You just say that because the RAVE act was passed it
> is automatically bad and fascist.

So, we have to wait until unconstitutional laws are actually used in
a harmful manner before we can complain about them? That's absolutely
rediculous. Oh wait, nevermind... the RAVE Act's already been used to
stifle *free speech*!

<http://www.drugpolicy.org/news/pressroom/pressrelease/pr060903.cfm>

> All I heard last year was how the US was becoming a police state
> because of Ashcroft's desire to arrest terrorist suspects without
> legal representation or rights for them.

Which is in direct conflict with the fifth and sixth amendments.

> I haven't heard of any of these mass arrests that the left predicted.
> In fact, I saw many a peace protestor doing tons of "subversive" acts
> during the war and still, no mass arrests.  I'm a show me guy.  Show
> me or save your breath.  

So... you think we should allow our publically elected lawmakers to pass
whatever law they want in good faith that they'll never *implement* it?
Hey, yeah, go ahead and pass that law that allows the RIAA to attack
your machine if you download copyrighted music -- they'd never actually
have the nerve to *use* it, right?!

> It is quite obvious when people are doing drugs other than alcohol at
> raves.

Is it, though? Could you unequivocally deduct that somebody was on
drugs, and would you be willing to stake your reputation as a party
promoter on your right to eject them based on your suspicion?

> You make sure people know you run a clean show and have security
> escort the pill heads out the door.  Life isn't as fun when you have
> to be responsible and follow the laws of the land is it?

Life isn't as fun when the government can tell you what you can or can't
do with *your own body*, or what you can or can't do in *your own home*.
You are aware that the RAVE Act, as it's written, could be used against
you if anyone under the influence of drugs was found in your home,
right?

> Btw.. this is the Dem underground.  Warning: it is a freak show of
> lefty idiots.  http://www.democraticunderground.com/ 

What is your obsession with left and right? Am I a "lefty" because I
enjoy freedom, or because I feel that nobody should be able to tell me
what I can or can't do with *my* body? Should I pigeonhole you as a
"conservative" because you like telling people how they should live
their lives?

On Thursday, June 19, 2003, at 02:48 PM, Captain Scarlet wrote:

>  If you
> don't like the law, start a grass roots campaign to get it over turned.
> Quit whining about is an do something.
>
> You bring up the Iranians as an analogy.  That's great.  Because they
> are taking matters into their own hands now.  See, they are doing
> something.  You aren't.

All political change needs to be started with discourse within the 
population or a community. So what you may label as "whining" could 
very well be the seeds to stir people into doing something about it. 
Airing grievances, whether in a mass protest or on a mailing list is a 
place to start. Bitching and moaning may not solve anything right away, 
but if it makes X number of people think about the issues, then the 
wheels are in motion. Over-idealistic? Perhaps, but silence is far 
worse.

> China?  You ever been to china?  The people that get shut down for
> violating a law didn't pay the police protection money.  LOL.  That is 
> a
> poor analogy for this situation.

Yeah, horrible analogy. Whereas in China it's a fistful of yuan 
changing hands to keep some people immune from the law, in the states, 
it's performed by giving millions in corporate contributions, or being 
school chums with the right people who ended up on Capitol Hill. So 
yeah, we're better because it happens on a much grander scale. (See: 
Harris, Katherine; Lay, Kenneth.)

and never been to a Pink Triangle Party, you are in for a sic time!
18th
and Castro near Cala foods is blocked off, and there is teckno up until
4am. Technically not legal, but a SF tradition and the 5-0 leaves it
alone and winks at open container laws as long as it's not too blatent
and things don't get out of hand, but most likely they don't. That's why
they're down with it. The only thing you may see that's funky is some
drunk str8 guy getting head in the Walgreen's parking lot. It's not
anything like the infamous Halloween party in the Castro,  because it
doesn't attract that kind of crowd, very little violence, totally
heathen
with just a bunch of queers and open minded str8 people having a good
time. Nothing wrong with that as long as people play safe.

first use was to shut down a NORML fundraiser in Montana after the venue
owners were shown what could happen to them if they let the event go off
and someone might be smokin' a joint.  It costs too much to directly
shut down a party, do the arrests, run the court time etc so most laws
are waved in people's faces as an overbearing warning to spook people
into abiding more by the law even if it is wrong.  In Utah they brew
beer at 2.8% alcohol to stay well under the 3.2% alcohol limit.

by owners of venue.  So far its got a 1 for 1 success rate.

DEA Uses RAVE Act to Shut Down Fundraiser
Posted by 033 on 10.06.2003 @ 23:11
Only two months after the RAVE Act was passed by Congress it has been 
used by the federal Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) to intimidate 
the owners of a Billings, Montana, venue into canceling a combined 
benefit for the Montana chapter of the National Organization for the 
Reform of Marijuana Laws (NORML) and Students for Sensible Drug Policy 
(SSDP).

On the day the fundraiser was set to take place a Billings-based DEA 
agent presented the venue owners with a copy of the RAVE Act warning 
them that they could face a fine of $250,000 if illicit drugs were 
found in the premises. Rather than risk the fines, they decided to shut 
the event down.

Also Popsicle had 150 undercovers. If they didn't comply, they'd 
probably cite the RAVE Act. There are more massives that will be the 
same. It will turn our parties into a police state.

Deepak

evidence that the CIA may have helped organize and finance the baathist
coup in iraq in 1963, and certainly that the US supported iraq in the
80's.  does this mean that  "the US was responsible for saddam's rise to
power?" no.  does this mean the argument stops there?  no.  the truth is
somewhere in the middle of all these clashing dogmas, and we can never
really know for certain what is the most "important" fact or which news
source to believe when they contradict each other.  noam chomsky is no
more 100% correct than rush limbaugh...

special olympics..."?

this right/left thing is a big scam.  the world is not that simple.

dead to empathy) liar and is using his presidency to give his corporate
cronies the opportunity to clean this country out of it's wealth. Hell

learning.

defence of the social, religious, cultural, and military institutions
that facilitate str8 white male supremacy. It's the archetype Bush
represents of the good 'ole days when men ruled the house with a iron
fist, where the man went to work and "earned" his living, like life is
something you earn, the man ate pussy and men didn't turn into a fag and
his women stayed home and kept his castle clean and took care of his
physical comforts. Children were property and a man could "discipline"
his children, even his disobedient wife without the government intruding
on his rights. It's the archetype Bush represents of pre 1880, before
unions, minimum wages, 40 hour weeks, overtime pay, PTO's, pensions,
unemployment insurance, health insurance, OCSHA, laws against
discrimination and harassment,  all these and other
social/political/sexual benefits we all enjoy today, brought to you by

would love to go back in time to,  those good 'ole dayz,  where employers
were the king of their business and government stayed out of his kingdom.

Wade and birth control, the 1964 voters rights, before gay rights, women
rights, before Madeline O'hair won the right to not have her son

universe is made up of the mass of str8, white, male, rich, drug free and
(fundamentalist) Christian people and that everything else revolves
around them. This is a serious battle for them, family values, government
intrusion into their lives, but not in those who they oppose,  the
homosexual agenda, partial birth abortion (the most rare of abortion
procedures done only when the mother's life is in danger), and so forth,

because it's false, but because it challenges the dominating paradigm. So
the closing of the mind begins and name calling forthwith when they start
to pitter out and can't win the debate technique.

myself a so called "liberal" or "progressive", I'm the one who takes that

labeling anti-Bushites as liberals and unpatriotic. This isn't about

'ole dayz".

>The Ascension of Saddam Hussein
>
>In 1979, President Bakr resigned, and Saddam Hussein Takriti assumed
>control of the government. He immediately purged the Ba'ath party after
>an unsuccessful coup, killing leftist members. War between Iran and
>Iraq, primarily over the Shatt al Arab waterway, erupted full-scale in
>1980 (see Iran-Iraq War). The eight-year war became a series of mutual
>attacks and stalemates, as both countries' oil production fell
>drastically, the death toll rose, and great mutual destruction was
>inflicted. Poison gas was reportedly used by both sides, and by Iraq on
>Kurdish villages as the Kurdish rebellion continued. Eventually, a
>cease-fire under the auspices of the United Nations led to the war's end
>in 1988. Iran and Iraq restored diplomatic relations in 1990.
>
>

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0306191801160.16236-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Pearls of Wisdom from the Authors of Last Night a DJ Saved My Life
 (the book silly)


A Quick Blurb from the BBC site...
( http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/dance/reviews/brewster_howtodj.shtml )

'How to DJ (Properly)' has become the bible for anyone wanting to improve
their DJing skills.

So, when co-author Bill Brewster offered to help judge out DJ at
Glastonbury competition we also got him to run down his top ten dos and
don'ts of DJing. Here they are:

DO...
1. Have fun
Everybody is a bloody DJ now and most of them are boring. Don't join them.
Be interesting, take chances and, moreover, enjoy yourself. It's supposed
to be fun, you know.

2. Throw your own parties
Sending tapes to superclubs and waiting to be discovered stopped working
years ago. All the veteran DJs started with their own parties. You should,
too. Forget flyers and trying to get features in DJmag. Invite your mates
down. Persuade any girls and gay friends you might have to join you.
They're the ones that get people on the dancefloor.

3. Play older records
Don't just limit yourself to the latest white labels and promos. There's a
world of recorded music out there at your disposal. It's as much fun
introducing an audience to a great old record as it is the latest upfront
test pressing.

4. Get out of your bedroom as soon as you can
Play at your mum's birthday, your mate's barbecue, the local boozer on a
Sunday afternoon, anywhere theres real people. You'll learn more in two
hours than a whole year locked in your room. A word of warning, though:
leave the drum'n'bass at home for your mum's birthday.

5. Take risks
Seamlessly mixing everything is cool, but it leaves no room for chances or
those truly memorable moments that people remember. Try things that could
possibly go wrong, because if they go right they'll be amazing. No-one
will lose an eye or die if you make a few mistakes.

6. Listen to older DJs
They might be grizzled old acid house bores, but they've also got the
tunes and the experience.

7. Be a collector
Don't just confine yourself to getting promos from Black Market or 3 Beat.
A DJ's real work never stops. Whether you're digging in second hand shops
or simply walking past a charity shop, there's never a time when you don't
think about digging out new and fantastic music.

8. Embrace technology
There's more to DJing than sniffing vinyl 24 hours a day. We're constantly
amazed at well-established DJs who are still fannying about with acetates
and vinyl only when CD-Rs and laptops are opening up new possibilities for
DJs.

9. Learn how to warm-up
Not just the peak-hour. No-one wants to arrive in a club at 10.30pm and be
blasted out of the bar by the hard and fast stuff you've spent three years
perfecting. Ease us in gently, please.

10. Buy our book
Available from all good bookstores (and a few crap ones, too).

DON'T...
1. Worry about perfect mixes
Most young DJs think mixing is the most important aspect of a DJ, when in
fact it's about 10% of the skills required. Yes, it's great that you can
mix two records together or scratch, but pay attention to other things,
too. Having great music and choosing the right tune for the right moment
is much more important.

2. Copy anyone
Having influences is fine - even recommended, we all need someone to
inspire us - but you won't get far if you don't express yourself and try
to be unique. People should know it's you playing, just by the records
you're playing.

3. Get an ego
The best DJs imagine they're down on the dancefloor partying with everyone
else, not hanging out with P Diddy in the enclosed area at Space.

4. Plan a set
DJing is about improvising, about sensing the atmosphere and choosing the
most perfect record for the moment. Don't ever think you can work it all
out beforehand. You're not designing a building, you're trying to capture
individual moments throughout the evening.

5. Stick to one genre
Does anyone really want to listen to 5 hours of gabber?

6. Keep your head down
Look at the dancefloor. Go on, it's not that hard.

7. Obsess about getting on to mailing lists
Lots of the records you'll get sent are crap anyway. Find your own gems.

8. Pay to play
Ignore any ads offering to get you gigs if you send them money. They will
rip you off.

9. Mither about the world not being fair when you can't get a gig
Get out there, be positive, make things happen. Throw your own parties
(see Do #2)!

10. Forget to invite us to your next party
We're handsome, fun and know lots of good-looking girls.

andyw    -   mutorsoundsystem   -    saturn5.com/andy
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to  me!

See, that's the problem with your attitude.  Your attitude is dogmatic in
the extreme....
if you don't think like me you must not love freedom and if you don't love
freedom
you must be a republican, etc.  You don't even see the catch-22 you place
anyone who
is *not* a democrat in?  Of course you don't.

Would you care to guestimate how many Israeli's have died in the past 3
years due to
terrorism as oppossed to how many Americans in the past 3 years?  Please,
give it a shot.
You may not feel as if any added security is needed, I do.  Does this mean I
agree with
Ashcroft?  No, although as a lefty if i'm not *with you* I *must* be with
Ashcroft....oh well.

So you're dead in the middle and that can't be leaving you no room for new
ideas, right?  Same
thing.  Don't make the mistake of mapping out left and right like it's a
ruler and there's some
special place on it that makes you right or more right.  Half of what can be
good about anything
in the spectrum is a decision by the person at any given point to do good.
Most of what's wrong
is that the majority at any given point wont do good.

There are things that are facts and indisputable.  One such fact is that we
didn't
sell any chemicals or helicopters to Saddam with the intent that he'd murder
anyone.

right would
get out of their dogma and put down the cliche banners.  Unfortunately, no
one is
interested in the truth (or a close approximation)...they're interested in
their view being
right and will purport anything as fact that supports that view.

Yay! I haven't written a poem in about 10 years!
Last weeks were good!
I'm Going to try to write one but I would like to share with you 
THE WORST POEM EVER!
 
razorblade, razorblade,
shiny and new,
I say one last prayer,
before I join you.
 
Ok, before you get mad at me for being an insensitive cretin for finding this funny, let me assure you that this poem was written in 1989, by someone at my high school, and they are FINE now ( I checked on classmates.com) , it was just normal teenage melodrama, and horrible horrible poetry. In fact, I bet they forgot they even wrote it! I on the other hand am cursed with this dreadful rhyme FOREVER! And yes, I CAN do better! (at least I could back then) I won "Best Poet" honors in my senior class, so yes, I can write better bad poetry!

On Thu, 19 Jun 2003 17:38:15 -0700 (PDT) "michael, the red stickman"
<red_stickman@yahoo.com> writes:
>NRR, bodhi.
>
 I really disagree, it's VRR (very rave related).  As much as we like to
shut that world out and be nihilistic and narcissistic and pretend that
we can dance the reality of our demise away, the larger world beyond
raves (controlled mostly by the Bushites) is crashing in on our party and
wants to brutally enforce it's fun repression on us. Bush being the man's
man, the man that gives American men goose bumps under their hairy chest,
goddamn!!!!  You gotta love that macho copilot entree to make a speech!
The man who makes Republican women's vagina juicy again, the man who
every Log Cabin Republican wants give him head and get fucked by him.
He's the man alright, and to mess with Bush is to mess with 100% American
manhood. But despite his manly sex appeal, he still is an enemy not only
of freedom and democracy, but the right to dance. Yes, a lot of Democrats
are just as guilty, fascism is fascism, both from the left and the right.
But right now, Bush who represents right wing fascism is the one who is
in power now. He's the one leading the charge to criminalize not only
dancing, but freedom and democracy. If he was a Democrat, I'd still speak
up against him. We are dealing with a President who makes Nixon such a
lovable Quaker!
  The punk knew what was up with authority long ago and understood the
value of politics. Dr. Martin Luther King was criticalized by many of his
on people for bringing up politics in the pulpit. "The church is for
spiritual things and politics is NCR" (non church related). But he knew
that what was keeping his people down wasn't that they didn't pray enough
and didn't meekly accept enough, as taking up one's own cross, 3rd class
citizenship in hopes that one day God would answer their prayers and that
the Holy Ghost would descend and upon the George Wallace, Turbans and
Jesse Helms of America and inspire them to take Christian pity on the
"colored people" and give them St class citizenship too. He understood it
was very political, and it meant that the church needed to get off it's
knees and come out of the safety of the church (so they thought until a
church was bombed In Birmingham in '64 by primitive Bushites) and self
righteousness and do some acts of civil disobedience and calling Creaser
by his true name, and this being as spiritual as Friday night prayer
meetings. 
  The hip hop scene is now beginning to discover that you can't hide in
your scene anymore and hope the fun police would ignore you and leave you
alone. The hip hop scene is beginning to realize that politics is a
necessary survival tool in Bush's world that wants to demonize you,
criminal you and put you down, like a real man would. Gotta protect
children, women, the white race, manhood and American values from the
scourge of raving, ganja, sexual pleasure, queer love, alternative
families, tolerance and other people's culture. Hell no, this isn't about
dogma, come on now!!!! It's about freedom a
  O.K... he's not exactly a friend of ravers, punks and hip hoppers and
such minded people. Why don't I just keep it as that? Why do I bring all
the war stuff and his economic policies in the discussion about the right
to dance? Because it shows the kind of man we are dealing with and his
lying and placating good people's patriotism to get us to support his
Iraqi conquest reveals his true character. If we can't trust him to tell
the truth, how can we trust him to protect our right to dance? A man who
will steal from the poor to give to the rich is not a friend to ravers. 
A man who will not think twice about killing thousands of Iraqis and
American soldiers to get the oil for his oil buddies down there in Texas
would not think twice about putting DJ's, promoters and venue owners in
prison for 20 years. How am I to admire a man like that?  I don't think
he's even sexy. I like men, not brutal socialpaths. I think he's too much
of a psycho cowboy for me to consider him a role model of manhood and a
masterbation fantasy! 
  When is the rave scene going to wake up and get political too? It's
almost like trying to wake up someone in a coma. No one want's to leave
the distractions of Disney Land, but you got to face the real world
sooner or latter. The rave scene is in a deep coma of self absorption and
a  "I don't care" attitude, and while everybody else is in the streets
trying to protect their rights, the rave obliviously goes on! Ravers are
not coming to grips to the fact that 20 year prison sentences for raving
are not far away, and yes, all American male Bush is the grand puba of it
all!  Yes, it's VRR! Our right to dance depends on it being VRR!
  Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

Subject: Left or Right...?

--part1_29.42ab11c8.2c244f16_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

     Although I am not a political expert, I think I am begining to 
understand what people are refering to when they describe views as being "left" or 
"right". I'd like to take a moment to explain how I see it and perhaps some of you 
will agree with or correct me. 
     To me, the Right wing of the U.S. seems to be proud of itself and where 
it stands. It sees itself as heroic and of course patriotic. This is the more 
common view of Americans. It is also a common view of non-americans who live 
in other countries or have just migrated here recently. When I talk to 
forenigners about what they think of America, they usually say things about how 
greatful they are and how much better it is here than in their country. How greatful 
they are of our nation to have given them a chance to live a better life. 
     The Left wing, on the other hand (no pun intended!) is very hard on 
itself. It likes to bring up the contraversial and sensative things from the past 
that people just don't want to talk or hear about anymore. It points out it's 
own open cuts and makes itself seem very vulnerable, where the right wings 
like to cover it's tracks and move on. 
     Think of a conservative family sitting around the dinner table having a 
conversation about how great their family is, when little johnny inturupts by 
saying... "I remember one time grandpa boxed my ears because I wouldn't eat my 
brocoli" That kid's a lefty! You see, it may be true, but you just didn't 
want to hear it now did you? The left wing can be sensative, and yet insensative, 
It's insightful and yet it's naive. It seems at first to be jumping to 
conclusions and making false accusations... and yet years later you may realize what 
was said just might be "right" afterall.
     Now I think this Right and Left wing analogy can be related to the right 
and left brain, and also right and left handed people. But actually it's 
confusing because lefty's use the right brain and righty's use the left brain, 
prodominantly. But since the right handed out-number the left handed 10 to 1 in 
population, you will never have any equality in that perspective. 
     Subconciously, right handed people may look to the right wing more 
favorably at first glance, subconciously making that connection of "rightness" that 
is so deeply grooved into their brain. I bet you, that in a survey you may 
find that a large number of left handed people, also consider themselves 
"left-wing" and unfortunately this may be due to a subconcious preference, more so 
than side by side research, pro and con evaluation of the two wings carefully 
deciding which "side" you want to support. Most people, I bet you, do not 
research open mindedly in this mannor, they just blindly support one side or the 
other, based on what is probably a child-hood preference of using your right or 
left hand... or you could be right handed but chose to be different in spite of 
conformity and prefer the left or vise versa. 
     In history Lefties (meaning lefted handed people) were at first looked 
at as disadvantaged. untensils, tools, cars and even desks at school were not 
designed for them to use, and so most of them would have to convert (conform) 
to being right handed, like everyone else. The left hand was even associated 
with the Devil and it was said that Jesus always used his right hand. But in 
more recent history people started to realize that lefties had certian abilities 
that were superior to righties, such as in sports. Notice while 1 in 10 is 
left handed in overall population, nearly half of baseball today is lefties 
including a lot of the all time greats. i.e. Babe Ruth, Bary Bonds, Randy Johnson, 
Ted Williams etc. 
     Nowadays, left has established itself as not disadvantaged but actually 
gifted in some ways. It's sort of symbolically shows that one can defy the 
odds and still come out on top. The left is sort of this "underdog" 
...underground, against the tide, state of mind. It is no longer about being left or right 
handed though. It's about taking the side of the one who is against the odds. 
Hence you will hear a lot of people refer to things as "radical left-wing 
politics" where as what you might think of right wing politics is just simply 
called "politics" with no reference to a "wing". And you will hear the term 
"left-wing nut" much more often then the term "right-wing nut". 
     It seems obvious still, the left, is associated with radicalness, 
creativity, and a naive faith that society is safe without conservative law 
enforcement. For some reason it seems the liberals, environmentalists, hippies and 
most other American sub-cultures have been catagorized into the left side of the 
evolutionary branch of politics. While the Military, Police, and up-standing 
citizens such as doctors, lawyers, and millionare's are catagorized on the 
right. While I suppose the average population is somewhere in the middle and must 
chose for themselves. 
     All this, of course, is just non-sense and we are all just people 
afterall, but while we're slinging these words around such "left" and "right" I like 
to try and find some clarity on what people actually mean by this. 
     I think we can all agree that one wing can not be right or wrong nor 
better or worse. It takes two wings to fly, respectively, and what we should be 
working towards is an <A HREF="http://dictionary.reference.com/search?r=2&q=ambidextrous">ambidextrous</A> America!
     Much Love - Johnny

--part1_29.42ab11c8.2c244f16_boundary--

Subject: RAVE Act Reverberations 

--=====================_2633948==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Newsbrief: RAVE Act Reverberations

In the wake of the cancellation of a Montana NORML/SSDP benefit by the 
venue's owners after a DEA agent warned them they could face a $250,000 
fine under the RAVE Act if anyone used marijuana at the event 
(http://www.drcnet.org/wol/290.shtml#dearave), organizers of some drug 
reform-related events have begun to cancel events or relocate them to 
friendlier territory. At the same time, national drug reform and civil 
liberties organizations are mobilizing against the RAVE Act, now officially 
known as the Illicit Drug Anti-Proliferation Act.

The Sonoma Health and Harmony Festival (http://www.harmonyfestival.com) in 
California has cancelled plans to have a medical marijuana smoking area due 
to fears of RAVE Act prosecutions, California NORML has reported. And the 
Wisconsin Weedstock festival (http://www.weedstock.com) is relocating 
across the border to Canada -- to Sault, Ontario, where there currently are 
no laws against marijuana possession, let alone anything like the RAVE Act. 
Weedstock will become part of the Planetary Pride Hemp Fest 
(http://www.planetarypride.com/comingsoon.html), an Ontario-based event now 
in its fifth year.

(US citizens thinking of attending but who have an arrest record should 
make sure they can get into Canada. Visit 
http://www.ccra-adrc.gc.ca/customs/individuals/visitors-e.html and go to 
the Citizenship and Immigration Canada's web pages to get more information 
about entry.)

As some groups change plans under RAVE Act prosecution pressures, the drug 
reform movement is mobilizing to roll back the law, which was stalled under 
stiff opposition in the Senate last year, but which passed easily once it 
was stealthily inserted into the popular Amber Alert by RAVE Act sponsor 
Sen. Joe Biden (D-DE). Drug Policy Alliance has made repealing the RAVE Act 
one of its action priorities (http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/action/), 
and other major reform and civil liberties groups continue to plot 
strategies to kill the law.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"Americans have, for the most part, been exempt from the genuine tragedy of 
war and, as a consequence, seem more ready to accept their myths about war. 
They have never endured the reality against which other nations readily 
measure the cost of combat. And this makes us a very dangerous people. "
-Richard A. Gabriel

(This is just too funny not to share.)
>
>Stop The Gay Canadians!
>First icky legalized homosexual marriage, then the
>apocalypse. Conservative America trembles
>By Mark Morford
>
>Hordes of quivering GOP lawmakers and vast throngs of
>proudly homophobic right-wing Christian Americans fell
>into an adorable tizzy the other day as the entire
>really, really big country of Canada announced it will
>change its national law to allow full-on homosexual
>marriage anywhere in entire country including Vancouver
>and Toronto and even "that weird province with all the
>gay French people."
>
>Hysteria and open weeping and panicky looks accompanied
>the uncontrollable overeating of many stale Ding-Dongs,
>as millions of sexually confused Bush-ites and members of
>self-righteous Bible-icious anti-everything groups like
>the American Family Association, along with entire towns
>such as Colorado Springs, were absolutely certain the
>world was coming to an end, like, immediately. I mean,
>Canada's right next door!
>
>Moreover, they fear, Canada's decision means the
>God-given sanctity of tepid hetero missionary-position
>marriage is utterly doomed and our innocent children are
>sure to become fans of modern dance and maybe even old
>Barbra Streisand movies, and all of this will undoubtedly
>result in the introduction of a pair of wacky gay
>Canadian neighbors on "Everybody Loves Raymond."
>
>"I don't really know what this means, what it represents,
>what it entails, what gay people stand for, where they
>come from or what they do or why they do it or how they
>become that way in the first place or even if they're
>allowed to vote or fly in airplanes," announced a very
>trembly George W. Bush at a hastily arranged press
>conference in the Super Mega Hetero Gun Room of the White
>House.
>
>"But I do know we won't stand for it, and if these
>gul-dang furriner evildoers think they can get away with
>these kinds of tender unions and hand holdings and loving
>smiles and beautiful intimate commitments, well, they
>haven't seen America's righteous firepower!" he shouted,
>pounding his cute little fist on the podium. "We shall
>prevail!" Then he fainted.
>
>Karl Rove, Bush's master strategist and known devourer of
>live puppies and breeder of the administration's swarms
>of evil flying monkeys, briefly waddled into the sunlight
>to quickly introduce the bitchin' catchphrase "Wussies of
>Mass Destruction" into the GOP lexical armament.
>
>Rove also pointed out, just before the tiny demon leeches
>sucked away the tiny shreds of what remained of his soul,
>how Canada's wicked WMD decision probably meant there
>were similar latent gay terrorist revolutions ready to
>burst all over Antarctica and Poland and probably Latvia
>like some sticky-smooth lubricating substance, and they
>must be stopped before the world is "converted" and we
>all end up getting regular pedicures and drinking white
>wine and belting out the words to "Cabaret" as we cruise
>around in our purple Miatas.
>
>"As far as I'm told, Canada actually borders our fine
>upstanding nation," Bush managed to continue, after being
>hoisted upright, as a paler-than-usual Dick Cheney
>whispered desperately into Bush's ear while Lynne
>frantically tried to dissuade their secret lesbian
>daughter from splitting for Saskatchewan with her lover
>on the next flight out.
>
>"This means we as a country are actually touching a bunch
>of gay married people right this very minute! Look at
>this map! It's like an adjacency thing! Like some sort of
>weird tidal wave of gay Canadian people in love, just
>waiting up north to ride big pink buses down here and
>open chains of well-appointed little erotic chocolate
>boutiques and buy up all the Cher Farewell Tour tickets.
>This will not do!"
>
>Already, America's perspective has been affected. In a
>shocking new poll, fully 41 percent of Americans now
>believe the terrorists responsible for the 9/11 tragedy
>were, in fact, gay married Canadians.
>
>Similarly, 23 percent are now convinced Saddam Hussein
>was either "somewhat" or "almost totally" Canadian. Or
>gay. Or a member of Loverboy.
>
>AG John Ashcroft, no stranger to uptight asexual
>homophobic hyper-Christian puling and all too familiar
>with looking exactly like he just swallowed a
>pleasure-ribbed condom filled with boiling road tar, was
>seen running around the Hall of Justice smacking a heavy
>King James Bible against his skull and dousing himself
>with buckets of holy anointing oil, just before running
>smack into the bronze left nipple of the swathed statue
>of Lady Justice and knocking himself cold.
>
>Bills were proposed. Sanctions were recommended.
>Emergency precautions were instilled. Bush vowed to cut
>Canada out of the will. Dick Cheney demanded a
>restriction on imports of Canada Dry and Canadian maple
>syrup and an outright ban on the sale of all Aldo Nova
>greatest-hits compilation records, countrywide.
>
>Donny Rumsfeld, feeling that a nice brutal unprovoked
>"regime change" in Canada was, of course, long overdue,
>immediately called for an insanely violent air assault to
>be quickly followed by an exhaustive deadly ground
>invasion on Canadian lumberjacks, one that positively
>reeks of bogus misinformation and lies and pain and hate
>and a wildly expensive military probe into the whole
>hockey thing.
>
>"A really, really long metal fence is what I endorse,"
>oozed Senate majority leader and noted closet Village
>People megafan Tom DeLay, between tongue baths from his
>personal herd of mildly narcotized French poodles. And
>Dennis Hastert.
>
>"You know, a big strong fence studded all over with those
>really sharp barb-wire stickler thingies? Like the kind
>they use on those leather dog collars? The thick black
>ones with the snaps that feel all tight around your
>ankles? And you can't help but squirm and moan and get
>all giddy?" he continued before falling into a fit of
>uncontrolled swooning.
>
>In the state of Texas except for Austin which everyone
>knows is surprisingly cool despite how it's in, you know,
>Texas, where you still cannot legally buy a dildo or
>engage in homosexual sex but they pretty much hand you a
>nice big phallic shotgun as a welcome gift when you
>visit, the legislature immediately passed a law requiring
>each and every male to smack any other male they see
>really hard on the back and buy him a pitcher of bad beer
>in a manly gesture of football-lovin' patriotic
>homoerotically repressed solidarity.
>
>Reaction was heated. Viewpoints clashed. Families
>bickered. Birds flew. Countries sighed. The U.N. napped.
>Belgians shrugged. Macy's had a big sale. Love exhaled.
>
>The air was thick with tension. Conservatives were
>stupefied. The religious right, so accustomed to viewing
>big scary cities like San Francisco and Amsterdam as
>debauched hedonistic Sodom-a-raffic pleasure palaces to
>be avoided like a good book or a genuine orgasm or an
>original thought, suddenly took one look at a map of the
>world and noticed the size of Canada and went, holy crap.
>
>Pat Robertson quietly dreamed of marrying Jerry Falwell.
>Everyone openly dreamed of pimp-slapping Franklin Graham.
>Wal-Marts in Canada were forced to carry issues of Bust
>and Honcho. Strangely, sales of Jackhammer Jesus dildos
>increased a hundredfold. Mostly in Texas.
>
>Meanwhile, the rest of the largely benevolent and
>open-hearted and divinely attuned polyamorous universe
>just laughed and nodded very, very approvingly at Canada
>and said, well Jesus with a riding crop and a rainbow
>flag, it's about goddamn time, you know?

(OK, for those of you unfamiliar with the "Nazi" rule, it is one of the oldest and most sacred rules on the Internet: as soon as one side calls the other a "Nazi" or Hitler, the side looses. some variations of this rule go as far to say as soon as the word Nazi is posted, the thread is dead. I AM INVOKING "THE NAZI RULE!" not because i think anyone is a Nazi, but this HAS TO STOP NOW.) Let us celebrate the end of this thread by resuming to talk about such important topics as rave goo, candy, fat beats, and parties that "were off DA hook" don't get me wrong, Like any social movement,  politics has its place in raving, but resorting to name calling isn't getting anyone anywhere. 



--
