Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr

  Let's try it again, it's VRR! Not to be insulting to anyone, but we
need to get out of our e-puddles and get with reality. I know I say
things, that I will stand by, in a deliberately provocative way. I say
what I say about Bush, "American" values, manhood and the war to get
people pissed off. I can't think of any other way to jump start people's
brains that have been dumbed down by our government and the corporate
media. I  want people to relearn critical thinking skills and to not feel
unpatriotic if you question authority, that's democracy, not regurgitate
the "official" line, that's tyranny, and hopefully, as I piss people off
and they are on the warpath to shut me up, that will get people off their
cyber asses, do the work and find out themselves that Bush is not a
conservative, but a neo fascist, and yes it's effecting the right to
dance. 
  I'm not asking people to accept everything I say. I don't know
everything, I'm as dumb as everybody else. But I can tell the difference
between democracy and fascism, and as we say in the ghetto a player from
someone who keeps it real.
  The point that I am making is why is all this Bush stuff VRR? Because
his actions are of a man who is a fascist, and raves, like everything
else that will suffer under fascism, will terribly suffer. If a man will
drop 18,000 bombs on Iraq and kill god knows how many civilians (The US
refuses to do a civilian body count, do you smell something rotten here?)
to get to the oil, what will this man do to, not only the rave community,
but to every music culture? Everyone else is getting it, why are ravers
still a day late and a dollar short on this? Many refuse to see the
connection between him pillaging the country of it's wealth and the right
to dance because many of us do like what he's doing.
  Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

more than about rave goo, phat beats and parties that were off da hook. I
love my right to dance, and people don't seem to get it that rave goo,
phat beats are about to be supressed and that parties that were off da
hook are about to get you 20 years in prision. Who's the Grand Puba of
all of this? I don't sound too Buddhist, but if I have to slap people in
thie faces (figuratively) to get the rave scene out of it's complacency
and lethargy, then I have done a very compassionate act. Censorship won't
stop the truth.
  Danny Picard and Apollo are getting it, why arn't you?

On Fri, 20 Jun 2003 11:40:15 -0700 (PDT) Sarah Schumm
<sarah_schumm@yahoo.com> writes:
>No way am I going to repost any of this!
>Somebody hurry up and call somebody a NAZI so this will stop!
>(OK, for those of you unfamiliar with the "Nazi" rule, it is one of 
>the oldest and most sacred rules on the Internet: as soon as one side 
>calls the other a "Nazi" or Hitler, the side looses. some variations 
>of this rule go as far to say as soon as the word Nazi is posted, the 
>thread is dead. I AM INVOKING "THE NAZI RULE!" not because i think 
>anyone is a Nazi, but this HAS TO STOP NOW.) Let us celebrate the end 
>of this thread by resuming to talk about such important topics as rave 
>goo, candy, fat beats, and parties that "were off DA hook" don't get 
>me wrong, Like any social movement,  politics has its place in raving, 
>but resorting to name calling isn't getting anyone anywhere. 
>

it's called Godwin's law and, as Quirks exception outlines, purposely =
trying to curtail the already irrelevant argument by invoking Godwin's =
law is futile. hence, this thread is still going ;)

i know i've posted it before.  but here it is again, as it's certainy =
more entertaining than this thread:

http://www.faqs.org/faqs/usenet/legends/godwin

Excerpt:
there will always be people who see the net
and are repulsed because there's stuff there they don't want to see - so =
they
set out to make sure noone else can, either. They invariably fail, =
because
there are no net.cops to enforce any such rules on UseNet; in the course =
of
the heated flamewar that usually follows, things escalate until either =
Hitler
or Nazis (or both) put in an appearance, at which point the thread has
officially lost all relevance. People scream at each other a bit more, =
then
give up and go home. Bleah. "Keep your brains up top; don't be a =
net.cop."
 This has mutated, in true UseNet fashion, to encompass *any* continuing
thread; if you mention Hitler or Nazis out of the blue, the thread is =
sure to
die irrelevantly soon (and, incidentally, you've lost the argument, =
whatever
it was)... and every continuing thread on UseNet *must* contain such a
reference sooner or later. Invoking Rule #4 deliberately in hopes of =
ending
a thread, however, is doomed to failure (Quirk's Exception)...


-=3Ddave
  ----- Original Message -----=20
  From: Sarah Schumm=20
  To: sfraves@hyperreal.org=20
  Sent: Friday, June 20, 2003 11:40 AM
  Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) BUSH SUPPORTERS: Still sounds like s&m to =
me!


  No way am I going to repost any of this!
  Somebody hurry up and call somebody a NAZI so this will stop!
  (OK, for those of you unfamiliar with the "Nazi" rule, it is one of =
the oldest and most sacred rules on the Internet: as soon as one side =
calls the other a "Nazi" or Hitler, the side looses. some variations of =
this rule go as far to say as soon as the word Nazi is posted, the =
thread is dead. I AM INVOKING "THE NAZI RULE!" not because i think =
anyone is a Nazi, but this HAS TO STOP NOW.) Let us celebrate the end of =
this thread by resuming to talk about such important topics as rave goo, =
candy, fat beats, and parties that "were off DA hook" don't get me =
wrong, Like any social movement,  politics has its place in raving, but =
resorting to name calling isn't getting anyone anywhere.=20

--0-1446554788-1056148122=:93273
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Hi All,
Have you guys/gals read "Last Night a DJ Saved My Life?"  I would strongly recommend it to anyone interested in the history of the 'DJ.'
This book discusses a myriad of genres from Northern Soul to disco to modern techno.  
There's a really cool section that covers all-night ballroom dances that date back to the 30's.
Well, without getting too far into it, I'll just say it's a great read.  
Regards,
chuck


AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:

A Quick Blurb from the BBC site...
( http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/dance/reviews/brewster_howtodj.shtml )

'How to DJ (Properly)' has become the bible for anyone wanting to improve
their DJing skills.

So, when co-author Bill Brewster offered to help judge out DJ at
Glastonbury competition we also got him to run down his top ten dos and
don'ts of DJing. Here they are:

DO...
1. Have fun
Everybody is a bloody DJ now and most of them are boring. Don't join them.
Be interesting, take chances and, moreover, enjoy yourself. It's supposed
to be fun, you know.

2. Throw your own parties
Sending tapes to superclubs and waiting to be discovered stopped working
years ago. All the veteran DJs started with their own parties. You should,
too. Forget flyers and trying to get features in DJmag. Invite your mates
down. Persuade any girls and gay friends you might have to join you.
They're the ones that get people on the dancefloor.

3. Play older records
Don't just limit yourself to the latest white labels and promos. There's a
world of recorded music out there at your disposal. It's as much fun
introducing an audience to a great old record as it is the latest upfront
test pressing.

4. Get out of your bedroom as soon as you can
Play at your mum's birthday, your mate's barbecue, the local boozer on a
Sunday afternoon, anywhere theres real people. You'll learn more in two
hours than a whole year locked in your room. A word of warning, though:
leave the drum'n'bass at home for your mum's birthday.

5. Take risks
Seamlessly mixing everything is cool, but it leaves no room for chances or
those truly memorable moments that people remember. Try things that could
possibly go wrong, because if they go right they'll be amazing. No-one
will lose an eye or die if you make a few mistakes.

6. Listen to older DJs
They might be grizzled old acid house bores, but they've also got the
tunes and the experience.

7. Be a collector
Don't just confine yourself to getting promos from Black Market or 3 Beat.
A DJ's real work never stops. Whether you're digging in second hand shops
or simply walking past a charity shop, there's never a time when you don't
think about digging out new and fantastic music.

8. Embrace technology
There's more to DJing than sniffing vinyl 24 hours a day. We're constantly
amazed at well-established DJs who are still fannying about with acetates
and vinyl only when CD-Rs and laptops are opening up new possibilities for
DJs.

9. Learn how to warm-up
Not just the peak-hour. No-one wants to arrive in a club at 10.30pm and be
blasted out of the bar by the hard and fast stuff you've spent three years
perfecting. Ease us in gently, please.

10. Buy our book
Available from all good bookstores (and a few crap ones, too).

DON'T...
1. Worry about perfect mixes
Most young DJs think mixing is the most important aspect of a DJ, when in
fact it's about 10% of the skills required. Yes, it's great that you can
mix two records together or scratch, but pay attention to other things,
too. Having great music and choosing the right tune for the right moment
is much more important.

2. Copy anyone
Having influences is fine - even recommended, we all need someone to
inspire us - but you won't get far if you don't express yourself and try
to be unique. People should know it's you playing, just by the records
you're playing.

3. Get an ego
The best DJs imagine they're down on the dancefloor partying with everyone
else, not hanging out with P Diddy in the enclosed area at Space.

4. Plan a set
DJing is about improvising, about sensing the atmosphere and choosing the
most perfect record for the moment. Don't ever think you can work it all
out beforehand. You're not designing a building, you're trying to capture
individual moments throughout the evening.

5. Stick to one genre
Does anyone really want to listen to 5 hours of gabber?

6. Keep your head down
Look at the dancefloor. Go on, it's not that hard.

7. Obsess about getting on to mailing lists
Lots of the records you'll get sent are crap anyway. Find your own gems.

8. Pay to play
Ignore any ads offering to get you gigs if you send them money. They will
rip you off.

9. Mither about the world not being fair when you can't get a gig
Get out there, be positive, make things happen. Throw your own parties
(see Do #2)!

10. Forget to invite us to your next party
We're handsome, fun and know lots of good-looking girls.

andyw - mutorsoundsystem - saturn5.com/andy
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

Subject: RE: [sfraves] what's the point of having hair? nrr

As a male who has had every style of hair from shaved to halfway down my
back to mohawk to bowl to whatever... I will say one thing about the
purpose of hair.  And anyone who has not had hair down to their
shoulders is missing out.  To me there's not much greater than long hair
blowing in the wind and tickling the back of the neck.  Its instant
stress relaxation as each little strand gently brushes against your
skin, exciting the hairs and tricking you into thinking you're getting a
massage.  About the only people I can't see liking this are those who
like stress more than being relaxed and people with fybromalgia (sp?)
After chopping all my hair off about 4 years ago I didn't realize how
much I missed it until I started growing it back out again.  Now I don't
think I'll ever cut it back above my shoulders, (although its not there
yet but getting there.)

Oh, and of course for someone else to run their hands through and/or
twirl. :)

-----Original Message-----

> This happened more than once by the time I decided to de-hippie myself.

Ok, so maybe the headphones thing can be a hassle (that and brushing my 
hair out of my face constantly while looking down on the decks) but 
there's nothing more relieving than being in a hot sweaty one, then 
stepping outside for a minute and letting some cold-ass wind blow 
through that hair. Nothing short of miraculous, i tell ya :)

   - omid

I want to learn how to do french pigtails, but cant seem to get it. I have some pipe cleaners that glow in blacklight, and I have these Giant Sparkly Balls I got for 50 cents at Big LOts! I knew i had struck candy kid gold when a 4 year old comlimented me on my pigtails. God I love hair deelies

Who is going to the SUNSET Summer Solstice Celebration (outdoor day =
party) on Sunday in Marin county? They always have a good groove going. =

I would check out this one, and I want to hear Galen & Solar spin. They =
were great at the SFraves 10-year party in McLaren park last year.

Anyway, I heard on the news that hundreds of thousands of NASCAR racing =
fans would be hitting the roads in North Bay on Sunday, so now I am =
wondering about traffic patterns. I sure don't want to be caught in a =
bottleneck on Sunday.=20

Does anyone have any advice (esp. if you live up in Marin Cty). 101 =
North is supposed to be pretty bad tomorrow. Just where the hell is =
Sears Point (the Infineon Raceway)? Do you think this will really cause =
a problem for the trip to and from Novato? I live in the East Bay. I =
guess I should avoid Highways 37 or 121, like they said on the news, but =
doesn't 101 go near those roads? I guess I better dig out my Bay Area =
map.

Thanks,

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_17792045==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 900/1000/N
Subject: SRR:  Free Cash for "Hipster" Parties

--=====================_17792045==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I had hoped to go to the Sunset party this afternoon, but my partner came 
down with a serious infection.  So instead I spent this morning reading the 
New York Times.  In the NRT Magazine I came across an article by Rob Walker 
of "Slate" titled "The Marketing of No Marketing."

There are many theories about capturing the "souls" of today's cool, 
anit-establishment youth through various marketing techniques.  One can 
hire hip kids, give them a new product, and have them show up at trendoid 
events "undercover" as it were.  They alert their friends to the new deal 
in self-validation, and away you go:  viral marketing.

Then there's "organic" marketing or Plan B, as Alex Wipperfurth (with an 
umlaut) of SF's youth marketing firm "Plan B" calls this tactic.  Take a 
dying, underdog brand, and facilitate its acceptance by "lifestyle as 
dissent" constituencies who view consumption as protest.  These people are 
all about, as Alex says, "freedom and rejecting middle-class mores."

Yes.

So we have Pabst Blue Ribbon beer.  My dad used to drink the stuff.  I 
thought they went out of business years ago.  But lo and behold, Pabst, or 
"PBR," recently appeared in the "Hipster's Handbook" and has been adopted 
by hipsters in trendy bars from the Mission District here to the Lower East 
Side in NYC.

Portland, that bastion of the alternative, is sucking this "retro-chic" 
liquid down the pierced gullets.  As 28-year-old Phil Barnes, who just had 
a PBR logo burned into his back says:  "Pabst is part of my 
subculture.  It's the only beer I think about."  Phil is a skate-boarder 
and punk rocker.

Good to see people with passionate beliefs.

Me...I guess I'm tragically unhip these days.  Without a consumer belief 
system. You see, I still wear cargo pants.  Wore them before they became 
trendy and wear them now, even though a couple of years ago --  it seemed 
to happen over night -- all my hip friends started to wear denim jeans.  I 
just couldn't part with all the pockets for cigs, weed, CDs and the 
like.  So uncool.  So no one is approaching me with organic marketing.

But Liquid Marketing from Chicago is seeking reps who live uber cool 
locales and know the hipsters at the local tattoo parlors and record 
stores.  These organic marketing reps have cash.  For the right hipsters.

Recently PBR funded a day party for cigarette-smoking, 
testosterone-charged, tattooed, pierced bike messengers in 
Portland.  $1,750.00.  Ummm.

The challenge:  you have to prove you are involved in a hipster 
subculture.  Is raving still hip?  My advice for promoters.  Get in touch 
with Neal Stewart, the divisional marketing manager at Pabst.  For the 
face-to-face with Neal or one of his local organic reps you should send 
someone with ample facial hardware and body art.  Take it from there.  Who 
knows, in a few weeks we might see a BSP for "PBR -- the hipster ug."

Good luck.

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"Americans have, for the most part, been exempt from the genuine tragedy of 
war and, as a consequence, seem more ready to accept their myths about war. 
They have never endured the reality against which other nations readily 
measure the cost of combat. And this makes us a very dangerous people. "
-Richard A. Gabriel

U 
--=====================_17792045==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Free Cash for "Hipster" Parties

Babst does have one thing going for it besides its brand though: It's
cheap. I don't think what these marketers are doing is anything new, it's
just that they have to be much more subtle and creative about it nowadays.
Today's youth are so used to being manipulated and marketed to that they
are much more resistant to it and it takes a lot more effort to get
through to them.

Another funny thing about Pabst, and its parent company Miller Brewing:
Miller was sold by its parent Phillip Morris to South African Breweries
last year. So Pabst Blue Ribbon, the classic American brand, is now owned
by a South African conglomerate.

To:  <prague@helsinki.cc.gatech.edu>

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0306221842250.23960-100000@charm>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: how to unsubscribe from sfraves

You're probably subscribed with a different address than the one you are
trying to unsubscribe from. Look at the full headers of one of the list
messages. Since you are using pine to read your mail, the command is "h".
Then look at the "Return-Path:" header, it will have the address you are
subscribed with encoded in it. Send a message to
sfraves-help@hyperreal.org for instructions on how to unsubscribe and
address that is different from your current one.


---------- Forwarded message ----------

account from this list (and have e-mailed the unsubscribe link four times

At 12:20 PM 6/23/2003 -0700, jacob z. wrote:
>can anyone give me some tips about where you can still buy 'rave' clothing
>around here?  all i need are some big pants, not too silly, preferably of
>the cargo variety (guess i'm not hip either, but whatever).  i've been in
>all the shops i used to have some luck in on haight street, in the castro,
>and around telegraph in berkeley, and nothing so far.  i even went looking
>a bit last weekend in hollywood, and i bought a pair of kikwear something
>or other pants, which have just now split a big hole in the ass and now i
>have to moon my coworkers all day long.  so someone help me with my
>ass-hole problem, and please don't say hot topic if you can help it...
>
>thanks,
>j

Denim, denim everywhere....  Have you tried Distractions on the upper 
Haight?  These days I get cargo pants cheaply by visiting Ross 
outlets.  They sometimes carry remaindered phat pants also.  Then there is 
Ragz.  I know the one at the Stonestown Mall used to carry Kikwear and 
similar products.

Love,

Apollo

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

Subject: Re: [sfraves] kitty litter grains: sujet du jour nrr

the number one thing you need to look for in a kitten
is the ability to talk. while this might not seem as
important as cute fur or pretty eyes, sooner or later
it is bound to come in handy.

the surprising thing is that many people who own
kittens and cats that can talk are totally unaware of
the fact. cats have oddly-shaped vocal chords, which
makes their utterances often seem devoid of meaning to
the average listener.

cats were actually created by the insane wizard Murp,
when he decided that the perfect animal would be half
owl and half monkey. however, cats are in denial of
the monkey side of their natures, which is why they
will say, if you ever ask them about it, "me owl."


Giles

This makes me so proud to be a resident of this city that I can barely
contain myself, topping the arrival of Polly Esther's and the return of
the Saddle Rack.  "House, down-tempo, R&B, and commercial hip-hop." 
Yessiree, that's exactly what San Jose needs more of.  =\

Deactivating the sarcasm, there are actually some cool things happening in
San Jose now.  Club Four on Bascom is becoming a fun place to be a few
times a month, with progressive and psy making inroads.

C.

PS - I still miss The Usual, being the sucker for 80s nights that I am...
as long as I don't feel like I'm having the decade forced down my throat
and jammed up my ass like at Polly's.

Subject: (NRR) a request from the east side of the bay

sorry to send this to the list but, this is aimed to
those that i know whose e-mail addresses i no longer
have and those that i don't know but can help...

the events of the weekend that i reference i'll
probably post to the list once i can gather all the
thoughts floating around in my head and make a clear
statement about them but, to paraphrase the weekend: 3
days/2 nights at angels camp with many, many beautiful
souls and one wonderful spirit of a woman whom i had
many lovely conversations with without using words...

----

due to the events and experiences of this weekend i
refuse to be defeated by the bay area and move to
florida so i'm asking you all for some help.  if you
could please inform me of any and all jobs that you
know of or come across i would appreciate it.  also,
please take a look at my resume
http://www.xp12.com/gkfrazee/resume/Gabriel_Frazee-Resume.txt,
http://www.xp12.com/gkfrazee/resume/Gabriel_Frazee-Resume.DOC
and
http://www.xp12.com/gkfrazee/resume/Gabriel_Frazee-Resume.pdf)and
keep me in mind.

i am not necessarily looking for IS/IT jobs, though
that would be preferred, but anything.  i've applied
to everything job that i am remotely qualified for but
with not luck as of now.  since i do not have a car it
would need to be accessible via public transit and i
would prefer the east bay.

i'm also in dire need of couches to sleep on that are
close to bart and preferably in the east bay as i am
without a place to stay at the moment; a place with
reliable internet access would be prefered as well.
the easiest way to get in touch with me is via e-mail
as i am unsure as to where i am staying next though i
will be updating my resume with my current contact
information once i know what it is.

thank you all, and i will try to stay in better touch
with you all once things in my life are more stable.

=====

> ATTACHMENT part 4 message/rfc822 
> Message-Id: <5.2.1.1.2.20030622145236.02820880@mail.speakeasy.net>
> Date: Sun, 22 Jun 2003 15:34:29 -0700
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> Mime-Version: 1.0
> Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
> 	boundary="=====================_17792045==.ALT"
> Subject: SRR:  Free Cash for "Hipster" Parties
> 
> I had hoped to go to the Sunset party this afternoon, but my partner
> came 
> down with a serious infection.  So instead I spent this morning
> reading the 
> New York Times.  In the NRT Magazine I came across an article by Rob
> Walker 
> of "Slate" titled "The Marketing of No Marketing."
> 
> There are many theories about capturing the "souls" of today's cool, 
> anit-establishment youth through various marketing techniques.  One
> can 
> hire hip kids, give them a new product, and have them show up at
> trendoid 
> events "undercover" as it were.  They alert their friends to the new
> deal 
> in self-validation, and away you go:  viral marketing.
> 
> Then there's "organic" marketing or Plan B, as Alex Wipperfurth (with
> an 
> umlaut) of SF's youth marketing firm "Plan B" calls this tactic. 
> Take a 
> dying, underdog brand, and facilitate its acceptance by "lifestyle as
> 
> dissent" constituencies who view consumption as protest.  These
> people are 
> all about, as Alex says, "freedom and rejecting middle-class mores."
> 
> Yes.
> 
> So we have Pabst Blue Ribbon beer.  My dad used to drink the stuff. 
> I 
> thought they went out of business years ago.  But lo and behold,
> Pabst, or 
> "PBR," recently appeared in the "Hipster's Handbook" and has been
> adopted 
> by hipsters in trendy bars from the Mission District here to the
> Lower East 
> Side in NYC.
> 
> Portland, that bastion of the alternative, is sucking this
> "retro-chic" 
> liquid down the pierced gullets.  As 28-year-old Phil Barnes, who
> just had 
> a PBR logo burned into his back says:  "Pabst is part of my 
> subculture.  It's the only beer I think about."  Phil is a
> skate-boarder 
> and punk rocker.
> 
> Good to see people with passionate beliefs.
> 
> Me...I guess I'm tragically unhip these days.  Without a consumer
> belief 
> system. You see, I still wear cargo pants.  Wore them before they
> became 
> trendy and wear them now, even though a couple of years ago --  it
> seemed 
> to happen over night -- all my hip friends started to wear denim
> jeans.  I 
> just couldn't part with all the pockets for cigs, weed, CDs and the 
> like.  So uncool.  So no one is approaching me with organic
> marketing.
> 
> But Liquid Marketing from Chicago is seeking reps who live uber cool 
> locales and know the hipsters at the local tattoo parlors and record 
> stores.  These organic marketing reps have cash.  For the right
> hipsters.
> 
> Recently PBR funded a day party for cigarette-smoking, 
> testosterone-charged, tattooed, pierced bike messengers in 
> Portland.  $1,750.00.  Ummm.
> 
> The challenge:  you have to prove you are involved in a hipster 
> subculture.  Is raving still hip?  My advice for promoters.  Get in
> touch 
> with Neal Stewart, the divisional marketing manager at Pabst.  For
> the 
> face-to-face with Neal or one of his local organic reps you should
> send 
> someone with ample facial hardware and body art.  Take it from there.
>  Who 
> knows, in a few weeks we might see a BSP for "PBR -- the hipster ug."
> 
> Good luck.
> 
> Love,
> 
> Apollo
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net
> 
> House Music 101: 
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> "Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor
> do 
> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is
> no 
> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a
> daring 
> adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
> 
> "Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.
>  It's 
> a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness
> well can 
> we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real
> when we 
> recognize our shared humanity."
> -Pema Chodron
> 
> "Americans have, for the most part, been exempt from the genuine
> tragedy of 
> war and, as a consequence, seem more ready to accept their myths
> about war. 
> They have never endured the reality against which other nations
> readily 
> measure the cost of combat. And this makes us a very dangerous
> people. "
> -Richard A. Gabriel
> 
> U 

> ATTACHMENT part 5 message/rfc822 
> Date: Sun, 22 Jun 2003 15:54:45 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Dan Haskovec <dan@pry.com>
> To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> CC:  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0306221543150.1672-100000@charm>
> MIME-Version: 1.0
> Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR:  Free Cash for "Hipster" Parties
> 
> Babst does have one thing going for it besides its brand though: It's
> cheap. I don't think what these marketers are doing is anything new,
> it's
> just that they have to be much more subtle and creative about it
> nowadays.
> Today's youth are so used to being manipulated and marketed to that
> they
> are much more resistant to it and it takes a lot more effort to get
> through to them.
> 
> Another funny thing about Pabst, and its parent company Miller
> Brewing:
> Miller was sold by its parent Phillip Morris to South African
> Breweries
> last year. So Pabst Blue Ribbon, the classic American brand, is now
> owned
> by a South African conglomerate.
> 
> 
>

> ATTACHMENT part 10 message/rfc822 
> Date: Sun, 22 Jun 2003 18:46:06 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Dan Haskovec <dan@pry.com>
> To:  <prague@helsinki.cc.gatech.edu>
> CC:  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0306221842250.23960-100000@charm>
> MIME-Version: 1.0
> Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
> Subject: how to unsubscribe from sfraves
> 
> You're probably subscribed with a different address than the one you
> are
> trying to unsubscribe from. Look at the full headers of one of the
> list
> messages. Since you are using pine to read your mail, the command is
> "h".
> Then look at the "Return-Path:" header, it will have the address you
> are
> subscribed with encoded in it. Send a message to
> sfraves-help@hyperreal.org for instructions on how to unsubscribe and
> address that is different from your current one.
> 
> 
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> Date: Sun, 22 Jun 2003 20:43:28 -0400 (EDT)

> the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is
> no 
> safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a
> daring 
> adventure or nothing."
> -Helen Keller
> 
> "Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.
>  It's 
> a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness
> well can 
> we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real
> when we 
> recognize our shared humanity."
> -Pema Chodron
> 
> "It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
> -Dizzy Gillespie

Subject: BSP: Rabbit In The Moon @ Braintree  Thursday 7.3.03

Hey folks, KZSU will be giving away tickets to this one!

---------- Forwarded message ----------
What: 	BrainTree 'Mythology' Multi Media Art Event
Where: 	1015 Folsom
When:	Thursday, July 3, 2003; 9:30pm-5am
Cost: 	$15 Advance ticket sales: www.1015.com 21+up w/id

RABBIT IN THE MOON DJ's CONFUCIUS and BUNNY w/ Gavin
Hardkiss aka HAWKE.

San Francisco, CA, July 3, 2003:  The BrainTree
presents Mythology, an evening of chaos and bliss
featuring a rare performance/ DJ set from RABBIT IN
THE MOON DJs Confucius and Bunny.  Based in Tampa,
Florida, Rabbit In The Moon is hailed as one of
electronic musics most innovative acts.  They have
deeply influenced American dance culture, and
developed a huge underground following with their
innovative shows.  They have also re-mixed tracks for
artists such as Garbage, Orbital, the Smashing
Pumpkins, and Sarah McLachlan to name a few. On July
3, for the first time in San Francisco, Confucius and
Bunny will perform with an array of choreographed
artists; including,  OVT visuals based in Chicago,
Mellodia a performance artist from San Diego, and a
group of San Francisco dancers and fire performers.
This rare performance will blow your senses sky high!

Legendary producer and electronic music innovator,
Gavin Hardkiss aka HAWKE(six degrees/sunburn), will
perform a live set of all new music with members of
his rotating band. Gavin says, "I've been working
really hard, and this is some the best music I've ever
produced."

ESP, extra sensory projection, a cutting edge, live
audio/visual trio that contains members of the
innovative Dimension 7 will perform their original
content to kick off the evening.

Also Performing: DJ Lorin (bassnectar.net), Alibi
(house of lotus), DR.LUNG, Laron, and DJ 34.

About the BrainTree:  The BrainTree creates
opportunities for artists and promotes collaboration
between artists of various genres. Every first
Thursday at 1015 Folsom, The BrainTree provides a
multi media environment for creative expression,
showcasing the best local and international visual
artists, musicians, and performers. Creative
Convergence.

HIGHTOWER: The Stupidity of Federal Drug Policy

By Jim Hightower, AlterNet
June 23, 2003

Let's hear it for Ed Rosenthal!

He's a marijuana grower  but before you can say "drug dealer," let me say 
that he grows his marijuana to be sold for medical purposes, supplying 
patients under doctor supervision and who need the medicine to treat severe 
and chronic pain, cancer-induced nausea, and other ailments.

Providing medical marijuana for these patients, many of whom are terminally 
ill and have no other medicine to ease their agonies, is not only humane 
and medically sound, but it's also perfectly legal  in 1996, the people of 
California voted to OK this use of the cannabis plant.

In 2001, however, George W chose John "Mad Dog" Ashcroft to be the U.S. 
attorney general, and this super-pious, right-wing extremist has zero 
respect for the will of the people. Asserting his personal bias over 
states' rights and democratic choice, the authoritarian Ashcroft is on a 
prosecutorial crusade against California and the eight other states that 
have passed medical marijuana laws.

Saying that his views and the federal law pre-empt state law, Ashcroft's 
agents have been going after people like Rosenthal with a vengeance. In a 
perverse, Orwellian twist of justice, the Feds convicted Ed by refusing to 
allow him to tell jurors that he was operating within state law. Jurors 
later angrily said they would've acquitted him had they known this.

Now the good news: Instead of 100 years in prison and a $4.5 million fine, 
as the absurd federal law allows, the judge only assessed a thousand dollar 
fine and one day in prison for Ed. Rosenthal will now appeal the silly 
conviction itself, and his case has become a rallying point for all of us 
who think this federal law is an anti-American assault on our basic 
liberties. Yet Ashcroft is as arrogant and autocratic as ever  as one of 
his agents said of Ed and us supporters of common sense: "We are not 
listening to them."

And that's exactly what's wrong with national drug policy.

http://www.alternet.org/drugreporter/


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: HIGHTOWER: The Stupidity of Federal Drug Policy

>(Hightower)"it's also perfectly legal  in 1996, the people of California 
>voted to OK this use of the cannabis plant...Saying that his views and the 
>federal law pre-empt state law, Ashcroft's agents have been going after 
>people like Rosenthal with a vengeance."

this is utterly specious.  you'd think that someone who, as Hightower did, 
has actuall worked in state government, would have come to understand that 
under federal law, a given federal law pre-empts (that's the legal term) any 
conflicting state law on the same subject.  that's how legalized segregation 
was eliminated.  that's the law of the land, like it or not.  and as such, 
whether Rosenthal--or anyone else--was acting under state law is totally 
legally irrelevant to the federal case.

--hb

At 08:48 AM 6/25/2003 -0700, innocentchild wrote:
>It was sad enough when Housewares was bought out by ESDJCO, but now to see
>it closing... =(

>ESDJCO Records on Haight (formerly Housewares) - Closing Sale.
>now through Saturday June 28th.
>1322 Haight St. at Central in the Upper Haight, San Francisco  (415)252-1440
>Hours Open. 12-7pm everyday.

Yes...I bought my house records there for many years when it was 
Housewares.  Knew the staff.  The place was like a second home to me.  I 
felt that when they were purchased by ESDJCO their days were numbered.  The 
selection of vinyl declined and the concentration seemed to be on clothes 
and other gear.

Love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

I loved how all of Owen's artwork was upstairs. I love that guy's art! I =
remember one day asking if I could go up and look at it all and they let =
me so long as I didn't touch anything. That was a good day.=20

But my number one memory of the place was back in Spring of 1999 before =
I got into partying. I was living in lower haight and a friend from San =
Ramon came out to see me and check out upper haight. I remember her =
wanting to check out housewares because it looked cool inside. We go in =
and I'm milling around and one of the guys working asks me *do you like =
house?* I looked at him blankly and said - *I don't really listen to =
this stuff anymore*  On our way out he yells *you will like it one day! =
everyone does!!*  All I could think was *yeah right kid... whatever*  =
Funny how things work out. 4 years later I love house and it's my =
favorite genre to dance to (besides good breaks). =3D)

:: r y a n ::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Remembering Relic....

Relic was a cool party. No I'm not biased because I helped throw it. It was
just a really fun, intimate party and the last party ever thrown at
Overworld (predecesor to the now Otherworld). There was a lot of work put
into that party. The most we have every done for a party come to think of
it. Personally I really liked Amalgamation more. It was nutso-chaotic and
full of energy. Relic seemed a lot more social and chill as I recall. Either
way both parties were a lot of fun. =)

My top party is a toss up between Cloudfactory 6yr and FnF Campout 2000.

>Where: 	1015 Folsom
>When:	Thursday, July 3, 2003; 9:30pm-5am
>Cost: 	$15 Advance ticket sales: www.1015.com 21+up w/id
>
>RABBIT IN THE MOON DJ's CONFUCIUS and BUNNY w/ Gavin
>Hardkiss aka HAWKE.
>
>San Francisco, CA, July 3, 2003:  The BrainTree
>presents Mythology, an evening of chaos and bliss
>featuring a rare performance/ DJ set from RABBIT IN
>THE MOON DJs Confucius and Bunny.  Based in Tampa,
>Florida, Rabbit In The Moon is hailed as one of
>electronic musics most innovative acts.  They have
>deeply influenced American dance culture, and
>developed a huge underground following with their
>innovative shows.  They have also re-mixed tracks for
>artists such as Garbage, Orbital, the Smashing
>Pumpkins, and Sarah McLachlan to name a few. On July
>3, for the first time in San Francisco, Confucius and
>Bunny will perform with an array of choreographed
>artists; including,  OVT visuals based in Chicago,
>Mellodia a performance artist from San Diego, and a
>group of San Francisco dancers and fire performers.
>This rare performance will blow your senses sky high!
>
>Legendary producer and electronic music innovator,
>Gavin Hardkiss aka HAWKE(six degrees/sunburn), will
>perform a live set of all new music with members of
>his rotating band. Gavin says, "I've been working
>really hard, and this is some the best music I've ever
>produced."
>
>ESP, extra sensory projection, a cutting edge, live
>audio/visual trio that contains members of the
>innovative Dimension 7 will perform their original
>content to kick off the evening.
>
>Also Performing: DJ Lorin (bassnectar.net), Alibi
>(house of lotus), DR.LUNG, Laron, and DJ 34.
>
>About the BrainTree:  The BrainTree creates
>opportunities for artists and promotes collaboration
>between artists of various genres. Every first
>Thursday at 1015 Folsom, The BrainTree provides a
>multi media environment for creative expression,
>showcasing the best local and international visual
>artists, musicians, and performers. Creative
>Convergence.

>Hey folks, KZSU will be giving away tickets to this one!

>---------- Forwarded message ----------
>What: 	BrainTree 'Mythology' Multi Media Art Event
>Where: 	1015 Folsom
>When:	Thursday, July 3, 2003; 9:30pm-5am
>Cost: 	$15 Advance ticket sales: www.1015.com 21+up w/id
>
>RABBIT IN THE MOON DJ's CONFUCIUS and BUNNY w/ Gavin
>Hardkiss aka HAWKE.
>
>San Francisco, CA, July 3, 2003:  The BrainTree
>presents Mythology, an evening of chaos and bliss
>featuring a rare performance/ DJ set from RABBIT IN
>THE MOON DJ's Confucius and Bunny.  Based in Tampa,
>Florida, Rabbit In The Moon is hailed as one of
>electronic music's most innovative acts.  They have
>deeply influenced American dance culture, and
>developed a huge underground following with their
>innovative shows.  They have also re-mixed tracks for
>artists such as Garbage, Orbital, the Smashing
>Pumpkins, and Sarah McLachlan to name a few. On July
>3, for the first time in San Francisco, Confucius and
>Bunny will perform with an array of choreographed
>artists; including,  OVT visuals based in Chicago,
>Mellodia a performance artist from San Diego, and a
>group of San Francisco dancers and fire performers.
>This rare performance will blow your senses sky high!
>
>Legendary producer and electronic music innovator,
>Gavin Hardkiss aka HAWKE(six degrees/sunburn), will
>perform a live set of all new music with members of
>his rotating band. Gavin says, "I've been working
>really hard, and this is some the best music I've ever produced."
>
>ESP, extra sensory projection, a cutting edge, live audio/visual trio 
>that contains members of the innovative Dimension 7 will perform their 
>original content to kick off the evening.
>
>Also Performing: DJ Lorin (bassnectar.net), Alibi
>(house of lotus), DR.LUNG, Laron, and DJ 34.
>
>About the BrainTree:  The BrainTree creates
>opportunities for artists and promotes collaboration
>between artists of various genres. Every first
>Thursday at 1015 Folsom, The BrainTree provides a
>multi media environment for creative expression,
>showcasing the best local and international visual
>artists, musicians, and performers. Creative
>Convergence.
>

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

TECHSPLOITATION: What is the Internet?

By Annalee Newitz, AlterNet
June 23, 2003

Several things in the past few weeks have driven me into a Hulk-like frenzy 
of geek fury. One of those things was the new Hulk flick, but we'll let 
that one slide for now. You'll just have to banish Ang Lee's misguided 
movie from your mind as you imagine me getting greener and greener, madder 
and madder, until I'm finally several yards tall, the glasses have popped 
off my distended face, and I'm punching the Windows 98 boxes that litter my 
office, screaming, "NERD ANGRY!!! NERD SMASH!!!"

It all started, like so many geek rampages recently have, with a stupid 
Microsoft puppet company called the Santa Cruz Operation. My devious hacker 
friend Mason kept sending me links about SCO that he'd ripped off from 
Slashdot, which he would follow up with a phone call. "What have you done 
to hurt SCO today?" he'd ask. When I admitted I'd done nothing more than 
read the SCO story told using characters from "The Dukes of Hazzard", he 
would giggle evilly and say, "I've been crank calling them all morning on 
their 800 number! Mwah, mwah, mwah!"

Great. I'm not cool enough to crank call SCO and ask why its network has 
mysteriously crashed yet again. Unix vendor SCO has been having strange 
problems with its office computers ever since it decided to sue IBM for $3 
billion.

You may be asking, What the hell is insignificant little SCO doing in a 
lawsuit like that? Well, SCO claims IBM yanked some proprietary 
intellectual property (i.e., lines of code) out of Unix (which SCO owns by 
virtue of some buyout shenanigans during the wild and woolly 1990s) and 
tossed it over to Linus Torvalds (the engineer responsible for creating 
Linux), who apparently smuggled that code into his dirty little operating 
system. Meanwhile, in a most amusing move, SCO has declined to identify 
exactly which pieces of the code in Linux were stolen from it.

Early in this whole shitstorm, Microsoft licensed SCO's Unix technology, 
thereby giving a hot cash injection to the flagging company and implicitly 
supporting its claim.

Basically, the whole damn circus is a plot to undermine the credibility of 
Linux, an operating system that Microsoft considers one of the greatest 
threats to its empire. And yet there might be some dangerous precedents set 
once the FUD vapor clears. SCO's high-powered lawyer, David Boies (who 
represented the federal government in its antitrust suit against 
Microsoft), intends to argue that SCO owns copyrights to parts of the Unix 
operating system, which would set all kinds of dangerous precedents in 
future litigation because so many operating systems have bits of Unix and 
Unix-like code in them. You see why Microsoft might be excited about this 
idea. It would lead to more lawsuits and could ultimately make it a lot 
harder for companies without deep pockets to adopt open-source systems 
based on Unix or Linux.

Musing disgustedly on all of this, I was interrupted by a call on my cell. 
"Is this Annalee Newitz?" an unfamiliar voice asked. Fuck if I wasn't 
getting a goddamn telemarketing pitch on my previously spam-free cell 
phone: "Hi, I'm Puke Licker from Comcast, and we're wondering if you'd like 
to sign up for our new digital Internet service for a special rate this 
month."
After a long pause, I asked, "What is the Internet?"

This question obviously wasn't on his script. "Well, it's like computers," 
he helpfully explained. "Do you use computers in your home?"

"Oh no, we don't do that at my house. Sorry," I replied, clicking off.

So there you have it, boys and girls, right from the mouth of some 
technoplebe at Comcast: the Internet is like computers. See, no matter what 
SCO says or what the courts decide or whose asshole Microsoft is ramming 
full of its giant splintery dildo this month, the people have spoken. The 
Internet, whose software infrastructure is almost entirely based on Unix, 
is computers. Can any single corporate entity claim copyright on computers? 
Nope. I mean, what are computers, after all? I'll bet they're like the 
Internet. And nobody owns that, right?

Yeah, right. This is one of those moments when I wish there were an 
emoticon for sarcasm.

Annalee Newitz (bleah@techsploitation.com) is a surly media nerd who 
finally did something to hurt SCO today. Her column also appears in Metro, 
Silicon Valley's weekly newspaper.

http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=16240
-

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_15748266==.ALT--

Subject: SRR: BSB: Altered States and the Spiritual Awakening

--0-990699056-1056651987=:5114
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Hi, There is this conference I am working on, well actualy I was hired to make presenter's gifts and sort of got sucked in because it was really interesting, and guess what! The person who is putting on the conference went to the same school as my husband! , Anyway, for those of you into the spiritual side of raving this would be a fun thing to check out. I put SRR instead of NRR because there is an optional  party for the participants of the conference, (not at the same location, but walkable) I have been to both locations and they are FANTASTIC (IMHO), and have a really good vibe. Please respect the disclaimer that this is a "substance free" event. It's ok to post to other lists as long as you include the disclaimer.
 
7/11-7/13 Altered States and the Spiritual Awakening [SF]
A cross generational conference with Lectures and Workshops exploring Parapsychology, Transpersonal Psychology, and Entheogens. Opening and closing ceremonies, morning yoga, catered meals included. Weekend pass: $85 regular, $55 students. For more information on ASSA visit: http://www.assacon.com


Altered States and the Spiritual Awakening aims to create a uniquely interactive meeting of the minds. We are gathering together pioneers in the field of consciousness luminaries who have shown how to deepen the completeness of the human spirit and connections between souls and encouraging them to share their discoveries with those who wish to learn.

One of the primary goals of this conference is to bring together experts in multiple forms of altered states. We seek to cover three main spheres of knowledge: transpersonal and para-psychology, entheogens, and counsciousness exploration through external (technological) means. While all of the fields share certain commonalities, they all provide unique insights into how we can enrich the human psyche and deepen understanding of our existence.

The time is ripe to have a meeting like the one were organizing. Many youth today are actively searching to fill gaps of meaning and connection in their lives. All too often, young people turn to the underground cultures mind-altering substances to quickly numb themselves and deaden the sensations of spiritual longing. The value of spiritual awakening via altered states that was discovered by older generations has faded out of view. This conference is an attempt to bridge the gap between multiple generations of the same community and help gurus pass their wisdom to students.

In order to succeed at introducing a new generation of people to this type of wisdom, we are conducting this gathering differently than an average conference. First of all, we are deliberately setting the entrance fee at a point that will make it much more accessible to young people. False Profit, the group hosting the event, is predicated on emphasizing human value over financial value, and will turn no profit from the enterprise.

Moreover, this conference will take a different approach to communication than most others. We will go beyond a formal lecture-and-listen model and encourage a more personal learning process. Our loft space is conducive to establishing the intimate milieu we are aiming for. Overall, we aim to create a comfortable set and setting that will allow people to share openly in the event.

The presenters:

Morgan Brent, Ph.D.
Etzel Carde#55622;#57120;Ph.D.
Dr. Concrescence
Frank Echenhofer, Ph.D.
Earth Erowid
Fire Erowid
Ruth Inge-Heinze, Ph.D.
Robert Jesse
Jon Klimo, Ph.D.
Stanley Krippner, Ph.D.
Luis Eduardo Luna, Ph.D.
Maria Mangini, Ph.D. FNP, CNM
Justine E. Owens, Ph.D.
Daniel Pinchbeck
Ann Shulgin
Stuart Sovatsky, Ph.D.
Charles T. Tart, Ph.D.
Robert L. Van de Castle, Ph.D.


\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\
***Altered States and the Spiritual Awakening is a substance-free
event. We ask for your courtesy and respect toward the presenters and
staff in committing to this policy and the intention of the
gathering. Staff will ask attendees using substances to leave the
conference without refund.***
\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

Subject: Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks

--=====================_1224667==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Well I guess we will have to put a heater in our "chill" room at the next 
Moksha party.  This is all so absurd.........


Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks

Weds, June 25, 2003


In a blow to free speech and public health, the Fifth U.S. Circuit Court of 
Appeals overturned a federal judge's ruling that prohibited the government 
from banning glow sticks, pacifiers, and air-conditioned "chill out" rooms 
at a New Orleans nightclub. The Court of Appeals ruled that U.S. District 
Judge Thomas Porteous overstepped his bounds by blocking the government's 
ban on glow sticks and pacifiers during raves at the club. The appeals 
court tossed out the decision saying that the judge can't stop federal 
prosecutors from enforcing a condition of a plea bargain made in the 
criminal case against a promoter at the club.

The plea bargain deal was reached in a criminal case against a promoter at 
the State Palace Theater in New Orleans. Barbecue of New Orleans, which 
promotes events at the State Palace Theater, was charged with violating the 
federal "crack-house" law - a federal law created to arrest owners of 
property used primarily for drug offenses. The federal government sought to 
send the promoter to jail even though he was not involved in drugs and took 
active steps to keep drugs out of the club. In a plea agreement, the 
company was fined $100,000 and put on probation for five years. Robert 
Brunet, president of Barbecue of New Orleans, also agreed to ban glow 
sticks, vapor rub, pacifiers, dust masks, and other legal items from future 
parties, as well as to eliminate air-conditioned "chill out" rooms where 
patrons could cool off in after dancing to avoid over-heating.

The ban caught the attention of the ACLU, which filed a civil lawsuit 
against the government on behalf of several patrons of the club. The suit 
claimed that the ban violated the First Amendment rights of club attendees. 
Judge Porteous sided with the ACLU and ruled that federal prosecutors could 
not enforce the prohibition as part of the plea bargain. In his ruling, 
Porteous said, "The government cannot keep legal items out of places 
because of illegal activities they associate with those items."

The federal government appealed this decision and the 5th Circuit Court of 
Appeals ruled that third-parties do not have the right to challenge the 
constitutionality of a plea agreement that they are not a part of, even if 
it affects them. The plea agreement's ban on glow sticks and other legal 
items was reinstated. The Court of Appeals, however, did not rule on 
whether or not the federal government could force defendants to accept such 
bans as part of a plea agreement to avoid jail time. This leaves open the 
possibility of legal challenges to such bans in future cases.

The ruling also opens the door to the federal government using the Illicit 
Drug Anti-Proliferation Act (more commonly known as the RAVE Act) to coerce 
nightclub owners and event organizers into banning glow sticks and other 
legal items at their events. The Drug Policy Alliance, which not only 
fought the legislation in Congress, worked to overturn the New Orleans ban 
and will continue to work to repeal or reform the law and protect the free 
speech rights and well being of all Americans.

http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2438
h



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

-----Original Message-----
From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org] 
Sent: Thursday, June 26, 2003 3:13 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks

Well I guess we will have to put a heater in our "chill" room at the
next 
Moksha party.  This is all so absurd.........


Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks

Weds, June 25, 2003


In a blow to free speech and public health, the Fifth U.S. Circuit Court
of 
Appeals overturned a federal judge's ruling that prohibited the
government 
from banning glow sticks, pacifiers, and air-conditioned "chill out"
rooms 
at a New Orleans nightclub. The Court of Appeals ruled that U.S.
District 
Judge Thomas Porteous overstepped his bounds by blocking the
government's 
ban on glow sticks and pacifiers during raves at the club. The appeals 
court tossed out the decision saying that the judge can't stop federal 
prosecutors from enforcing a condition of a plea bargain made in the 
criminal case against a promoter at the club.

The plea bargain deal was reached in a criminal case against a promoter
at 
the State Palace Theater in New Orleans. Barbecue of New Orleans, which 
promotes events at the State Palace Theater, was charged with violating
the 
federal "crack-house" law - a federal law created to arrest owners of 
property used primarily for drug offenses. The federal government sought
to 
send the promoter to jail even though he was not involved in drugs and
took 
active steps to keep drugs out of the club. In a plea agreement, the 
company was fined $100,000 and put on probation for five years. Robert 
Brunet, president of Barbecue of New Orleans, also agreed to ban glow 
sticks, vapor rub, pacifiers, dust masks, and other legal items from
future 
parties, as well as to eliminate air-conditioned "chill out" rooms where

patrons could cool off in after dancing to avoid over-heating.

The ban caught the attention of the ACLU, which filed a civil lawsuit 
against the government on behalf of several patrons of the club. The
suit 
claimed that the ban violated the First Amendment rights of club
attendees. 
Judge Porteous sided with the ACLU and ruled that federal prosecutors
could 
not enforce the prohibition as part of the plea bargain. In his ruling, 
Porteous said, "The government cannot keep legal items out of places 
because of illegal activities they associate with those items."

The federal government appealed this decision and the 5th Circuit Court
of 
Appeals ruled that third-parties do not have the right to challenge the 
constitutionality of a plea agreement that they are not a part of, even
if 
it affects them. The plea agreement's ban on glow sticks and other legal

items was reinstated. The Court of Appeals, however, did not rule on 
whether or not the federal government could force defendants to accept
such 
bans as part of a plea agreement to avoid jail time. This leaves open
the 
possibility of legal challenges to such bans in future cases.

The ruling also opens the door to the federal government using the
Illicit 
Drug Anti-Proliferation Act (more commonly known as the RAVE Act) to
coerce 
nightclub owners and event organizers into banning glow sticks and other

legal items at their events. The Drug Policy Alliance, which not only 
fought the legislation in Congress, worked to overturn the New Orleans
ban 
and will continue to work to repeal or reform the law and protect the
free 
speech rights and well being of all Americans.

http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2438
h



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.
It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well
can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when
we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, June 26, 2003 3:12 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks


Well I guess we will have to put a heater in our "chill" room at the next
Moksha party.  This is all so absurd.........


Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks

Weds, June 25, 2003


In a blow to free speech and public health, the Fifth U.S. Circuit Court of
Appeals overturned a federal judge's ruling that prohibited the government
from banning glow sticks, pacifiers, and air-conditioned "chill out" rooms
at a New Orleans nightclub. The Court of Appeals ruled that U.S. District
Judge Thomas Porteous overstepped his bounds by blocking the government's
ban on glow sticks and pacifiers during raves at the club. The appeals
court tossed out the decision saying that the judge can't stop federal
prosecutors from enforcing a condition of a plea bargain made in the
criminal case against a promoter at the club.

The plea bargain deal was reached in a criminal case against a promoter at
the State Palace Theater in New Orleans. Barbecue of New Orleans, which
promotes events at the State Palace Theater, was charged with violating the
federal "crack-house" law - a federal law created to arrest owners of
property used primarily for drug offenses. The federal government sought to
send the promoter to jail even though he was not involved in drugs and took
active steps to keep drugs out of the club. In a plea agreement, the
company was fined $100,000 and put on probation for five years. Robert
Brunet, president of Barbecue of New Orleans, also agreed to ban glow
sticks, vapor rub, pacifiers, dust masks, and other legal items from future
parties, as well as to eliminate air-conditioned "chill out" rooms where
patrons could cool off in after dancing to avoid over-heating.

The ban caught the attention of the ACLU, which filed a civil lawsuit
against the government on behalf of several patrons of the club. The suit
claimed that the ban violated the First Amendment rights of club attendees.
Judge Porteous sided with the ACLU and ruled that federal prosecutors could
not enforce the prohibition as part of the plea bargain. In his ruling,
Porteous said, "The government cannot keep legal items out of places
because of illegal activities they associate with those items."

The federal government appealed this decision and the 5th Circuit Court of
Appeals ruled that third-parties do not have the right to challenge the
constitutionality of a plea agreement that they are not a part of, even if
it affects them. The plea agreement's ban on glow sticks and other legal
items was reinstated. The Court of Appeals, however, did not rule on
whether or not the federal government could force defendants to accept such
bans as part of a plea agreement to avoid jail time. This leaves open the
possibility of legal challenges to such bans in future cases.

The ruling also opens the door to the federal government using the Illicit
Drug Anti-Proliferation Act (more commonly known as the RAVE Act) to coerce
nightclub owners and event organizers into banning glow sticks and other
legal items at their events. The Drug Policy Alliance, which not only
fought the legislation in Congress, worked to overturn the New Orleans ban
and will continue to work to repeal or reform the law and protect the free
speech rights and well being of all Americans.

http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=488&l=2438
h



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4910.0300
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks

Umm, I think you're kind of mis-construing what this article is saying,
Apollo.  The court did not say that the government could ban glowsticks.
The judge's ruling was purely procedural.  Read:

"The appeals
court tossed out the decision saying that the judge can't stop federal
prosecutors from enforcing a condition of a plea bargain made in the
criminal case against a promoter at the club."

"The federal government appealed this decision and the 5th Circuit Court of
Appeals ruled that third-parties do not have the right to challenge the
constitutionality of a plea agreement that they are not a part of, even if
it affects them."

This is a decision about plea bargains and the ability of third parties to
contest them; not about glowsticks or raves or anything like that.

So don't worry - no heater needed for your chill room.

-- Jonathan

All I can say without being hauled off by jack-booted thugs is this: 
get out there and vote these people out. I know it's hard to get a vote 
in edgewise these days, but it's time to mobilize. Clear the beltway. 
Get involved. I thought for sure all the rumblings about the RAVE act 
(before it was passed) would charge up the EDM community and get 
everyone involved, but it seems like after GWII was "won" everyone's 
been sheepishly silenced.  And I don't blame anyone - it's hard going 
up against popularity - but I have a feeling that most of us have been 
doing that since an early age.

Personally, I'm still trying to find a way to get people riled up 
again.. :)

Now, back to your regularly scheduled pumping techno party music, 
glo-sticks, and dust masks.

  - omid

--- Jonathan <jonathan@dawgbuddha.net> wrote:
> Umm, I think you're kind of mis-construing what this
> article is saying,
> Apollo.  The court did not say that the government
> could ban glowsticks.
> The judge's ruling was purely procedural.  Read:
> 
> "The appeals
> court tossed out the decision saying that the judge
> can't stop federal
> prosecutors from enforcing a condition of a plea
> bargain made in the
> criminal case against a promoter at the club."
> 
> "The federal government appealed this decision and
> the 5th Circuit Court of
> Appeals ruled that third-parties do not have the
> right to challenge the
> constitutionality of a plea agreement that they are
> not a part of, even if
> it affects them."
> 
> This is a decision about plea bargains and the
> ability of third parties to
> contest them; not about glowsticks or raves or
> anything like that.
> 
> So don't worry - no heater needed for your chill
> room.
> 
> -- Jonathan

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 03:29 PM 6/26/2003 -0700, Jonathan wrote:
>Umm, I think you're kind of mis-construing what this article is saying,
>Apollo.  The court did not say that the government could ban glowsticks.
>The judge's ruling was purely procedural.  Read:
>
>"The appeals
>court tossed out the decision saying that the judge can't stop federal
>prosecutors from enforcing a condition of a plea bargain made in the
>criminal case against a promoter at the club."
>
>"The federal government appealed this decision and the 5th Circuit Court of
>Appeals ruled that third-parties do not have the right to challenge the
>constitutionality of a plea agreement that they are not a part of, even if
>it affects them."
>
>This is a decision about plea bargains and the ability of third parties to
>contest them; not about glowsticks or raves or anything like that.

The full text of the decision is 
here:  http://emdef.org/c/state-palace/030620_plea_inj_vacated_us5.pdf

In the plea bargain the defendants agreed to eliminate glow sticks, chill 
rooms and other "evidence" of MDMA use from their parties.  A court 
overturned this element of the plea bargain -- and the new ruling 
reinstates these conditions, ie, that the glow sticks, etc. can be banned 
from further parties as a part of the plea bargain.  This is how I 
understand it.  Although this may be procedural, it reopens the whole issue 
that certain cultural artifacts of the rave subculture can be used to 
prosecute promoters and venue owners.  At least, this is how I understand it.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_4134622==.ALT--

At 03:40 PM 6/26/2003 -0700, Brian Lafferty wrote:
>Time for another Summer of Love eh? I do believe that
>at some point this whole move to the right has got to
>give. It started with Nixon in the 70's, continued
>with 4 years of mild rollbacks to the center in the
>Carter admin. Then came the black twelve years with
>Reagan/Bush and another respite with Clinton for the
>next 8.  But this is different. It's like we're going
>up a steep hill, something has to happen. We have to
>come down the other side.

I think that's beginning to happen.  I was waiting in the doctor's office 
yesterday, and I picked up a "Time" magazine to kill the time, as it 
were.  Now Time was always to the "right" of Newsweek, as I recall, though 
I rarely read either these days.  There were several articles about "Where 
Are the WMD?" of course.  But there was also an editorial very critical of 
the tax cuts -- taking the position they benefit the wealthy.  Then there 
was a piece about some minister who said, essentially, that the message of 
Christ did not concern things like sexual behavior and drug use.  Christ 
was much more focused in greed, and greed seems to have become a virtue in 
modern America.  Interesting.

As things become progressively darker on the economic front, people will 
want to party --  that is, feel human for a few hours a week.  If they have 
to go underground to do it, they will.  Always have.  Things in general are 
heating up.  Everyone has some limit to the bullshit they can eat and the 
oppression they can endure.


>The problem is, I don't want to wait. By the time it
>comes around, I'm going to be too old. Can SFR and
>other tribes (i.e. Friends N Family, Skills etc.) Get
>some serious response to the RAVE ACT this time? There
>is a National Day of Action coming. Make sure it's on
>a Saturday, announce it here. And show up on the
>Federal Court House Steps with all the sound you can
>bring! We have got to stand up or soon there will be
>no one who can.

Perhaps WE have to organize this.  I'm up for it.


>As a post script, did anyone besides me get the most
>non-committal, nonresponsive letter back from Boxer's
>office stating essentially "oh well, it's
>law...there's nothing we can do?" That made me mad. So
>I am in the process of writing back. Did anyone else?

I have been writing a letter a week to all my reps on this issue.  No days 
I get four or five letters from Pelosi in response to my stuff.

Apollo

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 27 Jun 2003 00:01:49.0337 (UTC) FILETIME=[4E748090:01C33C3F]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks

>"Although this may be procedural, it reopens the whole issue that certain 
>cultural artifacts of the rave subculture can be used to prosecute 
>promoters and venue owners. "

only in the case referred to; what the decision says is that after a final 
plea bargain and criminal judgement, the court can't go back and change the 
result absent a valid appeal, and it also affirms the principle that third 
parties (the people who sued to have the restrictions overturned, who were 
not parties to the original New Orleans criminal case) cannot appeal 
criminal judgements in cases with which they are not personally involved.

--hb

Anyone else find the irony that yesterday was George Orwells 100th
Birthday?

It seems his spirit still lives on....

On the news yesterday...
1. UK moves to register DNA of all babies "for future health care needs"
(NPR)
2. Internet providers will submit user information to record industry,
so they can search and prosecute "large file sharers." (NPR, CNN, KRON4)
3. In Santa Cruz, Pacific Mall lists and bans ex-convicts from entering
and shopping on the mall premises. (KRON-4)

Let's not forget talks of the Glow Stick ban.

Have a good day, comrade.

were.  Now Time was always to the "right" of Newsweek, as I recall,
though 
I rarely read either these days.  There were several articles about
"Where 
Are the WMD?" of course.  But there was also an editorial very critical
of 
the tax cuts -- taking the position they benefit the wealthy.  Then
there 
was a piece about some minister who said, essentially, that the message
of 
Christ did not concern things like sexual behavior and drug use.  Christ

was much more focused in greed, and greed seems to have become a virtue
in 
modern America.  Interesting.

As things become progressively darker on the economic front, people will

want to party --  that is, feel human for a few hours a week.  If they
have 
to go underground to do it, they will.  Always have.  Things in general
are 
heating up.  Everyone has some limit to the bullshit they can eat and
the 
oppression they can endure.


>The problem is, I don't want to wait. By the time it
>comes around, I'm going to be too old. Can SFR and
>other tribes (i.e. Friends N Family, Skills etc.) Get
>some serious response to the RAVE ACT this time? There
>is a National Day of Action coming. Make sure it's on
>a Saturday, announce it here. And show up on the
>Federal Court House Steps with all the sound you can
>bring! We have got to stand up or soon there will be
>no one who can.

Perhaps WE have to organize this.  I'm up for it.


>As a post script, did anyone besides me get the most
>non-committal, nonresponsive letter back from Boxer's
>office stating essentially "oh well, it's
>law...there's nothing we can do?" That made me mad. So
>I am in the process of writing back. Did anyone else?

I have been writing a letter a week to all my reps on this issue.  No
days 
I get four or five letters from Pelosi in response to my stuff.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.
It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well
can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when
we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U

	charset="Windows-1252"

X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.50.4807.1700
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4910.0300
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks

Hb is absolutely right.  The ruling relates to a plea bargain that the
defendants in New Orleans made with the government, and a plea bargain is
not the law.

This is not to say that the current regime in this country is not arrayed
against us, but when we jump to conclusions and mis-state things, it only
makes us look foolish.  There's lots of really really important things to
get upset about (the aforementioned black hole of Guantanamo Bay being one
of them), but a single plea bargain banning glowsticks at one single venue
is not one of them.


----- Original Message -----
From: "DJ Howlin' Bob" <djhbomb999@hotmail.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, June 26, 2003 5:01 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Court: Government Can Ban Glow Sticks


> >"Although this may be procedural, it reopens the whole issue that certain
> >cultural artifacts of the rave subculture can be used to prosecute
> >promoters and venue owners. "
>
> only in the case referred to; what the decision says is that after a final
> plea bargain and criminal judgement, the court can't go back and change
the
> result absent a valid appeal, and it also affirms the principle that third
> parties (the people who sued to have the restrictions overturned, who were
> not parties to the original New Orleans criminal case) cannot appeal
> criminal judgements in cases with which they are not personally involved.
>
> --hb

> Hb is absolutely right.  The ruling relates to a plea bargain that the
> defendants in New Orleans made with the government, and a plea bargain is
> not the law.
>
> This is not to say that the current regime in this country is not arrayed
> against us, but when we jump to conclusions and mis-state things, it only
> makes us look foolish.  There's lots of really really important things to
> get upset about (the aforementioned black hole of Guantanamo Bay being one
> of them), but a single plea bargain banning glowsticks at one single venue
> is not one of them.
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "DJ Howlin' Bob" <djhbomb999@hotmail.com>

certain
