final
> > plea bargain and criminal judgement, the court can't go back and change

Hell... Time magazine?  That's nothing.

Even Warren Buffett, founder and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, and (usually) the
second richest person in the world has condemned the shrub's tax cut package to
be nothing more than a bullshit payoff to the uber-rich!

He put it more eloquently than me, of course, in an editorial he wrote for the
Washingtom Post; in which he describes the way the shrub's tax cut plan gives
him a $310 million tax-free payout, and pushes HIS effective tax rate down to
about 3%; while leaving his receptionist's (his example) rate at about 30%!  He
then goes on to compare the idea that this will "stimulate the economy" to
"voodoo economics" the term first coined by the shrub's own father to criticize
reagan's plans to create money out of nothingness, by cutting taxes and raising
military spending.

http://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn?pagename=article&node=&contentId=A13113-2003May19&notFound=true


cya,
john

X-Priority: 3 (Normal)

Importance: Normal
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2727.1300
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: DJUnderground.com - We're still looking for more DJs and Producers!

------=_NextPart_000_001E_01C33CD1.53B729D0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

For those who have read this post already within the past few weeks and
have emailed me, thank you.  We are within the final steps of releasing
the site and making it "live".  Next week we are going into testing.
EVERYONE who has responded will get an email back, if you haven't heard
from me already.
 
There is going to be a new web site that has never been done before.  It
will cater to the underground electronic DJ scene in the Bay Area, with
styles of music ranging from House, Trance, NRG, Hard Trance, Hard
House, Jungle, DnB, Ambient, Acid Jazz, Turntablism, etc. (I think you
get the point).  Interested?  Keep reading...
 
Does this fit your description?  An electronic DJ or composer that is
too talented for their own good, but doesn't know how to get themselves
known...
 
...This is where we come in.  
 
If you think you got some killer dj mixes or some tracks you put
together yourself, then we are looking (more specifically, listening)
for you.  We're looking for 25-50 talented DJ's and composers to get the
site launched with fresh, off-the-hook slammin' music.  We're looking
for 192kbps mp3's of your mixes or tracks.  If we like what we hear,
then we'll give you a free 6-month membership to our site.  More details
will be explained once we make contact with you.
 
We are just like you - we are doing this for the music, and for the
electronic community.  This site will cater to the electronic DJ's in
every aspect imaginable.
 
If you are interested, please follow the below steps:
 
1) email djunderground@wctech.net with the subject "I am interested in
DJUnderground.com".  Let us know you will be sending your mix(es) or
track(s) in the mail.  ** We are not accepting any more tracks and mixes
by email or URL **
 
2) When you mail us your music, please be sure to include a tracked out
Audio CD, a 192kbps MP3 CD, tracklisting, specific genre and/or style
you want to be described as, and your contact information.  This ensures
everything to go smooth if we choose your music.
 
3) Send the package to DJUnderground.com, 15340 Charmeran Ave., San Jose
CA 95124-3409.
 
4) Once we receive your music and listen to it (turnaround usually a
day), we will send you an email with more detailed information.  If you
have music we like, we will give you all your account information, plus
extra instructions.
 
 
We are also looking for people who are interested in writing articles or
reviews on the electronic scene.  These can range from CD reviews, to
Singles reviews of tracks that are out there right now, clubs, raves - I
think you get the point.  Anything and everything that relates to the
electronic scene.  If you are interested, please email
djunderground@wctech.net with the subject "I want to write articles!".
 
 
If you know of places where we can get RSS feeds (free or paying) that
we can place on our site, please email djunderground@wctech.net with the
subject "I know where you can get RSS feeds!"  Don't send us URL's to a
list of 1 million non-related RSS feeds.  We're looking for good, solid,
electronica related feeds that are updated at least once a week.
 
If you feel you can offer ANYTHING else to the site, please by all means
email us.  Just email djunderground@wctech.net with the subject "I can
offer something to DJUnderground.com".
 
For some of you who have doubts about this site, or who don't really
know what this site is and are getting rather upset not knowing what the
heck this is about, just know that DJ Seven (http://www.djsevenpix.com)
has agreed to update the Calendar of Events on a weekly basis.  He will
be bringing over 80,000 members from his site and mailing list to
DJUnderground.com.  How's THAT for exposure?
 
If you're serious about DJ'ing or producing, send us an email.  If
you're not, don't bother.

------=_NextPart_000_001E_01C33CD1.53B729D0--

"For some of you who have doubts about this site, or who don't really
know what this site is and are getting rather upset not knowing what the
heck this is about, just know that DJ Seven (http://www.djsevenpix.com)

For the reason you listed above your site just lost all respect. Seven is a
spammer. He posts information about events that he shouldn't. You can't get
off his list. He is the epitome of club trash. I guess you have to have the
bad to balance out the good. Besides who are you really exposing the DJ's
work to? 80,000 email addy's grep'd from club/rave/industry lists? What a
blanket audience that is. You've got the crap that attends club nv/amnesia
sf/rouge/etc that are only out to be seen at the *hottest club* around.
You're helping promote that too. Take the *underground* part out of your
domain because you far, far, away from any semblance of the underground
culture here.

ryan.bailey

Subject: RE: [sfraves] DJUnderground.com - We're still looking for more DJs and Producers!

Innocentchild and John,

Thanks for the information.  I was not aware of this.  

In response to your comment innocentchild, you're right - you do have
the bad to balance out the good.  That's just how it is with any site.
The people who find this site to be beneficial will stay with the site,
while the others will find elsewhere to go.  I have a feeling you will
be with the latter.  No worries.

Underground is defined differently in each person's eyes.  To me, and to
the purpose of this site, underground means people without exposure.
And that's what I'm going to do, give the people who don't have exposure
the attention they deserve.

I'm not trying to flame anyone here, but next time you have very strong,
negative opinions about something, I'd rather you email me privately
than post on SFRaves how I am "far, far, away from any semblance of the
underground culture here" because quite frankly, this site is far, far,
away from any semblance of the NON-underground culture.  How can you
judge something you know nothing about?

Patrick Masciocchi
Founder
DJUnderground.com

>be with the latter.  No worries.

>Underground is defined differently in each person's eyes.  To me, and to
>the purpose of this site, underground means people without exposure.
>And that's what I'm going to do, give the people who don't have exposure
>the attention they deserve.

>I'm not trying to flame anyone here, but next time you have very strong,

Subject: Allen & heath Xone 32??


I currently own the Xone 64 and I really like the sound quality and
the filters on it, but honestly, the crossfader's contour is way too
soft for my taste. I looked at the Xone 32 online and noticed that it
has a knob to adjust the contour on the crossfader! Awesome! Has
anyone used this puppy? And if so, how does it compare to other
scratch mixers' contours? Is it harder than the Xone 64?

thanks!

-Damien

From: "Wesley Dabney" <slipstream341@yahoo.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Sat, 28 Jun 2003 07:35:31 -0700
Message-ID: <000001c33d82$877b8d90$b15cea0c@yahshipseki>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="----=_NextPart_000_0001_01C33D47.DB1E3C30"
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook, Build 10.0.2616
Importance: Normal
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2727.1300
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: club review: opening night at The Blue Tattoo in San Jose

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C33D47.DB1E3C30
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

One of the most irritating things about the "large expensive club"
circuit in America is the long lines at the door.  It's made worse by
staff working the line and picking out people to bring to the front and
the staff at the Tattoo were pros at it.  In the run up to opening
night, I saw advertisements that said "8 separate dance floors" then "4
separate dance floors" with W, X, Y, Z styles of music playing.  In
actuality, there were only two style of music, hip hop and cheap
American looped techno.  I didn't hear one euro tune the entire time.
There were "four" dance floors if you count several lounge areas as
dance floors but in that case you could count the outdoor area as a
dance floor as well.  However, there were still only two DJs playing
music so no matter what "dance floor" you were on you were hearing only
two styles of music.  The folks at the club seemed to sense the
disconnect and started leaving in droves at about one am.  The techno DJ
had about a half hour period where he couldn't play anything that would
make people get up and dance.  It was a big disappointment.  
 
Pluses: lot's of beautiful women on staff and in the club, the clientele
seemed friendly and out to have a good time.   

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C33D47.DB1E3C30--

  by taz3.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 28 Jun 2003 17:28:25 -0000
Received: from ocelot (209-128-79-122.BAYAREA.NET [209.128.79.122])
	by postman.bayarea.net (8.12.8p1/8.12.8) with ESMTP id h5SHSM9s026884;
	Sat, 28 Jun 2003 10:28:22 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Sat, 28 Jun 2003 10:31:04 -0700 (Pacific Daylight Time)
From: Plastic Nuclear Ferret <donut@bayarea.net>
To: lists@onefineline.com
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <200306280704.h5S74k9r024482@postman.bayarea.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.WNT.4.55.0306281027290.1636@ocelot>
References: <200306280704.h5S74k9r024482@postman.bayarea.net>
X-X-Sender: donut@imap.bayarea.net
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Allen & heath Xone 32??

the xone32 has a pretty crappy curve out of the box, but you can
upgrade the crossfader and it helps a LOT.  (it's the penny&giles
crossfader option, $80 and worth every penny).

keep in mind that while the 32 is a GREAT mixer, it is not a pure
scratch mixer by any means.  even w/the upgraded crossfader the curve
is still a little wonky for scratching...

all nit-picking aside, it's a fantastic piece of equipment.  i don't
regret buying one at all!

shane, a happy xone32 owner of 2+ years.  8^)

>
> I currently own the Xone 64 and I really like the sound quality and

To: Plastic Nuclear Ferret <donut@bayarea.net>
cc: lists@onefineline.com, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.WNT.4.55.0306281027290.1636@ocelot>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0306281126100.26739-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Allen & heath Xone 32??


Glad someone brought this up:

I have a major gripe with the A & H Xone series mixer crossfaders, and I'm
surprised I haven't heard more people bring this up.  In my experience,
it's become pretty obvious what the issue with them is.

It took a while to figure out.  The slope of the crossfader is fine... if
you slowly move the crossfader from side to side, it actually has an
aggressive curve (when set up to do so), coming in pretty close to the end
of the crossfaders travel.  The issue is not with the crossfader's
curvature, but with a time domain aspect of the design.

This warrants a little technical explanation.

So here goes:
The Xones, like several other mixers currently on the market (for example
the z series Ranes) use a VCA crossfader (aka "active").  What this means
is that the signal from either channel does not literally travel through
the crossfader... but rather a non-varying voltage signal is passed
through the crossfader, and that this signal is in turn used to drive a
circuit that controls the amplitude of the respective channels.  Overall,
this is great.  This means that slight degradation of the crossfaders
mechanism does not equal an equal degradation in the sound of the channels
being run through it (allowing active designs a much longer working life).
Even better, since a single signal is used to drive both the left and
right channels... as well as the A and B side of the crossfader, it's a
far more elegant design and allows features like mapping the crossfader
curveature... and mixer manufacturers benefit because now crossfaders can
be simple linear taper sliders rather than having four audio channels go
through a device that gets a lot of thrashing.

To add even more "smoothness" to the thrashing on the crossfader, A&H
seems to employ a filter on this signal coming from the crossfader, to
prevent sudden gain changes from 0 (off) to an "on" value (which could
result in a pop).  Problem is, this 'pop filter' ramps up when you perform
scratch style cuts... instead of jumping instantaneously to the new value.

And in the case of the A&H mixers, makes it almost impossible to perform
techniques like twiddles, crabs and fast transforms in a manner that
sounds right.  It sorta softens the "attack"... like so:
         ____
________/    \______

instead of:
        _____
_______|     |______

This slope, is very short (probably a few milliseconds)... but it certain
circumstances it has a noticeable effect.

For going smoothly between records, this design is awesome, and results in
a better more hi-fi sound, but if a DJ has fast hands... (imagine a DJ
just cutting in the snare from a second record)... you can actually hear
the circuit gradually smoothing into the crucial attack portion of the
snare, rather than just playing it right as the crossfader physically
comes in.  With common techniques where you cut in the crossfader *right*
as the sound comes in, it shaves off the beginning of the sound you're
cutting in.

While I think this type of design is incorprated in many of the "active"
crossfader designs, the slope on the A & H is slow enough that it's
distracting, even for slamming alternately between two records (I first
noticed this as more than an preference or getting used to a new mixer
during Ethan and mines' set at Persistence... Ethan who *always* cuts hard
and on beat was sounding like he was coming in late on some of his cut
tricks).  You end up losing the punch of turntablist style 'cuts' when
using the crossfader.

I haven't proven that there is a time domain smoothing on the A & H
crossfader (meaning haven't actually gone of the schematic or applied
*real* testing proving my hypothesis), but it's evident if you set one
next to another mixer, and a-b them... or try tricks you've done a million
times on old Rane/Pioneer/Realistic/Gemini/Numark mixers that suddenly
don't land right on an A & H.

This seems to exist with a couple other mixers using active crossfader
circuits (my Rane mp22-z might do this but to a far lesser degree).  On
the Xones it's enough to be really limiting (meaning it affects even
simple cuts, not just really weird esoteric tricks that I shouldn't be
doing in public until I've practiced a couple more years :P).

andyw

Subject: Judges OK ban on trappings of raves 

--=====================_29075591==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Judges OK ban on trappings of raves

No inalienable right to glow sticks, they say

Saturday June 21, 2003

By Gwen Filosa
Staff writer Times-Picayune, New Orleans

http://www.nola.com/news/t-p/metro/index.ssf?/base/news-0/1056178522150940.xml

Saying a federal judge overstepped his bounds by blocking the government's 
ban on glow sticks and pacifiers during raves at the State Palace Theater, 
an appeals court Friday tossed out a decision that sided with the American 
Civil Liberties Union.

U.S. District Judge Thomas Porteous can't stop federal prosecutors from 
enforcing a condition of a plea bargain made in the criminal case against 
the rave promoters, a unanimous three-judge panel of the 5th U.S. Circuit 
Court of Appeals ruled.

The court sent the case back to Porteous to be dismissed and took a swipe 
at the ACLU. "Concerning the First Amendment, they have not explained the 
significance of vapor rub," Judge Rhesa Hawkins Barksdale noted, referring 
to the mentholated product that Ecstasy users sometimes inhale for an added 
sensation during raves.

Acting U.S. Attorney Jim Letten called the ruling a vindication for the 
government, which he said went after raves in the interest of public safety.

"The ACLU stuck its nose where it didn't belong," Letten said. "And the 5th 
Circuit said, 'You represent a third party. You do not have a right to 
interfere in a judicial process.' "

The 23-page decision revisits the 2001 high-profile government 
investigation into the promoters of raves, all-night dance parties 
notorious for attracting illicit drugs such as Ecstasy, a synthetic drug 
with hallucinogenic properties.

Accused of violating the federal "crack house" law, the corporation behind 
the New Orleans rave scene pleaded guilty in August 2001 and accepted a 
$100,000 fine and five years' probation.

Barbecue of New Orleans, whose president is Robert Brunet of Metairie, also 
agreed to ban glow sticks, vapor rub, pacifiers, dust masks and other rave 
accouterments from future parties. That's when the ACLU stepped in with a 
civil lawsuit that charged the government was violating the First Amendment 
rights of those who thronged to the laser-light-filled techno dances.

In February, Porteous agreed with the ACLU. While the government's push to 
rid raves of drugs is "pure," he said, it went against the Constitution's 
intent.

"The government cannot keep legal items out of places because of illegal 
activities they associate with those items," Porteous wrote.

But the government only asked Barbecue to "take reasonable steps to 
prohibit" glow sticks and the lot from the theater, the appeals court said 
Friday. "It does not require their confiscation," the decision says.

At a December 2001 hearing before Porteous, one of the three plaintiffs, 
Clayton Smith, testified that security guards made him throw away his glow 
sticks at the door.

While the ACLU and rave defenders claimed that federal agents went too far 
in their narcotics investigation, the appeals court made note of the rash 
of drug overdoses, including one 17-year-old girl's death, that plagued the 
State Palace Theater between 1997 and 2000.

Seventy people were taken from the theater on Canal Street to hospitals for 
drug overdoses, the court said. DEA agents made 50 buys of Ecstasy or other 
drugs during undercover stings at seven raves.

Prosecutors said Brunet and his corporation came up with the ban on its 
own, but the ACLU countered that the men were bullied by the threat of a 
criminal trial.

Smith said the pacifier has become a symbol of the rave counterculture and 
not a sign of drug use. The symbol evolved because Ecstasy users are known 
to grind their teeth, making pacifiers a comfort during their highs.

Under then-U.S. Attorney Eddie Jordan, federal prosecutors secured 
indictments against Brunet, his brother Brian Brunet and party promoter 
Donnie Estopinal. They applied the "crack house" law in a novel way, 
accusing the men of using the theater as a drug haven.

The federal law was created to combat the crack cocaine scourge of the 
1980s, allowing agents to arrest owners of property used as crack houses. 
Jordan resigned, and later became Orleans Parish district attorney, before 
the plea bargain was signed.

Joining Barksdale in the opinion were Judges Will Garwood and Jerry E. 
Smith. Garwood and Smith were both appointed by President Reagan, and 
Barksdale was appointed by former President Bush. Porteous was appointed by 
President Clinton.

. . . . . . .

Gwen Filosa can be reached at gfilosa@timespicayune.com or (504) 826-3304.

safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

-----Original Message-----
From: AndyW [mailto:andy@saturn5.com] 
Sent: Saturday, June 28, 2003 12:14 PM
To: Plastic Nuclear Ferret
Cc: lists@onefineline.com; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Allen & heath Xone 32??


Glad someone brought this up:

I have a major gripe with the A & H Xone series mixer crossfaders, and
I'm
surprised I haven't heard more people bring this up.  In my experience,
it's become pretty obvious what the issue with them is.

It took a while to figure out.  The slope of the crossfader is fine...
if
you slowly move the crossfader from side to side, it actually has an
aggressive curve (when set up to do so), coming in pretty close to the
end
of the crossfaders travel.  The issue is not with the crossfader's
curvature, but with a time domain aspect of the design.

This warrants a little technical explanation.

So here goes:
The Xones, like several other mixers currently on the market (for
example
the z series Ranes) use a VCA crossfader (aka "active").  What this
means
is that the signal from either channel does not literally travel through
the crossfader... but rather a non-varying voltage signal is passed
through the crossfader, and that this signal is in turn used to drive a
circuit that controls the amplitude of the respective channels.
Overall,
this is great.  This means that slight degradation of the crossfaders
mechanism does not equal an equal degradation in the sound of the
channels
being run through it (allowing active designs a much longer working
life).
Even better, since a single signal is used to drive both the left and
right channels... as well as the A and B side of the crossfader, it's a
far more elegant design and allows features like mapping the crossfader
curveature... and mixer manufacturers benefit because now crossfaders
can
be simple linear taper sliders rather than having four audio channels go
through a device that gets a lot of thrashing.

To add even more "smoothness" to the thrashing on the crossfader, A&H
seems to employ a filter on this signal coming from the crossfader, to
prevent sudden gain changes from 0 (off) to an "on" value (which could
result in a pop).  Problem is, this 'pop filter' ramps up when you
perform
scratch style cuts... instead of jumping instantaneously to the new
value.

And in the case of the A&H mixers, makes it almost impossible to perform
techniques like twiddles, crabs and fast transforms in a manner that
sounds right.  It sorta softens the "attack"... like so:
         ____
________/    \______

instead of:
        _____
_______|     |______

This slope, is very short (probably a few milliseconds)... but it
certain
circumstances it has a noticeable effect.

For going smoothly between records, this design is awesome, and results
in
a better more hi-fi sound, but if a DJ has fast hands... (imagine a DJ
just cutting in the snare from a second record)... you can actually hear
the circuit gradually smoothing into the crucial attack portion of the
snare, rather than just playing it right as the crossfader physically
comes in.  With common techniques where you cut in the crossfader
*right*
as the sound comes in, it shaves off the beginning of the sound you're
cutting in.

While I think this type of design is incorprated in many of the "active"
crossfader designs, the slope on the A & H is slow enough that it's
distracting, even for slamming alternately between two records (I first
noticed this as more than an preference or getting used to a new mixer
during Ethan and mines' set at Persistence... Ethan who *always* cuts
hard
and on beat was sounding like he was coming in late on some of his cut
tricks).  You end up losing the punch of turntablist style 'cuts' when
using the crossfader.

I haven't proven that there is a time domain smoothing on the A & H
crossfader (meaning haven't actually gone of the schematic or applied
*real* testing proving my hypothesis), but it's evident if you set one
next to another mixer, and a-b them... or try tricks you've done a
million
times on old Rane/Pioneer/Realistic/Gemini/Numark mixers that suddenly
don't land right on an A & H.

This seems to exist with a couple other mixers using active crossfader
circuits (my Rane mp22-z might do this but to a far lesser degree).  On
the Xones it's enough to be really limiting (meaning it affects even
simple cuts, not just really weird esoteric tricks that I shouldn't be
doing in public until I've practiced a couple more years :P).

andyw

Actually, I like several different styles (I tend to favor tracks that
are above 135 bpm)
http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18876.ram trance/vocal trance
 
http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18890.ram progressive trance (my fav)
http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18869.ram
http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18671.ram
 
 
http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18883.ram vocal progressive
 
 
 
also, imo, uk and us techno is similar.  Mainland Europe has a different
style.  Mainland Europe tends to us more strings and horns in their
music.  Uk and us tend to use techno sounds, drums, and vocals.  I'm no
expert but I've lived and partied in Europe for years and that's just my
opinion.  
 
One of my fav mixed sets from this year:
andy_b._jones-in_motion__original_mix

From gregvp@attbi.com  Sun Jun 29 17:18:40 2003
Return-Path: <gregvp@attbi.com>
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 7231 invoked from network); 29 Jun 2003 17:18:40 -0000
Received: from sccrmhc11.attbi.com (204.127.202.55)
  by taz3.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 29 Jun 2003 17:18:40 -0000
Received: from gregvp (12-233-219-22.client.attbi.com[12.233.219.22](untrusted sender))
          by attbi.com (sccrmhc11) with SMTP
          id <2003062917183701100m6snte>; Sun, 29 Jun 2003 17:18:37 +0000

From: "Greg Van Pelt" <gregvp@attbi.com>

	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Date: Sun, 29 Jun 2003 10:11:50 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0

	boundary="----=_NextPart_000_0021_01C33E26.DBC36180"

X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Personal Review: Friends and Family, Saturday June 28th!

------=_NextPart_000_0021_01C33E26.DBC36180
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I really do not know where to begin. My head is still spinning from the =
intense energy of last night's exciting party at SomArts Gallery. I have =
never been to an F&F event until now, but I certainly feel like part of =
the family today. You can always say, "It's just a party" but the F&F =
crew put so much work into this event so it felt like a true production =
(worth every penny).

I arrived at 11 p.m. and promptly ran into my dancing buddy, RaVin Riz =
by the refreshment stand. He pointed out the beautiful Friends & Family =
blacklight poster on sale for 10 bucks, autographed by the artist and =
limited to 100 copies. I bought one and I am going to frame it for my =
office.=20

Can anyone tell me who did the F&F artwork for the poster? I cannot read =
the autographed name but I have number eight of 100.

After grabbing some H20, I hit the psy-trance dance floor, which had a =
soft, bouncy feeling. That was certainly a memorable space because it =
saved my joints from aching (danced for 5 hours straight).

The main room nearby had a linoleum tiled floor, not nearly as =
comfortable as the psy-trance room, but larger, so I kept running back =
and forth between the two arenas. Oh yeah, there was a chill space =
(large room with coat check and big-screen theater) in between the dance =
rooms. The visual entertainment throughout the venue was stunning. You =
did not even need psychedelic drugs to enjoy the sensation. By 4 a.m., =
several people were just laying on the floor soaking up the imagery like =
e-tards.

I must say this: hat's off to the Viberation graphics crew. Good work =
that was enjoyed by all (you could tell).

There was another chill room in the gallery space, with beanbag chairs =
and other comfortable spots strewn throughout. This was not your =
every-day chill room--it was massive with a stage set up for the ambient =
DJs. I've never seen a chill room like this, because they also had many =
Macintoshes set up for some kind of browsing. How unique and =
imaginative! And the computers were getting used throughout the night =
(not sure what kind of access was available; I was too busy dancing).

Just outside the chill room, on the outdoor patio, they were =
broadcasting to a local station (I think). And they had other =
entertainment outside but I missed most of the action.=20

Can anyone tell me what else was happening outside? It was a popular =
gathering place, by 3 a.m. rapidly approaching mini-massive status =
(people in every corner). So, I just stayed with my ever-favorite dance =
mania until complete exhaustion. Talk about moving your body. I know =
that I had some swiveling, hip action!

I thanked AndyW for one important item: the door crew allowed ins and =
outs, something that is unheard of at most venues, but it was a =
lifesaver for me. I was able to run out to the car, crank up the air =
conditioning, change shirts, and head back for more dancing. Usually, at =
bars and some parties, the venue owners are so uptight about possible =
liabilities, i.e. people going out and getting drugs or off-site drinks, =
but Andy just said to me: "We trust our guests" which was memorable.

Thanks, again, F&F.

Greg VP



------=_NextPart_000_0021_01C33E26.DBC36180--

Anyways, tonight's Dirtbox is gonna be a tight affair.  Check out the
lineup:

07-08pm EST - Evancipation - Our guest host for the night will be droppin'
some dubs and gettin' rowdy like he usually does.

08-09:30pm EST - Known Factor & Relapse - These guys always come with a
tight selection of heavy tunes, and put a lot of energy into their sets.

09:30-11pm EST - Scathe - Scathe rolls with DC's Ohm Resistance, is an
incredibly aggressive DJ, and favors that dark techy shizzle.

be performing here in the greater Metropolitan area, so expect something
special!

http://dirtboxradio.com/archives.html.  Therein, you'll find links to the
stream, chat, and webcam.

don't the A&Hs have those kill switches? for some of

Received: (qmail 46416 invoked from network); 29 Jun 2003 20:46:32 -0000

  by taz3.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 29 Jun 2003 20:46:32 -0000
Message-ID: <20030629204629.59948.qmail@web41810.mail.yahoo.com>
Received: from [66.82.9.25] by web41810.mail.yahoo.com via HTTP; Sun, 29 Jun 2003 13:46:29 PDT
Date: Sun, 29 Jun 2003 13:46:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: Psychedelic Armadillo <psychedelicarmadillo@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <Pine.WNT.4.55.0306281027290.1636@ocelot>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Allen & heath Xone 32??

> upgrade the crossfader and it helps a LOT.  (it's
> the penny&giles
> crossfader option, $80 and worth every penny).

it might be worth every penny, but the real question
is, is it worth every giles? we don't exactly grow on
trees. I've only met one other Giles in my life. (he
was a blues guitarist on heroin.)

crossfaders:

   1. "a good workman never blames his tools."

   2. "if it ain't been in a pawn shop, it can't
      play the blues."

and:

   3. in his teen years, Grandmaster Flash was as
      famous in his neighborhood for taking his
      mixers apart and rewiring them as he was for
      using them to play records.

but:

personally, I'll pay $1000 for a mixer when somebody
pays me $1000 to spin. I own a piece of shit $100
Vestax that doesn't even have stereo monitoring, and
I'm proud of it. if you practice on a piece of shit,
you'll have a harder time making your mix CD sound
good, but when you actually get in front of a crowd
and they give you an Allen & Heath or a Rane, you'll
find mixing so much easier than you're used to that
you'll be able to put all that freed-up energy into
your mix, and you can give that energy to the crowd,
instead of wasting it on equipment.

besides, $80 is a lot of records.

come to that, $1000 is two white labels, 100 copies
apiece, and that includes the mastering.


Giles

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Personal Review: Friends and Family, Saturday June 28th!

Dudes ad dudettes,
My legs are F'n sore from that party! 11-4:30: Nothing but dancing! Great

----Original Message Follows----
From: "Greg Van Pelt" <gregvp@attbi.com>
To: "Terry Estioko" <terry@saturn5.com>
CC: "RaVin RiZ" <ravin_riz@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: [sfraves] Personal Review: Friends and Family, Saturday June 28th!
Date: Sun, 29 Jun 2003 10:11:50 -0700

I really do not know where to begin. My head is still spinning from the 
intense energy of last night's exciting party at SomArts Gallery. I have 
never been to an F&F event until now, but I certainly feel like part of the 
family today. You can always say, "It's just a party" but the F&F crew put 
so much work into this event so it felt like a true production (worth every 
penny).

I arrived at 11 p.m. and promptly ran into my dancing buddy, RaVin Riz by 
the refreshment stand. He pointed out the beautiful Friends & Family 
blacklight poster on sale for 10 bucks, autographed by the artist and 
limited to 100 copies. I bought one and I am going to frame it for my 
office.

Can anyone tell me who did the F&F artwork for the poster? I cannot read the 
autographed name but I have number eight of 100.

After grabbing some H20, I hit the psy-trance dance floor, which had a soft, 
bouncy feeling. That was certainly a memorable space because it saved my 
joints from aching (danced for 5 hours straight).

The main room nearby had a linoleum tiled floor, not nearly as comfortable 
as the psy-trance room, but larger, so I kept running back and forth between 
the two arenas. Oh yeah, there was a chill space (large room with coat check 
and big-screen theater) in between the dance rooms. The visual entertainment 
throughout the venue was stunning. You did not even need psychedelic drugs 
to enjoy the sensation. By 4 a.m., several people were just laying on the 
floor soaking up the imagery like e-tards.

I must say this: hat's off to the Viberation graphics crew. Good work that 
was enjoyed by all (you could tell).

There was another chill room in the gallery space, with beanbag chairs and 
other comfortable spots strewn throughout. This was not your every-day chill 
room--it was massive with a stage set up for the ambient DJs. I've never 
seen a chill room like this, because they also had many Macintoshes set up 
for some kind of browsing. How unique and imaginative! And the computers 
were getting used throughout the night (not sure what kind of access was 
available; I was too busy dancing).

Just outside the chill room, on the outdoor patio, they were broadcasting to 
a local station (I think). And they had other entertainment outside but I 
missed most of the action.

Can anyone tell me what else was happening outside? It was a popular 
gathering place, by 3 a.m. rapidly approaching mini-massive status (people 
in every corner). So, I just stayed with my ever-favorite dance mania until 
complete exhaustion. Talk about moving your body. I know that I had some 
swiveling, hip action!

I thanked AndyW for one important item: the door crew allowed ins and outs, 
something that is unheard of at most venues, but it was a lifesaver for me. 
I was able to run out to the car, crank up the air conditioning, change 
shirts, and head back for more dancing. Usually, at bars and some parties, 
the venue owners are so uptight about possible liabilities, i.e. people 
going out and getting drugs or off-site drinks, but Andy just said to me: 
"We trust our guests" which was memorable.

Thanks, again, F&F.

Greg VP

_________________________________________________________________
MSN 8 helps eliminate e-mail viruses. Get 2 months FREE*.  
http://join.msn.com/?page=features/virus

Greg VP

I was able to run out to the car, crank up the air conditioning, change
shirts, and head back for more dancing. Usually, at bars and some parties,
the venue owners are so uptight about possible liabilities, i.e. people

"We trust our guests" which was memorable.

Thanks, again, F&F.

Greg VP

Greg-

Philip Diaz created the poster you bought. I believe that he is still on 
SFR. (Philip? Earth to Philip?)

It was really awesome to wake up and see such a heartfelt, wonderful review 
of FnF last night. I love it when people realize how much love we put into 
the space, the party, and the vibe- makes everything worthwhile. Also, I 
agree with you completely that we should all take our hats off to the 
Viberation crew, who made one of the coolest chill rooms I've seen in a damn 
long time!

It was great to see you (and everyone else I hadn't seen in a while) again. 
What a night indeed.... *grin*

Becca


>From: "Greg Van Pelt" <gregvp@attbi.com>
>To: "Terry Estioko" <terry@saturn5.com>
>CC: "RaVin RiZ" <ravin_riz@hotmail.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: [sfraves] Personal Review: Friends and Family, Saturday June 28th!
>Date: Sun, 29 Jun 2003 10:11:50 -0700
>
>I really do not know where to begin. My head is still spinning from the 
>intense energy of last night's exciting party at SomArts Gallery. I have 
>never been to an F&F event until now, but I certainly feel like part of the 
>family today. You can always say, "It's just a party" but the F&F crew put 
>so much work into this event so it felt like a true production (worth every 
>penny).
>
>I arrived at 11 p.m. and promptly ran into my dancing buddy, RaVin Riz by 
>the refreshment stand. He pointed out the beautiful Friends & Family 
>blacklight poster on sale for 10 bucks, autographed by the artist and 
>limited to 100 copies. I bought one and I am going to frame it for my 
>office.
>
>Can anyone tell me who did the F&F artwork for the poster? I cannot read 
>the autographed name but I have number eight of 100.
>
>After grabbing some H20, I hit the psy-trance dance floor, which had a 
>soft, bouncy feeling. That was certainly a memorable space because it saved 
>my joints from aching (danced for 5 hours straight).
>
>The main room nearby had a linoleum tiled floor, not nearly as comfortable 
>as the psy-trance room, but larger, so I kept running back and forth 
>between the two arenas. Oh yeah, there was a chill space (large room with 
>coat check and big-screen theater) in between the dance rooms. The visual 
>entertainment throughout the venue was stunning. You did not even need 
>psychedelic drugs to enjoy the sensation. By 4 a.m., several people were 
>just laying on the floor soaking up the imagery like e-tards.
>
>I must say this: hat's off to the Viberation graphics crew. Good work that 
>was enjoyed by all (you could tell).
>
>There was another chill room in the gallery space, with beanbag chairs and 
>other comfortable spots strewn throughout. This was not your every-day 
>chill room--it was massive with a stage set up for the ambient DJs. I've 
>never seen a chill room like this, because they also had many Macintoshes 
>set up for some kind of browsing. How unique and imaginative! And the 
>computers were getting used throughout the night (not sure what kind of 
>access was available; I was too busy dancing).
>
>Just outside the chill room, on the outdoor patio, they were broadcasting 
>to a local station (I think). And they had other entertainment outside but 
>I missed most of the action.
>
>Can anyone tell me what else was happening outside? It was a popular 
>gathering place, by 3 a.m. rapidly approaching mini-massive status (people 
>in every corner). So, I just stayed with my ever-favorite dance mania until 
>complete exhaustion. Talk about moving your body. I know that I had some 
>swiveling, hip action!
>
>I thanked AndyW for one important item: the door crew allowed ins and outs, 
>something that is unheard of at most venues, but it was a lifesaver for me. 
>I was able to run out to the car, crank up the air conditioning, change 
>shirts, and head back for more dancing. Usually, at bars and some parties, 
>the venue owners are so uptight about possible liabilities, i.e. people 
>going out and getting drugs or off-site drinks, but Andy just said to me: 
>"We trust our guests" which was memorable.
>
>Thanks, again, F&F.
>
>Greg VP
>
>

For the record when *techno* is mentioned we're talking about the specific
genre and not the blanket definition. Techno is a genre rock, jazz, and pop
all are. The music you listed is *trance* and not techno. Can't compare
apples to oranges. =)

----- Original Message -----
From: "Captain Scarlet" <slipstream341@yahoo.com>
To: "'AndyW'" <andy@saturn5.com>

Sent: Sunday, June 29, 2003 7:01 AM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] club review: opening night at The Blue Tattoo in San

Actually, I like several different styles (I tend to favor tracks that
are above 135 bpm)
http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18876.ram trance/vocal trance

http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18890.ram progressive trance (my fav)
http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18869.ram
http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18671.ram


http://www.cuepoint.info/sounds/18883.ram vocal progressive



also, imo, uk and us techno is similar.  Mainland Europe has a different
style.  Mainland Europe tends to us more strings and horns in their
music.  Uk and us tend to use techno sounds, drums, and vocals.  I'm no
expert but I've lived and partied in Europe for years and that's just my
opinion.

One of my fav mixed sets from this year:
andy_b._jones-in_motion__original_mix
flutlicht - Icarus (Daedalus Mix)
Madelyne_-_Beautiful_Child_(Hiver_&_Hammer_Remix)
Euphonic - Far And Away [Alphazone Remix]
ian van dahl - will i (flutlicht remix)
Dave Joy - First Impression ( S.h.o.k.k  Mix)
DJ Sequenza - Accept no Limits
Lyala-Time_To_Fly_(Climax69_Mix)_(2003.02.13)
Geilomatics-Geilomat__Wavetraxx_RMX
Look to the Sky (True Color Extended Mix)
Sonorous-Protonic-(Ronski_Speed_Mix)

-&e->One of the most irritating things about the "large expensive club"
-&e->circuit in America is the long lines at the door.  It's made worse
by
-&e->staff working the line and picking out people to bring to the front
and
-&e->the staff at the Tattoo were pros at it.  In the run up to opening
-&e->night, I saw advertisements that said "8 separate dance floors"
then "4
-&e->separate dance floors" with W, X, Y, Z styles of music playing.  In
-&e->actuality, there were only two style of music, hip hop and cheap
-&e->American looped techno.  I didn't hear one euro tune the entire
time.

YAY Cheap American Looped Techno!!!

(actually, if it's actually looped, it's usually a producer who missed
the
point... audio loops lack the subtle changes over periods of time that
define good hypnotic techno).

import... does that make it Euro enough to be good?

back when they were doing some remodeling and making a hell of a lot of
noise and generally annoying those of us who lived in the area.  The
shirts said "Construction 1997:  Proud to be a Part."  While it missed the
mark at the time it's the best summation I can come up with.

I was really PROUD to be a PART.

-----------------------
http://www.gotanproject.com/english/gotan_en.htm

Initiated by Philippe Cohen Solal and Edouardo Makaroff in 1999, with =
Christoph H Muller joining immediately, Gotan Project saw the light of =
day with the release of their first 10 inch in February 2000 on Ya =
Basta!, Solal's label.
The project which gathers on record, as well as on stage, top =
Argentinean musicians exiled in Paris, is experiencing an incredible =
international success with the release of their first album "La Revancha =
Del Tango". To date, more than 500 000 records have been sold in Europe. =
Their current live tour is taking them to some of the world's most =
prestigious stages and influential clubs. The show mixes video =
performances of Prisca Lobjoy and the technical skill of gathering =
acoustic musicians alongside machines.

Subject: Almost reviewed: Queer as Funk

------=_NextPart_000_0068_01C33EB4.D7395500
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Ok party people,=20

I rarely post negative comments to this list but now it is my turn =
because I am really pissed off tonight.=20

I have something to say to the production crew responsible for Queer as =
Funk. Do not piss off your local dancers. There is nothing more =
frustrating to a dancer then being on the outside of a venue "looking =
in," in this case through locked glass doors, and hearing the pounding =
bass with no access whatsoever due to ridiculous admission prices.=20

I drove over the bridge to San Mateo to The Crowne Plaza hotel, in a =
happy mood because my favorite DJs were spinning (Denise, Dragn'fly, =
Joey Mazzola).=20

I have questions for the DJs: How was the party? Did you have any active =
dancers? Did you sense a good vibe? Please let us know the outcome, =
especially if you have time for some opinions.=20

The immediate vibe at the hotel was extremely negative. For example, =
upon entering the lobby, this particular ballroom was locked off by =
glass doors plastered with Wild 94.9 posters. The doors were guarded by =
security guards and you had to walk around the building (outside) to =
find the entrance.=20

Thereupon you got the familiar search for drugs, weapons, and whatnot, =
and you were pointed to a ticket desk for immediate sticker shock: 40 =
bucks admission, and this was at midnight! (Party ended at 2 am).=20

What can you do at this point but ask politely, "But you only have two =
hours left for your party, do you have a discount?"=20

I have a job. I can afford a 40-dollar party but this did not seem like =
it was worth the time or money (not very many people attending). I was =
extremely pissed off that I drove all the way over there with no clue as =
to the price tag. (Talk about a "gay pride" swindle).=20

Moreover, I am not the only one. I met several ravers in the parking =
lot, most of who were students and we all felt disappointment. The =
ravers left your shitty party and headed to the Castro for some =
excitement. Too bad, because you lost many potential customers.=20

Finally, I talked to a beautiful Asian girl working at the front desk, =
and she wanted to dance, but even she could not gain admission without =
paying the steep price. I told her about SFraves and she appreciated my =
information.=20

In closing, I know from the web site that this event was supposedly for =
charity (the STOP AIDS Project), but I strongly feel that you guys are =
way off the mark on this one, especially with current economic =
conditions.=20

Maybe you are seeking the out of town crowd. I feel like reporting you =
to gay shame, but maybe you just do not know or understand your =
potential audience, the local rave dancers. Oh pardon me, you are The =
Official All Ages Gay Pride Event Sponsored by San Francisco Pride. Who =
the fuck cares? Get real, that's a lot of money to charge unless you are =
holding a massive in an arena (not a fucking hotel ballroom).=20

Greg VP=20


------=_NextPart_000_0068_01C33EB4.D7395500--

Subject: John '00' Fleming

For all of those who are progressive tranceheads and are 21+, I would highly
recommend coming out to Whisper this Friday and checking out John '00'
Fleming. He is regarded as one of the world's best trance DJs and recording
artists and the proud label owner of J00F Recordings.

A favorite amongst Ibiza clubgoers and a long-time resident for Godskitchen,
Slinky and Gatecrasher, this man does not disappoint! His recent Euphoria
White Label 2 CD release has been compared to the likes of Sasha and
Digweed's Northern Exposure.

Be certain to read his article in the forthcoming September issue of REMIX
Magazine.

You can find out more on John at <http://www.john00fleming.com>

For only $15, you can see him play a 3 hour set at Whisper at 535 Florida

Well, with the party happening in San Mateo, what did you expect?  ;)

On Mon, Jun 30, 2003 at 03:08:11AM -0700, Greg Van Pelt wrote:
> Ok party people, 
> 
> I rarely post negative comments to this list but now it is my turn because I am really pissed off tonight. 
> 
> I have something to say to the production crew responsible for Queer as Funk. Do not piss off your local dancers. There is nothing more frustrating to a dancer then being on the outside of a venue "looking in," in this case through locked glass doors, and hearing the pounding bass with no access whatsoever due to ridiculous admission prices. 
> 
> I drove over the bridge to San Mateo to The Crowne Plaza hotel, in a happy mood because my favorite DJs were spinning (Denise, Dragn'fly, Joey Mazzola). 
> 
> I have questions for the DJs: How was the party? Did you have any active dancers? Did you sense a good vibe? Please let us know the outcome, especially if you have time for some opinions. 
> 
> The immediate vibe at the hotel was extremely negative. For example, upon entering the lobby, this particular ballroom was locked off by glass doors plastered with Wild 94.9 posters. The doors were guarded by security guards and you had to walk around the building (outside) to find the entrance. 
> 
> Thereupon you got the familiar search for drugs, weapons, and whatnot, and you were pointed to a ticket desk for immediate sticker shock: 40 bucks admission, and this was at midnight! (Party ended at 2 am). 
> 
> What can you do at this point but ask politely, "But you only have two hours left for your party, do you have a discount?" 
> 
> I have a job. I can afford a 40-dollar party but this did not seem like it was worth the time or money (not very many people attending). I was extremely pissed off that I drove all the way over there with no clue as to the price tag. (Talk about a "gay pride" swindle). 
> 
> Moreover, I am not the only one. I met several ravers in the parking lot, most of who were students and we all felt disappointment. The ravers left your shitty party and headed to the Castro for some excitement. Too bad, because you lost many potential customers. 
> 
> Finally, I talked to a beautiful Asian girl working at the front desk, and she wanted to dance, but even she could not gain admission without paying the steep price. I told her about SFraves and she appreciated my information. 
> 
> In closing, I know from the web site that this event was supposedly for charity (the STOP AIDS Project), but I strongly feel that you guys are way off the mark on this one, especially with current economic conditions. 
> 
> Maybe you are seeking the out of town crowd. I feel like reporting you to gay shame, but maybe you just do not know or understand your potential audience, the local rave dancers. Oh pardon me, you are The Official All Ages Gay Pride Event Sponsored by San Francisco Pride. Who the fuck cares? Get real, that's a lot of money to charge unless you are holding a massive in an arena (not a fucking hotel ballroom). 
> 
> Greg VP 
>

Subject: FnF review..

hmm not sure what to say since most of the people already posted on this 
great party but I will give it a stab..

Right when I step out of the car I see Tina (moonchyld) and crew heading to 
the store for some dranks..   Always good to see a smiling familiar face 
when you first step out of your car..

Saw loads of people I have not seen in years.. And even one friend that I 
have not seen in the past 5 years. Marcos.. He was my first and only light 
guy for alot of my first parties. Also saw alot of the SFR planners etc.. 
Good to see old friends having fun.

The space is just wicked nuff said. Artwork and decor was super awesome the 
Psy trance room reminded me of those old dark warehouse days with lots of 
nice day glow DJ's/Live Pa's etc..

The music was a Mix of Techno,Psy and Downtempo/hip-hop

I had a rockin time everyone was getting down nice Older Ravey Vibe 
refreshing to not run into a lot of pubscent teens explaing how it is the 
first time at a "Rave" and on "E"

Only Complaint about the party and I know this is being DJ bitchy but.. Very 
few of the DJ's were really on beat.. Loads of trainwrecks all over the 
place.. And some were really bad. Know I don't claim to be the most skilled 
beat matcher.. Hell im not very great at beat matching.. But I think it is 
safe to say that I rarely train wreck super hard.. Maybe the phrashing is a 
lil off.. but not two locomotives..


But still a very excellent party to say the least.. One of the few parties 
that I personally will actually attend cause I know the environment will be 
damn good..

If you haven't been to a FnF party well you need to keep your ear to the 
ground and get out to one..


see ya,

Macadio

Subject: **BSP** CD DEMO "6TH DAY"

Well.. I have finally put something together for your audible pleasure..

Got my G4 and Peak and my sound card issues situated so alas after a 3rd 
pass trial I decided to make a mixed CD and it did not come out half bad.. 
It aint perfect by any means but then again.. If I keep trying to work on 
the  "Perfect" mix I will never release jack shit cause all the mixes I do I 
think sound like crap in one way or another..

So with  that.. I will be giving out/mailing my demo to a select few that 
would like a copy The music is "Progressive house" "tribal house" or just 
plain ol funky tribal.. whatever you want to classify it as..

I personally think it is mellow prog house.. not real dark like alot of prog 
but more on the funky side.. Similar to Steve Lawlers "Lights out" series.. 
It does have that small sweaty warehouse sound.

I need to bump the levels and normalize it before release so it may be a few 
days.. But if interested send me a private email and I will give ya the 
details of how it is going to go down.

Also I may have it upped to a friends website so you can DL if you don't 
want to wait on a physical copy.  These will be limited to about 50 CD's or 
so.. Just depends on how fast I can burn them on my supa pimp Lacie drive.

X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <Law8-OE15nbF503zJLT00014678@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 30 Jun 2003 20:33:46.0494 (UTC) FILETIME=[E7C0D1E0:01C33F46]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: fnf :: hot.damn! :: pictures.too

------=_NextPart_000_01AA_01C33F0C.3B480940
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

http://sninesix.dyndns.org/fnf062803/ - pictures from the party. (first =
things first yanno?)

I gotta say all expectations were blown away. I openly admit that I =
wasn't feeling this party like I wanted to prior to it happening. When I =
arrived for setup and saw the sheer amount of gear and production that =
was going into it that changed. Watching the chillroom evolve into that =
schwank-tech-lounge was by far the most impressive part to me. Take that =
chillroom, add a bar, stick it in SOMA and you would have the hottest =
new lounge in SF. Sound was off the hook. Damn! I loved those new =
bassbins that Pascal had. Beyond the sound of them the open driver =
design was just too cool. Overall ambience from the lighting crew was =
well thought out and fit the respective rooms quite well. The EL archway =
install looked great and was well worth the effort it took in digging =
the ditches and wiring them up. Look at the pictures to see that massive =
rats nest of wiring to understand what I mean. Oh I really liked the =
giant balloons in the black room. Nice interaction with the projections. =
Dave's LocalTalk Lounge was a big success! So many people would walk by =
and wonder what we were doing and were surprised to find out the =
machines were all networked. Some funny as hell conversations going on!

Music wise I was all over the chillroom that night. Brian and Larry's =
set seemed to fit my relaxed mood that night. Very impressed with how =
well the live soundtrack they produced went with Hero. I need to see =
that movie in its entirety now too. Ambient Mafia came through with a =
chill vengence. It was good to seem Boomy back behind the decks again. =
The only sets in the main rooms I heard were Miranda's and Ethan's and =
both were great. I didn't hear any trainwrecks while I was in there for =
their sets. That was my only gripe with the music. I heard a lot of =
trainwrecking that night. Was rather surprised by that.

Overall it was a very diverse crowd. Great amount of energy with a super =
friendly feeling. I had one girl come up to me and tell me that she knew =
me. Then proceeds to tell me that we went to high school together. =
Scary. 10 years later I run into a girl that I never associated with and =
she's now married with 4 kids. There were quite a few reconnections for =
me that night. Made for a wonderful evening amoungst friends. It seemed =
like everyone came out for this event. Michael the Red Stickman even =
sucked it up and came out and he's sick with the flu. It was just that =
kind of party. Awesome work and I hope to see something like this again =
sooner rather than another 3 years later. =3D)

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
design :: www.sninesix.com
photography :: www.innocentchild.com
------=_NextPart_000_01AA_01C33F0C.3B480940--

yeah, the chill room was the most expansive i'd ever seen !  terry and =
the viberation visuals crew turned it out again... and the ambient =
lighting was perfect... all set against the backdrop of the current =
gallery installation in that room made it a treat.  3 c-trl se/30's in =
each corner of the h u g e room kinda brought the 4 corners a bit more =
together i thought.  the many glowing faces that took the effort to =
express how much they enjoyed C-TRL Localtalk Lounge and concept made it =
all worth it for me.  big ups to t-dawg tyler for helping me with setup =
!  the other rooms were also nicely sweetened ... although, like most, =
the chill room was dole'n out the yummy vibe morsels of choice for me.  =
the Hero piece was cast over the room like a raver net that nobody could =
escape from !  and i can't forget the volunteers who prepared all the =
yummy fruits and refreshments - saints - fresh plumbs and strawberries - =
yumm :)   one of those nights everyone will remember.

-=3Ddave

ps- i luv my Sunfire True MKII but I WANT THOSE BASSBIN's IN MY HOUSE ! =
! ! =3DD

david christofer  .:.  c-trl interactive  .:.   http://www.c-trl.com/68k
